webTitle: Caniggia set for shock move to Dundee

fields.headline: Caniggia set for shock move to Dundee
fields.trailText: Former Argentinian World Cup striker Claudio Caniggia is set to join Dundee on loan until the end of the season.
fields.body:
Former Argentinian World Cup striker Claudio Caniggia is set to join Dundee on loan until the end of the season.

The shock news was confirmed by a club spokesman, who admitted: "We can confirm that Claudio will be arriving in the country tomorrow with a view to having talks with Ivano Bonetti."

The 33-year-old Caniggia - who was suspended for 13 months in 1993 when he tested positive for cocaine after playing for Roma against Napoli - could replace Fabian Caballero, who was injured in the Tayside derby last week.

fields.headline: Exchange battle begins
fields.standfirst:
Defence document against OM expected to trigger bids from rivals
The issues explained: stock exchange mergers
fields.trailText: The scene was set yesterday for a bidding war over ownership of the London Stock Exchange with publication of the market's defence document against a £800m bid from its Swedish competitor.
fields.body:
The scene was set yesterday for a bidding war over ownership of the London Stock Exchange with publication of the market's defence document against a £800m bid from its Swedish competitor.

The exchange urged shareholders to reject the bid from Sweden's OM, which it derided as "wholly inadequate" and an "attempt to buy your company on the cheap". It said OM would offer them new shares whose value was "uncertain".

Industry sources expect the official defence, released in accordance with the City's takeover code, will trigger either a counterbid by the Euronext alliance of French, Belgian and Netherlands exchanges which began trading last week, or the Deutsche Börse, the German exchange with which London was forced to abandon its iX merger.

Market rumours suggest Euronext is prepared to offer the London exchange a stake of more than 50%. Nasdaq, the US hi-tech exchange, is also said to be waiting in the wings.

Sources described the expected battle as similar to a poker game, with none of the potential bidders wanting to be first to show its hand. At the same time, all bidders want to use the London exchange as a showcase of their technology.

The significance of technology was acknowledged by Don Cruickshank, chairman of the the London exchange, who has also assumed the role of chief executive after the departure of Gavin Casey.

Yesterday's document showed Mr Cruickshank will receive one year's salary of £350,000 and "compensation" if a takeover is agreed. The exchange is protected from takeover by a 4.9% limit on any single stake, although shareholders vote next month on abolishing that limit.

Mr Cruickshank said the replacement chief executive needed to "understand something about running a technology company" as well as having an international perspective and an ability to run a "service company".

He insisted his exchange could fend off the OM bid and then "use the strength of London" to take the initiative on consolidation across Europe.

But London would embark on more consultation with its shareholders. "The precise conditions under which London should take part in consolidation needs far more debate," Mr Cruickshank said.

The first shot in a battle for the London exchange - which will run for 46 days even if a counterbidder does not emerge - was dismissed by OM as evidence London had "no strategy, no management and no vision".

"We urge the LSE board to reconsider our offer now," said the chief executive of OM, Per Larsson. However, a spokesman for Apcims, the lobby group for private client stockbrokers, said few of its members appeared prepared to back the Swedish bid.

"They feel that OM has given a good case for managing the facilities of the exchange but find it difficult to see why they need to own it."

Even though the plans for iX areshelved, Deutsche Börse chairman Rolf Breuer said yesterday, though that an alliance was still possible. "We have other options but if London comes to the conclusion that going together with Frankfurt is not such a bad idea, which I think is likely, then I think that Frankfurt would not say no."

fields.headline: Kings of Convenience
fields.standfirst:
Union Chapel, London
****
fields.trailText:
Union Chapel, London
****
fields.body:
"Hello, we are Kings of the Convenience." Singer Eric Glambek Boe has got it a bit wrong and being Norwegian probably doesn't realise why there are giggles to welcome him. But Glambek Boe smiles, brimming with innocence. Kings of Convenience are a duo - Glambek Boe and Erlend Oye - and you'd be right to start thinking along Simon and Garfunkel lines.

They stand side by side with their acoustic guitars, lost in their folky songs of sweetness and light, but still looking to entertain. Toxic Girl is a vignette of vanity, but not scathing - bitterness isn't allowed to taint the gentle harmonies. While Glambek Boe sings: "She's intoxicated by herself/Every day, she's seeing someone else," he's doing it with a sparkle in his eyes.

It's the sense of fun behind their heart-melting gems that makes Kings of Convenience so endearing. There's no cleverness or earnest melancholia here - well, you can't be solemnwhen you're covering an A-ha song. But that doesn't mean they play the Norwegian teen-idols' Manhattan Skyline for laughs. In fact they take the overblown epic and give it a majesty that would stun Morten and co.

Make no mistake, Glambek Boe and Oye are mouth-wateringly sweet. Wrapped in his zip-up cardigan, Glambek Boe is a latter-day Val Doonican. Oye, on the other hand, is a star in the gangly, bespectacled sense. He's unsure without his guitar and makes up for his awkwardness by doing odd little dances that make everyone laugh. Stepping off the stage, still singing, he bursts into a spot of dancing, staring at the floor like the geekiest boy in class who has been asked to dance with the girl of his dreams. It's always the quiet ones you always have to watch.

webTitle: Germans want to buy more British utilities

fields.headline: Germans want to buy more British utilities
fields.standfirst:
RWE clinches Thames Water for £4.3bn and plans to sell gas and electricity in UK

Money Unlimited
The Dealmakers - how they will be rewarded
fields.trailText: RWE, the German utility, could make further acquisitions of British companies and start selling gas and electricity in the UK after clinching an agreed £4.3bn cash takeover of Thames Water yesterday.
fields.body:
RWE, the German utility, could make further acquisitions of British companies and start selling gas and electricity in the UK after clinching an agreed £4.3bn cash takeover of Thames Water yesterday.

The Essen-based utility, one of Europe's big six, said it was "still on a growth path" and had amassed a £15bn war chest to grow outside Germany. Chairman Dr Dietmar Kuhnt said it would need to digest Thames before making any immediate moves but would take advantage of opportunities as they came up .

RWE is already in advanced talks about delivering gas and electricity to its water customers in Berlin where it works in partnership with Vivendi of France. The deal will create the world's third largest water and waste company. Thames has been considering cross-selling other services to its London and southeast England water users like other companies such as Centrica and Scottish Power.

A Thames spokeswoman said: "It's a natural development to bundle things up and get better value for the customers. We are looking at that in Berlin and will be looking at that here longer term."

But Mr Kuhnt was anxious to stress the global ambitions of Thames under RWE where it will challenge France's Vivendi Environment and Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux.

German financial muscle will be put behind Thames' management and growing ambitions in key markets such as the US and South America where it has just bought a Chilean company.

The agreed offer for Thames is £12.15 per share, and RWE will assume £2.5bn of Thames debt including its uncompleted US water acquisition E'town. Thames shareholders will also get an interim dividend of 20p per share for the year to March 2001 and a scheduled final dividend of 32.7p to March 2000.

Both Mr Kuhnt and Thames chief executive Bill Alexander described the deal as generous. Analysts agreed, pointing out that the Germans were paying a premium of 43% to Thames' average share price over the last month. Thames shares ended the day up 50p at 1210p while RWE shares continued a slide that began when the talks were first mooted.

RWE brokers Merrill Lynch bought 20% of Thames yesterday to "cement the relationship" rather than ward off any attempt by a third party predator to upset their new partnership. The German group said putting the two companies together was an "excellent strategic fit" with no overlap and therefore no job losses.

Senior management at Thames has agreed to stay on and the combined water operations are to be based in London under Mr Alexander. It will operate under the title Thames Water, a division of RWE and have 34m customers from London to Shanghai.

Thames chairman Roger Carr, who will bow out within 50 days after the deal is completed, said RWE backing gave Thames the kind of financial strength it needed to realise its international ambitions fully. "Its a win-win for both parties," he said. "As part of the RWE group, Thames Water's position and prospects will be strengthened and the opportunities open to its employees will be much enhanced."

There are many areas of consolidation in the water industry worldwide. Some industry experts warned that it was still a highly competitive market, pointing out that US-based Azurix, owner of Wessex Water in the UK, was spun off from its parent, the power group Enron, at $19 per share but its price has fallen to $5.

fields.headline: Toolshed
fields.standfirst:
Contact Theatre, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Contact Theatre, Manchester
****
fields.body:
For anyone starved of genuinely experimental music, Toolshed is a haven. Set up by 808 State's own techno pioneer, Graham Massey, the club night (which rotates around Mancunian venues) provides a platform for local and visiting musicians. Massey's own Toolshed Allstars are the house band. In the current climate of Stereophonics and Steps, seeing them feels like walking out of the Conservative Party conference into a strange, post-nuclear soundworld full of little green men with fabulous, unearthly tunes.

The Allstars certainly look different. There are 12 of them, including three drummers, a five-piece brass section and a Yoko Ono/ Shirley Bassey-ish singer, See Ming. Instruments range from Massey's heap of keyboards to a whirring ball on string. The band frequently don hard hats, presumably to protect themselves from the fireworks in their music.

Their entrance is stunning. Following the introductory chords of Michael Jackson's Ben, See Ming strides on and suddenly shrieks "Ben!" as the band explode into a futuristic punk rock freakout. Following this jape, the Allstars manage to be a blistering fusion of, say, Frank Zappa's Hot Rats, John Zorn and the Plastic Ono Band, and they just get better.

The voodoo soundtrack created by the drummers is terrifying but exhilarating. This percussion force is crucial, blasting the band off from dance music. The other key component is the brass section, whose enormous stabs of melody ensure that no matter how weird the Allstars get - and they certainly get weird - they are always orbiting around a killer tune. Everyone from avant jazzheads to techno kids should love them.

Once everybody has recovered, the core of the Allstars (with a few extra violinists and cellists) return as Homelife. The music is totally different. Oriental folk nestles against vaguely Massive Attack dub-songs, and although they lack the Allstars' tumult, the sound is almost as unusual. As for the tag "Toolshed", nobody plays a lathe or a coping saw, but if they can find one that can be tuned, I wouldn't put it past them.

webTitle: World music review: Argentina's deadly music

fields.headline: Argentina's deadly music
fields.standfirst:
Leon Gieco/ Victor Heredia
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText:
Leon Gieco/ Victor Heredia
Barbican, London
****
fields.body:
Latin American dance music has conquered the world, and established Cuba, Colombia and Brazil as centres for some of the most exhilarating sounds to be heard. But there is another Latin musical style that has been ignored - the political ballads of the Nueva Cancion (New Song) movement that flourished in Argentina and Chile in the 1970s and 1980s, when singers dared to stand up against military dictatorship, and suffered or (in the case of Victor Jara) were even killed because of their work. This was truly dangerous protest music.

The style has lived on in Argentina, and this four-hour concert showed how Argentina has changed, and what we've been missing. In support was Soledad, a 19-year-old who has shaken up that folk tradition to become one of the most successful, exciting new pop performers in South America. She was dressed in a cowgirl outfit, and came on like a Latin link between Madonna and Billy Bragg, with a stage show that was pure pop, complete with frantic dancing.

Backed by a rousing seven-piece band, she switched between furious and theatrical treatments of folk songs and finely sung ballads that dealt with violence or the importance of Argentina. At one point she disappeared from the stage to be replaced by an almost identical-looking singer, her sister Natalia. She, too, was an impressive balladeer, and joined Soledad for a serious of stomping duets, a seemingly impossible act to follow.

The headliners, Leon Gieco and Victor Heredia, had history on their side. Famous for their solo work, singing against the military dictatorship and the Malvinas/Falklands war, here they sang duets and solo songs. Gieco, the "Bob Dylan of Argentina", mixed bluesy rock songs with his ballads. Heredia, who was banned from performing during the military era, matched him with passionate dignity. He sang about surviving the military years, and about his sister, who was among those who "disappeared". Towards the end, the two men joined together for a stirring treatment of Gieco's emotional anthem, Solo Le Pido a Dios (I Just Ask God). It was a reminder that in Argentina popular music has been a matter of life and death.

fields.headline: Keith Coventry
fields.standfirst:
Emily Tsingou Gallery, London
****
fields.trailText:
Emily Tsingou Gallery, London
****
fields.body:
In the unlikely setting of a posh West End gallery, art's utopian project of the early to mid-20th century seems to have been reborn. On the way in, a bronze sculpture draws a shape in space; a large circle interlocks with a smaller circle, like an upside-down snowman. The walls are covered in hessian sacking, weaving an atmosphere of revolution. You are transported to a lecture room in Moscow or the Bauhaus 80 years ago, listening to a prophetic madman expound the principles of the new design. Downstairs, the sense of mission becomes more intense. Black paintings in black frames with two interlocking white circles hang in a space also covered with hessian.

Only a face on a private view card left near the entrance gives the game away. It's Kate Moss on the cover of Vogue. Two circles have been drawn over her, revealing an underlying geometry. Downstairs, the paintings are all titled Supermodel. The list of works confirms they are portraits of Kate Moss, Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington...

All have been made using a technique artist Keith Coventry borrowed from a 1930s book, Cassell's New Popular Educator, whose cover has a man staring into the sun of knowledge and promises to inform readers about "art and literature", "languages and history", and "science and mathematics". The drawing method Coventry discovered here claimed to reduce visible reality to its geometrical essentials. The inspiration came from Cézanne's statement that one must look in nature for the sphere, the cone and the cylinder.

Coventry has looked for the sphere, the cone and the cylinder in the pages of Vogue. He has found these circles repeated from face to face in an underlying system, a hidden structure. His paintings have a rough, matted texture; they replace glamour with severity, cosmetics with history. In them, the ghosts of modern art whisper. This is Coventry's best work to date, a provocative examination of what painting is and what it once was.

Until October 28. Details: 020-7839 5320.

webTitle: Art review: Can a charcoal drawing change the world?

fields.headline: Can a charcoal drawing change the world?
fields.standfirst:
Look Out
Wolverhampton Art Gallery
****
fields.trailText:
Look Out
Wolverhampton Art Gallery
****
fields.body:
Blood leaks from a TV screen showing signposts to Iraq and Kuwait. Richard Hamilton's photo-collage is part of Look Out, an exhibition of politically engaged contemporary art, curated by artist Peter Kennard. Hamilton's point is rather obvious, but his concern is shared by most of the artists here. If political realities are turned into virtual games, what images can artists create to share their discontent? How can artists creatively exploit needless and pointless suffering? Can art ever be relevant again without getting embroiled in self-conscious theoretical subtleties? Can it be direct as well as ironic? Can it rage as well as shock? Does it make any difference?

Kennard hopes the show will "bring it home...The over there will become over here", but the most affecting work expresses the impossibility of getting through. We are back to Theodor Adorno's line: is art possible after Auschwitz? Theorists say that all art is political, so how come so little of it dares to deal with politically significant events? The fact that Kennard is intrepid enough to tackle such questions makes him, against all expectations, almost fashionable. But even if protest artists are back in, they've got a problem on their hands. Imagine being an anti-propagandist who thinks it's about time somebody said something.

Here and there social commentary is disarmed by artiness. Tony Bevan's charcoal drawings of the homeless, crudely splattered with red pigment, come across in this company as tame art class exercises. Glenys Johnson's painted figures are more convincing because they are blurred through a newsprint-style grid of pixels. It must be significant that the most powerful images in the show are all distinguished by their recognition of the difficulties of seeing what's really going on. Mohini Chandra's wall of 100 photographs is more memorable than Leon Golub's installation of massive photographic negatives. Golub focuses on the bloodied heads of the war dead. Chandra's photographs are all turned to the wall. Her photographs-in-exile are embodiments of displacement.

The ironic wit of Nick Waplington's mock web page for anarchy.co.uk ("Feeling suicidal? Don't be selfish: we show you how to take some yuppie scum with you") seems slight compared with the simple obscurity of Christopher Stewart's Bomb Blast, a photograph of a theatrical turquoise veil. But it's Gustav Metzger who steals the show with his Historic Photograph, Hitler Youth, Eingeschweisst, two rolled steel sheets welded together and dumped against the gallery wall. The sheets are beginning to rust but are still impenetrable. You suspect that some unimaginable image is concealed but absolutely nothing is revealed. For the time being, maybe that's all the revelation we can expect.

Until November 11. Details: 01902 552055. Then at the Bluecoat Gallery, Liverpool, from November 21.
fields.bodyText: Blood leaks from a TV screen showing signposts to Iraq and Kuwait. Richard Hamilton's photo-collage is part of Look Out, an exhibition of politically engaged contemporary art, curated by artist Peter Kennard. Hamilton's point is rather obvious, but his concern is shared by most of the artists here. If political realities are turned into virtual games, what images can artists create to share their discontent? How can artists creatively exploit needless and pointless suffering? Can art ever be relevant again without getting embroiled in self-conscious theoretical subtleties? Can it be direct as well as ironic? Can it rage as well as shock? Does it make any difference? Kennard hopes the show will "bring it home...The over there will become over here", but the most affecting work expresses the impossibility of getting through. We are back to Theodor Adorno's line: is art possible after Auschwitz? Theorists say that all art is political, so how come so little of it dares to deal with politically significant events? The fact that Kennard is intrepid enough to tackle such questions makes him, against all expectations, almost fashionable. But even if protest artists are back in, they've got a problem on their hands. Imagine being an anti-propagandist who thinks it's about time somebody said something. Here and there social commentary is disarmed by artiness. Tony Bevan's charcoal drawings of the homeless, crudely splattered with red pigment, come across in this company as tame art class exercises. Glenys Johnson's painted figures are more convincing because they are blurred through a newsprint-style grid of pixels. It must be significant that the most powerful images in the show are all distinguished by their recognition of the difficulties of seeing what's really going on. Mohini Chandra's wall of 100 photographs is more memorable than Leon Golub's installation of massive photographic negatives. Golub focuses on the bloodied heads of the war dead. Chandra's photographs are all turned to the wall. Her photographs-in-exile are embodiments of displacement. The ironic wit of Nick Waplington's mock web page for anarchy.co.uk ("Feeling suicidal? Don't be selfish: we show you how to take some yuppie scum with you") seems slight compared with the simple obscurity of Christopher Stewart's Bomb Blast, a photograph of a theatrical turquoise veil. But it's Gustav Metzger who steals the show with his Historic Photograph, Hitler Youth, Eingeschweisst, two rolled steel sheets welded together and dumped against the gallery wall. The sheets are beginning to rust but are still impenetrable. You suspect that some unimaginable image is concealed but absolutely nothing is revealed. For the time being, maybe that's all the revelation we can expect. Until November 11. Details: 01902 552055. Then at the Bluecoat Gallery, Liverpool, from November 21.

fields.headline: William Bell
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe, London
****
fields.body:
It's like being dragged out to see the last surviving steam train. You feel like prodding William Bell's cream slacks: Coo! A real working soul legend! Bell was the first artist signed to Memphis record label Stax in the early 1960s. An early success, he stayed until the bitter end in the mid-1970s, writing and performing with label-mate Otis Redding. The surprise is that, despite rap's pilferings, there is no one under 30 in the house tonight curious about the real deal.

More poignantly, there is barely another black face. The blues and pre-1970s soul have been revised out of existence for younger black crowds. Which leaves tonight's audience: a committed band of white fifty- and sixtysomethings.

"I can see Lunnun is in party mood ta-night!" Bell asserts to a half-empty hall. And, against the odds, it is a bit of a party. A gang of, let's say, chartered accountants next to me are suddenly a Tennessee church congregation. "Amen!" they shout, and "Yes sirree!", complete with deep Southern inflections.

You find you know Bell tunes without realizing it. Born Under a Bad Sign is more famous for its Albert King interpretation but here it is, delivered with anguished melodrama by the man who performed it first. The songs are pure Stax: horns, bluesy organ and a big fella promising to "treat choo raht". Even now, with almost 40 years of renditions behind him, he sounds like he's going to suck the muzzle of a shotgun if you don't come back.

So what place do these great tunes and that grand old voice have in the culture? Ninth on the bill at a college ball headlined by Steps? The lurching stage of a cruise ship? A lifetime schlepping round provincial civic centres? Bell and the R&B legacy he represents deserve so much more.

webTitle: Neil Rhodes and Jonathan Sawday's top 10 internet and technology books

fields.headline: Neil Rhodes and Jonathan Sawday's top 10 internet and technology books
fields.trailText: Neil Rhodes and Jonathan Sawday are co-editors of The Renaissance Computer: Knowledge Technology in the First Age of Print. Jonathan Sawday is Professor of English Studies at the University of Strathclyde. Neil Rhodes is Reader in English Renaissance Literature at the University of St Andrews.
fields.body:
Neil Rhodes and Jonathan Sawday are co-editors of The Renaissance Computer: Knowledge Technology in the First Age of Print.

Jonathan Sawday is Professor of English Studies at the University of Strathclyde. Neil Rhodes is Reader in English Renaissance Literature at the University of St Andrews.
Buy The Renaissance Computer at Amazon.co.uk

1. The Gutenberg Galaxy by Marshall McLuhan
Still seems remarkably prescient. McLuhan invented the concept of electronic 'surfing' (his term) back in the early 60s.

2. Interfaces of the Word by Walter J Ong
A classic of media studies from a formidably learned Jesuit priest.

3. Hypertext 2.0 by George P Landow
An upgrade of Hypertext: The Convergence of Contemporary Critical Theory and Technology. The messiah of hypertext explores its relationship with theory and literary form and what it means for authorship and education.

4. Modest_Witness@Second Millenium.FemaleMan Meets OncoMouse by Donna Haraway
Crossing and recrossing many boundaries, Haraway describes the fascinating reconfigurations of the relationship between the human and the non-human in the new age of scientific experiment.

5. Life on the Screen: Identity in the Age of the Internet by Sherry Turkle
Highly readable book about how we live with computers and how they are altering our lives, especially in our conceptions of subjectivity.

6. Writing Space: The Computer, Hypertext and the History of Writing by Jay David Bolter
A wonderfully wide-ranging history of the evolving forms of communication and textuality.

7. The Cyborg Handbook by Chris Gray
Invaluable collection of documents tracing the history of the fusion between machines and humans.

8. The Electronic Word by Richard Lanham
A lucidly argued and provocative account of the conditions of electronic textuality by an expert in the history of rhetoric.

9. Neuromancer by William Gibson
The Bladerunner of the internet: a dystopic romance which may yet prove to mirror the reality of the virtual world we are creating.

10. The Internet: A Philosophical Inquiry by Gordon Graham
A fascinating discussion of what philosophy can tell us about virtual reality.

webTitle: Theatre review: Noël Coward versus Paul Daniels

fields.headline: Noël Coward versus Paul Daniels
fields.standfirst:
Blithe Spirit
Citizens Theatre, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
Blithe Spirit
Citizens Theatre, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
As much as a Noël Coward play can ever be about big issues, Blithe Spirit is about the past coming to live with you. Charles, a novelist toying with a book about spiritualism, finds himself in the uncomfortable position of being an "astral bigamist" when his long-dead first wife, Elvira, one night joins him and his second wife, Ruth.

The same issue - how to handle the past - troubles this production of the play, first performed in 1941. Philip Prowse's design and direction pull Coward into the present with a sleek black and red set with splashes of animal hide - very this season. A television flickers; they play CDs; there is even a reference to Paul Daniels, presumably replacing a more obscure, aged allusion.

Coward doesn't need all this, nor does the strong cast, including Ellen Sheean as a splendid, eccentric Madam Arcati and Sophie Ward as a suitably spectral Elvira. The comic situation and the writing are hardly impenetrable to a modern audience; the mannered upper-class civility he does so well is far from a puzzle.

Still, this is a charming enough production, light and funny, turning darker when the spirits possess the house. By this point, Ruth has also gone to the other side and love has turned to spirited loathing. "No one but a monumental bore would have thought of having a honeymoon in Budleigh Salterton," she yells, before confessing to an affair with one Mungo Gracegirdle.

This is what you want from Coward: put-down one-liners, ludicrous comic situations, chaps with names like Gracegirdle. To tamper with this is to water him down, whether it's by adding references to television or inserting another interval. The second feels unnecessary, breaking up the comedic tension and leaving the last act underwhelming. In fashion, the 1940s are also very much this season, and it's a pity to have squandered this. Worth seeing, however, for the performances and the play's humour, and for pondering, on the way home, how Coward might have described Paul Daniels.

Until October 14. Box office: 0141-429 0022.

fields.headline: The best spiritual scene
fields.standfirst: O brother, where art thou?
fields.trailText: O brother, where art thou?
fields.body:
Absconding from a chain gang in a pick-up truck, Everett (George Clooney), Pete (John Turturro) and Delmar (Tim Blake Nelson) have picked up a hitchhiker (Chris Thomas King) on a deserted crossroads. He carries a guitar.

"How you doin' son? The name's Everett. These two soggy sons of bitches are Pete and Delmar. Keep your fingers away from Pete's mouth - he ain't had nothing to eat for 13 years but prison food, gopher, and a little greasy horse."

"Thanks for the lift, sir. My name's Tommy. Tommy Johnson."

"How you doin' Tommy?" says Delmar, staring out of the window. "Say, I haven't seen a house out here for miles. What you doing out there in the middle of nowhere?"

"Well, I had to be out at that there crossroads last midnight to sell my soul to the devil."

"Well, ain't it a small world, spiritually speaking!" Everett exclaims. "Pete and Delmar have just been baptised and saved. I guess I'm the only one here who remains unaffiliated."

Delmar scowls.

"This ain't no laughing matter."

"And what did the devil give you for your soul, Tommy?" Everett goes on.

"Well, he taught me to play this here guitar real good."

Delmar looks aghast.

"For that, you traded your everlasting soul?"

Tommy shrugs.

"Well, I wasn't using it."

See also: Close Encounters Of The Third Kind, Bad Lieutenant, The Wicker Man

Don't see also: Sister Act 2: Back In The Habit

Pointless trivia: O Brother, Where Art Thou? is the title of the movie that director John L Sullivan wants to make in Preston Sturges' Sullivan's Travels.

fields.headline: Bould calls it a day
fields.trailText: Steve Bould yesterday announced his retirement on medical advice at the age of 37. The Stoke-born defender, who ended his long association with Arsenal to join Sunderland in the summer of 1999, has admitted defeat in his battle to recover from a toe injury suffered last season.
fields.body:
Steve Bould yesterday announced his retirement on medical advice at the age of 37. The Stoke-born defender, who ended his long association with Arsenal to join Sunderland in the summer of 1999, has admitted defeat in his battle to recover from a toe injury suffered last season.

He has been limited to only one appearance, as a substitute, this season and said: "The injury means I will be unable to continue to play at the highest level and I have therefore decided to retire while at the peak of my career. I'm hoping to stay in the game, perhaps by trying my hand at coaching.

Peter Reid signed Bould for £500,000 when he was no longer guaranteed first-team action at Arsenal.

Bould played a major role in Sunderland's seventh-place finish on their return to the Premiership last season despite a long absence due to his injury.

After signing professional terms with Stoke in 1980 he made 211 appearances before moving to Highbury in 1988 for a bargain £390,000.

He was one of the Gunners' "Famous Five" defence and his 373 Arsenal appearances brought three league titles, an FA Cup winner's medal in the 1998 Double side and European Cup Winners' Cup triumph. He won two England caps, against Greece and Norway in 1994.

fields.headline: Third Division  Round-up
fields.trailText: Chesterfield stay two points clear at the top after making it four succesive wins with a 3-1 triumph at Blackpool, beaten for the fifth time in six matches.
fields.body:
Chesterfield stay two points clear at the top after making it four succesive wins with a 3-1 triumph at Blackpool, beaten for the fifth time in six matches.

Luke Beckett, Ryan Williams (penalty) and Marcus Ebdon scored for the Spireites before Steve Bushell pulled a goal back for the sinking Seasiders.

Rochdale remain second with a blistering 4-0 win at Shrewsbury , Mark Monington scoring his third in as many matches with Tony Ellis, Clive Platt and David Bayliss striking the others. Kevin Ratcliffe was scathing about his side's display: "There are no injury problems because we never put in any tackles."

Cardiff, the division's only unbeaten team, were held 0-0 at home by Kidderminster and the Welsh club were overtaken by Cheltenham, who crushed Plymouth 5-2 with Martin Devaney netting a hat-trick, Brighton and Leyton Orient, who both won 1-0, Nathan Jones and Carl Griffiths scoring respectively.

Halifax pulled off their first win of the season with a 2-1 success at tottering Torquay , who had Alex Watson sent off for a professional foul in the 51st minute. Steve Kerrigan and Ian Fitzpatrick scored for the basement club.

fields.headline: Second Division  Round-up
fields.trailText: Jorge Leitao's fifth goal of the season gave Walsall a 1-0 win at Wrexham and kept them at the top of the table while their nearest rivals Cambridge United were losing 3-0 at home to Bristol Rovers and slipping to sixth.
fields.body:
Jorge Leitao's fifth goal of the season gave Walsall a 1-0 win at Wrexham and kept them at the top of the table while their nearest rivals Cambridge United were losing 3-0 at home to Bristol Rovers and slipping to sixth.

The Portuguese striker got on the scoresheet after 28 minutes when he picked up a pass from Paul Hall, beat a defender and finished from close range. "If you are going to win promotion this is the kind of result that you need, often," said the manager Ray Graydon, who takes the team to West Ham for a Worthington Cup tie on Wednesday.

Wigan moved into second place with a 2-1 win over Northampton, Simon Haworth and Andy Liddell scoring either side of Ian Hendon's penalty.

Bury had an own-goal from visiting Port Vale's Matt Carragher and a close-range shot from their captain Nick Daws to thank for the 2-0 win which lifted them into third place.

Reading moved up to fourth following their 5-1 rout of Swansea, which made it 19 goals in five home matches. Martin Butler scored a hat-trick while Jamie Cureton and Lee Hodges also got their names on the scoresheet.

Millwall , who expect to appoint a new manager later this seek, hit five against the bottom club Oxford , Neil Harris weighing in with a hat-trick and Sam Parkin, on loan from Chelsea, getting the first of his double two minutes into what was his league debut.

Danny Wilson's Bristol City are now without a win in eight games. Tony Lock put Colchester in front at Ashton Gate only for Tony Thorpe, who had several chances, to equalise in a game where United's Alan White was carried off with an ankle injury only for the stretcher-bearers to drop him near the touchline.

Luton made it seven without a win after Swindon left with a 3-2 victory. The home manager Ricky Hill, on being informed that a section of the crowd had barracked him and the team, commented: "They were unhappy with what they saw, but so am I."

fields.headline: First Division Round-up
fields.trailText: The sad times continue for Sheffield Wednesday, who still have only one club, Yorkshire rivals Huddersfield, protecting them from bottom place after the Owls' fourth home defeat in five games, this time 3-1 to Preston.
fields.body:
The sad times continue for Sheffield Wednesday, who still have only one club, Yorkshire rivals Huddersfield, protecting them from bottom place after the Owls' fourth home defeat in five games, this time 3-1 to Preston.

Owen Morrison put Wednesday ahead but Graham Alexander, Iain Anderson and a Des Walker own goal in 19 second-half minutes added to the manager Paul Jewell's worries.

Huddersfield are even unhappier at home, raising the pressure on Steve Bruce, whose side were beaten at the McAlpine stadium for the eighth time on the trot as Andy Payton's 17th minute strike gave Burnley a 1-0 victory.

Grimsby were the victims of Nottingham Forest's third successive away win, David Platt's team triumphing 2-0, while Crewe were held to 2-2 after Barnsley hit back with Darren Barnard's penalty and a Bruce Dyer goal in the last 10 minutes.

Watford stayed second with a 3-2 win at Stockport but had Tommy Mooney sent off in the 53rd minute for violent conduct. Crystal Palace's Neil Ruddock also saw the red card after two bookings in the 1-0 home defeat by Sheffield United , Marcus Bent striking again.

webTitle: Wolves propelled upwards by youthful energy

fields.headline: Wolves propelled upwards by youthful energy
fields.trailText: Four-star Wolves propelled upwards by youthful energy.
fields.body:
While Norwich answer a crisis by turning to a couple of 35-year-olds, Wolves' belief in youth remains strong. Yesterday they gave Adam Proudlock and Michael Branch their head and with a combined age not too far in front of Tony Cottee and Steve Walsh, they came through with honours.

Proudlock, 19, was some way down the pecking order at the start of the season and went on loan to Clyde to gain experience. Injuries demanded his recall earlier than had been expected but in those five weeks away the teenager had become a man. For Wolves' first against a dispirited Norwich he skilfully held off Walsh before drilling home a smart shot on the turn.

Branch later scored an eye-catching fourth to round off a marvellous day's work for a team who count the Olympic heroine Denise Lewis among their fans and who only a couple of weeks ago were being reminded that their results so far were well short of a pass mark.

"Hopefully this will give us a lift so that we can push on," said Colin Lee, savouring the climb to 13th place and hopeful that the worst of a heavy casualty list is behind them.

"It's been a difficult period but out of that comes some good and we now know that Adam, Ryan Green and Joleon Lescott are all capable of playing first-team football."

Of course it is of considerable help to the Wanderers manager that even in the more straightened times funds are still made available to invest in new players, unlike at Delia Smith's club where the first instinct is to open a new restaurant. Tony Dinning is the latest to arrive at Molineux and while supporters will have arrived expecting him to line up in an accustomed midfield position, he performed admirably as a makeshift centre-half alongside Neil Emblen.

Dinning, a £600,000 purchase who played in all 11 positions for Stockport, found time to head in the second following Andy Simpson's corner and it was his long ball that had put Branch on the chase for the cross that led to Proudlock's opener. webTitle: Pass masters Fulham look good for a place in history

fields.headline: Pass masters Fulham look good for a place in history
fields.trailText: Pass masters Fulham look good for a place in history.
fields.body:
A flyer in the match programme describes this season as "likely to be the most successful in the club's history" and though premature talk can often lead to lasting embarrassment, the only question remaining after this performance is how soon it will be before Fulham secure promotion.

Andy Hessenthaler had few doubts about the performance he had witnessed from close quarters. "They are the best side we have played so far, we just couldn't get near them," he said. "They taught us a lesson and I'm quite pleased it was only 3-0. A lot of Premier League sides could come here and not get anything."

Gillingham's chirpy player-manager, who three days earlier played a part in their honourable draw at Manchester City, saw his gutsy team finish a distant second to the leaders Fulham, who in the process equalled the eight straight league wins they managed under Kevin Keegan at the start of the Second Division championship season of two years ago.

Not that their player-coach John Collins is getting too carried away. Indeed his comments were a measure of how far Fulham have come in a short space of time. "It was below par today and we've played better than that," he said. "We were a little bit slack with our passing in the first half."

Ten seasons back Alan Dicks's relegation side waited 11 games for their first win while as recently as February 1996 Fulham plunged to second bottom of the Third Division before Ian Branfoot was shunted upstairs and Micky Adams took control of the team for the visit of Exeter.

That game was won 2-1, Fulham moved up a place and so began an ascent which seems certain to realise Premiership football for next term.

"We are passing teams off the park. There are a lot of players here who could play in the Premier League," Collins added. "We believe that if you pass for 90 minutes teams tend to tire. It's been the case in the previous seven games. But it takes a lot of hard work in the first half to make it look easy in the second."

So it came to pass on a sunny afternoon which saw the ground staff watering the pitch until five minutes before kick-off to minimise any chance Gillingham had of hustling the hosts out of their stride.

Fabrice Fernandes could have got the ball rolling for Fulham early on but his shot hit the inside of a post and after Louis Saha finished a fine run with a chip which whistled over, it was left to Steve Finnan to produce a testing cross which the unmarked Barry Hayles chested down and lashed into the roof of the net.

Hayles then slipped a ball through to Lee Clark who drew Vince Bartram before lifting the ball into the corner. And late on the striker added his second when he got past three defenders before firing into the top corner. Another job done.

webTitle: Celtic extend run as Dundee falter

fields.headline: Celtic extend run as Dundee falter
fields.trailText: Celtic make it eight from eight.
fields.body:
Bonnie Dundee, the saying goes north of the border, though the town, and sometimes the football team, can often take a bit of a savaging. Dire jokes about the city's grimness and lack of sophisticated attire have long been a black vein of humour in the Scottish idiom. Anyone who is re-located to Dundee to work, it is often said, will end up losing half their marbles.

The city's original football team - not to be confused with the currently toiling tangerines, United, who came along later - are at least trying to rectify this. Under their Italian player-manager, Ivano Bonetti, Dundee had started this season relatively breezily, claiming 12 points from their first eight matches and giddily finding themselves sitting fifth in the Premier League.

This progress has been achieved at the usual cost which currently blights the British game - local Scottish players have been yanked out of the team. Bonetti and his brother and assistant, Dario, spent the summer importing Italians and South Americans.

One of Bonetti's finest signings has been the young Argentine striker, Juan Sara, whose goals, including a midweek hat-trick in the city derby against United, have hoisted Dundee nearer their former glories. He is a born-again Christian who keeps thanking the Lord for every goal, lifting up his shirt to reveal some text of scripture daubed across his vest.

Normally it is the old John 3:16 number - "God so loved the world..."

On Saturday at Parkhead, Sara's header pranged against Celtic's bar after seven minutes, an incident which made us think this might be the hour of Martin O'Neill's seemingly unstoppable opening charge with Celtic grinding to a halt.

However, in the end Dundee flattered to deceive. Celtic scored through Stilian Petrov after 61 minutes, before which the Tayside team had long given up any notion of flooding their opponents' half with players.

Petrov's maturing with Celtic in his second season with the club is raising even the most bushily cynical eyebrows. Three weeks ago he scored with a plunging header against Rangers, and on Saturday he came up with a similar effort, meeting Alan Thompson's cross flush on his forehead to bury his header past a helpless Rab Douglas. The goal condemned Dundee and extended Celtic's streak to eight wins and 24 points at the top of the league.

Dundee's neighbours, United, meanwhile, continued their descent into disarray. Bolted to the bottom of the Premier League, United lost 5-3 at home to Aberdeen on Saturday, a hat-trick from the former United striker, Robbie Winters, applying salt to their many wounds.

Rangers, who today depart for Istanbul on the next phase of their Champions League campaign against Galatasaray, toned themselves up in a tedious 1-0 win at Motherwell. Battling Dunfermline, meanwhile, drew 1-1 at home with Hibs, while St Mirren continued to find Premier League life exacting in their home defeat to St Johnstone.

 Kilmarnock made it four wins in five games as they dispatched a Hearts side who perhaps had one eye on Thursday's Uefa Cup second-leg tie against VfB Stuttgart, who lead by the only goal. Paul Wright got Killie under way and Fréderic Dindeleux added a header as the visitors stayed in fourth place.

webTitle: Burchill may be Blues' missing link

fields.headline: Burchill may be Blues' missing link
fields.trailText: Burchill leaves Blues fans wondering if this will the year.
fields.body:
Trevor Francis's pursuit of a strike force potent enough to take Birmingham City into the Premiership has been a costly, unproductive process but with true Olympic timing his four-year quest could finally have struck gold.

None of City's strikers has scored more league goals than the 16 managed by Paul Devlin in 1996-97, Francis's first season in charge, and the failures of the likes of Paul Furlong, Dele Adebola and Peter Ndlovu have kept City firmly plugged in the First Division.

It seems a lot of pressure to heap on the shoulders of a 20-year-old but Mark Burchill, who agreed a three-month loan deal from Celtic on Friday with a view to a £1.5m move, has the credentials to allow Blues' fans to believe it might just be their year.

Described by Francis as "without question the hottest property in Scottish football", Burchill lived up to his billing on Saturday by having a hand in both goals. Indeed the introduction of Burchill and Ndlovu after an hour transformed a sterile game which Tranmere had controlled.

Burchill, who has six Scotland caps, is desperate to prove himself after becoming frustrated with life behind Henrik Larsson and Chris Sutton at Parkhead. He has been told by Craig Brown that he is guaranteed to start for his country if he plays and scores regularly.

"I'm behind two £10m strikers at Celtic and I'm just a young boy still learning," Burchill said. "So I've come to Birmingham to get a few games and improve my fitness." With the clubs having agreed a fee, Francis's task now is to persuade him to stay longer.

Birmingham supporters took to Burchill immediately on Saturday, if only because they had been given precious little else to cheer.

Within 10 minutes of his entrance City took the lead. After Martin Grainger hit the post with a free-kick, Burchill's presence caused Tranmere's goalkeeper John Achterberg to miss a looping cross from Nicky Eaden, allowing Grainger to fire into the empty net.

Danny Sonner also hit the woodwork before Geoff Horsfield tapped home after Burchill rounded the keeper and sent a shot goalwards.

The Scot had not even met his team-mates until 90 minutes before kick-off. Now the whole club will be hoping to get to know him a whole lot better.

webTitle: Allardyce looks to be a lifelong Wanderer

fields.headline: Allardyce looks to be a lifelong Wanderer
fields.trailText: Bo Hansen's 30-yarder rescues a point for Bolton.
fields.body:
Sam Allardyce clearly believes Bolton is his spiritual home. The man who made 231 appearances for the club in the days when centre-halves were still centre-halves is ready to commit himself to another 10 years of life with the Wanderers.

Allardyce is the 45-year-old manager of a First Division club with Premiership pretensions and his aim is to lay the foundations for years to come. He revealed on Saturday he has opened talks on a new deal that will keep him at the club until 2010. "I want to build something here that will last for a long time," he explained.

"I want to build from the top to the bottom - right down to where the kids are. And, if I can stay around for longer than anyone else has done as manager and break a few records along the way, then I will be highly delighted."

Bolton believe the man who was once their leader on the field can now achieve perhaps even more success as their manager. Certainly he is moulding a squad whose mental toughness is always uppermost in every game they play.

Rovers, their Lancashire rivals, could not have wished for a better start when James Thomas, their new boy up front, cracked in his third goal in two games after 47 seconds.

And, although it took Bolton another 87 minutes before they clawed their way back, courtesy of Bo Hansen's cruelly deflected 30-yarder, one always sensed they had an equaliser in them somewhere.

Allardyce was suitably impressed. "I was delighted for Bo," he said. "I think he is contributing a lot more from midfield than he did when he played as a striker."

Rovers' manager Graeme Souness, meanwhile, could not disguise his disappointment. "We didn't scrap as much as we should have done," he said. "We should have put them under the cosh a lot more."

webTitle: Owen keeps his head in front after Phillips bullet

fields.headline: Owen keeps his head in front after Phillips bullet
fields.trailText: Owen keeps his head in front after Phillips bullet.
fields.body:
In many respects Liverpool's Gérard Houllier and Sunderland's Peter Reid are soul-mates, driven relentlessly forward by the shared belief that the seemingly flawed personnel under their guidance are creatures who boast a rare gift, one which, given the right encouragement, can blossom.

Unlike Houllier, Reid, the scouser who grew up a Liverpool fan before becoming such a revered and feted figure at Everton, has probably never been called erudite.

That is not to say he is not smart, because unquestionably he is; certainly smart enough to have ascertained long ago that football management is a career where the street-wise are just as credible and coveted as the urbane.

Yes, he is demonstrative. Yes, he uses the industrial language of the shop-floor but Reid is a managerial war-horse who asks only of his players that they try and care. His chest was swelling with pride on Saturday evening.

As a player Reid always drew strength from adversity and would deride those, however proficient, who slipped prematurely into the comfort zone. Reid always loved his visits to Anfield because, as he once observed, the place brought out the gladiator in him.

"I must admit, I do like this place and coming here still gives me a real thrill," he said after watching his side punch holes in the theory that Liverpool's costly summer refit has improved them so markedly that they will, at last, be able to launch and sustain a meaningful challenge to Manchester United's rather embarrassing Premiership supremacy.

With Dietmar Hamann and Jamie Carragher preferring industry to artistry in central midfield, Nick Barmby as depressingly anonymous as he was during his darker days at Everton and Rigobert Song attempting to convince his manager that his future should lie elsewhere, Liverpool were abject for the most part and escaped with a point only because Sunderland could not convert the chances they created in the final quarter.

Houllier wisely made no attempt to drag wool over eyes, simply conceding that here was a ragged and undistinguished performance. "It just wasn't a good day for us; it never once felt right," he said. "But, if there is a plus point, it is that we took something out of the game when, perhaps, we might have ended up with nothing."

Houllier's assertion that teams who are off-colour and out of sorts will invariably lump the ball forwards optimistically was certainly more general than it was specific for, had the impressive Christian Ziege not lumped, often and with great accuracy, Liverpool would surely have lost.

Indeed, it was one of Ziege's many telling free-kicks which brought Liverpool their equaliser, Michael Owen rising majestically to head home via the underside of the crossbar.

Kevin Phillips, one of those whom Owen has helped to keep in the international shadows, had penned a curiously class-free afternoon's first meaningful chapter after 13 minutes when he made much of a retreating Liverpool defence to sprint 30 yards before planting a fine drive into the bottom corner. "He hit it early and that is the hallmark of a quality striker," purred Reid.

"We are all fighting for our England places and all I can do is keep reminding people what I can do," said Phillips when asked if his fourth goal in eight games held a message for Kevin Keegan. "We will have to wait and see. Michael Owen is on form and ahead of me, particularly after that goal he scored against France."

While Phillips and Owen made their mark, another England striker, Emile Heskey, looks to have been ruled out of the reckoning for the Germany game after he limped off after 10 minutes and he may now face surgery on the injured knee which has been nagging at him since the start of the season. Houllier has all but ruled him out of Thursday's Uefa Cup first-round second-leg tie at home to Rapid Bucharest.

fields.headline: Gascoigne shows his old class
fields.trailText: Gascoigne shows his old class to deny Leicester top spot.
fields.body:
A little of Paul Gascoigne can still go a long way and yesterday it went far enough to deny Leicester City the victory which would have put them on top of the league for the first time in 37 years. Gascoigne's performance in the second half inspired Everton to force a draw which looked well beyond them after Leicester had taken the lead midway through the first.

Gascoigne is in another of his lean periods, which is to say that in the player's latest search for full match fitness he is again looking on the slim side of sleek. The skills he will never lose, it is the length of time available to him to continue using them at Premiership level which has been questioned.

On this evidence it is clearly too early to write off the 33-year-old as a limp accessory. In the closing minutes of the match, Gascoigne made three strong challenges to win the ball near the left-hand touchline before picking himself up to find Thomas Gravesen unmarked in the penalty area.

Had the Dane not wasted the opportunity the afternoon would have ended perfectly for Gascoigne, who had earlier set up David Unsworth for Everton's equaliser. As it was the nation's icon of the day before yesterday offered a pertinent reminder of his qualities, with Kevin Keegan due to announce an England squad later this week.

The idea of Gascoigne facing Germany at Wembley in a World Cup qualifier on Saturday week is, to say the least, far-fetched and nobody would have lent it credence before half-time at Filbert Street, when he did little apart from play safe passes and watch the rest of the game go by.

Yet as Walter Smith, the Everton manager, pointed out: "Paul can give us something in parts of games and maybe he can do the same at international level."

Glenn Hoddle used to believe this until finally abandoning Gascoigne before the 1998 World Cup. At times yesterday Gascoigne looked the midfield creative force that he once was and David Beckham probably never will be.

His readiness to command the ball, backed by Gravesen and the Ghanaian Alex Nyarko, wrested the game from Neil Lennon, Muzzy Izzet and Robbie Savage after Leicester had taken a grip on midfield.

For a side poised to take Leicester to the top for the first time since the late summer of 1963, when none of them had been born, Peter Taylor's players were a disappointment.

Filbert Street was growing wet and impatient when quickly-struck passes from Matt Elliott and Savage gave Lennon the chance to produce a dipping cross which was smartly turned in by Ade Akinbiyi on 23 minutes. Soon afterwards Gascoigne skimmed the crossbar with a 30-yard free kick but at this point Everton's midfield and attack had all but melted away.

When they regained some momentum Nyarko, turning as Gary Rowett made a challenge, was caught by the Leicester defender's leg and went down. "Nobody would have disagreed with the referee if he had given a penalty," said Smith. Well, they would have but justice would probably have been done.

Something seemed to come over Leicester at half-time. Maybe the thought of going two points clear of Manchester United at the top of the Premiership prompted a touch of vertigo. Certainly they approached the bulk of the second half with the nervousness of men afraid to look down.

As Taylor admitted: "That was the worst second half we have played this season. We seemed to lose confidence passing the ball and the players were so quiet. I know they can talk, they've been giving me enough stick."

Whatever the reason for Leicester's ennui, Everton wasted little time exploiting it. In the 50th minute a stoutly-struck free kick by Unsworth which beat Tim Flowers and flew past a post sent a shudder through the home supporters, which was followed two minutes later by a convulsion.

Gascoigne took the ball across the penalty area before switching it from right foot to left, turning back inside Lennon and producing a flighted cross which Flowers could only pat down for Unsworth to drive it into the net.

Goalline clearances, by Rowett at one end and Niclas Alexandersson at the other, denied the game a winner but Gascoigne had won back some respect all the same.

webTitle: Charlton flying after coach is axed

fields.headline: Charlton flying after coach is axed
fields.trailText: Charlton flying after coach is axed.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
Another London club, another player launches a stinging critique of the team coach. But at Charlton disillusion is relative and last week it came in Gaelic, not Gallic, tones.

The Wales winger John Robinson has been pestering Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley to ditch the team bus and fly to away games. With his wish granted, it was apt that Robinson was the architect of the Graham Stuart goal which saw Charlton prevail.

"It definitely helps when you haven't been stuck in a coach for seven hours," said Robin son. "It's taken us eight years to get around to it, but we've finally taken a plane to an away game and perhaps we started brightly because of that.

"But the fact that we flew up here shows the progress the club has made. We met the Chelsea lads at the airport - this is what the big clubs do, and we're in that league."

Judging by this performance, they should stay in it too. Apart from Stuart's scrappy goal, Mark Kinsella smacked a volley against the bar as the visitors embarrassed Newcastle with a purposeful display. Even during the late bombardment, Curbishley's side remained unruffled with the goalkeeper Dean Kiely a reassuring presence.

"Two years ago we would have been happy with a point," Robinson said. "Confidence is up and this result shows we can live with the big boys."

But, as Curbishley acknowledged, Charlton are still some way from living like the fat cats. "We're in the top five but this is a different world," he said. "We've come a long way but we need to get our [ground] capacity up - we lock 15,000 out each week."

For Bobby Robson, top of the table 16 days ago, the curse of the manager of the month award has struck again. His team's first-half display was lacklustre and their approach play tended to fizzle out.

Alan Shearer is supposed to be revived by his international retirement, yet a solitary penalty represents his only goal of the season. With Richard Rufus shadowing his every move, Shearer was limited to a header from Lomana Lua-Lua's injury-time cross which Kiely claimed at the second attempt.

"We didn't get enough balls into the box," said Robson. "Nolberto Solano did plenty of pretty things, but he wasn't effective. If we continue to play like that Alan won't score. The team has to play better for him - he's fighting for service all the time."

Robson must now find a central defender after losing Alain Goma for 10 days, the Frenchman's nose being bloodied and broken in the first minute. "But he showed plenty of commitment to carry on," said Robson. "It's a pity some of the others didn't follow his lead."

fields.headline: Barren Spurs defy Graham's theory
fields.trailText: Jeered Spurs have now gone 303 minutes without a goal.
fields.byline: Russell Thomas at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Tottenham and Manchester City were moved by the Olympic motto - swifter, higher, stronger. Nothing went higher, indeed longer, than the ball. In terms of effort it was gold; in terms of football quality it was the basest metal.

A fixture seemingly guaranteeing goals failed to produce one; at best, it offered a crude excitement. George Graham dug in afterwards and found grim consolations, even if the jeers at half-time and at the final whistle suggested many Spurs' fans could discover nothing at the bottom of the barrel.

"It's very tight at the top," declared Tottenham's manager afterwards, which prompted much table double-checking. As partial explanation for another barren display, Graham looked into his past and saw City as "big, strong, well organised with good team spirit". This was the stuff of perverse admiration.

Spurs have now gone 303 minutes without a goal, 90 of them against a Second Division side. Yet Graham is the leading critic of standards of defending in English football, unquestionably lower than for many years. So what does this say about Tottenham's attack?

Les Ferdinand, at 33, is scarcely one for the future. Neither, in this mode, seems Steffen Iversen, despite being 10 years younger. The Norwegian has not scored this season and is developing the fatalism in front of goal that afflicted Chris Armstrong. No one knows which way Sergei Rebrov is heading. Judging by his bemused look, the Ukrainian does not know either.

Rebrov operated much of the time behind Ferdinand and Iversen, his quick feet and thought bogged in the midfield morass. He emerged to force two of Nicky Weaver's saves and once netted from a narrow angle, only to be ruled offside.

At least Spurs' fans will be encouraged by Graham's glowing assessment of Rebrov, and the striker's rejection of the arch-enemy. Now Rebrov has reportedly attacked Arsenal, saying: "Tottenham were more professional," adding: "There was interest from Arsenal and we were ready to sign a contract but the approach was second hand."

Graham admitted Rebrov "needs a bit of fortune in front of goal" and played down fears about his adjustment to the English game. "We've got a very talented player," said Graham. "There's more to come from him."

Yet Rebrov's abilities seemed almost as wasted as George Weah's, who came on belatedly to support the lonely, loping Paulo Wanchope. They soon interpassed in the move of the match only for Weah to shoot wide. But Joe Royle was not unhappy; it was clean-sheet mission accomplished. "Call us dour City, call us what you will," he said, grinning.

webTitle: Le Saux gets Ranieri up and drawing

fields.headline: Le Saux gets Ranieri up and drawing
fields.trailText: Le Saux masterclass gets Ranieri up and drawing.
fields.body:
Claudio Ranieri wears the flat, phlegmatic look of someone for whom life no longer holds any surprises. Football coaches tend to get that way after working under the manic Jesus Gil at Atletico Madrid for any length of time.

Coming from 3-1 down to hold Manchester United to 3-3 at Old Trafford is not a bad way for any coach to begin a career in the Premiership but, if Ranieri felt the merest twinge of joy at seeing his new charges respond so eagerly to his arrival at Stamford Bridge, he kept it well hidden.

After all, it was not as if Chelsea had achieved anything out of the ordinary. Before the abject surrender at Old Trafford in April, when a 3-2 defeat virtually ended Gianluca Vialli's chances of a Champions League place, they had not lost there in the Premiership for six seasons.

Manchester United, moreover, had again chosen the last weekend in September to drop two home points in a 3-3 draw; last year it was Southampton who came from behind to share six goals. A week later United were beaten 5-0 by Chelsea at the Bridge.

On Saturday Ranieri contented himself with a few general observations, praising his new team's spirit and the quality of their football. The quality of Chelsea's defending in the first half was something else but for Ranieri that was as easy to fix as changing a wheel.

Not that he was without assistance. At this stage last season another Italian, Massimo Taibi, was dropping clangers in the Manchester United goal. On Saturday, with Fabien Barthez still unfit, a Dutchman, Raimond van der Gouw, unwittingly ushered Chelsea back into the game in stoppage time at the end of the first half when he butterfingered a firm but stoppable header from Tore Andre Flo.

"Certainly the second goal gave us optimism", said Ranieri guardedly, "and the confidence which allowed us to play in the second half as we did." So did the remarkable goal-line clearance by Graeme le Saux, who somehow managed to scoop a shot from Andy Cole over the bar in the 66th minute.

Four minutes later Le Saux outpaced and outwitted David Beckham, covering back diligently on the United right, before driving in the low cross from which Flo completed the scoring after a lay-off by Gianfranco Zola.

Since Le Saux, captaining Chelsea because Dennis Wise had a stomach upset, had also played a strong part in his team's earlier goals his case for an England recall when Kevin Keegan announces the squad on Thursday is now beyond argument.

Le Saux's hard, deep cross from the left, which Flo volleyed back from beyond the far post for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink to chest the ball down and unleash a marvellous shot past Van der Gouw after seven minutes, was the sort of service for which England have been pining. And it was Le Saux's centre which Flo nodded through Van der Gouw's fumbling hands.

Almost as strong a plea for reviving an international career could be made out for Teddy Sheringham, whose excellence since the start of the season is keeping Dwight Yorke out of the Manchester United attack. On Saturday Sheringham helped set up two goals and scored the other himself; if he and Andy Cole really are not on speaking terms, then their partnership says much for the powers of telepathy.

Yorke, on learning he would not be playing on Saturday, was rumoured to have left in a huff before the game but Sir Alex Ferguson said the position had been explained to the player and he understood the situation. Then, presumably, Yorke's huff arrived and he left in it.

Paul Scholes brought the scores level after 12 minutes with a beautifully struck shot after Sheringham had laid the ball back following a corner. Then Sheringham drove United in front, after Frank Leboeuf had failed to intercept a dipping centre from Dennis Irwin, before sending Cole between the Chelsea centre-backs three minutes later. Cole's shot hit the near post and Beckham scored from the rebound.

At this point so drowsy were Chelsea defensively that they appeared to be playing catenappio, but once Ranieri had stiffened the midfield with Mario Melchiot they dominated the second half.

Now, crucially, Chelsea need to reproduce this sort of performance at Sunderland, Charlton, Southampton and other point-to-point meetings. Only then will it be possible to judge the effect of Ranieri's arrival.

For Manchester United the season has become a little choppy. This weekend Jaap Stam will have exploratory surgery on his troublesome Achilles tendon and is expected to be out for another month. With a succession of Champions League matches coming up, starting with tomorrow's game against PSV in Eindhoven, it is a bad time to be missing the Dutch defender's calming presence.

fields.headline: Keegan feels second quake
fields.trailText: West Ham exploit void in Coventry's midfield to gain first win.
fields.body:
Coventry's second earthquake of the day registered 0-3 on the Richter scale, barely enough to shrug the shoulders of home supporters, let alone shake trophies from cabinets. Though Gordon Strachan called it "a disaster", Coventry have gained only a point at home. To lose a third in four games was no surprise.

More important, they have lost Gary McAllister and Robbie Keane. There is no one managing midfield, doing simple things well and making life easy for the rest; and, though Craig Bellamy made some bullocking runs, there is no one up front to make something out of nothing. The Moroccans have been dumbed down; they speak English now.

Strachan, asked about special treatment for Paolo di Canio, who tore them apart in April, said beforehand that "man-marking can pull your system out of shape". There was no man-marking, no system, no shape - and no shock, despite West Ham's position at the foot of the table. As Harry Redknapp said, "it was only a matter of time before we won".

For all that, for half an hour "the best team West Ham have had for 20 years [Redknapp]" contributed to "the direst football I've seen here in 5 years [Strachan]". At least Strachan added that Coventry "played 80% of it".

Two players, two woeful bits of defending, two goals in three minutes sparked the change. The players were Di Canio and Joe Cole, who had more difficulty guessing what Frédéric Kanouté was going to do next than did City's defenders.

Di Canio, mostly wide, seemed to imagine extra licence in the city of "Lady Godiver". But, once his triple somersault with pike had failed to impress the judges, he turned to honest trickery. Then Cole, in the hole, paused to take a challenge on firm feet, darted away, still poised, to chip the advanced Magnus Hedman and drew a fine palming save. West Ham had found the mood and the measure.

The goals followed. Di Canio feinted, slipped in the first and threatened to take his kit off like the Lady before remembering the consequences. More sleight of foot made room for the cross that Cole collected and drove in.

Frank Lampard's third owed most to Nigel Winterburn's midfield tackle. The whole show owes everything to a manager who, like a collector of cars, enjoys beauty of performance as well as vintage curiosity. As if one old banger at left-back is not enough, he buys another, Winterburn, who at 37 is only a year younger than Stuart Pearce. He then makes use of both their whole hearts at once.

In Di Canio he has a classic Spyder, in Cole a lovely little motor - or "a frightening talent. It's all there, the head, the running, the work. But, if he's to be the player we want, he's got to get a dozen goals a year." When European frontiers first opened, Redknapp resembled a shopaholic. Now, when injuries might induce panic buying, he shops for pleasure and relishes his goods, if not always getting the best out of them.

Early on he lost Rio Ferdinand. Rather than bring on the dependable Steve Potts, he moved Steve Lomas, no loss to midfield creativity, brought on Michael Carrick and looked forward in every sense, possibly to life without Ferdinand. Kevin Keegan has already lost Sol Campbell and maybe Tony Adams for next month's World Cup games. Now there is Ferdinand's groin. The tremor was felt all over England.

In Di Canio he has a classic Spyder, in Cole a lovely little motor - or "a frightening talent. It's all there, the head, the running, the work. But, if he's to be the player we want, he's got to get a dozen goals a year." When European frontiers first opened, Redknapp resembled a shopaholic. Now, when injuries might induce panic buying, he shops for pleasure and relishes his goods, if not always getting the best out of them. Early on he lost Rio Ferdinand. Rather than bring on the dependable Steve Potts, he moved Steve Lomas, no loss to midfield creativity, brought on Michael Carrick and looked forward in every sense, possibly to life without Ferdinand. Kevin Keegan has already lost Sol Campbell and maybe Tony Adams for next month's World Cup games. Now there is Ferdinand's groin. The tremor was felt all over England.

fields.headline: Kinky silences mob
fields.trailText: Derby fight back as Leeds suffer another dose of weekend blues.
fields.body:
As a test of endurance the Premiership has got Leeds United huffing and puffing like a marathon runner developing cramp after the first couple of miles. Unless David O'Leary's team can build up a new head of steam they are in danger of hitting the proverbial wall.

In the past three weeks his team have picked up two points from 12 - against Manchester City, Coventry, Ipswich and now Derby, clubs for whom preserving top-flight status is anything but a foregone conclusion.

For Leeds, facing a team who have yet to win this season, this should have been as routine as they come once Ian Harte had scored from a free-kick, the more so after Derby's Horacio Carbonari was dismissed a minute later.

Instead their numerical advantage was scarcely evident for the remainder of a fractious contest in which Georgi Kink ladze, one of three second-half substitutes introduced simultaneously, deservedly levelled the game 15 minutes from time.

O'Leary, as is his wont, made a case for player fatigue and the Irishman has instructed his men to "take a complete rest" before tomorrow's Champions League visit from Besiktas.

"Tiredness is no excuse," countered his defender Danny Mills. "Last season we played on Thursdays in the Uefa Cup and still came back to win on Sundays in the Premiership.

"It's no good saying we were playing in midweek, because Derby were as well. We have to be up for every match, just like Manchester United are."

Not for the first time the thought "If only Ian Harte were English" occurred as his left-foot shot arced over Mart Poom and under the crossbar. And almost directly from the restart Michael Bridges scampered on to Bjorn Otto Bragstad's slack back pass and was brought crashing down by Carbonari's professional foul.

It was the Argentine's second successive sending-off, having incurred the same fate against West Brom in the Worthington Cup four days earlier. If he gets the hat-trick at the Hawthorns tomorrow, one wonders whether he will get to take the referee home.

Leeds were choking for air by the time Harte's superlative effort was countered by a classic Kinkladze goal, who jinked between Olivier Dacourt and Harte before curling a left-foot shot beyond Nigel Martyn.

With the first calls for Jim Smith's head emanating from the most boorish corner of Pride Park, the Georgian's timing was exquisite - even if the Derby manager later did his best to laugh off the criticism.

A disappointing day for Leeds then became a depressing one when O'Leary revealed that Michael Duberry had ruptured an achilles tendon and will be out for the season.

David O'Leary will summon Mark Viduka today to find out why the £6m striker did not report back from the Olympics until Saturday morning. Australia's final game was on Tuesday and Leeds had expected him back within 48 hours.

fields.headline: Halle howler serves Hoddle right
fields.trailText: Saints show first signs of long-term ambition.
fields.body:
It was not pretty, but it was effective. There are real signs now that Glenn Hoddle is succeeding in his quest to transform Southampton from perennial battlers to a side capable of residing comfortably in mid-table obscurity.

It was tempting to regard this match as a relegation six-pointer. From Bradford's point of view, they need to win games like this if they are to stay in the Premiership.

But Hoddle has built an efficient vehicle for his ambitions, based on the reliable chassis of Dean Richards with Marian Pahars adding high-octane excitement. On Saturday, Bradford were left on the starting grid and never caught up.

This victory was built on graft rather than craft. Scoring opportunities arose by chance rather than design, summed up by a decisive own-goal of suitable scrappiness. But Hoddle insisted the win was further evidence of changing attitudes at Southampton.

"We have to believe in ourselves, and churning out results like this will give us that belief," he said. "We have analysed how we play - we were creating a lot of chances but not defending properly. Now the balance of our play has evened itself out a bit better."

Hoddle admitted that Chelsea's defeat here last month influenced his tactics - "When you come to Bradford you can't play silky football for 90 minutes" - and with five Saints in the midfield Bradford's hopes of playing their way to victory were snuffed out.

Nothing went right for the hosts. Gunnar Halle, their Norwegian right-back, scored a comic own-goal at the second attempt. The first effort, with his hand, was stopped on the line by his goalkeeper Matt Clarke. But second time round, under pressure from Hassan Kachloul, he stuck out a foot and this time succeeded in poking the loose ball past Clarke and into the net.

The other big culprit was Benito Carbone, who let two inviting chances go begging - one of them a scuffed left-foot shot so wide of the target that he hung his head in shame.

The Italian has found the net just once this season but Bradford's manager Chris Hutchings refused to be downcast. "On paper, people would have said this was our easiest game so far, but it's how we react to this that's important."
