The residual United News and Media has plenty going for it. The business services division made more than £200m profit last year and powers on into an internet future. Lord Hollick's "consistent focus on a select group of core assets with high growth potential" still sounds single-minded enough. But nobody can quite put the two Expresses or the Daily Star into that high-growth basket. Are they up for sale again, to be traded off like the regional papers of yesteryear? There are rumours, of course, and Hollick bats them away. He sees a synergy between the fruit of the presses and the fruit of the web which shouldn't be relinquished whatever the analysts or the cynics say. Yet even he must occasionally feel that the dream which perished when Granada scooped away his ITV franchises needs replacing: and even he must wonder how Lord Beaverbrook's ancient crusader fits. What would a buyer, if one comes along, get for his money? A peerage, maybe, in the wake of Lords Stevens and Matthews. That seems to go with the Express patch. Two national dailies selling well over 1.5m copies each morning and a Sunday not too far off the million mark. Tolerable profits in the region of £20m. It could be a bargain for £200m or so - until due diligence turns to history. The Daily Express has plenty of history - 100 often glorious years of it. Great cartoonists such as Osbert Lancaster and Giles. Great editors such as Arthur Christiansen. A great showman of a proprietor called Beaverbrook. After the Second World War, it - and its Sunday sister - dominated mid-market journalism, utterly eclipsing rivals such as the Daily Mail. Look at Beaverbrook's legacy when he died in 1964. The Express that August sold 4,342,378, while the Mail - despite swallowing the News Chronicle - was a fading 2,415,957. No contest. Last month the Mail stood at 2,357,778, but the Express was 1,039,738: a brutal reversal of fortunes made bleaker when you take Sundays into account. In 1964 the Sunday Express had a 4,286,727 sale all to itself: there wasn't a competitor. Last month that figure was 969,009 and the Mail on Sunday had 2,239,062. (And Matthews' old baby, the Star, which once almost touched 1.6m, was on 560,000.) There's no more calamitous story in modern Fleet Street history. The mighty have not merely fallen; it has collapsed in a heap of broken careers and crumpled aspirations. What went wrong? What didn't go wrong? Beaverbrook's son, Max, was a shadow of his father and presided over consistent failure until he sold to Trafalgar House in 1977 and the aforementioned Lord Vic, who knew nothing about newspapers. Enter (in 1985) United Newspapers and David Stevens: enter (in 1996) Hollick's MAI. Through those years of chop and change, editors came and went like managers of Chelsea. There have been 12 since Beaverbrook died, talents as various as Alastair Burnet and Larry Lamb. But none of them made much difference. Nor, crucially, were they given the resources to make a difference. The papers were shrinking year by year. The readership was ageing fast; the grim reaper took his sickle to circulation. The Express was a disaster happening before our eyes. And today? Hollick may modestly claim to have done better than his three predecessors. He's shown ambition to rescue the titles and, in particular, to back an editor who will tackle the fundamentals. For a broken brand on the graveyard shift read a brand remade which looks newish Labour rather than right, young rather than old, to the future rather than a decayed past. That was the point of hiring Rosie Boycott, and that is the point of sticking with her. She has made progress over the past couple of years - but whisper it gently, because there is nothing to shout about. Sales have continued to slip (down 2.66 per cent year on year last month). Readership is down as well. Yet there are a few signs of brighter times. The paper fared a little better through early summer - and (buoyed by 82,000 cut-price copies) has marginally recovered again after a dire July. Decline isn't inexorable any longer. The first young shoots of hope may (just about) be glimpsed in the detail of the readership statistics. More A and AB readers than last year. (The AB move from 24 per cent to 29 per cent is particularly heartening.) Advertisers may soon sit up and take notice if this continues. The age profile is also beginning to shift marginally - in the middle-aged reaches between 35 and 54. No euphoria. The Sunday Express won't easily get over 1m copies again. Only 784,000 domestic copies went at full cover price in August. The Star dipped to 490,000 at full price - though it produced some notably feisty performances earlier in the year. But this is, at least, a mixed picture. Ailing newspapers don't suddenly bounce back after decades of neglect. They're like oil tankers turning in some narrow channel, inching their way to the right direction. Editors and their proprietors have to stop the fall, hold their patience and then push for growth. You can't buy momentum; you have to toil for it. Have Hollick and his shareholders the faith for 'this very long haul? In a smaller group, stripped of its ITV franchises, the newspapers are more visible - and the contrast with the £370m United is ploughing into new media seems uncomfortably clearer. That's why selling is always an option on the analysts' list. To sell, however, you need a buyer. The Barclay brothers were sniffing around last year, but their appetite, sated by Scotsman haggis, may be less keen now. Jimmy Gold smith is no longer with us. Mohamed Fayed may prefer promotion with Fulham FC to relegation struggles at Blackfriars. Trinity Mirror is often mentioned (as is Gannett, the American owner of Newsquest) but newspaper professionals will always be looking for synergies which aren't apparent here. The Expresses do not need more cost-cutting; even to begin to dent the Mail they need more investment. Any buyer will need deep pockets - and will need to come to terms with the fact that further slippage could simply render this paper bundle non-viable, too small to matter. Problematically, too, the hole in New Labour's electoral balloon raises a few problems for Rosie's way. "Utterly clueless"... "a student rabble"... trying "to destroy any reputation for competence it might have earned". That doesn't sound like Clive and Tony sweeping onwards and upwards: that sounds like continuing headaches. Still, after Granada, Hollick cannot afford the humiliation of a high-profile failure here. His thesis about the net and print is valid enough, if only he can get the right young readers for the Express. Changing tack would only throw away the work of the past two years. There's no doubt who ought to own the Express hereafter, beavering away. Carry on United. But do, in the light of history and experience, hold your breath.

fields.headline: Back with a bong
fields.standfirst: ITV and its regulators seemed set for a bloody court battle this week over News at Ten. Then ITV director of programmes David Liddiment surprised everyone with a dramatic U-turn.  Matt Wells  reports
fields.trailText: ITV and its regulators seemed set for a bloody court battle this week over News at Ten. Then ITV director of programmes David Liddiment surprised everyone with a dramatic U-turn. Matt Wells reports
fields.body:
Just as Bobby Ewing emerged from the shower in Dallas, Trevor McDonald should slide behind the ITN newsdesk at 10pm in January and everyone can pretend he was never away. Complete with bongs, And Finally and the Big Ben-style clock face in the opening titles, the programme that set the standard for television news around the world will be back. Like Victoria Principal's bad dream, the news nightmare will be over and the ratings will soar. At least, that's the theory.

The author of the idea was ITV director of programmes David Liddiment. His astonishing U-turn averted a damaging court battle with TV regulators, stunned the BBC executives who thought their 10pm news plan was sewn up, and probably even shocked Patricia Hodgson, the unflappable chief executive of the independent television commission, when he proposed the deal.

After more than a year of wrangling, and the judicial review due to start this week, no one expected an ITV climbdown. Just as surprising was the ITC's agreement to allow more peak-time advertising slots, which will easily pay for the promised £42m increase in the ITV programme budget. So what happened?

Simple. "The ITC's chief executive changed," says Liddiment. It is hardly a secret that ITV found Peter Rogers, Hodgson's predecessor, impossible to deal with. Once he had gone, everything was back in play: Hodgson was the BBC's deal-broker when she was the director of policy and planning under John Birt, and knows a win-win compromise when she sees one. This deal allowed the ITC to claim it had secured the return of News at Ten - when only a few months ago it had thrown in the towel and was ready to accept a 10.30pm bulletin - and gave ITV a more flexible schedule on at least two days a week, with a substantial cash sweetener in the shape of the relaxation of advertising restrictions. Set that against the possibility of losing the judicial review, and Liddiment says it was "pragmatic" to take it.

"On balance it's a pretty good deal and it gives us the flexibility we want. It's the right solution," he says, before emphasising: "For now." He adds, as if to convince himself: "I'm pretty happy with it really."

Pretty happy, pretty good: however much he attempts to paint a gloss on this deal, Liddiment is stung by having to concede the principle of rescheduling the news. He admits it is not the outcome he would have wanted in the "ideal world" - he still believes 6.30pm and 11pm are the right times for ITV's news bulletins.

Indeed, it was a risky concession to make. He is already under pressure: ITV's audience share is unlikely to meet even the already-lowered self-set targets this year. Liddiment concedes that some aspects of the schedule introduced after the scrapping of News at Ten have not worked. And now he is being forced to tear up half his weekday schedule and start again.

So has the news concession served only to undermine his own credibility as director of programmes? "I don't feel that at all." His hands twitch - he's irked. "I don't feel insecure in my position. And the people I work for haven't given me any indication that I should." Liddiment is determined to stamp his authority on this deal.

There are still a few loose ends to tie up. For a start, there's the tricky business of what the new programme is going to be called. There was an assumption that it would be simply News at Ten. Or, to fit in with the corporate branding of the network's other programmes, the ITV News at Ten. That's what the viewers, advertisers, ITN journalists (and probably executives) expect. Even Steve Anderson, the controller of news at ITV, is known to favour the revival of the News at Ten brand. But his boss has other ideas.

"It will be called the ITV Nightly News."

Not News at Ten?

"No."

Is that your final answer?

"That's my final answer."

With a bulletin at 10pm only three nights a week, it would make no sense, he argues. "We would have to have different titles for the news on different days and that's even more confusing. We've had the Nightly News for nearly 18 months, by the end of this year for 20 months and I think it's a perfectly good name for the news."

It may be that pride is at stake: changing the title of the programme would be a concession too far. But Liddiment will be put under great pressure within ITV to change his mind. After all, News at Ten was still called News at Ten even when football matches or films pushed it back.

As for the presenter, we are on surer ground. He wants McDonald to do it; so does McDonald. But the nation's favourite newscaster is in Jamaica, and will not make a final decision until he returns home this week. But it's difficult to imagine that the lure of presenting News at Ten once again, not to mention the prospect of an extra day off a week, will not prove irresistible.

For Liddiment, however, these are mere details: his relief is obvious. At last, he can get on with the job of running his channel. And it's more than just a job, it informs his life: there is no one more obsessed about television in general, and ITV in particular, than Liddiment. He has grown up with it, was nurtured by it at Granada, and now he's running it. He makes no excuse for taking his work home with him: "When I'm at home I watch the channel go out, with the ad breaks, the continuity announcements." He takes the network deeply personally: "If I don't keep an eye on it, I feel I'm not in touch with it." He must be a nightmare to live with.

The resolution of the news issue has injected Liddiment with renewed vigour - and as another schedule upheaval looms, there is plenty to worry about. With Richard Eyre, the former chief executive who departed for Pearson last year, Liddiment formed a formidable partnership that shook up the tired commercial network, cleared the decks of outdated shows and revitalised others. There were imaginative new commissions, some surprising successes and, with Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, one of the most inspired scheduling moves of the decade. Audience share went up, younger viewers started turning back to ITV (at least tentatively) and the advertisers were ecstatic.

But then Eyre left, just at the time when Liddiment felt that the job was only half done. While Liddiment, fiercely loyal, would never say it, you sense that he felt abandoned.

The conspicuous failure of ITV to find a replacement for Eyre is a standing joke in the industry. Liddiment is reluctant to be drawn into the debate, but it is clear that he is deeply frustrated at how the network's strategic planning has simply ground to a halt. ITV is being caned in digital homes because it is not on Sky Digital, with no prospect of that changing any time soon. There is no online strategy, and ITV2 is being left to languish when it could be developed as a breeding ground for new network talent.

But Liddiment believes that there will be a resolution soon, probably after the remaining issues around consolidation are sorted out.

So now he has the chance to regain the upper hand. A two-year plan is emerging: "We are looking not just at next year but beyond. Clearly getting the balance right between sustainable returnable shows that provide the foundation for the channel and the surprise of events - not just on single evenings but across weeks - is the trick. We should think differently about how we organise our schedule."

Note the word "events". There will be more of these - Premier League football, big drama, Survivor. And the schedule will be more defined: no more Bob Martin one Sunday and a costume drama the next. It just confuses the viewer. "It's all about ensuring that in certain slots on certain days we deliver a consistent experience. virtually year-round. So if you enjoyed watching Cold Feet on a Sunday night, if we then follow that with Oliver Twist in the same slot, are we missing an opportunity? Would it be better to follow a series of Cold Feet with a series of Metropolis, or Bob Martin, or whatever?"

His task at ITV is to satisfy what he terms the "coalition of interests" who come together for the big viewing experiences such as Coronation Street or Millionaire, but who split away into diverse groups that have to be satisfied elsewhere in the schedule.

Liddiment says Britain's biggest commercial network is not going to risk its dominant position on whims: ITV is not about cutting-edge television. "We will take the risks that we think are appropriate to include large numbers of people in the viewing experience. That requires us to innovate, but the notion that somehow ITV is about cutting-edge television is a misunderstanding of what we are about. Was Millionaire cutting-edge TV? No, it wasn't. It was bloody good popular TV. I'll settle for that any day."

That means not alienating the ITV viewer with something for which they are totally unprepared. Lily Savage's weekly live show, for instance, has bombed on Saturday nights. But instead of axeing it, Liddiment has decided it will return in a post-news, 10.20pm weeknight slot next year, where its natural audience might expect to see it.

Yet he insists that keeping an eye on the ratings does not mean he wants to water down ITV's public service commitments. "I like them, because they are a challenge. I'm really proud of Tonight with Trevor McDonald. It has become Britain's most-watched current affairs programme, and that's no mean achievement." Tonight's run has been extended to almost every week of the year. With self-confident mischief, he gleefully clambers up to the moral high ground to taunt the BBC's decision to cut the number of Panorama editions: "That means more episodes - more, not fewer."

So, as McDonald flies back to Britain to decide whether he will see out the two or three years to his retirement in style at News at Ten, Liddiment will no longer be woken in the middle of the night by the ITN bongs, or whatever demons have kept him awake over the past year. "I breathed a sigh of relief last night, and got a great night's sleep because this issue has been finally put to bed."

fields.headline: My new media: Chris Cramer
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Chris Cramer's internet loves and hates
fields.body:
Favourite sites?
I have to say CNN.com, of course. My absolute favourite is journalism.net, which is Julian Sher's site. Because I live in Atlanta, it takes me straight into the UK and European newspapers. Not that I would like the public to know, but I have bookmarked bbc.co.uk as well. I have my appalling share portfolio on there - on the Bloomberg site. I use the internet for work only.

Last online purchase?
Amazon.com. I bought a history book. It was a History of the US. I don't remember who wrote it.

Most recent technological faux pas?
I was trying to send an SMS text message on my mobile to my daughter in boarding school. But I forgot to press the send button.

Main news sources on web?
As well as those above, TVnewsweb.com, a site for industry gossip and news. Since its launch last Thursday, I go to the CNNeurope site. I use something called a Blackberry - a personal digital system, rather like a pager. But the beauty is that it has all my contacts on it, all my calendar details and it receives and transmits email. It has revolutionised my life, but they don't work outside the US. Filofax eat your heart out.

Most persistent spam emailer?
I get very little spam. I try to filter spams out, so I can't think of one. There are one or two persistent emailers I instantly delete - normally selling financial services.

Time spent on web?
10 hours a day, but not continuous - emails, browsing and communicating.

Next boo.com/clickmango?
Nothing I have shares in, I hope.

Least useful site/s on web?
Generically, the least useful sites for me are the ones that involve major scrolling down. I have a very short attention span and need instant gratification. Some European English-language newspapers are particularly tiresome.

Least user-friendly site?
One or two UK newspaper sites are particularly irritating. They'll have to work out who they are for themselves. They are hard to navigate.

What screensaver do you use?
Two frogs on a lily pad in a pond, catching flies. I use a personalised one, with audio, like a frog noise.

Most irritating thing about the web?
It's capable of taking over your life, if you're not careful.

Do you bother with old media?
I'm an avid reader of real newspapers and magazines, ones that leave print on your fingers. I'm also a sucker for old movies on TV.

 Chris Cramer is president of International Networks, CNN

webTitle: Will you pay? That's the real question

fields.headline: Will you pay? That's the real question
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: "Expert exchange" websites are the latest hot business models heading our way.
fields.body:
A penny for your thoughts. Or, depending on your pricing structure, 5p or £5, chargeable per minute and billable to other people's credit cards or phone bills. You're an expert, you see, and all that separates you from customers willing to pay for your specialist knowledge - on finding a reliable builder, perhaps, or overcoming baldness - is a website which allows them to find you.

Wait no longer: "expert exchange" websites are the latest hot business models heading our way. Drawing on the internet's extraordinary ability to link individuals to their peers, these "peer-to-peer" sites do for specialist knowledge what Napster does for music and eBay for car-boot junk. By restoring human guidance to the tricky business of researching information online, they have built strong traffic by finding individuals who can answer other people's questions. Yet there is one question that, even at a premium, these sites cannot yet answer with confidence: will enough people be willing to pay for web-delivered content to make a viable long-term business?

There is no shortage of sites trying to find out. AskMe.com promises "great answers from real people" in categories ranging from pets to the paranormal (currently recruiting experts in the Olympics, MP3 and Rosh Hashanah). Exp.com offers "real experts; real help" on subjects including US immigration law (advice at $1.10 a minute) and marathon running.

Search engines think there's money to be made here: Ask Jeeves was among those which put $33m into Exp.com in a recent funding round. Yahoo has also entered the market, with experts.yahoo.com, featuring such specialists as "Roumster", a 25-year-old woman keen to talk about dating problems. The New York Times has its own "knowledge network", Abuzz (top questions: what really happened to that Russian sub and whether geraniums work as house plants). KnowPost.com promises "meta-knowledge" on the Wizard of Oz and web-browsing technology.

Many of these sites rely on advertising as their business model, others customise their services for corporate customers. But it is the convergence of web and telephony that is currently exciting investors. Two phone-enabled expert exchanges are coming to London, betting on our willingness to pay by the minute to talk to specialists.

Keen.com, a San Francisco-based start-up that claims to be "the live answer community", has joined with Benchmark Capital in a $15m investment to form Keen Europe. Users will browse its subject listing, choose an expert, and then click on a "call now" button - and the site connects both parties by phone, taking a 30% commission on the call fee. Ten months after launch, parent site Keen.com claims 500,000 members, with 1.4m unique monthly visitors.

Up against Keen is Questico.com, a DM14m (£4m) German start-up founded in April that is soon to launch in the UK. The company claims to combine "the Internet's advantage of speedy information retrieval with the opportunity to instantly take part in a one-on-one dialogue over the telephone, putting an end to the long and difficult search process one often encounters". As with most of these sites, users rate the experts once they've bought the advice to ensure some measure of quality control.

These sites also benefit from the willingness of users to spend money on the telephone: premium-rate calls, after all, have been among the main money makers for companies such as the 365 Corporation, and relatively high per-minute call charges have not dented the growth of the mobile-phone sector. What is really exciting the investors is the mobile's promise to become the major means of accessing the internet in a year or two.

Keen.com's chief executive, Karl Jacob, has a vision for these information exchanges. "What eBay did for people selling what's in their garages and attics, Keen.com will do for people who want to sell what's in their heads," he says. The idea is attractive but what will determine the future of these sites is our willingness in enough numbers to abandon that tenet of web use: the public does not like paying for content.

"Every single site in the world that has tried to charge for content has rejected it - except the Wall Street Journal," notes James Ledbetter, newly arrived in London from New York as editor of the Industry Standard Europe. "The brilliance of Napster is it's free. To introduce that [peer-to-peer exchange] on a paid model is admirable, risky, but I suspect for a lot of people doing it, not ultimately successful."

I'm not so sure: for very specific information that can be delivered digitally or by phone - tips on a business plan, for instance, or professional advice on a medical problem - customers will be willing to pay a premium. And if you're still not convinced, for £1 a minute I'd be happy to tell you why.

 David Rowan is editor of Guardian Unlimited
david.rowan@theguardian.com

webTitle: Victoria Real builds UK Play website

fields.headline: Victoria Real builds UK Play website
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Victoria Real has been appointed to develop a new website for UK Play, the music and comedy channel from UKTV.
fields.body:
Victoria Real has been appointed to develop a new website for UK Play, the music and comedy channel from UKTV.

A holding page has been developed at ukplay.co.uk but the full site will not launch until early November.

The site, aimed at 16 to 34-year-olds, will build on UK Play's irreverent on-screen look and encourage visitors to post their own content, such as pictures, animation and MP3 files.

Other features will include an area for off-beat games such as Take George Best Down the Pub and Clay Boy Band Shooting. These will sit alongside traditional programme website features such as chat rooms, information about programmes and programme listings.

"At UKTV we see this launch as part of a much bigger commitment to new media and look forward to rolling out more websites and digital text services in the near future," said Neil Morris, recently appointed head of new media at UKTV

fields.headline: Give it your best shot
fields.standfirst:
Threatened by mergers and corporate buyouts, photographers are creating their own picture agencies online. Andrew Wasley reports
Net news
fields.trailText: Threatened by mergers and corporate buyouts, photographers are creating their own picture agencies online. Andrew Wasley reports
fields.body:
News photographers and photojournalists are increasingly turning to the web in a bid to secure their independence amid growing uncertainty sparked by a wave of controversial takeovers by the picture industry's largest agencies. Concerned by what they see as the beginning of an unprecedented corporate buyout, and taking advantage of the proliferation of cheap, readily available digital technology, an increasing number of photographers are turning freelance to create their own independent online picture agencies.

Last year's acquisition of the respected Paris-based Sygma agency by Bill Gates' giant Corbis operation kicked off a scramble among major players to scoop up smaller agencies and led to a degree of dispute between photojournalists and executives seldom seen in the world of news photography.

"What we've been seeing is a calculated drive to buy up the picture market," says Neil Burgess, picture editor of Network, one of the UK's few remaining independent outfits. "The big agencies - Corbis, Getty, Hachette - are each attempting to corner the market and diversify their own collections with the photographs from the smaller, specialist libraries. This way, eventually, they'll be able to undercut on price and offer images of just about anything, all from one place."

Several well-known Sygma photographers - including Allan Tannenbaum and Andrew Lichtenstein - recently quit over what they describe as unacceptable market domination, poor contracts and representation: "When Corbis took over [Sygma] there was a feeling they would attempt to restore it to its former glory," says Tannenbaum, staff photographer with the agency for almost 20 years. "Instead they went on a search and destroy mission."

He argues that far from using its size and influence to negotiate universally higher editorial rates, Corbis may have attempted to drive industry prices down in order to acquire greater market share; and in doing so it adversely affected the interests of photographers and squeezed out smaller, independent agencies. The situation was compounded earlier this month when Hachette Filipacchi Medias of France announced it was to buy the international Katz agency, "to ward off alternative approaches from US market leaders."

The defectors from Corbis claim that the big agencies' primary aim is to sell the greatest number of single photos to the greatest number of buyers in the shortest time scale, something not in keeping with the photojournalists' tradition of perfecting picture stories over a longer period of time.

"The photographers and - more importantly - the photographs, are becoming irrelevant. It's about profit and market share," one photojournalist "just hanging on" with Corbis-Sygma says. "This is why photographers are taking the risk, getting wired and going it alone."

"The industry is in a state of flux," says Linda Royles, executive officer of the British Association of Picture Libraries and Agencies (BAPLA). "This is partly attributable to the recent mergers and acquisitions, but also due to the wider effects of digitisation. Many of the UK's [estimated 900] existing picture agencies are having to rethink their approach in light of the new technology, as are those setting up new agencies."

Recent BAPLA figures illustrate the perceived importance of the web among those operating picture agencies: 70% have an online presence, 30% with fully searchable databases.

"The number of picture agencies launched is increasing, one recent month spawning 14 new outfits," says Royles. "Many are single photographers looking to market their work so they're planning extensive, or at least partial, web presence." The photographers' bids for autonomy have been made possible by high street access to increasingly inexpensive technology.

"For as little as the cost of a decent computer, digital camera, scanner and - if you're prepared to do everything yourself - a server and basic software for a searchable database, you can be up and running as a small independent outfit," maintains Andrew Wiard, founder of his own reportphotos.com agency. "If you've got money to spend, however, there's effectively no upper limit."

While many freelance photographers use established internet service providers or web companies - Imagenet, for example - specifically geared towards the needs of online picture libraries, others are more creative. Photojournalist Howard Davies launched his own specialist online picture agency, exileimages.co.uk, in July, exploiting little more than a trusty computer and a colleague's web design skills to make available more than 15,000 images.

"I had to commission a database which is unique to the agency, but sales have already covered the [web] design and maintenance costs," he says. "It was a case of utilising this newly available technology to undertake an idea that I'd had for years."

Davies says the prime motivation for going it alone is control and being able to deal direct with clients. "I'd become a bit disillusioned with sales from the big agencies, so pulled some stock images out. Now I take 100% rather than negotiate for 50% or 70%."

Despite the online project he still maintains distribution deals with a couple of big agencies. "I've not had too rough a deal - they do pay," he says but admits fears brought about by the recent string of acquisitions are becoming increasingly visible: "A young photojournalist approached me to undertake work; when I asked why he'd chosen such a small, specialist agency, he said it would be better not to have to negotiate with the bigger, more traditional outlets - ten years ago that would have been unheard of."

Such views are echoed by Gary Trotter, founder of Images Sans Frontieres (ISF) - the UK's first reportage agency to launch entirely via the web: "I've built up a network of about 30 freelances who don't wish to work for major players where the struggle to retain intellectual [property] rights and control becomes harder than obtaining decent shots."

Despite the apparent success of ISF and Exile, staff at the (decreasing) number of established agencies are sceptical about the long-term viability of freelance projects: "There's not enough agencies willing to take on photojournalists anyway so it's logical they try to go it alone," says Network's Burgess. "Unfortunately, without a glowing track record, they're likely to disappear - retain their editorial independence certainly, but run the risk of being forced off the market."

One way round the problem, according to Andrew Wiard, is to identify a unique niche and specialise. "If you can build up a reputation for covering a particular area - Scotland, for example - then people will come to know you for that and visit your web library before trying other 'one-stop shops'." Another answer, he says, is more fundamental. "It's easy to forget that even with the best technology in the world for presentation and delivery, you have to deliver quality products. You still have to be able to take a decent shot."

fields.headline: Big Brother website ranks eighth most popular
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The official Big Brother website's unprecedented growth in July was even more impressive in August.
fields.body:
The official Big Brother website's unprecedented growth in July was even more impressive in August, according to the latest batch of home usage figures from internet reach specialist MMXI Europe.

In August, BigBrother.terra.com was the eighth most popular website in the UK, reaching more than 17.8% (1.9m unique visitors) of the home internet population. The site entered the rankings in July at number 26.

The impact on Channel 4's website was noticeable, with more than 1.3m unique visitors hitting Channel4.com, lifting the site up to number 16 in the chart.

The rest of the top 10 for August showed little change, with MSN, Yahoo! and Freeserve leading the way in first, second and third place respectively.

In the latest sector rankings from MMXI Europe, Barclays.co.uk ousted Egg.com from the number one spot in the business and finance category. Barclays.co.uk has moved from third place to pole position, increasing the number of unique visitors from 460,000 in July to 641,000 in August - an overall reach of 5.9% of home users.

Another Barclays brand, Barclaycard.co.uk, this month also experienced significant growth, moving from tenth place in July to fifth in August, with 300,000 unique visitors.

Lloydstsb.com is now the second most popular UK site among home users, with 583,000 unique visitors - a 5.4% reach - in August.

Other movers in the business and finance category include Directline.com, which makes its top 10 debut, and Egg.com, which is level pegging with Lloydstsb.com in terms of home reach.

A new entry to the category in August was Rapidinsure.co.uk, which achieved 142,000 unique visitors and is ranked 15th.

In all, more than 3.4m UK internet users are banking, insuring and investing online on a regular basis, making it the eighth most popular category overall.

webTitle: True North buys out The Opus Group

fields.headline: True North buys out The Opus Group
fields.trailText: US ad giant True North Communications has bought IT marketing consultancy The Opus Group, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
US ad giant True North Communications has bought UK IT marketing consultancy The Opus Group to add to its FCB network.

True North will integrate The Opus Group into its FCBi brand.

"This is a first-rate company and it will significantly add extra talent to the FCBi brand in London," said John Banks, FCB group chairman.

Opus will retain its own brand identity.

"The acquisition by True North gives The Opus Group the opportunity to offer truly global marketing services to the IT industry and provides us with the resources to take the group into its next growth phase," said Tim Beadle, Opus Group senior director.

The Opus Group comprises the previously separate businesses of PCMC direct marketing, Motive Public Relations, Revelation Research and Accord Relationship Marketing which merged to form The Opus Group in June 1997.

The group employs 52 staff, turns over £4.5m and has a range of blue-chip IT clients including 3Com, Gartner Group, Motorola and Citrix.

fields.headline: Beware the feeling PM
fields.trailText: The hottest ticket in town at this week's Labour party conference will be to see Cherie Booth chairing tonight's fringe meeting entitled "Has New Labour delivered for women?". We're developing a fascination with Ms Booth, the supermum par excellence, and the fact that she has agreed to chair such a meeting is a spectacular shot across her husband's bows.
fields.body:
The hottest ticket in town at this week's Labour party conference will be to see Cherie Booth chairing tonight's fringe meeting entitled "Has New Labour delivered for women?". We're developing a fascination with Ms Booth, the supermum par excellence, and the fact that she has agreed to chair such a meeting is a spectacular shot across her husband's bows. With the departures of Betty and Mo, Ms Booth is fast becoming the most prominent woman in British political life. And there are a lot of people around who do not like it.

The right wing disapproves of her advocacy of the human rights agenda on the grounds that she stands to reap a handsome income from it. Now the hostility is spilling out on to the left. The cover of the New Statesman's conference issue makes the ambivalence plain: a photomontage of a 50s-style tupperware party has Cherie peeling apples along with Hillary Clinton and Madonna. Placing these powerful, ground-breaking women in the archetypal domestic set-up cuts them down to size. (It is also entirely gratuitous given that the article it illustrates has nothing to do with Cherie.)

Hillary has been through this. Women on the political scene attract a disproportionate amount of attention. They can establish a much stronger emotional rapport with the electorate than men - for good or for ill. It's a precarious position, because women can become lightning conductors for the electorate's emotional response to a political party. And deep reserves of sexism are always there to be galvanised: suspicion of clever women and fear of the power-behind-the-throne syndrome. Look how both Laura Bush and Tipper Gore have been reassuring the US electorate that they are not interested in politics.

Cherie's position is all the more difficult now because a significant proportion of the population has developed a visceral dislike of her husband. She could quickly find herself becoming additional ammunition. The extent and depth of Tony's unpopularity has taken the political class - commentators and politicians alike - by surprise. The collapse of his opinion poll lead indicates a volatility in politics which seems to be new, and no one is sure what has caused it or how significant it is.

The British have never liked left-of-centre leaders; it is rightwing figures such as Thatcher or Churchill on whom we lavish loyal devotion. Despite the political achievements of Labour - the welfare state, the NHS - we ungratefully bundle them out of office at the first opportunity. Partly this is because in class-ridden Britain one of the greatest points of tension has been between middle-class intellectuals/professionals and the aspirant working-class. Disraeli was the first Tory to turn that to the advantage of Conservative politicians more than a century ago.

It is one of the curious features of the British class system that those most committed to meritocracy are often the worst snobs. New Labour is falling into this trap. It is perceived as patrician and its populism appears patronising: the Dome is emblematic. It is seen as being dominated by ambitious, London, middle-class, university-educated professionals. A revolt is brewing against a metropolitan elite - spanning politics, the media, the economy - which is running the country. Such a person is not "one of us" is the view from outside the south-east. Hence the complaints about "not listening" when, a couple of months ago, the charge was that Blair listened to focus groups too much. New Labour's attempts in recent months to correct that trend centred around the need to tell a narrative. But no one wanted to be told a story: it only exacerbated the perception of being patronised - or indeed, lied to.

But the new political volatility goes beyond these trends. It can only be explained by a kind of electoral psychology. Emotion has always been a hugely powerful force in politics and has traditionally been much underestimated on the left, with its essentially rationalist world view. But emotion is now centre stage in a therapeutic culture. Politicians are judged less on the quality of their policies, more on personality issues such as trust and credibility. They have happily played along, offering an ersatz intimacy with the electorate. So we get to hear of Blair turning for comfort to Longfellow in the early hours after his son was found drunk. Our political behaviour - voting, protesting, expressing opinions on call-in programmes - is driven by feelings towards a leader. The issue is not what is good for the country, but whether we find this prime minister irritating or likeable. Blair may have pulled off some remarkable political achievements - billions more for health and education, stable economic growth - but to the surprise of political advisers, that is not earning loyalty, let alone affection.

The idea of a relationship with a political figure is palpably absurd. It requires constant media manipulation to maintain the fiction. And it is a dangerous kind of politics, Professor Andrew Samuels argues in a book to be published early next year, Politics On the Couch, because one of the commonest patterns in human relationships is the flip from idealisation to denigration. What we build up, we pull down. Blair's popularity could plunge to the depths in proportion to the heights it once scaled. On such a political rollercoaster, the only long term prognosis is bitter disillusionment and cynicism.

Blair must in part blame himself for this. He modelled his style of leadership on Margaret Thatcher: heroic purposefulness and dramatic ambition. Both aimed to shift the mindset of a whole nation. (Whereas Thatcher wanted us to stiffen our backbone and stand proud again, Blair wanted to rejuvenate us, turn us into a young country.) They both desired idealisation: it lasted Thatcher three election victories, Blair will be lucky to get more than one. But as Bertolt Brecht has one of his characters comment: "Unhappy is the country which needs a hero."

The alternative, Samuels argues, is the "good enough leader" in which leadership is "the study and practice of failure". The politician is modest and realistic about what he/she can achieve.There is a truth here that we all understand but no one admits: politicians want to appear omnipotent and we want to berate them for not being so. What about Walter Bagehot's political ideal of "animated moderation" instead, asks Samuels. Interestingly, Samuels first mentioned these ideas at a fringe meeting at Labour's 1996 conference. New Labour wasn't interested, and went for the heroics. Now the failures of Blair and Brown are viewed not as the inevitable inadequacies of being human and subject to the limited nature of any government's power, but as a betrayal of the fantasy of omnipotence and perfection which we were promised. Such disillusionment can turn vicious, hence the uses to which Cherie could be put as emblematic of this metropolitan elite. Blair had better go for humble this week.

webTitle: John Menzies' CEO slates WH Smith distribution plan

fields.headline: John Menzies chief slates WH Smith distribution plan
fields.trailText: Amid growing criticism of WH Smith's distribution plans, John Menzies' CEO has warned that the newsagent will make an enemy of the press. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
The chief executive of John Menzies has attacked WH Smith's plans to push magazine publishers and distributors into a national distribution network.

In the latest attack on WH Smith, which has come under fire from the Periodical Publishers' Association and publishers, chief executive David Mackay warned that the newsagent risked making an enemy of the press.

"If you cock a snook at the power of the pen," said Mackay, "the pen is going to come back at you."

He argued that if WH Smith, along with Tesco, persisted in its plan to force the UK's patchwork of regional distributors onto a national network, thousands of pounds-worth of business would be lost. The retailers' plans have been criticised by the Periodical Publishers' Association (PPA) and its newspaper counterpart, the Newspaper Publishers' Association (NPA), which have argued that national distribution would force many small, independent newsagents to close.

"A one-size-fits-all solution simply doesn't work," Mackay told MediaGuardian, adding that if small newsagents were forced to close, many specialist titles would suffer.

The PPA last week unveiled a plan designed to resolve the current impasse. The system, which has been agreed "in principle" by PPA members and Tesco, would retain regionally-based distribution but would create a central unit for better stock, inventory and accounts management.

webTitle: AOL/Time Warner merger in anti-competition challenge

fields.headline: AOL/Time Warner tie-up faces anti-competition scrutiny
fields.standfirst:
Competition commissions on both sides of the Atlantic are sceptical about the implications of the recent AOL and Time Warner merger.
AOL and Time Warner submit concessions
fields.trailText: Competition commissions on both sides of the Atlantic are sceptical about the implications of the recent AOL and Time Warner merger. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
When the £125bn merger between US media giants AOL and Time Warner was announced in January, it was obvious that it faced a long walk through the regulatory minefield.

The two companies have been under intense scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic, from the Federal Communication Commission in Washington and the European Commission in Brussels, and it's easy to see why.

AOL is the dominant internet service provider in the US and co-owns AOL Europe with German media giant Bertelsmann. Time Warner controls cable access to about 20% of all US homes and has plenty of media content thanks to its CNN, Warner Brothers and Warner Music subsidiaries.

The EC told the companies last month that the merger "would create a dominant position in the markets for online music delivery, music software, internet dial-up access, broadband internet access and integrated broadband content" that would "significantly impede" competition.

The picture is further complicated by the proposed £14bn merger between UK music group EMI and Time Warner subsidiary Warner Music. Some analysts call this the "first cousin" of the AOL deal, as it will provide even more content for Warner cables and AOL portals, but it has made the tough-talking competition commission even more sceptical.

AOL and Time Warner have worked hard to please EC competition commissioner Mario Tinto. They submitted four concessions ahead of yesterday's deadline for handing in compromises to ease competition fears, which were reported to include Bertelsmann's withdrawal from AOL Europe. Bertelsmann owns BMG music, and the commission does not want any collusion between the company and a newly-formed EMI Warner. The same caution is being applied to AOL France, which is part-owned by French media company Vivendi. Vivendi is currently attempting to merge with Seagram, the owner of Universal Music.

The other compromises are said to include a Time Warner pledge that it will make its music content available on other internet systems. EMI and Warner will also make their music compatible with three other software music players not owned by themselves or AOL, for at least five years. Finally, AOL has guaranteed that for three years it will not force content providers who link up with AOL in the US to make a commitment to AOL Europe.

The concessions are wide-ranging, and EMI and Warner Music have also offered to spin off labels and publishing rights, but they don't address the sheer scale, and main point, of the merger. AOL Time Warner would be a vertically integrated media giant, with powerful interests in content, the internet and cable. The possible dominance of the internet music download market is a key concern for the EC, but it is not the only issue.

It is likely that Time Warner will have no qualms about dropping EMI if it becomes too big a barrier to completing the bigger and more lucrative deal. The EC will then have its hands full running the rule over the many potential buyers of EMI, which would include Telefonica of Spain and Bertelsmann. The Competition Commission will give its verdict on the Vivendi and Seagram deal at the beginning of October, although the merger is likely to have an easier time of things than the AOL Time Warner link-up.

The deadline for the EC ruling on the AOL and Time Warner merger is October 24, and October 18 for EMI and Warner Music. The US Federal Communications Commission will decide on the fate of AOL and Time Warner within the next 30 days.

webTitle: Fuji Film draws up agency shortlist

fields.headline: Fuji develops shortlist to pitch for film range
fields.trailText: Fuji Film is reviewing its above-the-line business for the Fuji Colour Film range, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Fuji Film is reviewing its above-the-line business for the Fuji Colour Film range.

Roger Moore, strategic business unit manager for Fuji's consumer division, confirmed that the company was in the process of shortlisting four UK agencies to pitch for the account.

The business, which is currently handled by Impiric, part of the Young & Rubicam network, is worth £3.5m in the UK. However, Mr Moore said it was possible that the appointment would develop into a pan-European task.

fields.headline: Defiant Prescott rallies party faithful
fields.trailText: A buoyed-up deputy prime minister enjoyed a standing ovation today as he kicked off Labour's annual conference proper, insisting Labour "does listen and does act".
fields.body:
A buoyed-up deputy prime minister enjoyed a standing ovation today as he kicked off Labour's annual conference proper, insisting Labour "does listen and does act".

John Prescott rounded on recent critics who had claimed the government was aloof and had not listened, particularly over the petrol crisis.

As expected, he again stressed the government's determination not to give in to the protesters, who had called for a drop in fuel duty within three months. "Yes we do listen and yes we do act," he told delegates. "But I want to make it absolutely clear - no government, no prime minister, no chancellor can simply chop and change taxes by the month or renegotiate them at the refinery gate at the threat of 60 days' notice."

There were the usual sideswipes: at Tory snobbery ("no wonder they are so interested in the countryside - they own half of it"); at Conservative environmental policies ("under the Tories we were known as the dirty man of Europe"); and at the pro-hunting lobby ("every time I see the Countryside Alliance and their contorted faces, I vow to redouble my efforts to abolish foxhunting").

But Mr Prescott also threw in the surprise announcement that all pensioners would be entitled to a free bus-pass, scrapping some local authorities' practice of charging up to £40 per pass. He said the scheme would, for the first time, be extended to the disabled too. "That's social justice," he said.

Mr Prescott used much of his speech in the Brighton conference arena to list Labour's achievements in the environment, transport and the regions, for which he has responsibility. He said the party's supporters should be proud of what had been achieved because it was "delivery, delivery, delivery".

He said that at the Kyoto summit Britain had led the way on curbing pollution levels. The government's 10-year plan for transport represented the biggest long-term investment in road and rail that the country had ever seen, Mr Prescott said. And water and air quality had drastically improved, local government was now enjoying greater powers and the country's town, cities and villages were now better places to live.

He ridiculed Margaret Thatcher's statements that there was "no such thing as society" and that the key point about the Good Samaritan was that he had money in his pocket. "We believe there's such a thing as society and we do not walk on the other side of the road."

In typical combative spirit, he accused Tories of wanting to drive a wedge between town and country. "We want a living, working countryside," he said.

Turning to Labour's hopes in the coming election fray, he said the party's policy commission had put forward an exciting programme of work. "Now we need to get out campaigning to win that second term, to put those ideas into practice."

With the prime minister sitting alongside, Mr Prescott praised both Mr Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for providing the circumstances for a major improvement in public services. "Too often in the past, politicians have dodged long-term responsibility for the sake of short-term expediency.

"I've always been a bit of a conviction politician," he said. "I will always do what I believe is right. Sometimes I get attacked for it. So be it - because when I decide policies I decide them not for tomorrow's headlines but for tomorrow's children."

On public transport, he said he had "wasted no time" in calling for the "long overdue" public inquiry into the Thames Marchioness disaster. And following the Paddington and Southall rail tragedies, he insisted that the best train safety system would be installed, despite claims the government was planning to "do it on the cheap".

fields.headline: Brighton
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Tony Blair's kingdom by the sea
fields.trailText: 1. That George IV has a lot to answer for. If he and John Nash had only stayed at home, there would be no Royal Pavilion, and Brighthelmstone could have stayed a decent little fishing village. But their insistence on seaside pleasure means that we are saddled with Brighton.
fields.body:
1. That George IV has a lot to answer for. If he and John Nash had only stayed at home, there would be no Royal Pavilion, and Brighthelmstone could have stayed a decent little fishing village. But their insistence on seaside pleasure means that we are saddled with Brighton.

2. Even Brighton has to have a better reason than history to exist. These days it justifies itself by hosting, and making pots of money from, seaside conferences. This week, as you may have heard, it is the turn of the Labour party.

3. You can unravel the intricate nuances of the New Labour debates very easily on the best conference website.

4. Loyalists may prefer the party's official site, but they will have to hang around a bit for updates.

5. Delegates queuing to enter the fortress-like security perimeter around the conference hall can catch up on Mr Tony's exclusive column in the splendid Brighton Evening Argus.

6. Anyone playing hookey will find lots of diversions elsewhere. Like the aforementioned Royal Pavilion, which is gorgeously decadent and voluptuously curved.

7. Talking of which, Julie Burchill lives in Brighton. As does - what's the collective term for celebs? - a standing ovation of other famous folk.

8. Apart from the usual slew of restaurants and boutiques catering for those with a money/sense imbalance, Brighton offers more quirky delights. Like Volk's electric railway.

9. Best of all, there is the wonderful West Pier, at last undergoing an expensive and thoroughly worthwhile face-lift. And there are always the slightly more earthy attractions of the Palace Pier.

10. For fans of the truly esoteric, there is Brighton and Hove Albion. Amazingly, they're doing rather well at the moment.

fields.headline: Lastminute.com signs contract with American Express
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com has teamed up with American Express to offer exclusive deals and offers to Amex cardholders, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com has signed a contract with American Express to offer exclusive late deals and offers to Amex cardholders.

The offers, ranging from extreme experiences such as learning to race a powerboat or taking a Tiger Moth flight, to booking holidays or concert tickets, are listed on a special American Express-lastminute.com co-branded website. American Express Green Charge Card holders can access the deals though Americanexpress.co.uk/green.

"This arrangement will enable us to offer some great and exclusive offers to American Express's high-spending, internet-savvy card members," said Martha Lane Fox, chief operating officer at lastminute.com.

Lastminute.com has been very aggressive on the deal front of late. Last week it announced a deal with Holiday Autos to provide a car rental service to its users, just two days after it said it had launched a catwalk fashion guide in partnership with inshop.co.uk. Despite the number of deals, investors were not entirely convinced and Lastminute.com's shares dropped 16.5p to 134.5p by the end of last week.

According to research by MMXI Europe, Lastminute.com is losing customers, dropping 22,000 unique users (to 711,000) between July and August.

fields.headline: ITV on song with Stars in their Eyes
fields.trailText: Cilla Black's Moment of Truth may have died against the BBC's talent show Star for a Night, but ITV hit back this week with its big gun in the Saturday night showbiz war.
fields.body:
Cilla Black's Moment of Truth may have died against the BBC's talent show Star for a Night, but ITV hit back this week with its big gun in the Saturday night showbiz war.

ITV's karaoke stalwart, Stars in their Eyes, returned for its autumn run at the weekend and helped the commercial broadcaster to its highest weekly share for nearly four months.

At 6.9m viewers and a 40% audience share, the 12th series of Stars in their Eyes at 6.55pm easily beat off BBC1's similarly themed amateur talent-fest hosted by ex docu-soap star Jane McDonald (4.5m, 26%). ITV had 37.8% of all viewing in the seven days to Sunday (September 24).

Later on Saturday night, the return of Charlie to Casualty drew a healthy 8.4m (40%) from 8.05pm, against Family Misfortunes (7.2m, 36%) and Family Fortunes (6.1m, 29%) on ITV.

At 9.30pm, ITV's Lily Live limped off with 4.6m, a 23% share. It is scheduled for one more Saturday outing before retiring gracefully, due to return next year in a post-late news weekday slot. It was up against BBC1 repeat This Is Your Life Presents the Night of 1,000 Lives ((6.8m, 33%) and News and Sport (6.1m, 34%).

Over on Channel 4, the UK terrestrial premier of Matt Groening's Futurama drew 1.4m (7%) from 9.35pm, as part of the broadcaster's Animation Night. The Channel 4 themed evenings' best performer came at 10.05pm, with celebrities cogitating about their favourite cartoons in Our Toon (1.4m, 8%).

On Sunday night, BBC1 scheduled an extra instalment of EastEnders (8.9m, 35%) at 8pm as part of its weeklong push to introduce the bold and brassy Slater family to the square. But the Slaters were no match for ITV's 60-minute Who Wants to be a Millionaire? (13.5m, 51%), back to exocet missile strength and also from 8pm.

From 9pm on ITV, Martin Clunes's two-part drama, Dirty Tricks (8.7m, 39%), benefited from Millionaire's inheritance, beating BBC1 dramas Down to Earth (7.1m, 28%) and Other People's Children (5.2m, 23%).

BBC1's lavish coverage of the 2000 Olympics from Sydney finally began to pay serious ratings dividends as the medals rolled in over the weekend. The channel dominated daytime, with Saturday's Olympic Grandstand pulling an average audience of 3m and a 41% share over a marathon stint between 7.55am and 5.15pm.

The following day, Olympic Grandstand had an even better 4.5m and a 55% share between 7.55am and 1pm as viewers tuned in through the morning to see Denise Lewis clinch gold in the heptathlon.

On Sunday afternoon Channel 5's Abba Day line-up from 12.40pm included Abba Jukebox (0.6m, 6%), quiz show 100 Per Cent Abba (0.6m, 6%) and Abba in Concert (0.7m, 6%). Later, Abba tribute band documentary Abba: Bjorn Again drew 1m (6%) from 5.35pm. A whole day of 6% share should make the shareholders happy - particuarly when the whole day was a repeat.

webTitle: The former meteorologist who scores for Cambridge

fields.headline: The former meteorologist who scores for Cambridge
fields.standfirst: In a new weekly series that starts today in place of My Day in the Sun, we talk to a figure from the cricketing world about his plans for the close season. We begin with Reg May, the veteran scorer for Cambridge University
fields.trailText: Reg May, 77, is the scorer for Cambridge University, the British Universities and Cambridgeshire in the Minor Counties league.
fields.body:
Reg May, 77, is the scorer for Cambridge University, the British Universities and Cambridgeshire in the Minor Counties league.

"Last winter I went to South Africa with the British Universities. We spent two and a half weeks in Port Elizabeth, which was lovely - but unfortunately they're not going anywhere this year.

"So what I'll mainly be doing is catching up on cricket stats. I have them all on pen and paper but I do check the first-class and minor-counties ones on the internet as well. I've already had to send the Cambridge University non-first-class results to Harriet Monkhouse, the deputy editor at Wisden.

"For the last few winters I've also been going back through the Cambridgeshire Minor Counties records. It all started a few years ago when we were playing Lincolnshire and one of their players was playing in his 100th match. Someone asked me how many matches one of our long-timers had played but I didn't know because I didn't have the records. So now I'm trying to bring everything up to date, with the help of my wife, Diana, of course. She likes cricket, especially when the weather is good and she has a deckchair and a book. Though I'm not sure she watches that much.

"I've got a few health problems at the moment. I've got a form of leukaemia which they were hoping to keep in control but it has flared up again so I've been on a fortnight of steroids. They've actually made me feel a lot better, though I think I'd be disqualified from the Olympics. Next I think it will be another dose of chemotherapy.

"But at least I've got plenty to do - I'm mostly indoors in my study or gardening. But doing statistics is easier than gardening. It is all voluntary though I do get a little honorary fee from Wisden and a copy of the Wisden Almanack. I also do the books for my wife's cousin who runs a golfing business in Bury St Edmunds.

"I've been retired 18 years and it's been a wonderful retirement. I've been scoring for 15 of the 18 years and have got to know all the first-class cricketers and scorers and, apart from Cambridge, have scored at Lord's more times than anywhere else.

"I was a meteorologist before I retired and spent most of my working life with the RAF - including three years in Singapore and two in Bahrain. Then I spent the last few years at the London Weather Centre helping the oil and gas industry. When I started my career they were looking for oil in the North Sea but by the time I retired in November 1982 they had found it and I used to fly out to the production platforms."

Reg May was talking to Tanya Aldred. To read the final My Day in the Sun of the season, in which Toby Bailey, Northamptonshire's reserve keeper, recalls how he took on Glenn McGrath (and came out on top), click here
