fields.headline: John Prescott's conference speech
fields.standfirst: Full text of the Labour party conference speech of transport minister John Prescott
fields.trailText: Full text of the Labour party conference speech of transport minister John Prescott.
fields.body:
This is an important week for all of us. The media are saying we are downbeat. Well Im not downbeat. The Partys not downbeat, and neither is the Labour government.

And why? Because were proud of what this Labour overnment has achieved. It has been delivery, delivery, delivery.

On May 1st 1997, we won the election on a radical programme for the environment, transport and local government. As the first step, Tony Blair created a new government department, whose very purpose is a better quality of life for the people of this country. And Ive got an excellent team of ministers who are putting it into action.

Conference, all our policies will count for little if they are not delivered centrally, regionally and locally. That is why its so important to bring decision-making closer to the people it affects. We have brought devolution to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. And a strategic authority back to London. And weve taken steps towards the sort of regional government I have always believed in. All English regions are enjoying greater prosperity. The new Regional Development Agencies have already saved 35,000 jobs.

But the Tories want to abolish them. So lets ask them why they think development agencies are good for Scotland and Wales, but not for the English regions?

And let me say this, Im proud of the work our 10,000 Labour councillors do for their local communities, up and down the country. I want to see the potential of local government liberated.

We abolished compulsory competitive tendering.

We ended the Tory capping regime.

We offered new modern choices in the way councils work, including a directly elected Mayor if local people want it.

Of course there are still problems. But local councils are now better funded than ever before. They have new freedoms. And they have more responsibility too.

Local government is our partner - no longer 'the enemy within'.

That's Labour democracy in action.

Weve given local councils new powers to promote the economic, social and environmental well-being of their communities. The environment is central to our quality of life. Under the Tories, Britain became known as 'the dirty man of Europe. Weve changed all that.

Im proud of what this government has done for the environment, at home and abroad - cleaning up the air we breathe, the water we drink, our seas, our rivers and beaches  all far better under Labour. Cutting water leaks by a quarter-saving enough to supply London for a year. Protecting our wildlife and the beauty of Britains countryside.

But the environment doesnt just begin at the edge of town. It starts when you step out of the door.

Thats why we are improving people's homes, neighbourhoods, public services, how we travel, and how we live. Not just as individuals, but as part of a community.

As our Constitution says: We believe that "by the strength of our common endeavour we achieve more than we achieve alone". We believe there is such a thing as society. We believe we do have responsibilities to others. Thats why weve set up a £1 billion programme to help pensioners keep their homes warm, including brand new central heating.

And weve done more.

Weve set a new goal to wipe out fuel poverty by the year 2010, because we in the Labour Party do not believe elderly people should die, just because they cant afford to keep warm. That's Labour social justice in action. And nowadays we have world responsibilities in a global environment, where pollution respects no national boundaries.

The greatest environmental threat facing the world today is climate change. Britain led the way at the historic summit in Kyoto. In November Ill be going to the next round of talks in the Hague. The scientific evidence is clear. If we dont cut greenhouse gases, then climate change will cause havoc across the world.

In Britain, floods in winter, drought in summer, low-lying areas swamped by the sea. And tropical diseases will spread - right here in Britain. In Britain. But in Bangladesh, millions of people face devastation from floods. Africa will be stricken by drought and famine. Small islands submerged forever. Ice caps melting. Already in America we see violent storms and the return of the dust bowls.

All this and more will plague our world environment, unless industrialised countries stop poisoning the atmosphere. Theres too much talk about the pain, not the gain, when it comes to our environment. Wasting less energy makes industry more competitive. Properly insulated homes are easier to warm. And cleaner cars cut our fuel bills.

I know people want cheaper petrol. We hear them loud and clear. But we also hear people when they say they want cleaner air, a better environment. We hear people say they want money spent on schools and hospitals, not to mention farm subsidies, and relief for road haulage.

Yes, of course there are real problems. Yes, of course we will listen. Yes, of course we do act. But we will deal with those problems through proper democratic representations in the budget process.

And one thing is clear.

No government, no prime minister, no chancellor can simply chop and change taxes by the month, Or renegotiate them at a refinery gate, under threat of 60 days notice. That is no way to make decisions in a democratic country.

Some of the press might think so. But they sang a different tune when it came to the French blockades, and one or two legal industrial disputes I could mention. So you have to find the right balance in government (and as a nation) which is never easy. But who said politics was easy?

I knew when I took this job, that it would take time to transform our transport, after decades of stop-go funding.

As a former seafarer, Im proud that - while the Tories devastated our merchant fleet  now, under Labour, ships are coming back to the British Red Ensign flag - over a million tonnes so far.

Across transport, were providing new resources, new powers, new means of delivery  perhaps most crucially the Strategic Rail Authority, which will ensure private rail firms act in the public interest.

The Policy Commission document is full of good ideas on transport and the whole range of issues, on which Im sure well all agree. And let me congratulate all those involved in the difficult and detailed work, which will give us a new framework for future policy.

But let me deal with a point of disagreement on train protection.

Let's be clear about this. On the road, on rail, in the air and at sea, safety always comes first in my priorities. One of the main reasons I came into politics was to make shipping safer. Earlier this year I set out a strategy to reduce deaths on the roads by 40%, and by 50% for children.

And remember how the Tories ignored  for 8 years  pleas for a public inquiry after the sinking of the Thames boat the Marchioness, where 51 people died, causing so much suffering for their families? We restored some form of justice to those grieving families, and not before time.

I wasted no time in calling public inquiries after the Southall and Paddington tragedies. After talking to the relatives and walking amongst the wreckage, I was determined they must mark a watershed in rail safety.

Thats why I appointed Lord Cullen  the man who transformed safety in the North Sea  to head a public inquiry covering the whole safety regime on the railways. We have taken over 30 separate measures to improve rail safety since coming to office, ranging from better driver training to safer rail carriages.

Already the number of trains passing red signals has been cut by a quarter in one year.

We took advice from Britain's most respected engineer, Sir David Davies. His recommendation was clear. He said install Automatic Train Protection on faster lines, and were doing it. But install the Train Protection Warning System across the whole network first, and were doing that too.

Why? Because this can save more lives than alternative systems which would take ten years to install. That is the sort of difficult decision we face - save lives now or wait for better technology in ten years.

Nevertheless I have asked Lord Cullen, together with the chairman of the Southall inquiry, to make specific recommendations on this very question. His public inquiry on this point started last week. But everyone  relatives, trade unions, lawyers and safety experts - has urged me not to do anything that would pre-empt Lord Cullens inquiry. I agree.

And I recommend to conference that you do the same and reject the alternative wording that would pre-empt Lord Cullen  as the National Policy Forum agreed at Exeter in July.

Conference must understand that I have given my word that I stand ready to implement whatever is required as a result of Lord Cullens proposals, and I will stand by that.

But for most people, its the daily business of travelling by road and rail that dominates. Our ten-year plan represents the biggest long-term investment in transport this country has ever seen. 180 billion pounds over ten years. In the next three years alone, public investment on transport will rise from £5 billion to a record £9 billion a year.

But this is a joint effort between the public and private sectors. In public and private partnership. So, in railways, well see more invested in the next ten years than we saw in the last one hundred years. New track. New trains. New signalling. New services. New stations.

More priority for buses in towns and more bus links in rural areas. More supertrams and safer walking and cycling.

On our roads, we will tackle the major bottlenecks. We can get more capacity out of the existing road network, but we recognise you cant simply build your way of congestion.

Its all about balance. Through this and better public transport, we will actually reduce congestion below current levels. And the ten-year plan is not just about figures. It will roll out into real improvements in the years to come. Here are a few examples.

This year, the SRA has negotiated the first new rail franchises with more guaranteed investment and better services. By 2001, well start 12 major road improvements. By 2002 half the countrys rail fleet will be new or refurbished, the first phase of the West Coast Mainline will reduce journey times between London and Manchester or Preston to under two hours and the first phase of the channel tunnel rail link will be built and the second phase to St Pancras will begin.

In 2003 we will finish 100 safety and congestion improvements to our trunk roads and complete the Nottingham Express transit. In 2004 two hundred more motorway cameras to help traffic flow and reduce congestion. In 2006 all three new Manchester Metrolink lines will be completed. In 2007 widening on motorway bottlenecks will begin. By 2008 weve agreed with manufacturers that new cars will do 25% more miles to the gallon. By 2009 the East Coast mainline railway will be upgraded. In 2010 we will see 50% more passengers on trains and 80% more on rail freight.

And the benefits will affect every corner of the country.

Thats integration in action. Not only better transport links, but integrated thinking that will make life better in our towns and cities.

Many of you know from bitter experience, the Tories ripped the heart out of our cities. As the Rogers report, that I commissioned makes clear, this calls for nothing less than an 'urban renaissance'. As he said:  Cities make citizens and citizens make cities. How true. That means not just better housing, planning and design, but better jobs, transport, schools, policing and health. Because the quality of life is not contradictory to economic growth; its critical to economic growth. If the local school is failing, or the streets are dirty and dangerous, people start to move away. Businesses and investment follow, leaving behind a cycle of poverty and rising crime.

We need to think creatively.

For example, our universities should not be ivory towers. They should be a resource for their communities, helping to bring skills, jobs and growth. We need social investment. We have released over £5bn of capital receipts to renovate 2 million homes. We need imagination. We are preparing a new Starter Home Scheme to help key workers like nurses and teachers set up home in high cost areas.

And for our coalfield communities, destroyed by the prejudice of theThatcher regime, we produced a £350m package, bringing jobs and hope where the Tories brought the dole and despair.

Thats a matter of honour, that we have delivered.

And remember this, the greater the exodus from the towns, the greater the strain on the countryside. The Tories want to drive a wedge between the town and the country. We want a living, working countryside.

I see the Countryside Alliance are outside to celebrate our hundredth birthday. They are very kind - they came to celebrate my 30th year as an MP for Hull. But I ask the protesters outside the Hall, when the Tories were shutting 2,000 post offices, selling off 10,000 council houses, ending bus services and closing village schools  why weren't you outside Tory Party conferences protesting for those 18 years?

But I tell you this, every time I see the Countryside Alliance I redouble my determination to vote in the House of Commons to abolish fox hunting forever.

And I reject claims that people who oppose fox hunting are out of sympathy with rural Britain. From the day my school took me as a boy to the Lake District, I have always loved the countryside. It was Labour, just over 50 years ago, that gave Britain its first national parks. Last year, I announced two new national parks in the South Downs and the New Forest - a great gift to the British people  especially on our 100th birthday. And we Ive introduced legislation to extend the right to roam in open countryside.

Some of the Tories in the House of Lords don't like it. They think they know all about the open countryside. After all, they own most of it.

But I say to members of the House of Lords, this is Government policy and we fully intend to implement it.

We believe our natural heritage is not just for the privileged few, but for the whole of our people to respect and enjoy. That's Labour freedom in action.

Now Conference, earlier I talked about transport safety. But a life lost in a factory accident is just as important as a life lost in a traffic accident. Labours Health and Safety at Work Act has helped reduce accidents dramatically since the 1970s. But in some industries, like construction, lives are being lost through sheer bad working practices, and a degree of indifference.

And Ive warned the construction industry this is totally unacceptable.

So we are shaking up health and safety. Company directors must take responsibility for safety. Penalties will be tougher. And weve begun consultation on the offence of corporate killing.

Company directors whose negligence costs lives must not be allowed to hide behind workers and get away 'scot free'. So, once Lord Cullen has reported on rail, well take decisive action to strengthen our safety law, in transport and in the workplace.

For the first time in 25 years, we will bring forward a new wide-ranging Act of Parliament to make Britain a safer place to travel and a safer place to work in. That's Labour caring for our people.

So Conference, we have already begun our task: to clean up Britain. To bring new life to our cities and countryside. And to give Britain a transport system we can once again be proud of.

We have laid the foundations. But there is still a lot to do.

Our Policy Commission has proposed an exciting programme of work.

Now we need to get out campaigning to win that second term, to put those ideas into practice. And if you want a good example of integrated thinking - heres one:

From next April, well introduce half price concessionary bus fares for all pensioners, wherever they live, England or Wales, under Tory, Liberal or Labour councils.

And whereas some councils charge as much as £40 for the pass we will insist the pass is provided free of charge. In a few weeks well amend our legislation to extend this scheme to disabled people as well for the first time.

That's Labour social justice in action. Thats Labour helping the environment. That's Labour backing public transport.

But we dont get those sort of benefits without taking the hard decisions which make it possible. With Tony Blair as Prime Minister, committed to long term decisions, and Gordon Brown as Chancellor sorting out the public finances and stabilising the economy, thats how weve been able to plan for this major improvement in public services. And I would like to record my appreciation and support for what they have achieved.

Too often in the past, politicians have dodged long-term responsibility for the sake of short-term expediency. Ive always been a bit of a conviction politician. I will always do what I believe is right. Sometimes I get attacked for it.

So be it.

Because when I decide policies, I decide them not for tomorrow's headlines, but for tomorrow's children.

And that's the way Ill always be.

And thats how this Labour government will be.

So you have to find the right balance in government (and as a nation) which is never easy. But who said politics was easy? I knew when I took this job, that it would take time to transform our transport, after decades of stop-go funding. As a former seafarer, Im proud that - while the Tories devastated our merchant fleet  now, under Labour, ships are coming back to the British Red Ensign flag - over a million tonnes so far. Across transport, were providing new resources, new powers, new means of delivery  perhaps most crucially the Strategic Rail Authority, which will ensure private rail firms act in the public interest. The Policy Commission document is full of good ideas on transport and the whole range of issues, on which Im sure well all agree. And let me congratulate all those involved in the difficult and detailed work, which will give us a new framework for future policy. But let me deal with a point of disagreement on train protection. Let's be clear about this. On the road, on rail, in the air and at sea, safety always comes first in my priorities. One of the main reasons I came into politics was to make shipping safer. Earlier this year I set out a strategy to reduce deaths on the roads by 40%, and by 50% for children. And remember how the Tories ignored  for 8 years  pleas for a public inquiry after the sinking of the Thames boat the Marchioness, where 51 people died, causing so much suffering for their families? We restored some form of justice to those grieving families, and not before time. I wasted no time in calling public inquiries after the Southall and Paddington tragedies. After talking to the relatives and walking amongst the wreckage, I was determined they must mark a watershed in rail safety. Thats why I appointed Lord Cullen  the man who transformed safety in the North Sea  to head a public inquiry covering the whole safety regime on the railways. We have taken over 30 separate measures to improve rail safety since coming to office, ranging from better driver training to safer rail carriages. Already the number of trains passing red signals has been cut by a quarter in one year. We took advice from Britain's most respected engineer, Sir David Davies. His recommendation was clear. He said install Automatic Train Protection on faster lines, and were doing it. But install the Train Protection Warning System across the whole network first, and were doing that too. Why? Because this can save more lives than alternative systems which would take ten years to install. That is the sort of difficult decision we face - save lives now or wait for better technology in ten years. Nevertheless I have asked Lord Cullen, together with the chairman of the Southall inquiry, to make specific recommendations on this very question. His public inquiry on this point started last week. But everyone  relatives, trade unions, lawyers and safety experts - has urged me not to do anything that would pre-empt Lord Cullens inquiry. I agree. And I recommend to conference that you do the same and reject the alternative wording that would pre-empt Lord Cullen  as the National Policy Forum agreed at Exeter in July. Conference must understand that I have given my word that I stand ready to implement whatever is required as a result of Lord Cullens proposals, and I will stand by that. But for most people, its the daily business of travelling by road and rail that dominates. Our ten-year plan represents the biggest long-term investment in transport this country has ever seen. 180 billion pounds over ten years. In the next three years alone, public investment on transport will rise from £5 billion to a record £9 billion a year. But this is a joint effort between the public and private sectors. In public and private partnership. So, in railways, well see more invested in the next ten years than we saw in the last one hundred years. New track. New trains. New signalling. New services. New stations. More priority for buses in towns and more bus links in rural areas. More supertrams and safer walking and cycling. On our roads, we will tackle the major bottlenecks. We can get more capacity out of the existing road network, but we recognise you cant simply build your way of congestion. Its all about balance. Through this and better public transport, we will actually reduce congestion below current levels. And the ten-year plan is not just about figures. It will roll out into real improvements in the years to come. Here are a few examples. This year, the SRA has negotiated the first new rail franchises with more guaranteed investment and better services. By 2001, well start 12 major road improvements. By 2002 half the countrys rail fleet will be new or refurbished, the first phase of the West Coast Mainline will reduce journey times between London and Manchester or Preston to under two hours and the first phase of the channel tunnel rail link will be built and the second phase to St Pancras will begin. In 2003 we will finish 100 safety and congestion improvements to our trunk roads and complete the Nottingham Express transit. In 2004 two hundred more motorway cameras to help traffic flow and reduce congestion. In 2006 all three new Manchester Metrolink lines will be completed. In 2007 widening on motorway bottlenecks will begin. By 2008 weve agreed with manufacturers that new cars will do 25% more miles to the gallon. By 2009 the East Coast mainline railway will be upgraded. In 2010 we will see 50% more passengers on trains and 80% more on rail freight. And the benefits will affect every corner of the country. Thats integration in action. Not only better transport links, but integrated thinking that will make life better in our towns and cities. Many of you know from bitter experience, the Tories ripped the heart out of our cities. As the Rogers report, that I commissioned makes clear, this calls for nothing less than an 'urban renaissance'. As he said:  Cities make citizens and citizens make cities. How true. That means not just better housing, planning and design, but better jobs, transport, schools, policing and health. Because the quality of life is not contradictory to economic growth; its critical to economic growth. If the local school is failing, or the streets are dirty and dangerous, people start to move away. Businesses and investment follow, leaving behind a cycle of poverty and rising crime. We need to think creatively. For example, our universities should not be ivory towers. They should be a resource for their communities, helping to bring skills, jobs and growth. We need social investment. We have released over £5bn of capital receipts to renovate 2 million homes. We need imagination. We are preparing a new Starter Home Scheme to help key workers like nurses and teachers set up home in high cost areas. And for our coalfield communities, destroyed by the prejudice of theThatcher regime, we produced a £350m package, bringing jobs and hope where the Tories brought the dole and despair. Thats a matter of honour, that we have delivered. And remember this, the greater the exodus from the towns, the greater the strain on the countryside. The Tories want to drive a wedge between the town and the country. We want a living, working countryside. I see the Countryside Alliance are outside to celebrate our hundredth birthday. They are very kind - they came to celebrate my 30th year as an MP for Hull. But I ask the protesters outside the Hall, when the Tories were shutting 2,000 post offices, selling off 10,000 council houses, ending bus services and closing village schools  why weren't you outside Tory Party conferences protesting for those 18 years? But I tell you this, every time I see the Countryside Alliance I redouble my determination to vote in the House of Commons to abolish fox hunting forever. And I reject claims that people who oppose fox hunting are out of sympathy with rural Britain. From the day my school took me as a boy to the Lake District, I have always loved the countryside. It was Labour, just over 50 years ago, that gave Britain its first national parks. Last year, I announced two new national parks in the South Downs and the New Forest - a great gift to the British people  especially on our 100th birthday. And we Ive introduced legislation to extend the right to roam in open countryside. Some of the Tories in the House of Lords don't like it. They think they know all about the open countryside. After all, they own most of it. But I say to members of the House of Lords, this is Government policy and we fully intend to implement it. We believe our natural heritage is not just for the privileged few, but for the whole of our people to respect and enjoy. That's Labour freedom in action. Now Conference, earlier I talked about transport safety. But a life lost in a factory accident is just as important as a life lost in a traffic accident. Labours Health and Safety at Work Act has helped reduce accidents dramatically since the 1970s. But in some industries, like construction, lives are being lost through sheer bad working practices, and a degree of indifference. And Ive warned the construction industry this is totally unacceptable. So we are shaking up health and safety. Company directors must take responsibility for safety. Penalties will be tougher. And weve begun consultation on the offence of corporate killing. Company directors whose negligence costs lives must not be allowed to hide behind workers and get away 'scot free'. So, once Lord Cullen has reported on rail, well take decisive action to strengthen our safety law, in transport and in the workplace. For the first time in 25 years, we will bring forward a new wide-ranging Act of Parliament to make Britain a safer place to travel and a safer place to work in. That's Labour caring for our people. So Conference, we have already begun our task: to clean up Britain. To bring new life to our cities and countryside. And to give Britain a transport system we can once again be proud of. We have laid the foundations. But there is still a lot to do. Our Policy Commission has proposed an exciting programme of work. Now we need to get out campaigning to win that second term, to put those ideas into practice. And if you want a good example of integrated thinking - heres one: From next April, well introduce half price concessionary bus fares for all pensioners, wherever they live, England or Wales, under Tory, Liberal or Labour councils. And whereas some councils charge as much as £40 for the pass we will insist the pass is provided free of charge. In a few weeks well amend our legislation to extend this scheme to disabled people as well for the first time. That's Labour social justice in action. Thats Labour helping the environment. That's Labour backing public transport. But we dont get those sort of benefits without taking the hard decisions which make it possible. With Tony Blair as Prime Minister, committed to long term decisions, and Gordon Brown as Chancellor sorting out the public finances and stabilising the economy, thats how weve been able to plan for this major improvement in public services. And I would like to record my appreciation and support for what they have achieved. Too often in the past, politicians have dodged long-term responsibility for the sake of short-term expediency. Ive always been a bit of a conviction politician. I will always do what I believe is right. Sometimes I get attacked for it. So be it. Because when I decide policies, I decide them not for tomorrow's headlines, but for tomorrow's children. And that's the way Ill always be. And thats how this Labour government will be.

fields.headline: Bertelsmann in ISyndicate joint-venture
fields.trailText: Bertelsmann is making further inroads into the e-commerce market by launching a joint venture with US internet company ISyndicate.
fields.body:
European media group Bertelsmann is making further inroads into the e-commerce market by launching a joint venture with US internet company ISyndicate.

The venture will link Bertelsmann content with ISyndicate's independent content providers on a common European internet platform.

ISyndicate delivers audio, video, animation, interactive games, comics and weather reports from more than 1,100 sources, including the Reuters and Associated Press news services.

Bertelsmann will also take on the role of internet middleman, liaising between media companies seeking to put their products on the internet and websites looking for content.

The syndication process allows companies to offer content packages on the web without building an internet platform.

The German company is building a strong portfolio of companies in its e-commerce division. It owns European online bookseller BOL.com and its US counterpart Barnesandnoble, and recently paid $117m (£80m) for ailing internet music retailer CDnow.

Bertlesmann will pay DM80m (£24.6m) for a 4% stake in ISyndicate, and has a DM30bn (£9bn) war-chest to make further acquisitions.

The company is expected to make a move for UK music group EMI if its merger with Warner Music is vetoed by European Commission regulators, as it plans to turn its BMG record label into the world's market leader by the end of the year.

Bertelsmann chief creative officer Rolf Schmidt-Holtz said: "Bertelsmann is a content powerhouse. The joint venture is an important step towards strengthening our position in the content sector. We want to ensure that Bertelsmann's diverse content is available wherever the customer wishes and expects to find it."

webTitle: Healthy marketing tie-up for Excite UK

fields.headline: Healthy marketing tie-up for Excite UK
fields.trailText: Marketing deal ties up Excite UK with health portal NetDoctor.co.uk.
fields.body:
Excite UK has signed a two-year marketing deal with health portal NetDoctor.co.uk.

The deal includes both on and offline marketing with future Netdoctor.co.uk marketing material carrying Excite's logo, and Excite.co.uk taking more Netdoctor.co.uk ads across the sites.

Visitors to Excite's health channel will see content from NetDoctor.co.uk, including the latest information on diseases, medical conditions, symptoms, causes and treatment.

"This is another example of Excite's commitment to establishing strong relationships with its partners and advertisers. NetDoctor.co.uk will add a valuable dimension to our users' experience, reinforcing Excite's position as one of the most comprehensive portals in the UK marketplace," said Evan Rudowski, managing director of Excite Europe.

NetDoctor.co.uk, which launched February this year, is the UK division of NetDoktor.com.

Last week Excite.co.uk launched a free SMS messaging service similar to that launched by Lycos last month.

webTitle: We learn from BBC and the flowerpot men

fields.headline: We learn from BBC and the flowerpot men
fields.trailText: For an area of the dot.com world that has often been heavily criticised, it seems that a number of organisations are now getting their customer service right. It is something that we are going to work hard to achieve.
fields.body:
"As you may appreciate, scheduling is not an exact science. The cult TV series Seinfeld is put on late at night to guarantee that we can show the series without disruption caused by coverage of the Olympics."

This is an extract from an email sent to us by the BBC and an excellent example of good customer service. It felt like we were receiving personal attention and we received a response within 24 hours of our inquiry. When you have as many late working nights as us, knowing what's on when you do have free time is very important.

A second good customer service experience occurred to us last week when we bought some flower pots from Crocus.co.uk for plants we had purchased the previous weekend from Columbia Road flower market in east London. We were keen to take advantage of a special offer and also the convenience of heavy pots being delivered to our door.

In the middle of the recent fuel crisis we thought that Crocus might struggle to fulfill the order. But even as ambulances and hospital staff were threatened with immobility, Crocus got through.

For an area of the dot.com world that has often been heavily criticised, it seems that a number of organisations are now getting their customer service right. It is something that we are going to work hard to achieve.

So far, this has not been too much of an issue for us. We estimate that we have been able to respond to 90% of inquiries via the website within 24 hours (apologies to the few that had to wait longer).

That is the easy bit. Most of the inquiries so far have been from other businesses, potential suppliers or partners and have been relatively standard. Dealing with active customers will be a whole new game. The volume of inquiries go up, as will the variety and complexity of those inquiries. And we are in no doubt that our customers will be demanding. We anticipate inquiries ranging from the relatively straightforward complaints about retailers' deliveries to the more unusual "can you ask my mum to give me £50".

Covering all these angles requires a significant investment. For example, a company receiving 100 inbound calls per day, each effectively costing around £3.50 to answer (a common industry benchmark) will spend just under £130,000 on supporting a call centre.

We are still developing the full customer support services, having spent a lot of time researching various options. Some key elements are almost in place, core email and phone support for example. Our strategy is to resource these to a level above which we expect to have to support initially and learn rapidly from the experience that we gain when we go live.

Not everyone is getting it right. This week's email survey results from CallScan found that some of the country's largest companies, including FirstDirect.co.uk and Norwich-union.co.uk, failed to respond to customer emails within two weeks. But if the BBC, with millions of web visitors each week, can get it right, there is not much excuse for the rest of us. We would be even happier if they moved Seinfeld to an earlier time, of course.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com, a service that enables teenagers to shop online without a credit card

webTitle: Students are prime target for robbers

fields.headline: Students are prime target for robbers
fields.standfirst: Security measures stepped up as violent attacks proliferate
fields.trailText: Security measures stepped up as violent attacks proliferate
fields.body:
Scott McManus describes himself as the average student. He is about to start a BA in film studies at Manchester Metropolitan University. Everything he wears is black, except his German army jacket. He dyed his hair black for the start of term and likes night life.

But his education about life has started early - Mr McManus, 22, has been robbed three times since the start of freshers' week.

"I've lost £500 since the beginning of term. The first time they took my walkman and some cash, the second time they took my bank card. They don't usually go for my mobile phone, but in the last attack they did. It tends to happen on Portland Street, just behind the gay village. I have also been done over during the day, by lads under 18 jumping out of cars at traffic lights."

Last academic year, Mr McManus, who is 6ft 4in and from Manchester, was robbed five times. He said the average age of his attackers was 16.

"Once I was coming home on the bus drunk and I got off at my stop in a bit of a daze and I found myself up against the bus shelter with a knife to my throat.

"Nobody has pulled a gun on me yet, but most of my friends have been held up at gunpoint at cash machines."

Mr McManus said he had not provoked the attacks and believes any student with a pierced chin or hair in bunches had the equivalent of a target painted on their backs. "Thieves see students and pounce."

In Manchester, last year, there were 1,000 street robberies in a two and a half mile radius of the universities. The National Union of Students says there has been a rise in the number of students targeted by petty criminals, and students now represent one of the highest victim brackets in the UK.

Rachel Kashman, vice president of NUS welfare, said: "We have a growing problem and if funding for universities is cut, unions will not be able to finance the security measures in place to help students escape the cycle of mugging."

Almost one third of street robberies in Manchester are committed against students, according to police. This month, Greater Manchester police received £3.2m in government funding for Operation Hawk, a project to fight street robbery. Police officers handed out leaflets near student unions offering advice on "How to go out in Manchester without getting the tripe beaten out of you". Officers patrolled student areas with cameras to photograph suspects as an extension of the stop and search tactic. Students were advised to reduce cash card limits to £50, so thieves could only withdraw the minimum amount of cash.

Superintendent Andrew Holt said the problem was not unique to Manchester. "With four universities and one of the biggest student populations in the country, we illustrate problems other forces are finding in Merseyside, London and the West Midlands."

In Cambridge, police have invested £34,800 this year in tackling the problem through security staff and deterrents like warning stickers. PC Anil Soni said 75% of offenders who burgled student accommodation were under 30, and so blended in with the community.

Cambridge police were also working to reduce street attacks on foreign students. West Yorkshire police launched an offensive last week to reduce crime against students in Leeds; and Leicester has launched a £30,000 burglary reduction project in collaboration with the university.

In Manchester, police have produced a profile of student victims. Most are white males between 19 and 24, who own mobile phones or bicycles. Mobile phone thefts on the streets have risen by 9% since last year, but cash card holders are the main targets.

"Female students are also targeted but they tend to take precautions against sexual violence that also prevent them being robbed, " Superintendent Holt said.

Offenders who attack students tended to be young men, aged between 18 and 20, according to the police. Their numbers were rising because they worked in pairs and were therefore harder to catch.

Detective Superintendent Peter Minshall, who coordinates Operation Hawk, said crimes ranged from street robberies to incidents where students were marched from their accommodation to cashpoints to withdraw money.

At the freshers week events, most students had a story. Lyndsey Gordon, 22, a first year postgraduate at Umist, was held up at gunpoint at a cash machine in Didsbury Village in south Manchester. She had drawn out £20. "Two of my friends were at the next cashpoint, it was a well-lit street and I had taken care not to be alone. We were chatting when a man came up behind us. He kept the gun close to his groin so no one could see it and kept repeating, 'Give me the money'.

"We shouted and he ran off. I was so shaken I didn't report it to the police until the next day and by that time it was too late."

Roland Cory-Wright, a computer studies student, woke up one night to find two strangers downstairs in his house. They fled when they heard his voice, but he found the stereo, television, microwave and his computer lined up by his front door wrapped in towels.

Superintendent Holt said it was wrong to attribute crime against students to Manchester's reputation for armed gangs.

"We do have an armed crime and gang problem in Manchester but it is young men with criminal records killing other young men with criminal records.

"The gangs deal with drug running, not street robbery. They are highly unlikely to come into contact with students. They consider themselves above mugging students. They have graduated up the hierarchy of crime."

But police said thieves played on fear of gangs, telling students: "I'm from Moss Side, give me all your money."

Nicola Moore, a welfare officer at Manchester University, advised students to use the "safety bus", which for 75p picks up from late clubs at the union and drops students at their door, or the special service for students who have had their wallets stolen.

Students give the driver their library card as a deposit and pay their fare the next day.

Mr McManus plans to use common sense in future. "If I see three lads coming towards me, I always cross the road. They will still come after me, but it gives me a headstart on running away. I have stopped going out on my own at night. You just can't."

They have graduated up the hierarchy of crime." But police said thieves played on fear of gangs, telling students: "I'm from Moss Side, give me all your money." Nicola Moore, a welfare officer at Manchester University, advised students to use the "safety bus", which for 75p picks up from late clubs at the union and drops students at their door, or the special service for students who have had their wallets stolen. Students give the driver their library card as a deposit and pay their fare the next day. Mr McManus plans to use common sense in future. "If I see three lads coming towards me, I always cross the road. They will still come after me, but it gives me a headstart on running away. I have stopped going out on my own at night. You just can't."

fields.standfirst: This is the second of a series of four reports from Save the Children UK examining the impact of ongoing World Bank policy on the welfare of children in transition countries.

fields.body:
As in the rest of the world, World Bank, IMF and donor policy advice and lending in transition countries has two potentially contradictory directions in relation to social services. On the one hand, investment in social services is upheld as essential for building and maintaining a healthy, educated population. On the other, concerns about fiscal deficits lead to strong pressure to reduce public spending . While social services expenditure fell most severely immediately after the collapse of the Soviet Union, in many countries the decline continues. In Kyrgyzstan, for example, public expenditure on health and education has fallen approximately 50 per cent in real terms since 1993. Uzbekistan, which has not substantially reformed its economy, is the only Central Asian country where education expenditure has not declined to a third of its pre-independence level.

In many transition countries, user charges - fees for medical treatment or school attendance -have been introduced. This is part of an explicit strategy to reduce public expenditure on social services and to increase the contribution of families, communities and the private sector. In addition, parents usually have to provide children's books and stationery, and often to contribute to school maintenance, and in many countries, patients must provide their own drugs. Official exemptions for poor families and for certain vulnerable groups - seen by donors as guaranteeing poor people access to key social services - are often poorly designed and not implemented in practice, as service staff demand additional or informal payments, administrators find exemptions too bureaucratic and time-consuming, or people are ashamed to claim their exemptions. Significant increases in user charges for utilities such as gas, electricity and water are limiting households' ability to pay for essential services for children.

In Kyrgyzstan and Mongolia, privatisation and decentralisation has left some public services such as pre-schools in the hands of local authorities. With no budget to run pre-schools and a limited tax base, coupled with the mandate to sell or "privatise" assets, many pre-schools - formerly community assets - have been sold to private investors for housing, commercial use or other development. In Kyrgyzstan by 1996, there were approximately one third the number of pre-schools there had been in 1991.

Effects of these policies:

Where user fees have been introduced as part of reform packages, such as in Africa and Latin America, school and clinic/ hospital attendance has fallen while some health problems have spread: · in Mongolia, where extensive school subsidies were abolished, fees introduced, and the demand for children's labour as herders increased, school attendance declined 25 per cent from 1990-1994. There are signs of literacy rates decreasing among young people. · school infrastructure has deteriorated considerably over the last 10 years. Lack of heating is a major reason for children's non-attendance in countries such as Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Tajikistan, Armenia and Georgia. · The quality of education is declining in many countries, as budgets cannot stretch to educational materials and salaries, which motivate teachers. Many parents feel their children are receiving a worse education than they themselves received. · in Kyrgyzstan, the incidence of tuberculosis - a disease strongly related to poverty - now affects over 120 per 100,000 of the population. · 49 per cent of people surveyed in Kyrygzstan in 1997 said they would not seek treatment when sick because they expected the costs to be too high.

Recommendations

1. User fees should only be charged for non-essential health services and for tertiary education. Failing to ensure all children's access to a good quality education and to guarantee basic health services to all is mortgaging the welfare of present and future generations, and jeopardising countries' economic development. User fees in poor countries have been shown to be a tragic experiment with poor people's lives . With exemption systems largely ineffective, it is by no means clear that formal charges will replace informal charges, and it is extraordinary that donors and international financial institutions have not learnt from this experience. The World Bank has signed up to the Dakar Framework for Action on Education for All which aims to ensure free primary education for all children - this is clearly incompatible with user fees. Through processes such as Poverty Reduction Strategy Papers and the Comprehensive Development Framework, the Bank can play a key role in urging governments and donors to implement this commitment to children in transition countries.

2. Short to medium term donor support for free social services. If countries cannot finance free essential health and education services in the short to medium term, donor assistance should focus on budgetary support. This may well mean greater coherence and rationalisation of technical assistance, rather than each donor providing their own consultants on similar issues. Reform policies need to be widely discussed rather than pushed through without adequate public debate.

3. Debt relief should be explored. Many transition countries e.g. Kyrgyzstan are highly indebted and poor. However, they have mostly been ignored by debt relief campaigns. Debt relief should urgently be explored as a mechanism for social services financing in poor transition economies.

For further information contact:

Caroline Harper, Head of Research and Development (c.harper@scfuk.org.uk) Rachel Marcus, Research and Policy Advisor (r.marcus@scfuk.org.uk) Anna McCord, International Advocacy Co-ordinator (a.mccord@scfuk.org.uk) John Wilkinson, Policy and Learning Officer (j.wilkinson@scfuk.org.uk)

fields.headline: 'They sent someone in every five minutes to check I was still breathing'
fields.standfirst: Spanking nuns, freezing showers, a hellish spell in a boot camp - being Ewen Bremner is a seriously dangerous job.  Brian Pendreigh  talks to the Trainspotting star about his new movies
fields.trailText: Spanking nuns, freezing showers, a hellish spell in a boot camp - being Ewen Bremner is a seriously dangerous job. Brian Pendreigh talks to the Trainspotting star about his new movies
fields.body:
What do you do after starring in one of the most successful British films of all time? If you are Ewan McGregor, you grab your light sabre and sign a long-term deal for Star Wars. If you are Bobby Carlyle you take a turn as a James Bond villain. And Ewen Bremner? If you're the man who as Spud mainlined into the Trainspotting audience's funny bone, you take roles in a number of low-budget, little-seen flops, before opting for art-house kudos with American wunderkind Harmony Korine, and mainstream glamour with the forthcoming blockbuster Pearl Harbor.

Unusually for a film star, Bremner is better looking in real life than on screen. Still in his 20s, fresh-faced, with hair closer to strawberry blond than ginger, his features are drawn in bold, angular lines. Bremner made his film debut as a dim-witted schoolboy in the comedy Heavenly Pursuits, 10 years before Trainspotting. With a resumé ranging from Shakespeare to Judge Dredd, he has also produced a string of unforgettable cameo appearances, most recently in Snatch, when Vinnie Jones shuts the car window on his head and drives off.

Bremner first met writer-director Harmony Korine several years ago. Korine had shocked public opinion with Kids, a portrait of underage sex and drug use which he wrote in his teens. Bremner had been "blown away" by Korine's directorial debut Gummo, a low-budget drama about white-trash Ohio kids who kill cats and sell the corpses to a supermarket.

"I'm making a movie that's going to be like nothing else," was Korine's modest pitch for Julien Donkey-Boy, the "plot" of which was inspired by his Uncle Eddie, who had been in a mental institution for years. The finished script was simply a description of a series of scenes. The actors would mix with members of the public, improvising their lines and being recorded on tiny "spy cameras".

Korine had been impressed by Bremner's performance as Archie, the inarticulate, twitchy Scots headbanger in Naked, and he suggested Bremner play the supporting role of Julien's brother, an aspiring wrestler and misfit in a film entirely populated by misfits. "I said, 'I want to play Julien,'" Bremner recalls, "and I think he was delighted that I had the audacity to say that I wanted to do it."

Initially, however, Bremner had grave reservations about his ability to pull off the American accent that would be required. "I believed that I would be capable of it, but I'm not an actor who is gifted with that aptitude for accents. It was a real struggle for me to lose my Scottish accent. That was the hardest part, it wasn't the psychological aspects of Julien." Bremner tried out his accent when he went to visit Korine's Uncle Eddie. "It was quite difficult to get access to him, but they sneaked me in as a relative." He listened to Eddie's fantastical stories, studied his speech patterns - "so fast and so slurred" - and crafted a character. He maintained his accent off-set and refused to see Scots friends, for fear those Rs would start rocking and rolling again. "My girlfriend was losing her patience with me when I was on the telephone... I didn't think I was in character, I was just trying to be American." Bremner also totally changed his appearance for Julien and is almost unrecognisable with black, loosely-permed hair and metal teeth.

Julien Donkey-Boy is unlike any other film, not just in content, but in tone and ambiguity. In the opening scene, Julien appears to attack and possibly kill a boy at a pond. The incident is never referred to again. Julien works as an assistant at a blind school and is part of a dysfunctional family that includes Chloe Sevigny as his pregnant sister, and the German director Werner Herzog as the father who forces Julien to slap himself for being stupid, and hoses down his other son with cold water because it is character-forming.

The film is composed of seemingly dislocated scenes, including a nun masturbating and spanking herself, but a loose storyline eventually starts to emerge, and there is considerable black comedy. "Stop that shivering," says the father, aiming the hose at his son. "A winner doesn't shiver." Meanwhile Julien asks passersby which tree is his family tree.

The San Francisco Chronicle called Julien Donkey-Boy a "self-indulgent mess", while Entertainment Weekly compared it to the poetry of Robert Frost. "It's probably the thing that I feel most proud of," says Bremner, who, in Julien, has created a character both touching and appalling. He admits it was a huge relief when it was over. "I had been living in a different world," he says. "Personally I had really isolated myself to do that job. It took me a couple of weeks or so to get it out of my system."

The film left Bremner not only physically and mentally exhausted, but skint, having spent five months working for next to nothing. It did, however, get him an American agent and a reputation as a Brit who can do an American accent - which ultimately led him to director Michael Bay, producer Jerry Bruckheimer, and their take on the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Bremner doubts the makers of The Rock and Armageddon saw Julien Donkey-Boy. "I'm sure it's not a film that they would want to watch," he says.

Going from a no-budget, straight-to-video film to a $145m movie must have been quite a culture shock. "I don't see Julien as a product," says Bremner. "But I see this as a product, a very custom-built blockbuster, a classic of the genre. I don't always have hundreds of options and this was a pretty good one."

In Pearl Harbor Bremner plays Affleck's co-pilot, but he laughs at the notion that they might replace Cruise and Kilmer as the top guns for the 21st Century. "There's a lot of stunts and special effects," he says. "We're running around firing guns and that sort of thing, but I'm not putting myself in much danger."

He did have to go to boot camp, however. "They really broke us down, me particuarly. The last night of boot camp they were sending someone in to check on me every few minutes, to check I was still breathing." He maintains his character is not so different from his previous hapless supporting characters. "I play an American pilot with a speech impediment, who falls in love and goes to war and becomes a man or a hero. I'm just making Ben Affleck look good, ha-ha."

 Julien Donkey-Boy opens on Friday. Pearl Harbor will be released next year.

fields.headline: Dome too ambitious admits Blair
fields.standfirst:
PM expresses project regrets for first time

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Tony Blair admitted yesterday that the Millennium Dome has become a liability when he said that the government should never have run the project in the first place.
fields.body:
Tony Blair admitted yesterday that the Millennium Dome has become a liability when he said that the government should never have run the project in the first place.

In his first public expression of regret about the Greenwich attraction, the prime minister said that the dome was "too ambitious" for a government to run. Speaking on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, Mr Blair said: "If I had known [in 1997] what I know now about governments trying to run a visitor attraction of this sort ...it would probably have been too ambitious a thing for a government to have tried to have done."

Mr Blair's frank admission, on the opening day of the Labour conference, was designed by Downing Street to draw a line under the dome which has become a severe embarrassment to the government. Aides hope that by admitting that mistakes have been made, the sting will be drawn out of further criticisms.

In his television interview, Mr Blair conceded that the dome has not been a "runaway success", although he refused to apologise. "It's not been the runaway success we hoped but neither has it been the disaster that it's portrayed in some parts," the prime minister said.

Asked whether he sympathised with people, who believe that the hundreds of millions of pounds of public money poured into the dome should have been used for worthier projects, Mr Blair said he understood their concerns. But he added: "I say to people, [the dome] was part of a £2bn worth of millennium projects right round the country - it's important to put it in context but I understand the concern people have over it."

The prime minister was the first of a series of ministers who conceded yesterday that the dome had proved a costly embarrassment. Stephen Byers, who managed to escape responsibility for the dome when he succeeded Peter Mandelson as trade and industry secretary in 1998, admitted that the dome had lost money.

"I think it is right we should say, look, this was not what was intended, it hasn't worked as well as we wanted it to and we should acknowledge that," he said.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who played a key role in persuading the cabinet to endorse the dome in 1997, admitted that he was a "little suspicious" of the original estimate that 12m people would visit Greenwich. Six million will have visited the dome by the end of the year, a shortfall which has plunged it into repeated financial crises.

Mr Prescott added: "It's clearly cost a lot more than [expected] largely because the figures then were not achieved and therefore we end up with this kind of deficit. That is unfortunate but at the end of the day it is still one of the most successful attractions round the world."

The Tories said that the prime minister should now apologise for the dome, having admitted that it was a failure. The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said: "When are we going to see any minister shoulder the responsibility for this catastrophic fiasco? The prime minister should start by sacking Lord Falconer, who is the sole shareholder in the failed dome company."

The admission by senior cabinet ministers follows Clare Short's attack on the dome last week when she called it a flop and a disaster.

In his television interview, Mr Blair conceded that the dome has not been a "runaway success", although he refused to apologise. "It's not been the runaway success we hoped but neither has it been the disaster that it's portrayed in some parts," the prime minister said. Asked whether he sympathised with people, who believe that the hundreds of millions of pounds of public money poured into the dome should have been used for worthier projects, Mr Blair said he understood their concerns. But he added: "I say to people, [the dome] was part of a £2bn worth of millennium projects right round the country - it's important to put it in context but I understand the concern people have over it." The prime minister was the first of a series of ministers who conceded yesterday that the dome had proved a costly embarrassment. Stephen Byers, who managed to escape responsibility for the dome when he succeeded Peter Mandelson as trade and industry secretary in 1998, admitted that the dome had lost money. "I think it is right we should say, look, this was not what was intended, it hasn't worked as well as we wanted it to and we should acknowledge that," he said. The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who played a key role in persuading the cabinet to endorse the dome in 1997, admitted that he was a "little suspicious" of the original estimate that 12m people would visit Greenwich. Six million will have visited the dome by the end of the year, a shortfall which has plunged it into repeated financial crises. Mr Prescott added: "It's clearly cost a lot more than [expected] largely because the figures then were not achieved and therefore we end up with this kind of deficit. That is unfortunate but at the end of the day it is still one of the most successful attractions round the world." The Tories said that the prime minister should now apologise for the dome, having admitted that it was a failure. The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said: "When are we going to see any minister shoulder the responsibility for this catastrophic fiasco? The prime minister should start by sacking Lord Falconer, who is the sole shareholder in the failed dome company." The admission by senior cabinet ministers follows Clare Short's attack on the dome last week when she called it a flop and a disaster.

webTitle: Unmetered net access test fails to produce winner

fields.headline: Unmetered net access test fails to produce winner
fields.trailText: The first thorough test of unmetered internet access in the UK has opened a can of worms, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The first thorough test of unmetered internet access in the UK has opened a can of worms in terms of customer service and produced a climate of chaos and confusion.

Huge improvements are needed in this area, according to an in-depth two-month review by VNU-owned Uk.internet.com and TheITLabs.com.

The two companies tested eight of the UK's largest unmetered internet service providers and, unsurprisingly, were unable to identify an overall winner. However, two recommendation awards were made to 24-7 Freecall and Freeserve.

Another well-performing unmetered offering from Ezesurf, which was one of the best packages tested, has since been ditched.

The good and bad news for NTLWorld is that it would have won hands down if it had a realistic waiting list and more helpful technical support.

X-Stream, the UK's first subscription-free ISP and one of the first to adopt an unlimited model, was not included in the tests because it failed to respond to requests for a test account. The ISP, which was recently bought out by Libertysurf, is no longer taking new customers, according to the report.

The worst performing ISP was RedHotAnt, which the testers were unable to access at all due to continuously busy lines and an unobtainable helpdesk.

Telewest also scored badly, particularly in terms of helpdesk support.

"Companies promising unmetered services have the potential to dominate the UK ISP market, but only if they are able to deliver what they are promising. The quality of these services is crucially important for the growing number of businesses and remote teleworkers using the services," said Robert Jaques, editor of Uk.internet.com.

fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title Campaign Media Business.
fields.body:
Emap Advertising has gone through another restructure, prompted by the appointment of Zenith Media's Theresa Coligan as sales director and the departure of brand management director Julie Harris to Emap Digital. The brand management group is to be disbanded and the 16 sales staff integrated into the sale and agency team.

Former Times Newspapers deputy ad director Gary Savage is joining Associated Newspapers to run Metro's advertising sales operation.

FutureNet.com is to offer skyscraper banner ads (ads which run down the length of the screen) for the first time on its new electronics site T3network.co.uk.

IPC Media's NME is to appear in November as a masthead TV show on Bravo.

Agency buyers are disappointed by ITV2's, performance, with at least three major clients refusing to renew ad contracts.

Style magazine Wallpaper has booked £1.5m of ad revenue into its October issue - it's largest ever at 444 pages.

Carlton TV and Carlton Food Network have signed up Rosemary Conley to make a series of 30-minute programmes starting on January 1.

UPS, the official Olympic Games sponsor, is sponsoring the Daily Express and Sunday Express' Olympics coverage. The courier company's branding will appear on every page of the papers' Olympics sections.

fields.headline: Exorcist rises again, 27 years on
fields.trailText: The re-released Exorcist, with eleven minutes added to its original running time, stormed to second place in the American box office chart this weekend
fields.body:
The re-released Exorcist, with eleven minutes added to its original running time, stormed to second place in the American box office chart this weekend, turning a few heads in the process. "There's never been a movie this old," said a spokesman for Warner Bros, who have distributed the film, "that has come back to find this kind of success."

William Friedkin's 1973 chiller took $8.5m, bringing it into silver medal position this Olympic weekend after Urban Legends: Final Cut took gold with $8.8m, albeit on four times as many screens. Third behind the horror duo came Cameron Crowe's acclaimed Almost Famous. Britain's sleeper hit Saving Grace accrued another $700,000 to bring its US total to $10.8m.

Total takings for the weekend, at some $64m, constituted an improvement on last weekend's three-year low, but was down a massive 20% on the equivalent weekend last year, when Bruce Willis's Sixth Sense was riding high.

The Exorcist's success comes on a weekend when its writer, William Peter Blatty, was quoted as saying of the film's provenance, "its intended effect was to bring about spirituality and reinforcement of religious belief... It was never meant to scare anybody along the way." Hmmm.

fields.headline: Voters deliver blow to Milosevic
fields.standfirst: As votes are counted in the Yugoslav elections, Balkans expert Jonathan Steele says the Serbian leader's days in power are numbered
fields.trailText: As votes are counted in the Yugoslav elections, Balkans expert Jonathan Steele says the Serbian leader's days in power are numbered.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav electorate has thrown President Slobodan Milosevic into the biggest crisis of his 13 years of power.

The man who has always been able to cast himself as the true defender of Serbia's national interests against foreign enemies, whether they be Croats, Bosniacs, Albanians or Nato and the west, has suffered a heavy body-blow from his own people.

Whether he has lost the election outright is not yet clear. No official results have been announced, and there is an ominous pause in the counting.

But it is already obvious that far more people voted against him than he expected when he called the elections early and decided to submit himself to a popular vote for the first time since 1993.

Disarray in his own camp is palpable. His own party, the Socialist party of Serbia, is giving out a completely different set of preliminary findings from its ally, the party known as the Yugoslav Left, which is run by Milosevic's wife.

While the SPS claims that Milosevic has 44% of the vote against 41% for his main challenger, Vojislav Kostunica, officials of the Yugoslav Left put the gap between the two men at 25%.

To add to the confusion, the state news agency, Tanjug, has reported claims by the Radical party, another of Milosevic's government allies, that Milosevic is losing. Normally Tanjug suppreses bad news, so the fact that it is indicating that Milosevic is facing defeat means that the regime is either in a total quandary or split into rival camps.

Everyone in Serbia is now waiting to see how Milosevic reacts. One option which his prime minister floated at the weekend was that the president was entitled to stay in power until next summer to serve out his full term, even if he accepts he has lost the vote.

But this is constitutional nonsense. When you hold early elections, it means you are submitting yourself to the popular will. Otherwise why hold them early?

The more violent option is that he brazens it out, claims to have won, and puts down opposition protests with force. But that is unlikely to work. The fact that there is so much dissension within Milosevic's own camp over the results makes it hard for the police and army to be used as a political tool. Senior officers could mutiny.

After more than a decade, Serbia is finally in the end game of Milosevic's destructive rule. It took the west until the Kosovo crisis came to the boil two years ago to realise that he is not a reliable partner with whom to do business.

Now at last a significant part of the Serbian electorate has come to the same view. Milosevic has long tried to manipulate their emotions through his nationalistic wars and his control of the state-owned media.

The lesson of this election is that urban voters and the younger generation who have access to alternative sources of news as well as those Serbs who have close contacts with the huge Serbian diaspora abroad have given the dictator the thumbs-down.

webTitle: Hungry villagers attack relief teams in flood-hit India

fields.headline: Hungry villagers attack relief teams in flood-hit India
fields.trailText: Relief teams and troops on boats have been attacked by hungry mobs in flood-hit eastern India, where monsoon flooding has left at least 208 people dead and 165 missing.
fields.body:
Relief teams and troops on boats have been attacked by hungry mobs in flood-hit eastern India, where monsoon flooding has left at least 208 people dead and 165 missing.

"People were fighting with each other and attacking our men to make sure they got a place in the rescue boats," said a senior army official. Hundreds are stranded on rooftops and in trees as the boats can carry only 25 people at a time.

Police had to fire shots in the air to disperse an angry mob in Nadia, 150 km north of Calcutta, which had clashed with other police carrying food for flood victims.

In the worst-hit district of Murshidabad, 100 km further north, air force helicopters dropped food packets for marooned villagers, officials said. Relief officials are scheduled to meet later today to discuss the situation.

In West Bengal, as many as 800,000 houses have been washed over by flood waters causing about three billion rupees (about £41m) of damage, a government official said on Sunday.

The flooding, triggered by heavy annual monsoon rains, took a dramatic turn for the worse last week when the sluice gates of three major rivers were opened to prevent dams from bursting.

Torrential rains also lashed neighbouring Bihar state, where monsoon floods have killed 86 people in the past two months. Although river waters in the poverty-stricken province subsided in August, fresh downpours over the past six days have submerged large parts of the state.

Officials said many major rivers in the state such as the Ganga, Punpun, Sone and Phalgu were at dangerous levels.

Fresh floods also crippled Bihar's train services as vast stretches of the state's railway tracks were either uprooted or flooded. Hundreds of flood victims along with their cattle and poultry have taken shelter in stranded trains, some setting up makeshift kitchens inside the coaches.

webTitle: September 25: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Screen therapy for Dennis Quaid, Eszterhas holds steady on Farrah claim, and Julianne Moore evolves with David Duchovny
fields.body:
 Dennis Quaid (pictured) is reported to be exorcising the demons of his split with ex-wife Meg Ryan - who left the actor for current megastar Russell Crowe - by writing a screenplay about adultery. The film labours under the title Shame on You, and is said to feature a celebrity who murders his wife, whom he believes is having an affair. A spokesperson for the actor confirms that a script drawn from Quaid's recent experiences is in the pipeline. "I'm not going to say it's not true," says the mouthpiece. "All I will say is that a finished movie script is a bit premature."

 Basic Instinct scriptwriter Joe Eszterhas is sticking by claims made in his book American Rhapsody that former Charlie's Angel Farrah Fawcett once peed on the lawn at a prestigious industry party. The actress has, much to the world's amusement, vehemently denied the charge. "I sure don't see why," says Eszterhas, who recalls an occasion at the same venue when his own wife couldn't locate an available toilet. "I certainly understand the same thing could have happened to Farrah, and she couldn't get in - and nature called. May the Lord forgive me, but yes - Farrah did it!"

 Julianne Moore looks likely to appear in the Ivan Reitman comedy Evolution, with David Duchovny. The film is about a group of misfits who encounter an alien organism that lands in the New Mexico desert.

webTitle: Channel 4 freezes plans for gay portal

fields.headline: Channel 4 freezes plans for gay portal
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Channel 4 has abandoned plans to set up an internet portal aimed at the gay community
fields.body:
Channel 4 has abandoned plans to set up an internet portal aimed at the gay community - a project which had been identified by chief executive Michael Jackson as one of the company's key projects in new media.

A spokesman for Channel 4 said plans for the site, which had been scheduled to be launched over the summer, had been put on ice because of a lack of resources. The broadcaster recognised that the market for gay websites was one of the most competitive online.

"The site has been put on hold for the immediate future," he said. "It is not that we changed our minds, it is more about prioritising our investments when we have a limited amount of resources."

He said the development of an internet version of the pay television channel, E4, to begin in mid-January, would allay criticisms that the company was not committed to building an online presence.

A growing number of websites for the gay community have won financial backing.

Users often have a higher disposable income than average and research in the internet magazine, Industry Standard, noted that gay and lesbian people have a higher propensity to use the internet.

Earlier this month a British-based internet portal called Queer company raised £3.5m in funding, while the US portal Gay.com raised $23m (£15m) in June.

Channel 4 has a growing number of financial commitments on top of the core channel. It has announced that it will invest £100m in the start-up of E4, a general entertainment station which will feature the first runs of popular shows including the US series Friends and ER.

The company initially planned to seek outside investment, but then decided to fund the business itself.

Channel 4 is also still supporting FilmFour, its art house movie pay-TV business which last year lost £20m but is expected to break even in 2003.

webTitle: Noble Grossart chief denies being approached to buy the Scotsman

fields.headline: Noble Grossart chief denies being approached to buy the Scotsman
fields.standfirst: Andrew Neil hits back at Tim Luckhurst
fields.trailText: Noble Grossart's chairman denies reports that he was approached by ex-Scotsman editor Tim Luckhurst with a plan to buy the Scotsman.
fields.body:
The chairman of Noble Grossart has denied a story in this morning's Business AM that he was approached by former Scotsman editor Tim Luckhurst with a plan to buy the Scotsman.

Business AM claimed Luckhurst and Alan Ruddock canvassed support for a bid to buy the newspaper and merge it with rival the Herald.

The newspaper said Luckhurst's company, Solstrale Associates, proposed to buy the Scotsman, Scotland on Sunday, Edinburgh Evening News and Sunday Business for £175m, and the Herald group for £200m.

The paper also claims Luckhurst approached Sir Angus Grossart, chairman of merchant bank Noble Grossart which is an adviser to the Barclay twins, owners of the Scotsman, Scotland on Sunday, Edinburgh Evening News and Sunday Business,

But Sir Angus told MediaGuardian.co.uk the story was "totally untrue", adding "I don't believe I've ever met Mr Luckhurst."

Business AM, which launched last week, has taken a number of senior staff from the Scotsman and its launch has produced considerable acrimony between the two papers.
