webTitle: Journalists play new online game to vent frustration with PR fluff

fields.headline: Hacks play Whackaflack to combat fluff rage
fields.standfirst: Journalists, driven round the bend by technology PR agencies, are letting off steam with a new online game called Whackaflack.
fields.trailText: Journalists, driven round the bend by technology PR agencies, are letting off steam with a new online game called Whackaflack, write Damon Crane and Bridget Fishleigh.
fields.body:
"Hunkered down behind the safety of a cubicle wall, you are equipped with an arsenal of badly written and boring press releases which have been folded into paper airplanes. Your job is to send them back to their makers! Shoot the paper airplanes one at a time at the PR flacks that pop up from behind their cubicles - everyone knows that a flack can't stay out of sight for too long."

So read the instructions for Whackaflack.com, a new online game in which infuriated hacks can vent their frustration on some 20 large and boutique tech PR agencies for a catalogue of crimes and irritating character traits, from the annoying and clueless, to the plain pushy and arrogant.

The technology PR business has grown and changed beyond recognition in recent years as CEOs working in a marketplace crowded with products and services that are either very complex or very similar, increasingly identify PR as being the most cost-effective element of their marketing mix.

Meanwhile, journalists in the burgeoning and ever-fragmented technology media market are increasingly being forced by publishers to boost readership figures and make more money, with fewer resources.

The press gravy train of old has been derailed. These days there simply isn't time to spend three days at The EuroDisney Hilton learning about the new IBM storage solution. But do tech PR agencies really deserve such a bad rap from their buddies in the press?

Kate Nicholas, editor of the industry bible PR Week, says: "PR has evolved and media relations is just one element of the industry these days. In the past five years we've seen PR companies taking a more strategic role and acting almost as management consultants to client CEOs, but journalists often don't see that.

"The problem has come, Nicholas says, because PR agencies have traditionally promoted their brightest talent into these strategic positions from the front line of media relations - which leaves the inexperienced, less knowledgeable or plain inept to pitch the media every day. No wonder Whackaflack has become so popular.

Stan Woods, MD of tech agency Brodeur, says: "Media relations is a punishing job. You have to deal with a lot of arrogance and rudeness. It's really no place for a college leaver."

Simon Hill, MD of Connors UK, is a gamekeeper turned poacher, having spent 13 years working as a journalist. "Most PR pros suffer from having not worked in journalism," he says. "Like all journalists I received my fair share of bad pitches, and one thing I will say is that journalists have long memories and tend to remember times when flacks have pitched them a stupid story, not known the subject, or just called at the wrong time."

Not surprisingly, the greatest cause for amusement, apathy and anger among the journalistic fraternity is the poor standard of writing churned out by PR agencies. At the lower levels of the PR totem pole, client-agency pressure is often to blame for poor writing skills, says Jo Chipchase a freelance journalist who left PR. "The editorial agenda is set either by the client or by the in-house account directors who just want to churn out press releases as efficiently as possible with a cookie-cutter style approach. That lack of creativity was one reason why I left the industry and became a writer."

Chipchase is not alone in her opinion. Buzzkiller.net is yet another site that has sprung up, naming and shaming hapless flacks, along with their inane pitches and frequent murdering of the English language. Only now, it seems, is the tech PR industry coming round to the fact that they cannot execute any type of PR strategy without excellent writing and media relations. Chipchase says she knows of several agencies which now use creative writing as their major selling point.

Hill admits that his company is perfectly willing to employ people who do "nothing but write" so great is its importance, and Nicholas is witnessing agencies devoting more talent and experience to media relations every week.

Daryl Wilcox, a former IT journalist, now chief executive of Sourcewire.com - an online resource for both journalists and PR pros which posts journalistic enquiries to the PR community - points out that it's not all one-way traffic. "I hate to say it, but the performance threshold for journalism is simply not as high as in a PR agency where you have pressure from all sides - clients, the agency's management and the press," Wilcox says. "Even in these days of intense competition between titles, many journalists are inherently lazy and rely on PRs massively, even though they hate to admit it. I've heard hacks yell down the phone at flacks because they were 'not being serviced properly'."

It's what Woods calls the "sausage factory" approach: You put out a press release, the journalist rewrites it and publishes it the following day. "When I was an IT journalist I'd be meeting VPs of large companies every week, and while they rambled on, I'd just be thinking, "I wonder how many multiples of my wage you earn?" webTitle: Designers vie to set record for dearest dress

fields.headline: Designers vie to set record for dearest dress
fields.trailText: It is usually just the celebrities who are flanked by bodyguards during London Fashion Week - but this season, the largest security teams will be those watching over the dresses.
fields.body:
It is usually just the celebrities who are flanked by bodyguards during London Fashion Week - but this season, the largest security teams will be those watching over the dresses.

London's reputation as a poor relation of the fashion capitals of Milan and Paris is about to be vanquished with two designers vying for the cachet of showing the most expensive dress ever on a British catwalk.

Julien Macdonald and Maria Grachvogel are two of the most publicity-hungry characters in the London fashion scene. Macdonald's revealing clothes ensure him plenty of publicity: he created the dress and matching knickers that Kelly Brook wore to the premiere of the film Snatch.

In February Grachvogel, who is popular among society ladies but seldom listed among fashion's most innovative talents, made the front pages by persuading Victoria Beckham to grace her catwalk.

It was Grachvogel who fired the opening shot yesterday in the race to reveal the million-pound dress. Her show, staged in Harrods, was originally due to take place on Wednesday but was brought forward at the last minute.

The dress everyone had come to see was modelled by Jodie Kidd, and comprised a seamed black bodice fastened with belt buckles, and floor- length black chiffon skirt, slit thigh-high. Scattered over the dress were 2,000 cut diamonds, each set in 18 carat white gold. Because of the value of the diamonds, which had been lent by jewellers Van Peterson, the dress was to be driven away in a security van within minutes of Kidd taking it off.

Tonight Macdonald, a 29-year-old Welshman, will attempt to steal back the limelight with a black lace minidress featuring a shoulderpiece of more than 1,000 cut diamonds. It is rumoured that Elizabeth Jagger, 16-year-old daughter of Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall, will wear the gown.

There is some dispute over the value of Grachvogel's dress, which will now be auctioned in aid of the Nelson Mandela children's fund.

The designer's spokespeople said that it was "the equivalent of 1,000 pairs of VanPeterson.com diamond stud earrings, which retail at £800 each", giving a value of £800,000 for the stones alone. Other sources, however, put the value at £250,000.

Macdonald claims that his dress, which is the result of a collaboration with De Beers, is worth £1m, although even this does not beat the record for the most expensive dress on a catwalk. That is held by the Italian designer Antonio d'Amico, companion of the late Gianni Versace, who last year showed a dress featuring £1.3m worth of jewels.

What £1m would buy

40,000 blouses from Top Shop (£25 each)

6,250 wool skirts by Alexander McQueen (£160 each)

772 dresses by Matthew Williamson (£1,295 each)

1,142 duffle coats by Louis Vuitton (£875 each)

684 dress coats by Coco Chanel (£1,460 each)

8,333 dresses from Karen Millen (£120 each)

2,597 dresses by Betty Jackson (£385 each)

699 wool evening coats by Gucci (£1,430 each)

fields.headline: From front room to front row
fields.standfirst: It's a big hit on the small screen and now Sex and the City is stalking the catwalk.    Jess Cartner-Morley  reports from the New York shows
fields.trailText: It's a big hit on the small screen and now Sex and the City is stalking the catwalk. Jess Cartner-Morley reports from the New York shows
fields.body:
Who were the stars of New York fashion week? There was simply no contest. Neither Ralph nor Calvin, Donna nor Gisele, nor even front row compadres Puff Daddy and Donald Trump could compete with four diminutive actresses who have American fashion at their feet. Stars of every front row they graced, Sarah Jessica Parker and her co-stars in HBO's hit TV show Sex and the City are without doubt having a fashion moment. The whole of New York wants to dress like Sex and the City. In fact, the whole of America wants to dress like Sex and the City.

Oscar de la Renta could not have hoped for better publicity than Parker, who plays the show's protagonist Carrie, telling the reporters hanging on her every word after his show that she "loved it", wanted "to wear it all".

Kristin Davis, aka uptight art dealer Charlotte, gracefully acknowledged the extent of her influence by diplomatically rushing home to her Upper West Side apartment between shows to change from the head-to-toe Ralph Lauren she wore for Ralph's show into a Michael Kors red satin and tweed ensemble for Michael's show. "I'm only going to shows I like," she declared regally, smoothing her MK logo pencil skirt for the cameras. The only woman who could divert the attention of the American press from Parker, Davis et al was Patricia Field - not an actress, nor even a model, but chief costume designer for the show and, therefore, a king-maker.

The Sex and the City look is sophisticated but not uptight, provocative but knowing. Short skirts worn with tiny vintage T-shirts or rock-chick glam coats. Stratospherically high, spindly sandals in bright colours worn with lean hipster trousers. Slivers of body-hugging cashmere. Touches of ironic trashiness, like the gold name necklaces that had to be dropped because they launched such a huge following that they turned into a cliché. America wants this look and in economic boomtime is prepared to pay through the nose for it. And the designers are more than happy to oblige. The upshot, as seen on this week's catwalks: hemlines that would make Kelly Brook blush. Evangelical devotion to the modern woman's religion, shoe fetishism. And an obsession with marrying cash with trash for the requisite "groupie on spring break from finishing school" look.

Like Stella McCartney, Daryl Kerrigan has the knack of knowing exactly how young women want to look. "She just gets it," as one devotee sighed after her show. Clever and cool, the Daryl Klabel epitomises the femininity-with-an-edge look of which Sarah Jessica Parker is the poster girl and this collection was right up to speed: a spine of tight pleats down a pair of low-rise, long-legged trousers, a tiny pelmet skirt balanced by an easy off-the-shoulder top, neutral cream and black offset with metallic gold and rust.

Similarly, at DKNY a sharp, sassy collection pivoted on slim, low-rise trousers gathered at the ankle and belt-width skirts in denim or leather. Instead of 80s-style bustiers or boob tubes, these were worn with fluid, sequin-smothered vests in bronze or sky blue.

Elsewhere, the 80s revival that fashion has for some seasons now seemed unable to shake off wielded a heavier hand. There were ra-ra skirts at Marc Jacobs and mini puffballs at Oscar de la Renta, while at Anna Sui, the combination of long lace gloves, leather belts on the hips, poodle bows in the hair and Camden Market dangly earrings was alarmingly similar to Bananarama singing Robert De Niro's Waiting on Top of the Pops. Helmut Lang, however, achieved the seemingly impossible by producing a heavily 80s-referenced show that was both modern and sexy. Known for somewhat austere, cerebral designs, Lang turned up the sex appeal with this collection, entitled When Love Comes To Town. The tight, bandage-strapped jersey dresses and vest tops were reminiscent of Azzedine Alaïa and Hervé Léger, but the shades of cream, black, flesh and beige, and the precision-cut leather coats and dresses, were pure Lang.

Within two days of the start of the collections, the trade press were pronouncing turquoise the new black. Randolph Duke themed his collection around the colour of the sea in different parts of the world, while turquoise also featured in two of the most colourful shows of the week, the nostalgic candy-store palette of Marc Jacobs and Hussein Chalayan's block-printed designs for Tse. The vivid geometry of the Tse collection was inspired, Chalayan explained with characteristic directness, by "a circle, a square and a triangle".

At Joop!, prints were a similar combination of sweeping curves and hard angles, creating what looked like a colourful astronomical map, reminiscent of the abstract patterns of classic Louis Feraud. At Oscar de la Renta, Marc Jacobs and Ralph Lauren, meanwhile, the graphics were restricted to diagonal stripes.

Ralph Lauren bucked the colour trend with a collection entirely in white, black and chocolate brown. Shapes were elegant and simple, brought to life with contrast trims and the addition of "Coco Chanel at Deauville" touches, pearls and neckerchiefs. Compared with some of the more left-field shows, this was hardly edge of the seat stuff - shift dresses just don't make great theatre. But judging from the reaction of the audience, who met every pencil skirt and turtleneck with gasps of rapture, it is sure to sell and sell.

Michael Kors is another hugely successful American designer whose clients have a taste for discreet luxury and the money to indulge it. If you have several thousand dollars to spend on a powder-puff soft cashmere wrap cardigan, perfect for turning an evening in front of the TV into a style statement, Kors is your man. This collection, entitled Desert Divas, was the week's strongest showcase for a Wild West theme which is tipped to dethrone fashion's long-term love affair with all things oriental. Buttery suede palazzo pants, duck-egg blue bikinis, stetsons and mink-lined leather jackets were perfect for Upper East Side cowgirls.

Last but not least, fashionistas played the inevitable game of "spot the decade". With designers seemingly picking out and chewing up decades like penny sweets, it can be hard to keep up - unless, of course, you have a team of wardrobe assistants out there scouring charity stores day and night to find the perfect oh-my-god-where-did-you-get-that vintage Yves Saint Laurent for your next episode. With the 80s still breathing down our necks, another era is emerging for spring: the 50s. Marc Jacobs' collection, his most effervescent for some seasons, had a milkshake-sweet 50s flavour with satin bomber jackets, girlish French horizontal striped T-shirts and full-skirted day dresses with sweetheart necklines.

Chaiken, best known for their hip-slimming trousers, showed demure circle skirts; Christina Perrin featured cropped trousers and St Tropez cap-sleeve shirts; Michael Kors and Oscar de la Renta both did flirty broderie anglaise sundresses; and even Betsey Johnson's Playmate models squeezed gamely into gingham dresses and sailor-striped tops. The million dollar question, of course, is will it catch on? Well, you'll just have to wait until the next series to find out.

fields.headline: All the media stories from today's papers
fields.standfirst: Sign up for the daily email cuttings service, Media Briefing, by emailing: briefing@mediaguardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Channel 4 has abandoned plans for a gay portal, one of the channel's key new media projects. The portal has been put on ice because of lack of resources. Media Guardian. (p20)

MEDIA GUARDIAN

Back with a bong. Just as Bobby Ewing emerged from the shower in Dallas, Trevor McDonald should slide behind the ITN newsdesk at 10pm in January and everyone can pretend he never went away. Regarding the tricky question of the name, it seems ITV is not going to revert back to News at Ten, but instead stick with the ITV Nightly News. (p2-3)

Advertising industry applauds decision to move the news back to 10pm, particularly the bit where it says ITV (and other terrestrial channels) gets an extra 2.5 minutes of advertising in peaktime per day. (p3)

The decision to move the news was all a matter of timing, oh, and of course the new boss of the ITC, Patricia Hodgson. (p4)

Death by celebrity. Roy Greenslade talks of his first meeting with Paula Yates 20 years ago. (p8)

Scotsman editor in chief Andrew Neil hits back at Tim Luckhurst, former editor of the Scotsman, who last week criticised the Scottish newspaper scene. Neil can't help but have a sly pop at new rival Business AM, whose "debut on Wednesday verged on farce. Printing problems meant most of the guests at the Edinburgh launch party had gone by the time the first edition arrived at 1am, over two hours late." (p9)

Targeted ads are the way forward, says Peter Bazalgette, creative director of Endemol Entertainment. (p10)

NEW MEDIA GUARDIAN

Photographers are creating their own picture agencies alone. (p64)
Chris Cramer of CNN's "My new media" reveals he spends 10 hours a day on the web. (p64)
How to sell words online. (p62)

FINANCIAL TIMES

The Post Office is backing a scheme to introduce digital signatures at branches, following a joint venture with internet start-up UK Smart. (p25)

Lord Borrie is to replace Lord Rogers, who is retiring after six years, at the helm of the Advertising Standards Authority. Borrie takes over as chairman in January. (p16)

THE MIRROR

Paula Yates was on the verge of a TV comeback, say the 3am girls, with an agony aunt show on BBC Choice. (p19)

THE SUN

"Snog pair" Mel and Andy from Big Brother are spotted by a Sun photographer on a "secret date". The couple are pictured, er, harmlessly walking down the street together, but they did seem to be getting on very well, said an onlooker. Mel ate ravioli and Andy had a Thai beef salad.(p11)

Channel 5 is planning a 13-part series where celebrities plan their own funerals, called It's Your Funeral. Already lined up are Leslie Joseph and Brian Blessed. Sounds like a sure-fire ratings winner. (p11)

Radio 1 DJ Chris Moyles has fired manager Bruno Brookes because, a station source said, he looked too much like Keith Chegwin. (p19)

DAILY MAIL

Mariella Frostrup's friends says the BBC played a blinder by getting her to present Panoroma because she knows TV inside out. (p15)

DAILY EXPRESS

The BBC is planning a £20m drive to woo back viewers. BBC Sport will use a budget of £150m to give snooker and golf a makeover, as part of Peter Salmon's drive to make the most of the sports rights the BBC has. Watch out for jazzy new graphics and jingles. (p20)

THE TIMES

Leisure group Rank is poised to sell its holiday division, which comprises Butlins to Bourne Leisure Group. (p22)

And Finally...

DAILY STAR

Telly chiefs were disappointed there was no sex in Big Brother, and next time plan to install more flirts and extroverts in the house. (p3)
Madonna is to star in the film version of Red Dwarf. (p10)

fields.body:
Liverpool look like they have overtaken Barcelona in the race to sign Croatian international Igor Biscan, a player who has been dubbed "the new Frank Rijkaard". Planet Football claims the 22-year-old midfielder secretly travelled to Merseyside last week with Dinamo Zagreb director Velmir Zajec, and that Gerard Houllier could pip the Catalan giants with an £8.23m deal.

Planet Football are also reporting that Celta Vigo midfielder Gustavo Lopez has rejected a move to Chelsea. "I am happy here," admitted Lopez. "My representative has said something to me but I immediately asked him not to tell me more because I don't want to be distracted from what I am now doing."

Chelsea might have more luck chasing Sol Campbell, with new coach Claudio Ranieri admitting an interest. "Campbell is one of the best central defenders in Europe," he said. "He is strong, skilful and has a good brain. I think most coaches would like him, especially for nothing."

Bryan Robson has made a sneaky £5m bid for former Blackburn target Lucien Mettomo, reports the Mirror. They say that the Cameroon international is expected for talks at Middlesbrough today - and he could move by the end of the week.

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is lining up a bid for Blackburn's Christian Dailly because of the increasing injury crisis at the club, reports Teamtalk.

Steve Bould will announce this week that he is retiring.

webTitle: Church of Labour, broad or otherwise, prays harder

fields.headline: Church of Labour, broad or otherwise, prays harder
fields.standfirst: In the first instalment of his conference diary, Labour MP Ben Bradshaw gives an insider's insight into Conference 2000
fields.trailText: In the first instalment of his conference diary, Labour MP Ben Bradshaw gives an insider's insight into Conference 2000
fields.body:
 Curtain raiser for this year's conference: the left leaning IPPR's political "Oscars and turkeys" award.

The venue, appropriately, Brighton Aquarium, complete with live as well as journalistic sharks.

Among the Oscar winners, the comprehensive spending review and Saint Mo. Turkeys went to the Dome and vouchers for asylum seekers.

The loudest boos, though, were reserved for the compere, chain-smoking Observer journalist Andrew Rawnsley, whose recent book has done more damage than all the Government's turkeys.

 The annual Christian Socialist Movement Eucharist - a "service of reconciliation" - at Brighton's St Peter's Church. Tony and Cherie attended as usual, along with a clutch of ministers and conference delegates. A reflection of New Labour's "broad Church", with incense and song and a sermon from the head of the Evangelical Alliance (not to be confused with the Christian Institute or any of those other nasty, right wing Christian groups.)

The Church was fuller this year. It looks like Labour's praying harder.

 Saint Mo dominated proceedings again inside the conference hall with her farewell speech. The only Labour politician apart from the prime minister guaranteed a standing ovation. She still won't tell us why she is giving up British politics, except she's 50 and wants to do "something else" before it's too late.

She does have the grace to stay on the platform long enough to present the Exeter Labour Party with this year's prize for being the best organised in the country (I'm the MP for Exeter).

 On the fringe, Peter Mandelson produces his best pro-European speech to date as well as his strongest attack on the Tories. One of the consolations of being behind in the polls is that people are beginning to take the nightmare possibility of a Hague government seriously.

 It wouldn't be Labour Party conference without a Socialist Workers Party demo. They've stopped chanting; "Whadda we wan? - sooooowcialism - when da we wannit? - naaaaa". But you have to hand it to the Trots - they can still produce huge numbers of identical hand held placards on the latest "ishoo" apparently overnight.

fields.headline: EU brands Milosevic victory claims 'fraudulent'
fields.standfirst:  Calls for leader to 'get out of the way'
fields.trailText: Any claim from Yugoslav President Sloboban Milosevic that he had won the country's elections would be a fraud, the European Union said today.
fields.body:
Any claim from Yugoslav President Sloboban Milosevic that he had won the country's elections would be a fraud, the European Union said today.

While the final result is not yet known, the vote has been plagued with accusations of ballot rigging and intimidation, and the joint statement from the 15-nation union made it clear that any attempt Mr Milosevic made to claim a victory would be viewed as false.

It said: "According to all available information, it is clear that any attempt by Milosevic to declare himself the victor would be fraudulent" and in a reference to the large turnout, which the union said showed the people of Serbia wanted change, it added, "they wanted to speak up, regardless of intimidation, manoeuvring, pressure and all sorts of manipulation by the Belgrade regime leading up to this ballot."

The EU statement came on the day the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, called for Mr Milosevic to stand down after new figures showed he had in fact lost the country's presidential elections.

Mr Cook, in Brighton for the Labour Party Conference, told delegates "all the reliable evidence" available showed Mr Milosevic would be voted out "by a massive majority" and he urged the leader to "get out of the way" and allow his opponent to take up the mantle.

The results on a third of the polling stations around Serbia suggested opposition candidate Vojislav Kostunica had polled 57% of the votes and Mr Milosevic only 33%. Mr Milosevic and his supporters, however, claim he has a lead and his 13-year rule would continue.

Mr Milosevic was a "beaten, broken-backed" president, Mr Cook told reporters, adding: "My message to him today is be honest with your people, don't cheat them, get out of the way and let Serbia get out of the prison into which you have turned it."

But Mr Milosevic showed no signs of conceding defeat after an election marked by a huge turnout - and allegations of fraud and ballot-rigging.

His spokesman in Belgrade, Nikola Sainovic, said he doubted there would even be a need for a run-off vote - required if no candidate gets more than 50% - because "our candidate is leading".

Voting was yesterday plagued by reports of blatant irregularities by Mr Milosevic backers, including ballot box stuffing, according to the few domestic monitors watching the polls.

But Kostunica said after the voting: "According to our count, the first-round victory is certain. Dawn is coming to Serbia. I'm excited."

There were 7,861,327 eligible voters in Yugoslavia, of whom 444,130 were in Montenegro, Serbia's smaller sister republic. There were around 10,000 polling stations in all.

A candidate needs more than 50 percent of the vote to win outright without having to contest a second round.

webTitle: 'Hilary and Jackie' team gamble on Caine remake

fields.headline: 'Hilary and Jackie' team gamble on Caine remake
fields.trailText: The creative team behind 1998's Hilary and Jackie are to produce two new films for Universal Pictures
fields.body:
The creative team behind 1998's Hilary and Jackie, for which Emily Watson was Oscar-nominated for her role as cellist Jacqueline du Pré, are to produce two new films for Universal Pictures, reports Daily Variety.

Director Anand Tucker (pcitured) will take the reins first on a remake of the 1966 Michael Caine/Shirley Maclaine crime flick Gambit, and then on a new film version of the life of Cleopatra. The films will be Tucker's first since he won Best Director, for Hilary and Jackie, at the British Independent Film Awards in 1999.

Gambit tells the story of a con man who needs a female partner to embroider his latest scam but who, on meeting the lady in question, gets more than he expected. Details of Tucker's Cleopatra project, meanwhile, are sketchy. Film-makers have fought shy of the Egyptian queen since the notorious Richard Burton/Elizabeth Taylor flop back in 1963.

Tucker will work on both pictures with Hilary and Jackie screenwriter Frank Cottrell Boyce and producer Andrew Paterson. The trio - who together form the production house Archer Street - are also at work on the film The Railway Man, based on the true story of a British PoW in the second world war.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Week six in Football Unlimited's attempt to beat the bookies. Blue Square's Patrick Murray thinks he's getting somewhere with our pundits. Sort of
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £107.41
Sean Ingle = £98.42
Paul MacInnes = £83.80
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £67.50
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £107.41
Sean Ingle = £98.42
Paul MacInnes = £83.80
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £67.50

Scott Murray
Chelsea to beat Manchester United £5 @ 4/1

We've all seen it time and again, a new manager walks in the door and suddenly teams that couldn't string together three passes in a row are transformed into world beaters. Indeed we've seen it so often that we expect it, we see a new manager and we expect their new team to play a blinder on Saturday, remembering all the times it has happened before (and forgetting all the times it hadn't).

This is not to say the expectation is entirely fallacious - I'm sure it isn't - just that it is entirely predictable and as such your friendly bookie will have got there before you yet again and artificially shortened that team up in expectation of a flood of money. Had Vialli still been in charge I doubt very much if a badly out of sorts Chelsea side would have been as short as 4/1 to do what no team has done in the league since 1998, namely beat Manchester United at Old Trafford.

I applaud Mr Murray's intention in staying away from the all too obvious odds-ons, looking for value rather than winners, but fear he has fallen into another trap by going for the obvious outsider. The secret to finding value is in avoiding the obvious, seeing something the bookie won't see. And on this occasion, I fear, that was not the case - though Chelsea certainly gave Mr Murray a run for his money.

Paul MacInnes
Preston to win at half time against Sheffield Wednesday. £5 @ 3/1

One has to have sympathy for the unfortunate Mr MacInnes - he did almost everything right. First he identified a bad favourite, namely a Sheffield Wednesday side out of form and low on confidence but still a big enough name to attract mug money. Next he found an underrated outsider in Preston, newly promoted, unfashionable, but so far looking comfortable playing First Division football. Then he put the two together with a little help from the fixture computer, reached into his metaphorical wallet and slapped his money on the metaphorical counter.

But then, alas, somehow, it all went horribly wrong. Greed got the better of him. 9/4 about Preston winning wasn't good enough for him, he wanted more and he wanted it now. So he went for the 3/1 available on Preston to be winning at half-time.

Half-time score 1-0; full-time score 1-3. Say no more.

Sean Ingle
Manchester United v Chelsea to draw @ 9/4; West Ham to beat Coventry @ 7/4; Aston Villa to beat Middlesbrough @ 7/4 and Blackburn to draw with Bolton 9/4. Four £1 trebles and one £1 accumulator.

It had to happen someday, I knew that, but somehow nothing could prepare me for the full horror of one of Sean's trebles coming in. I feel empty and worthless, everything I believe in lying in tatters upon the floor. Soon you will all be doing trebles and backing draws convinced this is the way forward, all my advice will be forgotten and once more the bookies' coffers will be bulging to bursting point. (Actually that doesn't sound too bad, they do pay my wages after all).

For an investment of just five pounds sterling Mr Ingle made a tidy profit of almost twenty five pounds and it would have been a lot more had it not been for an 89th minute Alpay own goal at the Riverside Stadium (never mind that the Bolton equaliser was in the 88th). And then surely we would never have heard the end of it.

And there is definite hope for the future. Mr I does seem to have weaned himself off odds-on shots, at least for the moment, and to be looking for value, bad favourites to oppose, underrated teams to support and so forth. But he does insist on minimising his chances of winning by putting them all in multiples.

But enough. Mr I, in one fell swoop, has got back almost all the money he has frittered away over the opening weeks of the season and for that he must be congratulated. The trick now is to build upon this. Mr Ingle - destiny awaits, do not let us down.

Football Unlimited Punter's Collective: Ben Taylor, contract manager
Aston Villa to beat Middlesbrough @ 7/4, Liverpool to beat Sunderland @ 2/5, Tottenham to beat Manchester City @ 4/7. £5 treble.

Its those odds-on trebles again. I try, Lord knows I try, but they don't listen.

Enough, I grow weary, dear punter. Search for value. Avoid the obvious. Stick to singles. Its for your own good.

fields.headline: Obituary: Dorothy Emmet
fields.standfirst: Philosopher who taught Plato to unemployed Welsh miners and helped to create Manchester university's philosophy department
fields.trailText: Professor Dorothy Emmet, who has died aged 95, was a distinguished philosopher who headed the department of philosophy at Manchester university for over 20 years; she built it up from a handful of students and a single lecturer to 400 students and a strong and varied staff.
fields.body:
Professor Dorothy Emmet, who has died aged 95, was a distinguished philosopher who headed the department of philosophy at Manchester university for over 20 years; she built it up from a handful of students and a single lecturer to 400 students and a strong and varied staff.

Emmet's father was a scholarly country parson in West Hendred, Berkshire, who encouraged wide reading and discussion; she was taught by him, and a governess, until she was in her teens; then, in 1918, she went to St Mary's Hall, Brighton, where the headmistress emphasised the importance of precision in the use of words. She later remarked this was "not a bad background for philosophy".

In 1923 she went to Lady Margaret Hall, Oxford, to study classics and philosophy. She was influenced by AD Lindsay (whose concern to link intellectual and practical issues in political philosophy made such a lasting impression that she once described herself as "a step- daughter of Balliol"), RG Collingwood, HA Pritchard (whose agonising over moral problems appealed to her), and J Macmurray. During the general strike of 1926, she heard RH Tawney speak on behalf of the miners, and towards the end of her life she said that this gave her "the nearest thing I have ever had to a conversion experience". From then on her interest in philosophy was combined with a serious concern about political and social issues.

For several years she spent part of her vacations tutoring for the WEA summer school at Balliol. After graduation, she joined the Maesynhaf Settlement in the Rhondda valley, teaching classes, largely based on Plato, to unemployed miners, many of whom were strongly influenced by Marxism. There were vigorous arguments about morals, politics and economics. One student looked after the books she had brought from Oxford; he was George Thomas, later Speaker of the Commons.

From 1928 to 1930, Emmet held a Commonwealth Fellowship at Radcliffe College and attended a graduate seminar held by AN Whitehead, whose thought attracted her to Cambridge, Massachusetts. On returning to England, she held a temporary teaching post at Somerville College, Oxford, had another spell in the Rhondda, and produced her first book, Whitehead's Philosophy of Organism (1932), in which she attempted to demystify his puzzling terminology and ideas.

Emmet was appointed lecturer in philosophy at Armstrong College, Newcastle-upon-Tyne (now the University of Newcastle) in 1932. She later described the department as one man and his dog: she was the dog. The department had to cover the whole range of philosophy, but she also managed to include several courses in political philosophy.

In 1938, she moved to Manchester as lecturer in the philosophy of religion, becoming reader in philosophy in 1945 and the Sir Samuel Hall professor of philosophy in 1946. During her early wartime years at Manchester, she took her turn fire-watching, and used to describe how classes began with people sharing their air-raid stories of the night before. She used the quieter nights towards the end of the war to write The Nature of Metaphysical Thinking (1945). In it, she responded to the criticisms of logical positivists by suggesting that metaphysics uses concepts analogically to develop a plausible way of interpreting the world.

In more than 20 years at Manchester, she showed grace and charm as well as practical wisdom and firmness in dealing with the business of the department and, as dean of arts from 1962 to 1964, with that of the faculty. Her question was: "But, then, why play the game?"

Since Emmet was convinced that philosophy had much to contribute to the study of other subjects, she encouraged the establishment of joint honours schools and enthusiastically developed links with colleagues in the departments of government, economics and anthropology. Her activities were not confined to Manchester. She gave the annual philosophical lecture to the British Academy in 1949, the Stanton lectures in Cambridge in 1950-53, and was president of the Aristotelian Society in 1953-54.

Her philosophical interests in social and political affairs resulted in Function, Purpose and Powers (1958) and Rules, Roles and Relations (1966). In The Moral Prism (1979), she returned to the complexity of individual moral decisions, considering how reliable moral judgments are to be made when there is no single moral theory that adequately solves all problems. Later, she returned to earlier interests in The Effectiveness of Causes (1986), The Passage of Nature (1992), and The Role of the Unrealisable (1994). In 1996 she produced a series of delightful cameos and penetrating comments in her book Philosophers and Friends: Reminiscences of 70 Years in Philosophy.

She became a regular member of the Moral Sciences Club and, as one of the Epiphany Philosophers, was involved in the publication of the journal, Theoria to Theory. She was elected an emeritus fellow of Lucy Cavendish Hall in Cambridge and an honorary fellow of Lady Margaret Hall.

Her last paper there was given in 1994, when she addressed the question "Could God be a Person?" - her delight in probing ideas was just as evident as ever. fields.headline: Big Brother website ranks eighth most popular
fields.trailText: The official Big Brother website's unprecedented growth in July was even more impressive in August.
fields.body:
The official Big Brother website's unprecedented growth in July was even more impressive in August, according to the latest batch of home usage figures from internet reach specialist MMXI Europe.

In August, BigBrother.terra.com was the eighth most popular website in the UK, reaching more than 17.8% (1.9m unique visitors) of the home internet population. The site entered the rankings in July at number 26.

The impact on Channel 4's website was noticeable, with more than 1.3m unique visitors hitting Channel4.com, boosting the site up to number 16 in the August chart.

The rest of the top ten chart for August showed little change, with MSN, Yahoo! and Freeserve leading the way in first, second and third place respectively. In the latest sector rankings from MMXI Europe, Barclays.co.uk has ousted Egg.com from the number one spot in the business and finance category it has relished since the start of the year.

Barclays.co.uk has moved from third place to pole position, increasing its unique visitors from 460,000 in July to 641,000 in August - an overall reach of 5.9% of home users.

Another Barclays brand, Barclaycard.co.uk, this month also experienced significant growth, moving from tenth place in July to fifth place in August, with 300,000 unique visitors.

Lloydstsb.com is now the second most popular UK among home users, with 583,000 unique visitors, and a 5.4% reach, in August.

Other movers in the business and finance category include Directline.com, making its top ten debut, and Egg.com, which is level pegging with Lloydstsb.com in terms of home reach.

A new entry to the category in August was Rapidinsure.co.uk, which achieved 142,000 unique visitors and ranked 15th.

More than 3.4m UK internet users are banking, insuring and investing online on a regular basis, making it the eighth most popular category overall.

webTitle: Redstone Telecom seeks access to BT exchanges

fields.headline: Redstone Telecom seeks access to BT's local exchanges
fields.trailText: 10.00am: Redstone Telecom has applied for access to BT's local exchanges to provide SDSL services to business customers, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Redstone Telecom has applied for access to 1,250 local exchanges run by rival operator BT.

The telecoms firm said it plans to provide Symmetrical Digital Subscriber Line (SDSL) services to 80% of Britain's small and medium-sized enterprises next year.

Oftel, the telecoms regulator, has faced criticism from BT's rivals for allegedly allowing the former state-owned operator to drag its feet over opening up its local exchanges to competing services.

fields.headline: BT to float 20% of shares in BT Wireless
fields.trailText: BT is this week expected to announce plans to float part of its mobile phone subsidiary.
fields.body:
BT is this week expected to give the City some much-needed good news by announcing plans to float part of its mobile phone subsidiary.

Press reports state the company is set to release 20% of the shares in its mobile phone business BT Wireless, raising £8bn in the process. BT is under pressure to reduce its debts, which will reach £30bn next year due to the massive cost of acquiring third-generation mobile phone licences in Europe.

Analysts have for some time been calling for the flotation of BT Wireless, saying a restructured BT is worth around 1250p a share, against the current level of below 800p.

BT's shares have been hit by complaints over the pace at which it is opening up its telephone exchanges for broadband internet access, and a profit warning from US telecoms group Sprint.

BT is holding a strategic review of all its businesses, which will finish by the end of the year. The company will select businesses for flotation or sale, with internet portal Excite and yellow pages service Yell among the candidates.

"Nothing is ruled in and nothing is ruled out," said a BT spokesperson. "We are evaluating all the businesses in terms of the possibility of flotations, and that process is ongoing."

The speculation was warmly received on the stock market, with BT's shares ring 3.8% to 763p in early trading.

fields.trailText: Technology channel .tv has appointed a new head of programming, reports Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Technology channel .tv has announced the appointment of Gay Flashman as its head of programming.

Flashman replaces Stephanie Couillard who was promoted to channel head earlier in the year. Flashman joins from BBC Knowledge, where she was programming executive. She has also worked on Channel 5's 5 News bulletin.

Couillard said that Flashman "brings a wealth of experience and new ideas to the channel, and through her innovative approach, will take [.tv]'s unique programme offering to the next level".

webTitle: What the advertisers make of News at Ten's return

fields.headline: What the advertisers make of News at Ten's return
fields.trailText: While David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, may be championing News at Ten's return as a "real win for viewers", the ad industry is finally seeing an end to much of the uncertainty that has surrounded the channel's schedule.
fields.body:
While David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, may be championing News at Ten's return as a "real win for viewers", the ad industry is finally seeing an end to much of the uncertainty that has surrounded the channel's schedule.

With the programme's return comes an extra 2.5 minutes of advertising in peak time; the addition of programme promotions of up to 20 seconds in centre breaks, and an increased number of commercial breaks throughout the schedule - enough, you would think, to put the smiles back on the faces of ad chiefs and marketing directors across the UK.

But while the consensus in ad land is that ITV has not made the most of the slot vacated by News at Ten, the persistent interference by the regulators over what is broadcast and when is still a source of frustration.

"I find it astonishing that we live in a country where bureaucrats regulate what goes on commercial TV channels - it's pathetic, they should have better things to worry about," says Rupert Howell, president of the institute of practitioners in advertising. That said, Howell described the turnaround as a "creative and inventive compromise" and one that would go a long way to alleviate the problems of airtime inflation.

The Incorporated Society of British Advertisers was more reserved in its praise. Ian Twinn, its public affairs director, says the decision brought a mixture of good and bad news for the society's members, which include the majority of the biggest TV advertisers in the country.

"The good news is that we are further forward than we were 18 months ago," he says. "But the bad news for advertisers is that the viewing figures for News at Ten, before the switch to the later slot, were draining away. Advertisers pay for ITV, they are the funders, there is no one else, and if people are switching off that is a big concern."

These worries were supported by Andy Farwell, sales director at sales house TSMS, who points out that while the 10.15pm slot always used to be a highly sought-after commercial spot, with car advertisers using it to break their ad campaigns, that is no longer the case. The popularity of the slot had decreased, he said, because of the growth in the number of multi-channel homes, meaning that audiences for flagship news programmes has declined.

Howell adds his concern over the increased number of ads that the inflated minutage will deliver: "We certainly don't want a situation like that in the US where there is lots of clutter on screen - it's something we will have to monitor."

Despite his reservations, Howell believes that, in general, advertisers will welcome the move. Mike Moran, commercial director at Toyota which spends around £20m a year advertising on TV, is a believer. "The increase in minutage may not sound like much, but what it means in reality is another 30-second spot in Coronation Street, for example, which delivers between 15m and 18m viewers," he says.

This view was shared by Barry Cook, managing director at ad agency D'Arcy which handles the advertising for some of the UK's biggest spenders, including Mars, Procter & Gamble and Fiat. Cook adds: "It's a win-win situation that will help all of our clients. For those targeting ABC audiences, the return of News at Ten gives a focal point to their viewing."

But these are temporary joys. As the dust settles on the announcement, advertisers and their agencies will be taking a close look at what the new ITV schedule is actually offering. The attraction of the increased peak-time minutage and extra ad breaks could prove to be a very fleeting sweetener.

fields.headline: Narrow outlook
fields.standfirst: As the mass audience fragments, targeted ads may be the way forward, says Peter Bazalgette
fields.trailText: As the mass audience fragments, targeted ads may be the way forward, says Peter Bazalgette.
fields.body:
Today's reading is taken from the Book of Dyke, chapter 16, verse 2: "If in the commercial world you lose share year after year, you either change your cost base dramatically or fall off the cliff. And when you combine channel fragmentation with the introduction of new technology, which makes recording programmes and skipping ads easy, the medium-term economics start to look fragile."

In his recent MacTaggart lecture in Edinburgh, Greg Dyke argued that if advertiser-funded television declines then the BBC will increasingly be the main financier of British programming. At first this sounds like the usual BBC megalomania, but behind the cheekiness is an interesting point. If technology erodes the income of commercial channels, how will we pay for programming? All this time we have been beating our breast about how the licence fee will become unacceptable. But were we looking in the wrong direction? After all, subscription income will outstrip advertising revenues within a couple of years. So the habit of paying directly for television is growing, not diminishing. The only difference between the new services and the licence fee is the element of compulsion - not something there is as yet any discernible resentment about.

However, in the short term, even as ITV's share declines, the effect is to increase its income. Advertisers have to pay more to reach what is still the last mass audience available. As my media-buyer-on-the-Clapham-omnibus put it to me this week, ITV is more resilient than it has a right to be. But every programme maker should be pondering the medium term because, despite the BBC's efforts to paint itself as the only white knight, the investment of the commercial channels in content is a crucial part of our ecology. We all need to work out how to continue harnessing advertisers' money.

In the immediate future there will need to be an increase in programme sponsorship. It is rising by 20% a year but still accounts for only 2.5% of the cake. The advantage here is that the advertiser's brand gets attached to the programme that is watched rather than ads that might be skipped. But sponsorship messages are going to have to be delivered with more skill. At the moment ad agencies too often commission stand-alone creative briefs that do not blend with the programme and are often at odds with it. The Vauxhall stings for Euro 2000 were cringe-making. Yes, young men like humour, but not when they're watching football (was it Bill Shankly who said soccer is more important than life or death?).

Product placement will also become more important. Like prostitution, it currently exists in a twilight world, harassed by the authorities. But one of the first tasks of the new, post-white paper regulators should be to rehabilitate this particular vice and make it a virtue.

Broadcasting is getting narrower all the time. Witness Channel 4 and Sky's success in delivering more focused audience groups to advertisers. And it will get narrower still. In the broadband, online world, the advertisers may well become broad/narrow casters themselves. The likes of Ali G might be directly funded by Nike and exclusively available on Nike's channel. This "sticky content" could, alternatively, be funded by its producer and syndicated to other non-competing content services from companies such as Lynx or Gap. What this means is that content creators will need to start forging direct links with advertisers rather than merely relying on the midwifery of the traditional broadcasters.

Producers of high-cost material, particularly drama, also have to increase their co-production skills. The programme distributors' association, BTDA, held an instructive conference about this last week. It demonstrated that creators and sellers can work much more closely.

Finally, there is the bounty from the sell-off of analogue spectrum to be fought over. Government "sources" have floated the idea of spending it in advance to assist all homes to go digital. But what about a content fund, too? Far from being on the way out, perhaps the idea of spending public money on programming is just coming into its own.

 Peter Bazalgette is creative director of Endemol Entertainment UK.

fields.headline: Grey wins Unisys account
fields.trailText: Grey Worldwide has picked up the multimillion pound global advertising account for Unisys, the IT solutions company. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Grey Worldwide has picked up the multimillion pound global advertising account for Unisys, the IT solutions company.

Grey beat Leo Burnett and McCann-Erickson for the business, which was previously handled by FCB.

MediaCom has been awarded the global media planning and buying business.

Richard Badler, vice-president of corporate communications at Unisys, said: "After conducting a wide ranging review, we found that Grey really grasped the fast-moving, hi-tech environment where Unisys lives, as well as the unique characteristics that set us apart from the competition."

Grey's first work will break worldwide in the first quarter of 2001.

fields.headline: BSkyB looks beyond St Luke's in £10m ad drive
fields.trailText: BSkyB is extending its roster of creative agencies beyond St Luke's as it looks to boost its marketing effort, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
BSkyB is extending its roster of creative agencies beyond St Luke's as it looks to boost its marketing effort.

The broadcaster will continue to work exclusively with St Luke's until the end of the year, after which several agencies will be appointed to work across Sky's various platforms, including Sky TiVo, Sky Digital, Sky.com and Skysportsstore.com. The broadcaster plans to invest an additional £10m in advertising spend across these areas.

A shortlist of creative agencies is being compiled.

webTitle: Brown doing a 'good job', insists Prescott

fields.headline: Brown doing a 'good job', insists Prescott
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister,  John Prescott, today defended the under-fire chancellor, Gordon Brown, and insisted Labour was "in good heart".
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, today defended the under-fire chancellor, Gordon Brown, and insisted Labour was "in good heart".

He argued the government and Mr Brown had a good track record on pensions and was working hard to improve further the situation for the elderly. Speaking at the party's annual conference in Brighton, Mr Prescott also defended the chancellor's approach, saying his strategy had been to first target financial help on the poorest pensioners who had seen the gap between their incomes and those of better-off pensioners widen during the Tory years.

He said the government, having dealt with that priority, was now turning its attention to seeing what could be done to help slightly better off pensioners.

"The only real advances come for pensioners under a Labour government, that is a matter of record and history...we won't let them down. The chancellor is doing a good job," said Mr Prescott.

The government has come under increasing fire in recent weeks for raising pensions by only 75p a week, and for not looking fully into restoring the link with pensions and earnings.

Mr Prescott pointed out that although this year's increase in the basic state pension was only 75p a week, pensioners had also benefited from additional types of aid including winter fuel payments, free TV licences and the Minimum Income Guarantee.

On fuel duties, Mr Prescott insisted the government would not be dictated to by the demonstrators. But he argued ministers had taken note of concerns about high fuel prices. He pointed out the government had reduced taxation on lorries and ditched the fuel duty escalator introduced by the previous Tory government.

"That is a Government listening and acting - you can't argue we are not listening," said Mr Prescott.

He also went on to dismiss suggestions cabinet members were at odds over the strategy on pensions and fuel. "Of course we are not feuding," he said, "we are a very united cabinet that is clearly very proud of three years of delivery."

He said the whole point of the Labour conference was to work through disagreements on policies, but morale was high.

"The party is in good heart and it is wanting and looking forward to the next General Election," he concluded.

fields.headline: ITouch announces pre-tax losses of £3.1m
fields.trailText: The first results from mobile phone company iTouch puts it on target to break even in 2004, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone services company iTouch posted its first results since floating in August, with its strongest figures coming from abroad.

ITouch has announced first half pre-tax losses of £3.1m on turnover of just over £1m, with Ireland and South Africa providing 90% of the revenue. The company raised £49m from its stock market launch and analysts expect it to break even in 2004.

Ivan Fallon, iTouch chairman, said: "We have made a very encouraging start towards our goal of becoming a major international provider of value added services to mobile consumers and corporate customers. We are on track to fulfil our strategy of rolling out our established business model internationally."

The company is 50% owned by Ireland's Independent News and Media, publisher of the Independent and Independent on Sunday titles, which provides content and marketing. ITouch has also linked up with mobile phone giant Vodafone, providing a text messaging service for the Sydney Olympics.

webTitle: Anne Diamond to front Loose Women

fields.headline: Diamond makes TV comeback
fields.trailText: Former Good Morning presenter Anne Diamond is making a TV comeback in a revamped series of the daytime chat show, Loose Women. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Good Morning presenter Anne Diamond is making a TV comeback in a revamped series of the daytime chat show, Loose Women.

The Granada show is being relaunched as Live Talk - but is replacing Sun columnist Jane Moore with Diamond.

Frontwoman Kaye Adams will return alongside Ms Diamond. But it is understood that the producers felt that the combination of Adams and Moore would be too much for the viewer. An insider said "Kay and Jane were both very feisty women, there wasn't room for both. We needed someone with a softer edge."

Ms Diamond has been out of the TV limelight since the show she co-hosted with Nick Ross was axed in 1996, and despite a presenting slot on LBC radio her media profile has been low following her tempestuous divorce from agent Mike Hollingsworth. Last week she returned to screens as Sheena Easton in Celebrity Stars in their Eyes, singing For Your Eyes Only.

Loose Women will be series produced by Suzan Price, with Granada controller of lifestyle James Hunt as executive producer.

fields.headline: DoubleClick restructures UK operations
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Global new media sales house DoubleClick has revealed details of a wide-ranging restructure for its UK office, writes Amy Vickers
fields.body:
Global new media sales house DoubleClick has revealed details of a wide-ranging restructure for its UK office.

Eric Stein, managing director of DoubleClick UK, said that the move was a result of the way the UK market for online advertising had matured over the past year.

He said: "It's a similar structure to that adopted by the US office a year ago and has come about because the market has reached a scale where we can do this. Essentially we're reacting to client demand."

Growth in the number of online advertising options with new platforms and new technology also contributed to the revamp, meaning DoubleClick can offer more than just a banner or a sponsorship.

DoubleClick is introducing Boomerang into the UK, an e-commerce marketing tool that uses cookies to encourage people back to the retail site, converting browsers into buyers. British Airways is the first UK client to sign up.

The restructure will create four new vertical divisions, sorting sites - for which DoubleClick handles sales - by type into business, leisure, consumer and technology and auto. Each will have a separate publisher, a business development person and a sales team. A group publisher who reports to the managing director will oversee all four divisions.

These vertical networks will work alongside a separate agency team, a sponsorship team, a marketing team and customer services.

Mr Stein is currently recruiting two publishers for the leisure and consumer divisions and has promoted Anne-Catrin Sallaba, director of business development, to group publisher. Paul Goad, senior account manager, has been put in charge of the business network and Ben Auchettl, business development manager, has been promoted to publisher of the technology and auto network.

The appointments will take the staff tally at DoubleClick to 34. The changes, which are expected to roll out to other European offices in the coming months, will come into effect on October 1.

fields.headline: A word to the wise
fields.standfirst:
Forget graphics and visual gimmicks. What you really need to sell on a website are words, John E Shreeve argues
Net news
fields.trailText: Forget graphics and visual gimmicks. What you really need to sell on a website are words, John E Shreeve argues
fields.body:
Internet entrepreneurs are increasingly realising that creating a successful e-commerce site demands more than just attractive prices, well-stocked virtual shopping malls, and reliable ordering structures. They recognise that the magic ingredient is content and that it has the much sought-after power to inspire return visits. In other words, it makes sites "sticky". Not only that, it makes them sell.

One man who has long understood the selling power of content is Ken Evoy, a 46-year-old internet entrepreneur from Quebec. His company, SiteSell.com, is a provider of e-commerce information and software and has proved a significant internet success story. The company's first publication, Make Your Site Sell! (MYSS!), written by Evoy himself, quickly went into sales overdrive and is now acknowledged web-wide as the bible of internet marketing.

How did Evoy manage to sell so many copies of the book? "Words - the right ones," he replies. "Of course, the words have to be backed up by great products, or you only end up with angry customers. But it's words that get sales."

Many dot.coms - especially the much-hyped ones - tend to think that technical pyrotechnics will make their sites sticky and encourage sales. But Evoy dismisses this as a loser's game. "Technology does not sell products," he insists. "Nor do graphics or animated monkeys. Great products don't even sell themselves. Words sell."

Because of his belief in the power of words, Evoy teamed up with veteran advertising copywriter and web-savvy author Joe Robson to write an e-book called Make Your Words Sell! (MYWS!), which was released earlier this year by SiteSell.com. Robson is a Yorkshireman who writes web copy that is generally considered to be unparalleled when it comes to selling e-products and services. Indeed, MYWS! - which offers a wealth of practical advice on how to write sales copy for the internet to your best advantage - is a testament to just how compelling and persuasive language can be.

During the course of his work, Robson has done a lot of research into what does and doesn't work on the internet. And, like Evoy, he is in no doubt that the websites that are currently successful employ well-crafted copywriting. "Contrary to popular opinion, there are people out there on the web quietly making extremely good money," he reveals. "But their websites look more like Joe Bloggs in his bedroom. They're not flash. But because they're using good sales copy, they're churning out products like there's no tomorrow and really are making huge profits."

Growing numbers of dot.coms are waking up to this fact and are consequently looking to hire "content providers" (otherwise known as writers) in a big way. One London-based company that has recently added an extensive selection of content to its internet site is Smarterwork.com - an "elance" site which enables freelance workers to bid on projects posted by businesses. For Pierre Reyland, content editor at Smarterwork, the job of bringing together a team of e-writers proved relatively straightforward. He selected them from the global pool of freelancers who use the Smarterwork site.

But he wasn't just looking for good writers - he needed writers who could write specifically for the web. "Writing for the web is very different from writing for newspapers and magazines," he says. "A monitor screen is not a very friendly interface to read from. So the writing has to be much clearer and more concise. To make a point on the web, you really have to hammer it home - using clear, simple language, highlighting important words, and splitting the text into small paragraphs, with headings and sub-headings, or using devices such as bullet-point lists, and so on."

Although the skills needed for writing for the web are different from those for print media, a conventional publishing background can be helpful when embarking on an e-writing project. George Giokas, CEO of Staffwriters, a leading US writers' agency, for instance, believes that journalists make excellent web writers. "For one thing, they are highly skilled in embracing concepts and then relating them in simple form," he says. "But to be successful in writing content for a site, a journalist must also learn the tricks of direct mail, headline writing and advertising. I think a good web writer needs all of the skills from journalism, marketing, graphics and copywriting."

One writer who has successfully integrated online and offline writing styles is Ann Logan, a freelance education writer from Warwickshire. She relishes the challenges of writing for the internet, but feels it requires more responsibility on the part of the writer. "Print publications have editors and sub-editors, but the web doesn't," she points out. "So there are fewer critical readers of your work. Because of that, it needs to be triple-checked before you submit it."

Ability and a conscientious attitude are key attributes to look for when hiring an e-writer. But how can the average internet entrepreneur - who may have had little experience in dealing with writers - be sure that the person they are considering for a project really has what it takes to pen effective web pages? One way is to hire a web writer through Plain Words, a well-established writers' agency based in Berkshire. It tests candidates to ensure they can handle a given project. "We describe a scenario - fictitious web entrepreneur and product/service - which is relevant to the sort of work they will be doing, and ask them how they would go about researching and writing the website," explains Peter Meherne, recruitment director at Plain Words. "We'd then ask them to produce some brief copy on a particular aspect of the product or service to test their writing skills."

While strong technical writing skills are essential for keeping readers glued to their VDUs, the cream of web writers take it even further and employ the novelist's technique of writing in "character" - in a specific voice. Joe Robson's current web project, The Newbie Club, which he co-runs with US computer wizard Tom Glander, is a case in point.

The site is aimed at new computer users and, although Robson and Glander have done little in the way of publicity, the site is proving a runaway success. Why? "Because we use a distinct voice in the copy," says Robson. "We get into the mindset of our ideal customer. That way, we can talk to them in their language and avoid falling into the trap of talking down to them, like many websites do. The mindset of the Newbies is that of frustration at the amount of technie talk in help files. So I speak very casually, using non-technical words like 'computerish' and 'geekspeak', which they relate to."

Such a strategy certainly seems to be paying off in terms of sales and the number of visitors to the site. "It's just phenomenal," says Robson. "And it goes to prove that the big dot.coms who lavish obscene amounts of money on flash websites - and still don't sell anything - must be doing something wrong. They'd save themselves a lot of money if they cut out the gadgets and gizmos and brought in some good copywriters."

webTitle: PM's statement jeopardises euro rescue mission

fields.headline: PM's statement jeopardises euro rescue mission
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Tony Blair unwittingly threatened to jeopardise the concerted global rescue mission for the euro yesterday when he suggested that there were no immediate plans for further intervention in the market this morning to support the beleaguered single currency.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny  and  Larry Elliott in Prague
fields.body:
Tony Blair unwittingly threatened to jeopardise the concerted global rescue mission for the euro yesterday when he suggested that there were no immediate plans for further intervention in the market this morning to support the beleaguered single currency.

With traders braced to test the resolve of central banks when dealing opens today, the prime minister's remarks appeared to suggest that Friday's $7bn euro buying spree was a one-off and that policymakers would leave the euro to find its own level.

Asked yesterday morning if he expected central banks to buy more euros today, the prime minister said: "No, that's not anticipated, but whatever we do, we will do with other countries."

Within minutes of the comments being flashed up on financial news wires, the Treasury was forced to mount a damage-limitation exercise. It said that Mr Blair's statement on Breakfast with Frost had been misinterpreted and that Britain's stance had not changed from the position taken by finance ministers of the Group of Seven leading industrialised economies on Saturday.

"The G7 remains committed to monitoring developments in foreign exchange markets and will cooperate as appropriate, the Treasury said.

However, the prime minister's remarks were in stark contrast to the refusal of either the chancellor or the governor of the Bank of England, Sir Eddie George, to make any comment on the possibility of further attacks on currency speculators by the G7.

The need to keep markets guessing means that central bankers and politicians rarely say anything about intervention, particularly at times when they are seeking to act in concert. In its communique on Saturday, the G7 sought to keep dealers in the dark, saying: "In the light of recent developments, we will continue to monitor developments closely and to cooperate in exchange markets as appropriate."

Sir Eddie said Saturday that he was "technically happy" with the way Friday's action had gone. "The moment was well chosen and it took the market by surprise." Gordon Brown said that the action in the foreign exchange markets reflected concern about the level of the euro against the dollar, adding that it was not justified by the relative states of the European and US economies.

"It was coordinated and everybody that had been asked took part. You don't judge these things over a minute, an hour or a day. The action was a signal of our concern."

Even before Mr Blair's comments, there was speculation that central banks would be taken on by the markets. All seven members of the G7 - the US, Germany, Japan, Italy, France, Canada and Britain - took part in the three separate bouts of action, which resulted in the euro rallying from just over 87 cents against the dollar to 90 cents, but it later slipped back to close at around 88 cents.

While some analysts say the G7 action marked a watershed for the euro, veterans of the guerrilla warfare of intervention know it will take a protracted fight in order to succeed. Speculators betting on the uncertainty of Thursday's Danish referendum on euro membership next Thursday are also likely to ensure a volatile week ahead.

"The markets are going to test G7 resolve and the euro is in for a period of volatility. But ultimately G7 will win," said Kit Juckes, head of bond and currency strategy at RBS in London.

webTitle: Jon Henley on France's referendum on constitutional reform

fields.headline: Politicians blamed for stirring up apathy in France
fields.standfirst: The referendum on the length of a French presidential term attracted a record low turnout. No surprise there, says Jon Henley in Paris.
fields.trailText: The referendum on the length of a French presidential term attracted a record low turnout. No surprise there, says Jon Henley in Paris.
fields.body:
France has decided to elect its next president for a five-year rather than a seven-year term. But at what cost to democracy and the public's faith in the country's political elite?

Very nearly 70% of the French electorate failed to vote in yesterday's referendum on whether to to shorten the presidential term and bring it in line with the French parliament's and most of the rest of western Europe.

The change, France's most important constitutional reform in the past 40 years, was approved by about 73% of those who bothered to cast a ballot. But it was the abstention rate - a record for the nine referendums held during the fifth republic - that preoccupied the commentators.

"A little yes, but a big slapdown", was the verdict of le Parisien, while Liberation and France Soir referred to "the vote strike" and the conservative le Figaro called the poll "a huge political and symbolic failure".

The value of the reform, most commentators agreed, was not in doubt. The presidential mandate is out of step with the five-year lifetime of parliament, and three times in the past 14 years there have been paralysing "cohabitations" between presidents and prime ministers of different political persuasions that have effectively stymied major institutional change.

Most were also agreed that it was President Jacques Chirac's chosen method for ratifying the reform that was at fault.

France's constitution can be changed by a special joint congress of the upper and lower houses of parliament, and putting such an arcane issue to the people - which Chirac did in an attempt to make French democracy "more open" - was simply inappropriate.

Because all major parties and a sizeable majority of the public backed the long-discussed change, the campaigning was uninspired if not non-existent. In addition, public attention was far more concerned by more practical issues, such as soaring petrol prices, a heavy tax burden and growing accusations of corruption levelled at Chirac and his Gaullist RPR party.

"The referendum was a fiasco," said one political analyst, Alain Duhamel. "It was bad for Chirac, who chose the referendum, and above all, it was very bad for democracy. Our institutions have been improved by the referendum, but democracy has been weakened."

Besides the president, Lionel Jospin also comes out of the debacle with his image blackened. The prime minister was firmly in favour of the reform but failed to make campaigning for it a priority. He said it was "a necessary step towards further important reforms", but failed to say exactly what those further reforms might be and why they were important.

"One of the chief lessons of this must be that you cannot play with universal suffrage," said another commentator, Jacques Esperandieu. "France is not Switzerland, where referendums are commonplace. Here, putting an issue before the people should be sacred, a tool used to decide true national debates, not politico-technical quarrels."

For it is not that the French dislike referendums as such. When the issue is one that inspires passion, the turnout is high: Some 70% of the electorate voted on the Maastricht treaty in 1992. And in an opinion poll published in le Figaro today, 67% of respondents said they favoured more referendums - but only on major political issues such as taxation or pension reform.

So yesterday's record low turnout may not be a crisis in French democracy. Just a warning to the country's political elite that the French do not take kindly to being consulted about issues that only really concern politicians, particularly when those politicians should be thinking about rather more important things.
