webTitle: London's as bitchy as Rushdie claims

fields.headline: Scalpel, razor and hatchet
fields.standfirst: On bitchy literary London
fields.trailText: John Sutherland on bitchy literary London
fields.body:
Salman Rushdie has announced to the world his intention to remove to New York. The reason? The "bitchiness" he has encountered on this side of the Atlantic. How spiteful is the London literary world? Or is it just that writers as successful and talented as Salman bring out the worst in Grub Street and its venal hacks?

When it comes to grievous literary harm it is said that Rushdie can give as good as he gets. Reviewers who have been unkind, it is rumoured, have come home to find blisteringly angry messages on their answering machines. His fiction has provoked at least one successful libel suit (when he alleged in Midnight's Children that Mrs Gandhi was complicit in her husband's death). Few novelists can claim as high a body count as that racked up by The Satanic Verses.

Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of Uncle Tom's Cabin, the "little woman whose book started a big war" (as Abraham Lincoln put it) heads that league. None the less there are people dead who would still be living had Rushdie never put pen to paper. At the end of the day, of course, it is fanaticism, not literature, that pulls the trigger. Whatever dispute there may be about his status as a novelist, Rushdie has at least made the English novel matter again.

I personally think he is the greatest living novelist we have. And now we have him no longer. Are we then driving away the geese that lay our golden literary eggs? Could we reverse this talent drain by being nicer to our great writers?

I suspect that one of the things that most irked Rushdie was the literary party gossip. In the past few weeks, for example, I've heard - as choice, if suspect morsels over the canapés - that Rushdie nowadays has a personal trainer (picture that!) and that although he gets a million-dollar advance from his publisher, he leaves one-and-a-half million negative equity when he moves on.

But what really got to him, I suspect, were the reviews. There is no question that bad reviews hurt. As much as sticks and stones, if they are done well enough. Nor is there any question that British literary pages do little to discourage hatchetry or the snide review.

If you contribute, as I occasionally do, to the literary pages of American organs like the New York Times they virtually do a background check on you and your family to make sure you are unbiased. Not over here. British editors like it when reviewers get personal.

America has nothing equivalent to Fleet Street's literary gossip columns (see, for example, the Guardian's own Loafer). Nor in the US is there anything equivalent to Private Eye's book pages.

The Eye's bookworms are anonymous. But prime suspects are David Sexton (otherwise literary editor of the Evening Standard), Francis Wheen (who has actually published a collection of his Lord Gnome reviews) and the freelance man of letters, DJ Taylor. As long as they are not writing about you, Private Eye's bitchery is addictive reading. And good reviewing.

The London literary world runs on bile. Competition for readers is part of the reason. There are 10 times as many book-page inches in London as in New York and fewer readers for them. As any reviewer knows, readers love the smell of fresh blood above all things. Write something slashing, and your friends will all tell you how much they enjoyed it. Use the word "splendid" in the first sentence and you can kiss the reader goodbye.

Competition for space is the other main factor. There are some 2,000 new novels published every year in the UK. Only a few hundred can get reviewed at all; only a few score get multiple reviews; only a handful get lead reviews.

To achieve visibility for a new novel you need a big advertising budget and a lot of expensive pre-publication promotion. "Hype", in a word. Reviewers see themselves as merchandisers of anti-hype. If that means the scalpel, the razor, or even the hatchet, so be it. This is a cancer they must cut out. So what if you lose a genius or two to America in the process. Bitch on, London literary world.

webTitle: 'When does your child sit on the potty?'

fields.headline: 'When does your child sit on the potty?'
fields.standfirst: In the competitive atmosphere of New Delhi you have to tread carefully if you want to get your child into nursery school.
fields.trailText: In the competitive atmosphere of New Delhi you have to tread carefully if you want get your child into nursery school.
fields.body:
Getting your child into school in India is no easy business. In fact, it is a nightmare. I only discovered just how big a nightmare when, two months after arriving in New Delhi as the Guardian's new correspondent, I finally managed to get an interview at our local Indian nursery school, Tender Feet.

"And when does your child sit on the potty?" "Er, around 9am," I replied. "Oh dear," came the reply. "Oh dear."

True, it was not actually me who was going to be taking up the place - if we got one - but our daughter Tilly, aged two and a half. Nonetheless, I was the one being interviewed. Sitting in my best, hideously warm Jigsaw suit, as a fan whirled above our heads chopping the hot lunchtime air, I smiled back at the school's director Mr Kenny. He was right: I did not have a post- graduate qualification. But might he consider taking Tilly anyway?

It came as something of a blow when we were told that Tilly was, alas, too old for Tender Feet's programme, which begins at two. In effect the rejection meant our daughter was already on life's scrapheap.

We shared this dismal news with our neighbour, a famous Indian painter recently decorated by the Indian government, whose grand-daughter had just left the school. She agreed to put in a good word for us. Within hours Mr Kenny had performed a nimble volte-face: Tilly would of course be welcome at Tender Feet and could start on Monday.

The next step was to purchase Tilly's uniform. Like all the other children she had to wear white plimsolls, and have a clean handkerchief pinned to her dress every morning. She required a tiffin box for late-morning tiffin which consisted of a cheese or jam sandwich without - as the prospectus made clear - stuffings.

It would be nice to think that our experience of school entry was atypical. In fact, we appear to have got off lightly. With a middle-class of around 200 million people, it is the handful of successful Indian schools that choose the parents, rather than the other way round.

The same demographic pressure can be felt everywhere in India: in cinemas, on trains, and in the perpetually crowded and surprisingly upmarket branches of McDonald's. Another of our neighbours was grilled with his wife for four hours before their small son was accepted at a pre-school. Further along the system, the pressure grows intolerably. Middle-class Indian teenagers rarely leave the house, such is the competition to succeed, and only those with the very top grades make it into university. In such a frenzied atmosphere, it is hardly surprising that rumours flourish of certain headmasters willing to accept "donations".

In the end, Tender Feet proved to be well worth the effort. Tilly's morning walk to school takes her past the ironing stall, where two men labour over crumpled saris with giant charcoal-powered irons, past the young beggar woman with no legs, who gets around on a cart. We see vegetable stalls selling aubergines and okra, and a children's playground which is too hot most days to use. At the school gates I hand Tilly over - parents are strictly forbidden from entering the school. At going home time, India's enduring caste system prevails: parents collect their children from the front gate, while ayahs or nannies have to queue at a side door.

After four months of taking her to Tender Feet we still have little idea what exactly Tilly does inside, but it is clear she is happy and stimulated. Her Hindi-speaking playmates are the sons and daughters of Delhi's bourgeoisie - garment exporters, building contractors and government officials. She is the only foreign child. What is more, Tilly has a special friend, Karla, who may or may not exist. Karla, she tells us, "is forty hundred fat" and "gets into trouble with the teachers for eating his tiffin too quickly".

webTitle: Weakest Link proves strong contender in TV ratings game

fields.headline: Weakest Link proves strong contender in TV ratings game
fields.trailText: For years, Richard Whiteley has been the undisputed king of teatime quizzes. But now there is a pretender to the pun-loving Countdown presenter's throne, in the form of Anne Robinson and her hit new BBC game show.
fields.body:
For years, Richard Whiteley has been the undisputed king of teatime quizzes. But now there is a pretender to the pun-loving Countdown presenter's throne, in the form of Anne Robinson and her hit new BBC game show.

The combination of Robinson's schoolmistress manner and a format that forces contestants to vote out their worst-performing team members has made The Weakest Link one of the most dramatic TV successes of the year. Gaining a cult following at teatime, the BBC2 show is now beating Channel 4's stalwart afternoon quiz.

With her catchphrase "You're the weakest link," delivered sternly to each departing victim, topped off with a jaunty "goodbye," Robinson has transformed herself from Watchdog's consumer champion to quirky quizmistress queen.

The show, dubbed "mean TV" by the BBC2 controller Jane Root, has gained some unexpected fans. During the recent petrol crisis, one trucker fan draped his vehicle with a banner which read: "Tony Blair, you're the weakest link, goodbye."

Now it is enjoying ratings success: in the past week, the show has gained audiences of up to 4m at its peak, making it one of the best-performing shows in its timeslot, 5.15pm. On average it gets 2.5m, beating Countdown, which airs at 4.30pm, by about 200,000.

Jane Lush, the BBC's controller of daytime programmes, has commissioned 90 more episodes of the programme. It will run every day, except for a break at Christmas and during a handful of major sporting events, until well into next spring. "I knew we had a hit on our hands, but I didn't think it would be this big," said Ms Lush.

She believes its success comes from its human interest. "You get to know the contestants, and you start rooting for them. Then there's the drama when they are voted off."

Robinson's mean manner - she berates contestants who are performing badly - has polarised the audience, Ms Lush said. "People either love her or hate her."

Since Who Wants to be a Millionaire? torpedoed its way through the television schedules, TV executives have been searching for the next hit game show. Bosses at rival TV channels are concerned that the BBC might attempt to capitalise on the success of The Weakest Link by showing it at peak time.

Ms Lush will fight to keep the programme at teatime, but Lorraine Heggessey, the new controller of BBC1, might have her eye on it.

Gaining a cult following at teatime, the BBC2 show is now beating Channel 4's stalwart afternoon quiz. With her catchphrase "You're the weakest link," delivered sternly to each departing victim, topped off with a jaunty "goodbye," Robinson has transformed herself from Watchdog's consumer champion to quirky quizmistress queen. The show, dubbed "mean TV" by the BBC2 controller Jane Root, has gained some unexpected fans. During the recent petrol crisis, one trucker fan draped his vehicle with a banner which read: "Tony Blair, you're the weakest link, goodbye." Now it is enjoying ratings success: in the past week, the show has gained audiences of up to 4m at its peak, making it one of the best-performing shows in its timeslot, 5.15pm. On average it gets 2.5m, beating Countdown, which airs at 4.30pm, by about 200,000. Jane Lush, the BBC's controller of daytime programmes, has commissioned 90 more episodes of the programme. It will run every day, except for a break at Christmas and during a handful of major sporting events, until well into next spring. "I knew we had a hit on our hands, but I didn't think it would be this big," said Ms Lush. She believes its success comes from its human interest. "You get to know the contestants, and you start rooting for them. Then there's the drama when they are voted off." Robinson's mean manner - she berates contestants who are performing badly - has polarised the audience, Ms Lush said. "People either love her or hate her." Since Who Wants to be a Millionaire? torpedoed its way through the television schedules, TV executives have been searching for the next hit game show. Bosses at rival TV channels are concerned that the BBC might attempt to capitalise on the success of The Weakest Link by showing it at peak time. Ms Lush will fight to keep the programme at teatime, but Lorraine Heggessey, the new controller of BBC1, might have her eye on it.

fields.headline: One nation under a groove
fields.standfirst: How did the British army use dance music to unite the Serbs, Croats and Muslims?  Stephen Armstrong  tunes in
fields.trailText: How did the British army use dance music to unite the Serbs, Croats and Muslims? Stephen Armstrong tunes in
fields.body:
Standing in a night club in Banja Luka in the Republic of Serbska, I'm starting to feel a wee bit nervous. We've bunked out of Nato's vast metal factory base with five pissed squaddies for a Friday night on the town, and the locals have got wise to the fact that we're Brits, mainly because the squaddies are wearing Sheffield United shirts. Three terrifying Serb boneheads are gathering nearby, getting just that bit too close for comfort. No one is talking to us. We stand out like sore thumbs.

The promoter, clearly sensing trouble, moves over to talk to the safest face among us - Julie Dawson, who manages British DJs for UK production and management company Wise Buddah. The two of them quickly reach the international language of dance music - hard house, trance, Tong, Rampling and Cox. Then she reveals that she's over here because her company produces Boy George's radio show Clubversive, and the promoter erupts with joy.

"Yes, yes, Clubversive, I hear it on Oxsigen." And then he's clapping us on the back and getting us drinks and asking if Boy George would play his club. I think to myself - if only Captain David Bailey were here. He'd practically be in tears by now.

Captain Bailey is the man who created Oxsigen for the British army's element of Nato's stabilisation force SFOR. He almost single-handedly built the station's prefab hut studios on the metal factory base. Oxsigen is a dance station, programmed and scheduled just like Kiss, Galaxy or Radio 1, although with curious ad breaks which carry only advice and information on mine clearance and learning to live together again. When Radio 1 says One Love on air, it's a corporate slogan. When Oxsigen's local Serbian, Croat and Bosniac Muslim DJs say it, they mean let's all stop shooting each other.

Bailey has been working on the station for two years - an unusually long period in Bosnia where most soldiers only do a six-month tour - but he clearly loves radio. It was his desperate enthusiasm which got Boy George to play on the station: Bailey contacted Wise Buddah which - with George - was so impressed by the outfit that it basically gave him the show for nothing.

"It sounds a bit naive in the UK to talk about dance music changing things, but there's something about it that really brings people together," says Boy George. "That's why we were so happy to give them the show. The generation in Britain before acid house was uptight, homophobic and unsophisticated. Clubbing was about ultra-hip exclusivity and knowing the right people. Since acid house, kids from Britain are now far more sophisticated. I get no one giving me grief because I'm queer and happy, so that can work out in Bosnia too. We're hoping to do some DJ dates there - I'll be the first western DJ out since the war - and it'd be great if Serbian, Croatian and Muslim kids could all be dancing together in the same nightclub."

Captain Bailey credits George's show with building the station's success. "Out here there's no radio research, so we have to do what the rest of the local stations do - calculate how many listeners we have from the calls, letters and emails we get," he explains. "That method gives us a 19% share and makes us the most popular station in our area, which I think is a bit optimistic. I reckon we've probably got around 16%, and I'm quite happy with that."

It's curious for, well, how many reasons do you want? For a start, this is the British army we're talking about. The unit responsible for creating Bosnia's own Kiss FM is called info ops, or in the American army's terrifying newspeak, psyops - psychological operations. This is the section of the military that spent the second world war dropping leaflets over Germany urging all soldiers to overthrow Hitler and surrender. Given the outstandingly poor results that the leaflets delivered, it's no surprise that the section was pretty hard hit in the army's popularity charts and by the time the Gulf war rolled round it didn't really exist.

The Americans had kept this whole business going, however, and spent much of the cold war broadcasting "join capitalism" messages into places such as Cuba and eastern Europe. Their Gulf war operations had some success and the Brits were impressed. Come the occupation of Bosnia, info ops was back up and running and trying to work out what best to do with its radio frequencies as delivered by the international media commission before Bailey's radio enthusiasm offered an answer.

The French and the Americans were also given frequencies for their stations and the Americans are doing just what you'd expect the Brits to do. Their station is very formal and laced with ads for peace that would make a media novice cringe. In one advert, a couple are doing a crossword and the bloke's stumped on a clue. "Six letters meaning peace..." he wonders. "Why darling, that's Dayton," she coos. And you can almost hear the militia laying down their arms.

The Brits appear to have embraced clubland for inspiration, using Oxsigen. It has also created a free weekly magazine called Mostovi which is handed out by patrolling soldiers and distributed around shops and town centres.

Mostovi similarly eschews any sort of heavy-handed SFOR propaganda. Instead, it has a diet of celebrity interviews and lifestyle features with news about all areas of Bosnia Herzegovina - as local media in the Republic of Serbska refuse to write about the Bosnian Croat Federation and vice versa. Of course, there's also mine-clearing information and stories about war criminals which jar to my British eyes when placed next to a feature on George Clooney.

"Our job is to support the mission for SFOR," explains Major Nigel Jones, whose job title runs to the delicious SO2 information campaign, HQ multi national division south west. "And that's to maintain a safe and secure environment. To me, that means stopping people going back to war. To do that, we have to try and change the way they see each other and change what they think is an acceptable way to resolve disputes. With the radio, we're targeting the young. We've got multi-ethnic presenters, give unbiased news - including news that is critical of SFOR - and we work on the premise that if the magazine we produce is boring and worthy then no one's going to read it."

Up in Prijador - the town where ITN filmed those infamous concentration camp-like scenes of starving Croats behind barbed wire - two of the station's 18-year-old listeners chat about its popularity. "I listen because it gets the new music quicker than local stations," says Rada, a Serbian girl. "I listen to it because it is the only station where I can speak my mind," says Alecsandra. "There's almost 300 radio stations out here and all of them are controlled by political factions," she explains. "I call Oxsigen's phone-ins because I've seen and heard things I shouldn't have and I need to tell someone."

And so she tells me. Her dad is Serbian and her mum is Muslim. When she was 11 years old, the locals burned down her next-door neighbours' house because they were Muslims. She lay awake that night hearing her neighbours' screams as they burned to death, wondering if her mother was next. Now she wants to leave. It all looks grim to her and she's the sort of person the station needs to reassure.

Back in the club, you could believe there is some hope. The squaddies have split and they're all in the middle of the dance floor, hands in the air as the DJ builds a storming set. There are Croats and Serbs and Bosnians here and people may be slagging off SFOR but they're buying the squaddies rounds of Amstel. The guy on the podium with the lurid green glo-sticks steps down and chats to me about music, always music, and doesn't want to know when I get on to politics, so that just for one, naive, 1988 Summer Of Love moment you actually do think that music could make a difference. Or maybe that's just the beer talking.

fields.headline: Bring them all on
fields.standfirst: Last week in Media Guardian, Tim Luckhurst, a former editor of the Scotsman, claimed the Scottish newspaper scene was overburdened with second-rate titles. Here, Scotsman editor in chief,  Andrew Neil, hits back
fields.trailText: Last week in Media Guardian, Tim Luckhurst, a former editor of the Scotsman, claimed the Scottish newspaper scene was overburdened with second-rate titles. Here, Scotsman editor in chief, Andrew Neil, hits back
fields.body:
It is always interesting (though not necessarily instructive) to read the media musings of former editors like Tim Luckhurst, even though he lasted only two weeks in the editorial chair of the Scotsman. This short experience was an unhappy one for all concerned and, judging from last week's article in Media Guardian, has left him with a bitter and distorted view of the vibrant Scottish newspaper scene.

You would never guess from what he wrote that since his departure as editor and the launch of the new Scotsman on May 8, sales of Scotland's most famous and distinguished newspaper have soared by more than 30%. The Scotsman, with independently-audited sales of almost 105,000 in August, is now selling more than it has ever done and, for the first time in its 183-year history, has become the largest-selling daily broadsheet in Scotland.

The success of the relaunch of the Scotsman has been achieved by eschewing incremental change, which had done nothing to reverse a quarter century of steady decline (in common with every other Scottish broadsheet), in favour of radical reform.

This was accompanied by a price cut to 20p to encourage new readers to sample the new Scotsman and an extensive promotion campaign which repositioned it as a truly national paper for all of Scotland, not just Edinburgh and its environs. Luckhurst is living in the past when he claims that the Scotsman is still just a "city-state product". Over 60% of our sales are now outside Scotland's capital. We are no more an Edinburgh paper than the Times is a London-only paper.

Luckhurst is also behind the times when he writes that "The Scotsman and the [Glasgow] Herald are engaged in a feud which can only end in disaster." It is true that sales of the venerable but ailing Herald have recently slumped to around 92,000 (from a 70s peak of more than 126,000) and that our circulation has almost doubled in the Strathclyde region. But the Herald's sales were falling long before our relaunch. We are aiming at a different target.

The Scotsman's competition is no longer the local big-city papers of Glasgow, Aberdeen and Dundee. The English invaders which have made recent inroads into the Scottish market are now the enemy and the early signs are that they are already retreating across the border. The Scotsman now outsells the tartan editions of all the London-based broadsheets (including the Financial Times) combined.

I do agree with Luckhurst, however, that Scotland's new parliament "has not sold a single additional copy". That is why I used to urge him and his predecessor not to lead the paper almost every day with the latest devolutionary wrinkle. They ignored this advice and, between them, managed to cut sales of the Scotsman during the first session of the parliament from a healthy 80,000 last August to a record low of 72,000 by December.

The radical and rapid transformation of the Scotsman would not have been possible, however, without the threat of a new paper on an already-crowded Scottish scene. If you are minded to protect your franchise, there is nothing like the prospect of fresh competition to open your chequebook and galvanise you to force through major changes; I will be forever grateful to Bonnier, the Swedish publishing group, for inducing both at the Scotsman. Their new Scottish business daily, Business am, was launched last Wednesday. For most of this year, its imminent arrival has steeled and spurred us to do to the Scotsman what should have been done years ago.

Much has been made by those who would undermine us, including Luckhurst, of the recent exodus of staff from the Scotsman, much of it to the new Scandinavian title. Luckhurst writes that our paper has "shed almost 50% of the Scotsman team since April". In fact, though the exodus began under his watch (when several key figures left), it has been nothing like as massive as he suggests and a loss has been almost entirely therapeutic and beneficial.

The insistence on radical change at the Scotsman and the arrival of a Swedish safe haven has encouraged around 20% of editorial staff to leave in recent months. There are always a few casualties in such circumstances - journalists you would rather not lose - but overall the exodus has been a godsend.

Luckhurst writes about the "shedding of quality staff" and others have talked about the Scotsman "haemorrhaging talent". This is self-serving drivel: most of those who have gone are the "talent" which presided over the relentless decline of the Scotsman for over two decades. Let us hope they do for the sales of the Scandinavians what they did for the Scotsman's.

They have been replaced by journalists of the quality that the paper could never attract before (such as Ian Watson and Bill Jamieson) and exciting new talent (like Charlotte Ross, Steve McGinty and Rona Johnson) more attuned to the culture and attitudes of the 21st century than the 1970s. We also have Scotland's first-ever female editor, the indefatigable Rebecca Hardy, who has presided superbly over our relaunch and is building an impressive new team.

Business am's debut on Wednesday verged on farce. Printing problems meant most of the guests at the Edinburgh launch party had gone by the time the first edition arrived at 1am, over two hours late. More important, late deliveries to the trade compromised the first day's distribution; merchandisers hired to give away copies were still waiting for stocks at 7.30am; subsequent print delays forced them to use taxis to deliver copies to newsagents. Trade estimates suggest they are selling a paltry 7,000 out of a 30,000 print run; advertising revenues in the launch edition were only around £20,000. Bonnier's fabled deep pockets had better be bottomless.

No doubt the teething problems will be overcome. More worrying is the poor quality of the journalism. The Scottish executive had helpfully leaked the paper an exclusive on public spending; unhelpfully, our own Edinburgh Evening News ran it just as Business am was preparing to go to press. The fallback splash was a story about a Dunfermline computer games company which was old news. After six months of preparation, rival journalists were amazed this was the best they could do. The inside news stories were pedestrian and the columnists and commentaries risible. Matters had not improved much by the weekend.

No matter: it is the market which will determine the fate of Business am, not the opinions of rival journalists. But we have seen the enemy and it is not 10 feet tall; it is a Nordic pygmy, likely to be in crisis before Christmas.

As we move from battle-stations to our normal state of alert there is only one possible response to our new competitor: the price of the Scotsman will rise later this week.

 Andrew Neil is publisher and editor in chief of the Scotsman

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • Feeling lost for something to watch now the obsession of the summer is over? Help is at hand courtesy of Pig Brother, a new venture from a farm in Devon. A canny pig farmer has registered pigbrother.uk.com, and is setting up a webcam in a pig shed to follow the porkers 24 hours a day. But there's a sinister side - while viewers are encouraged to get involved in the piggies' lives, the influence they exert is a little more final than that exerted by Big Brother viewers. The piggies that get the chop will, er, end up as chops. A fly on the wall webcam that's not for the faint-hearted.

 Far be it for Media Guardian to use any opportunity to have a pop at News International, but the debacle at Learnfree.co.uk makes it impossible not to refer to the old chestnut that NI is still miles from getting its head around new media. News has reached us that all 14 staff, eight of whom only started in May, are being laid off on September 29. The official skinny? The adverse nature of the b2c market. So that's another £5m of NI's money down the Swanee. Will they ever learn?

 It's been a week of frenzied corporate dealings over at T-Online, the ISP offshoot of German telco behemoth Deutsche Telekom. Freeserve execs have been watching with interest as their mooted tie-up with T-Online falls by the wayside. It seems that while T-Online sees value in Freeserve, parent company DT doesn't and the knife has fallen on those at T-Online who dare to disagree. It's two down and two to go (at time of writing) and all because the board can't agree on its expansion strategy. It's fair to say there are a few unhappy campers at T-Online and it's ever more unlikely that Freeserve will find itself celebrating with a wurst and a tankard in a bierkeller.

 If ever there was something I wish had been around 10 years ago, it's revise.it - a veritable paradise for lazy students. fields.headline: A matter of timing
fields.standfirst: Shortly after arriving in the hot seat at the ITC, Patricia Hodgson seems to have been instrumental in engineering a solution to the News at Ten debacle.  Maggie Brown  finds out how she did it
fields.trailText: Shortly after arriving in the hot seat at the ITC, Patricia Hodgson seems to have been instrumental in engineering a solution to the News at Ten debacle. Maggie Brown finds out how she did it
fields.body:
By an odd coincidence last Friday was the 45th anniversary of both ITV and ITN - the company set up to provide its news. And though the date passed uncelebrated the surprise decision to reinstate News at Ten (sort of), dominating front pages and bulletins, seemed fitting and symbolic.

In fact, ITN, whose shareholders have advanced plans to float it on the stock exchange, emerges as more valuable, back at 10pm on ITV from January with its brand enhanced - and with the BBC's governors forced to reconsider the plan to move BBC1's news to 10pm.

So how was the deal struck after six months of unprecedented and bitter deadlock? Well, it was nail-bitingly touch and go. Rightly criticised for being a bit of a fudge, the outcome is a just-in-time pragmatic repair job, putting Humpty Dumpty back together again. The key figure was Patricia Hodgson, the new chief executive of the independent television commission (ITC). Elated by the defusing of the crisis, she says: "There has been generosity and realism on both sides. There is no victory. We were solving the issue. But I think it creates a new relationship between us and ITV, which can ensure aspects of public service broadcasting will continue into the digital age."

On Tuesday August 29, the day after the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival - where Greg Dyke's announcement of the projected BBC News at Ten, backed by the BBC governors, had dominated press coverage - she began exploratory talks with Charles Allen, chief executive of Granada Media. He is the most powerful figure in ITV following the summer's merger agreement with United News & Media's TV franchises. The meeting stemmed from his honest assessment at Edinburgh two days earlier that ITV had taken its eye off the ball in letting the dispute get out of hand - to the point of seeking an unprecedented high court judicial review when the ITC ordered the return of News at Ten at its July meeting.

Hodgson, about to take up her new post, seized the moment in Edinburgh to say publicly the two sides could talk "up to the courtroom door". But she needed an acceptable proposal by September 21, the last ITC members' meeting before the high court hearing pencilled in for this week. Together that Tuesday they reviewed frankly how divisions during the tense takeover battle absorbing Carlton, Granada and United - when the barons vied to undermine each other in the struggle to come out on top - had meant the ITV network's interests had been damaged.

Hodgson made it clear she was prepared to back a single ITV under the right conditions, finally ending the key problem - the "London split" of weekday and weekend licence-holders. Then, with the clock ticking away, Hodgson led talks with David Liddiment, programme director of the ITV Network, to explore the options for bringing forward the 11pm Nightly News, though not to 10pm. A 10.30pm compromise worked on during the summer was now impossible because of the BBC's decision to move to 10pm.

But on Friday September 15, negotiations suddenly fell apart as conflict between Carlton and Granada flared up again. Hodgson retired from this battlefield, feeling she had done her best, while at ITN the tension mounted. Then Hodgson tried another tack, holding meetings with ITV's commercial directors and sales houses, seeking to reduce their hostility towards news in the prime-time schedule. This was sensible.

Advertisers and airtime sales chiefs were alarmed by the sour stalemate. Nick Phillips, director general of the institute of practitioners in advertising, rushed to welcome the 10pm agreement last week because the alternative - a court case, bad blood, a weakened ITV - was worse. Powerful airtime buying agency Zenith Media had already shifted, denying ever supporting an end to News at Ten two years ago. And with the BBC planning to colonise 10pm and pump immense new resources into more popular programmes before it, advertisers were alarmed.

Last Tuesday, with only two days to go, Hodgson was suddenly called by the ITV Network, and to her surprise found that a return of News at Ten, with conditions, was being offered. Detailed but good-natured haggling then ensued all through the day. The concession of an extra two and half minutes of prime advertising airtime will roughly offset the loss of the £70m over a year ITV reckons to have gained from ending News at Ten. The ITC is happy, since £42m goes into programmes, taking the network's annual budget to £747m.

And although the revived News at Ten is a third shorter at 20 minutes, it will not suffer the disruption of a commercial break. The agenda is unlikely to be dumbed down, despite the loss of longer reports, and the bulletin will extend to a full half-hour during elections and when big news stories are breaking. A delighted Stewart Purvis, chief executive of ITN, says that the flexibility, allowing ITV to move the bulletin later on Friday and one other night a week, should be seen as a potential strength: in the run-up to News at Ten's abolition in 1999 it was moved frequently to 10.15pm to accommodate Champions League matches and Coronation Street, but notched up bumper viewing figures. As for Friday nights: well, people go to bed later, parliament breaks up early.

Underpinning ITV's confidence in reinstating News at Ten is that in the past three months there has been a marked stability in commercial news audiences. After years of gentle decline, figures for all three of ITV's news programmes (lunchtime, evening and nightly) have either held steady or gone up slightly when compared to last year, while Channel 4's news is up nearly 20%.

ITV will now have two prime-time news services, at 6.30pm (instead of 5.40pm before News at Ten's axeing) and 10pm, from January: what remains un-fixed is the late-night regional news, stuck at 11.20pm and seen by viewers as irrelevant and far too late. Other potential problems are evident: as the decision was rushed through, catching even ITN by complete surprise, Hodgson's celebrated political skills deserted her. She failed to brief powerful critics, specifically Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the culture, media & sport select committee, who has led the attack over News at Ten.

On Friday a defiant Greg Dyke was flying off to Sydney, and had the long flight to ponder his next move. The political guns are firing. Dyke rashly predicted the move would win higher audiences for news; yet going head to head at 10pm - as he still seems determined to do - is bound to cut audiences overall, and open up a huge opportunity for rivals Channel 4, Channel 5 and Sky. As Purvis points out, "Greg's problem is that he thinks he knows ITV, when he doesn't. He has failed to read ITV correctly, just as he did with the summer's football deals."

Top BBC executives are sticking to the line that ITV's plans are strangely half-hearted, and that the reinstated news will be driven by ITV's entertainment agenda. But they nevertheless know there will have to be a frank reappraisal. A key commercial sector critic says: "We don't tax every household £100-plus a year for the BBC to mount a spoiling operation. Dyke must back down." ITV bosses are watching the BBC like hawks to make sure ITN moves to 10pm first, by January at the latest, but if they scent trouble News at Ten could return earlier than that - "we can move quickly," Purvis promises.

Hodgson, meanwhile, is off to the remaining party conferences, to lobby hard. The ITC's past week could not contrast more sharply with the disaster experienced by Oftel, often cited as the model for a replacement communications regulator, which remains in disgrace over its lax approach to BT. With the white paper on communications still fluid, the ITC is decisively back in the game.

fields.headline: Death by celebrity
fields.standfirst: When  Roy Greenslade  first met Paula Yates 20 years ago, she was desperate for fame and exposure in the press. By the time she died last week, the notoriety brought about by a career as tabloid fodder had played its part in her downfall
fields.trailText: When Roy Greenslade first met Paula Yates 20 years ago, she was desperate for fame and exposure in the press. By the time she died last week, the notoriety brought about by a career as tabloid fodder had played its part in her downfall
fields.body:
When I was features editor of the Daily Star in 1980, a startling young woman appeared in my office claiming to have "a huge scoop". It was, she trilled, the first-ever interview with Linda McCartney. I recall it being difficult to concentrate on the amateurish article which the 20-year-old Paula Yates placed in front of me. She was underdressed, sporting a striking tattoo on her arm (then a novelty), talkative and unable to sit down for longer than a few seconds at a time.

There was something about the piece - or was it about her? - that struck me as quirkily original and Linda certainly wasn't speaking to anyone at the time, so I decided it was worth the effort. With Paula at my side, and a gaggle of male reporters rubber-necking the glass cubicle that passed for my office, I spent an hour rewriting the interview.

After she had gone, one of the guys asked if I wanted, nudge nudge, to see "the Penthouse set". I wouldn't have even known about the raunchy pictures of Paula draped across leather chairs in a gentleman's club but for her having mentioned it within the first 10 minutes of our meeting.

She had been astonished, and perhaps even a little miffed, that I hadn't seen them. She appeared keen to cast herself as the wayward, sexy, blonde daughter of the disgraced Stars on Sunday presenter Jess Yates. "Look at me, aren't I naughty!" Now, she explained, she was cleaning up her act. At the time I didn't realise she cleaned and dirtied her act every other week.

She claimed to have run a gossip column at the Record Mirror, and wanted to become a "proper journalist". In those pre-Wapping days, without union membership, that wasn't at all easy. Since she wasn't in the NUJ that first article carried a bizarre byline: "Exclusive interview with Linda McCartney by Paula Yates as told to Roy Greenslade."

She also caught the attention of editor Derek Jameson and I seem to recall he gave her a column a couple of years later at the News of the World before he lost patience with her unreliability. By that time she was "a celebrity", having presented the notorious Tube on Channel 4 and become Bob Geldof's partner. I met her again when I bought the serial rights to her first silly book, Rock Stars in their Underpants. Again, I found her fun to be with. All those things people have said about her being a smart girl pretending to be an airhead were true, she was a wacky woman with a self-deprecating sense of humour and oodles of charm. I have never been so charmed by someone who swore so much.

In 1986, when I was assistant editor at the Sun, her fame had reached such proportions that I bought the serial rights to her next book, Sex with Paula Yates, after reading only a synopsis. Unfortunately, the finished manuscript turned out to be a turkey, too trivial and too controversial even for our august organ. But I had agreed to pay a lot, Paula's name was good enough to sell anything, so I arranged with her that - just for the Sun - we would write a new version. So I turned up at the house she and Geldof shared in Chelsea ready to enjoy an afternoon with Paula.

Instead, Bob came in, introduced himself, said the book was "a load of shite", that Paula wasn't up to the task of re-doing it and that he and I should tackle the job. Paula could leave us to it. She, as chirpy as ever, accepted this slight and vanished upstairs while we did indeed cobble together a reasonable load of nonsense. A smiling Paula delivered cups of tea occasionally and though we tried to interest her in what we were doing in her name, she seemed blithely unconcerned. Anyway, the serial went off successfully, although I always wished the byline could have read: "Sex with Paula Yates by Bob Geldof, as told to Roy Greenslade."

In telling that anecdote, by the way, I'm not trying to infer anything sinister, or otherwise, about the nature of the relationship between Paula and Bob. The point I'm seeking to make is about the casual way Paula treated herself and the way we in newspapers treated her. She was one of our commodities, a famous person whom we used to sell more copies. Yet, of course, we were also the carriage she boarded on her route to fame and wealth. It is this duality which is so fascinating.

I fully realise there were traumas specific to Paula. In the past week, her obituary writers have properly drawn attention to the psychological blows she suffered due to a loveless childhood, her acrimonious split with Geldof, the discovery that the man she thought was her father was not, and the sordid death of the father of her fourth child. At some stage the kookiness that set her apart, her disorienting habit of changing clothes and personality, sometimes two or three times a day, probably tipped over into disorder. But was that because of her own emotional problems or due to the pressures of living life in a goldfish bowl?

Mary Kenny in the Daily Express was in no doubt, suggesting that Paula was murdered by a lethal substance called celebrity. The Guardian's Yvonne Roberts took a similar stance, arguing that the cult of the celebrity has now become a blood sport: "for our entertainment," she wrote, "we watch as a mentally ill individual 'blessed' by fame disintegrates before us."

There can be little doubt that the cult of celebrity, which is both the raw material and end product of modern media, devours many of those people who struggle so hard to attain fame. For a while, a very short while, it's fun to be recognised in the street, to sign autographs in the supermarket, to be invited to the parties and premieres, to be primped and praised. The Big Brother contestants, the archetypical media-created celebrities, are in that phase just now.

But Kenny and Roberts are right when they point to the darker side that inevitably follows, the moment when, to borrow that excellent Australian phrase, the media deem it time to cut down the tall poppies. How many times have I read in tabloids that someone is "just famous for being famous" as if the papers themselves had not been responsible for generating that fame? For a variety of reasons - a moment's indiscretion, perhaps, a waning of the stardom, an insult to a photographer, or just Buggins' turn - the celebrity begins to get the treatment. We've had enough of the saccharine. We can't sell on that any longer. If you want the publicity then we need more exposure: that rocky private life, the dalliance with your best friend's wife, the flirtation with drugs, the rift with your parents. Come on, give us all you've got, and then some.

Appealing to public prurience, tabloid newspapers and tabloid TV eat their own children with undisguised relish. The dehumanisation of "the celebrity" is one of the most cynical of media acts. They make them and they break them. As Princess Diana, that classic media-heroine-cum-victim, discovered, whether the story is good or bad, it's always news if you are famous. Your misfortune is manna from heaven for a tabloid, and the greater the misfortune, the better.

Hey, wait a moment, say the editors. When these people are wannabes, they seek us out. They use us as their springboard to fame. Once we've granted them their 15 minutes, it's our turn. But does a moth understand the danger of flying too close to the candle? Do those who crave fame realise the consequences? Was Paula, the exhibitionist daughter of a famous father with some notion of the celebrity circus, able to understand what she was letting herself in for?

There are mature, sensible people who handle fame without becoming creatures of the tabloids. We know a lot about, say, Anne Robinson or Michael Parkinson, but they retain their privacy and their dignity. Not so the young and the glamorous - models, rock singers, actors, TV presenters - who are required to reveal every one of their intimate secrets in order to satisfy the passing whims of press and public. It may not have been the only reason for Paula Yates's degeneration, but it sure played its part. As, of course, did I.

But Kenny and Roberts are right when they point to the darker side that inevitably follows, the moment when, to borrow that excellent Australian phrase, the media deem it time to cut down the tall poppies. How many times have I read in tabloids that someone is "just famous for being famous" as if the papers themselves had not been responsible for generating that fame? For a variety of reasons - a moment's indiscretion, perhaps, a waning of the stardom, an insult to a photographer, or just Buggins' turn - the celebrity begins to get the treatment. We've had enough of the saccharine. We can't sell on that any longer. If you want the publicity then we need more exposure: that rocky private life, the dalliance with your best friend's wife, the flirtation with drugs, the rift with your parents. Come on, give us all you've got, and then some. Appealing to public prurience, tabloid newspapers and tabloid TV eat their own children with undisguised relish. The dehumanisation of "the celebrity" is one of the most cynical of media acts. They make them and they break them. As Princess Diana, that classic media-heroine-cum-victim, discovered, whether the story is good or bad, it's always news if you are famous. Your misfortune is manna from heaven for a tabloid, and the greater the misfortune, the better. Hey, wait a moment, say the editors. When these people are wannabes, they seek us out. They use us as their springboard to fame. Once we've granted them their 15 minutes, it's our turn. But does a moth understand the danger of flying too close to the candle? Do those who crave fame realise the consequences? Was Paula, the exhibitionist daughter of a famous father with some notion of the celebrity circus, able to understand what she was letting herself in for? There are mature, sensible people who handle fame without becoming creatures of the tabloids. We know a lot about, say, Anne Robinson or Michael Parkinson, but they retain their privacy and their dignity. Not so the young and the glamorous - models, rock singers, actors, TV presenters - who are required to reveal every one of their intimate secrets in order to satisfy the passing whims of press and public. It may not have been the only reason for Paula Yates's degeneration, but it sure played its part. As, of course, did I.

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: • Celebrity!, ITV's new stripped tea-time showbiz fiesta, launches tonight on a wing and a prayer. It has been pulled together by Nick Bullen, former producer of doomed OK!TV, in record time - three and a half weeks after ITV's deal with the mag collapsed. Andi Peters and Penny Smith are presenting, with the not-at-all-clear brief of targeting teenagers and the over-50s. Tricky, particularly as the set was still being built at the weekend - apparently, because of the fuel crisis, the necessary wooden parts couldn't be delivered until last week.

 Celebrity!, ITV's new stripped tea-time showbiz fiesta, launches tonight on a wing and a prayer. It has been pulled together by Nick Bullen, former producer of doomed OK!TV, in record time - three and a half weeks after ITV's deal with the mag collapsed. Andi Peters and Penny Smith are presenting, with the not-at-all-clear brief of targeting teenagers and the over-50s. Tricky, particularly as the set was still being built at the weekend - apparently, because of the fuel crisis, the necessary wooden parts couldn't be delivered until last week.

 Monkey hears that rap entrepreneur Puff Daddy racked up an impressive $10,000 (£6,680) bill at a club in the Hamptons, where rich New Yorkers spend their summers, while a documentary about the area was being filmed. But towards the end of the evening, Mr Daddy left in something of a hurry, apparently forgetting to settle his tab, despite the notorious size of his wallet. Perhaps mindful of appearing like a miser on national TV, Mr Daddy was persuaded to return and pay out a reduced fee of $5,000 (£3,340). He wouldn't get away with that at the Ivy...

 Last seen mauling various executives connected with Big Brother at the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival, Steve Hewlett was due to reprise his presentational skills for a Royal Television Society masterclass on popular factual TV later this month. And who present can forget his Paxman-esque turning on Peter Bazalgette over the automatic signing of Big Brother contestants to Bazal's in-house talent agency? Sadly for those of us who believe Hewlett is wasted as director of programmes at Carlton, the engagement has been abruptly cancelled. Monkey hears that when the masterclass decided to focus on Big Brother, some panellists were reluctant to take part with Hewlett hosting.

 They aren't even real celebrities, part 64. We are living in a very strange world when the stars of a hit TV drama are edged into second billing by a cheat who was thrown off a gameshow. Yet "Nasty" Nick Bateman took the star slot on The Priory this week, to the bemusement of Cold Feet's Fay Ripley and John Thomson. The hapless pair even had to share a dressing room, while Bateman got one of his own. "And he had a TV," muttered Ripley, as she procured Nick's autograph in the bar. It seems that all those years at drama school count for nothing compared with a couple of months locked up in a prefab in Bow.

 Monkey couldn't help but notice two rather different Manchester United stories this weekend. The Mail on Sunday profiled lucky life-long Reds fan Alison Ryan, who has just landed her dream job as director of communications at the football club, but it looks as though there is already trouble in paradise. Note the Sunday People's front-page splash: "Man United boss caught with a hooker." Manchester United chairman Martin Edwards seems to have been playing away from home! And all this in her first week. Perhaps not-so-lucky Alison's £125,000 salary will be about right.

 Memos going out to BBC staff detailing new expenses changes show that Birt-era Stalinism is alive and well at Dyke Towers. In a document that makes the Magna Carta look like a bus ticket, the BBC's Expenses Committee gives "guidelines" to staff for understanding the new regime.

Staff will no longer be entitled to advance expenses, and overnight accomodation will be subject to a cap of £55. And if you were thinking of taking your other half along on a lig, think again. The guidelines stipulate: "Your accommodation should be a single, standard room with bathroom facilities." Lunch, staff are told, should not exceed £16, with breakfast coming in at £6.

But suggestions that Dyke's new broom may mask a return to Dalek culture are unfounded. "It is recognised that at certain times of the year a social occasion for all staff to mix informally may be appropriate," say the guidelines. "It is usual for you to make a contribution towards the cost of such an occasion, but where your contribution does not cover the actual cost, the business unit may meet the difference. Provided the BBC's annual contribution is no more than £75 per head, no tax liability arises." Phew.

fields.headline: Lennon uncut
fields.standfirst: The surviving Beatles have laid out their own version of the band's history, but one voice is conspicuously missing. Now the publication of a remarkably candid 1970 interview with John Lennon offers us a taste of what he might have said. And, reports  Mark Lawson, it's not nice
fields.trailText: The surviving Beatles have laid out their own version of the band's history, but one voice is conspicuously missing. Now the publication of a remarkably candid 1970 interview with John Lennon offers us a taste of what he might have said. And, reports Mark Lawson, it's not nice
fields.body:
Though terrible for loved ones, the early death notoriously solves certain late career problems. Escaping or surviving Oswald's bullet, President Kennedy would probably have been blamed for Vietnam and divorced by Jackie. Princess Diana in her 40s - remarried to a heart surgeon or playboy and obsessively consulting cosmeticians as the vital capital of her glamour dwindled - would have struggled to maintain the love of her middle England constituency.

John Winston Lennon was born in Liverpool on October 9 1940. Among the events to mark his ghostly landmark birthday is the republication in book form - with the restoration of material previously deleted for reasons of legality, tact or (in the case of Yoko's interventions) tedium - of a marathon interview Lennon gave in December 1970 to Jann Wenner, the editor of Rolling Stone magazine. Almost exactly a decade after speaking to Wenner, Lennon was freeze-framed at 40 by Mark Chapman's bullet, but the book and the birthday taunt us to look forward.

Lennon at 60? Imagine... A Parkinson or South Bank Show Special? Possibly, although, provided he was clear of drugs, the pop star would surely realise how silly the bed-ins and bag-ins and primal scream therapy could be made to seem now. The 30th wedding anniversary with Yoko? Unlikely, given the failure rate of rock marriages. And the published interviews show him bickering with Yoko even deep in new love. Perhaps John would now be having a fling with Patsy or Meg on their rebounds from Noel and Liam.

A Beatles reunion concert? Perhaps only if he had broken with Yoko because the strongest material in these interviews is the hatred of his band-mates for their treatment of his wife. Imagine... it really is very hard to do. Probably the only certain project would have been the Greatest Hits album in which, you fear, Lennon would have played down the Beatles songs and played up the Plastic Ono collaborations. It also seems likely that - alive in the year 2000 - Lennon would have mobilised attorneys against the publication of this fuzzy, troubled, bitter conversation from the 70s.

This isn't because the book is bad but because the chats put Lennon's reputation in a context which it has been spared by the reverence inevitably given to those slain young.

It's clear that Lennon had exceptional verbal talents. These are present most obviously in the song lyrics (although his "poetry" collections consist mainly of facetious puns) but also in some magnificent ad-libs. Asked once if Ringo Starr was the best drummer in the world, Lennon answered that he wasn't "even the best drummer in the Beatles", a response which reveals true comedic gifts. In the same way, his remark that the Beatles were "more popular than Jesus" - which was widely seen at the time as a deliberately shocking teasing of the priests - contains a far more subtle acknowledgment of the power and passion of the crowd: a fear of what the Beatles were getting into. One of the best stretches of the Rolling Stone interviews recalls that the sick and the crippled would be placed in the front row at Beatles concerts and then brought round to their dressing rooms. Lennon recalls that the band had an uneasy running joke about how they were being asked to heal them.

But little of what comes from Lennon's clever tongue in these interviews matches either the Ringo joke or the Jesus insight. This was probably because, at the time he grudgingly agreed to the grilling, Lennon was adjusting to the end of one significant relationship - with Paul, George and Ringo - and the beginning of two newish ones: with drugs and Yoko Ono.

When the 30-year-old Lennon and Wenner, six years younger, sat down in Manhattan before the Christmas of 1970, the Beatles' lawyers were gathering for the final splitting of the spoils - on December 31, McCartney would file suits against Starr, Harrison and Lennon - and John was increasingly going solo with Yoko.

Lennon several times tries to abandon the conversation - citing boredom - and seems to continue only because he wishes to settle scores. He word-playingly called one of his verse collections In His Own Write and, in the same spirit, these interviews might have been titled Putting His Spokes In.

The most important restored passage for Beatles admirers and music historians is the one dealing with the reaction of the other three to Yoko. When Wenner asks "How would you characterise George Paul and Ringo's reaction to her?", Lennon replies: "It's the same. You can quote Paul, you can look it up in the papers. He's said it many times: at first he hated Yoko and then he got to like her. It's too late for me. And for Yoko. Why should she take that sort of shit from those people? They were writing about her looking miserable in Let It Be.

"You sit through 60 sessions with the most big-headed uptight people on earth and see what it's fuckin' like, and be insulted just because you love someone... I'll never forgive them. I don't care a fucking shit about Hare Krishna and God and Paul... I don't forgive 'em for that."

For the original publication, Wenner apparently extended the quote with a soothing coda in which Lennon admits "although I can't help still loving them either". The truthfulness of this version matters because Anthology, written by the surviving three, suggests that the boys eventually got over the Yoko coldness. Perhaps there was a rapprochement in the final decade of Lennon's life but, in 1970, his hatred of McCartney in particular spatters from these transcripts. The others "got fed up with being sidemen for Paul". Paul was impressed by Linda's dad because "he's got Picassos hanging on the wall and because he's some kind of East Coast suit. Form and not substance. And that's McCartney."

There has always been psychological interest in the extent to which the boy band was shattered by the incursion of girls. This sexual sub-text is further illuminated in these interviews. Angry with his colleagues for their suspicion of Yoko, Lennon seems most obsessed in the finally terminal business wranglings with the fact that Paul wants to bring Linda's family into the management of the band.

This lack of self-knowledge also applies to the star's discussion of gurus. He is witheringly funny about the Maharishi Maresh Yogi, who counselled the Beatles in the late 60s. He is with them in Bangor when news of Brian Epstein's death comes through and advises them to "be happy". And yet, even as he sees through the Maharishi in this interview, Lennon is being psychologically blindfolded by the "primal scream therapy" of Dr Arthur Janov. He tells Wenner: "It's a process going on - we primal almost daily... and, in a nutshell, primal therapy allowed us to feel feelings continually, and these feelings usually make you cry."

This book captures a moment on the cusp between the 60 and the 70s when the religion of celebrity - now our everyday faith - was taking seed. Interviewers seriously expected pop stars to speak wisdom and the performers responded to this pressure by fleeing to gurus and pharmacists.

But there are many intriguing incidental details here. Lennon explains that the opaque lyrics of Norwegian Wood were not attributable to drugs - although the poetic streak in his writing elsewhere often did have a chemical provocation - but to the fact the the song describes an affair and he couldn't let his then wife know that. It's also fascinating to hear him insist that he knew he was a genius at the age of eight or nine and railed against the aunt who raised him for throwing away some early verse because "it'll be worth millions when I'm famous". The problem with printed interviews, however, is that we can't be sure of the tone of this. Lennon may be sending up himself - or Wenner.

Although the Lennon legend has undoubtedly been helped by martyrdom, it was also crucial to his allure that, unlike former colleagues, he had done nothing as embarassing as Mull of Kintyre or Thomas the Tank Engine voiceovers.

His death kept him cool. Though influenced by the music of the Beatles in general, Noel and Liam Gallagher copied Lennon in appearance and attitude. It was the writer of Imagine's fame which Chris Evans tried to aggrandise in the mobile phone ad.

But only under the influential of acute nostalgia or strong narcotics could a reader get through these interviews with a straight face.

A lyricist whose words on many occasions touched poetry here spews angry and amnesiac ramblings. The Rolling Stone conversations are his Mull, his Thomas. Yoko Ono, in her introduction, suggests that John would have loved the internet because "he liked to experiment with new media". Perhaps. But it's hard to weep too deeply for this website we missed and there's always the alternative possibility that Lennon would have been in court with today's living pop stars protecting his royalties from unauthorised downloading. The life of John Lennon had a tragic shape but - as so often in these cases - it can seem a kinder shape than the alternative.

 Lennon Remembers by Jan S Wenner is published by Verso at £13

fields.headline: Prescott Tube plan damned
fields.standfirst:
Inquiry into public-private scheme reveals safety risks

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A sweeping indictment of John Prescott's plans to part-privatise London Underground - commissioned at Labour's insistence - will be published today, threatening to upstage the deputy prime minister's keynote party conference speech on the simmering transport crisis.
fields.body:
A sweeping indictment of John Prescott's plans to part-privatise London Underground - commissioned at Labour's insistence - will be published today, threatening to upstage the deputy prime minister's keynote party conference speech on the simmering transport crisis.

The government's public-private partnership (PPP) plan for the Tube system should be abandoned in favour of a bond-financed public option, unless tougher safeguards on safety, contract compliance and value-for money are introduced, according to an in dependent report for the London mayor, Ken Livingstone.

The review, led by the head of the Industrial Society think tank, Will Hutton, was commissioned as a condition of Labour politicians joining Mr Livingstone's administration. It is based on criteria suggested by Frank Dobson, Labour's London mayoral candidate, and had been welcomed by the party's leadership.

But it provides no comfort for the government's scheme, which involves breaking the network into three parts and handing over its infrastructure and maintenance to private firms on 30-year contracts.

Mr Prescott's PPP plan, says the report, has been pushed through on the basis of unwarranted assumptions about cost, risk and efficiency advantages; involves potentially serious safety problems; is based on badly-designed contracts and would lead to a loss of democratic accountability.

Speaking at a supporters' rally in Brighton yesterday, Mr Livingstone - who will only be given responsibility for the Tube once the private contracts are locked in place - described the Hutton report as "devastating" and said it would now be "almost impossible for the government to go ahead".

He later said the report showed that PPP "as presently constituted would be unsafe and poor value for money, giving some of the world's nastiest private sector monopolies intolerable leverage over London's elected government".

Although the contracting process is behind schedule, the government currently shows no signs of backing off, despite PPP's unpopularity among core Labour supporters and the hostility of trade unions.

The review by Mr Hutton, the former Observer editor, took evidence from all sides, but also commissioned research from a contract theory expert, David Ulph, of University College London, and transport economist Peter White, of Westminster University.

Their report is scathing about the state of the Underground and its management, but points out that performance targets for the PPP have been set 5% below even what is being achieved now. It is also sceptical about the extent to which investment risk will really be transferred to the private sector.

The design of the PPP has been loaded to favour the private contractors against a notional "public sector comparator", Mr Hutton argues, and the government has unreasonably assumed that a public sector option could only secure 6% efficiency gains, compared with over 20% under PPP.

The public sector bond option is cheaper unless the private scheme delivers 21% efficiency gains on investment, the reports says. But much higher efficiencies could be expected in the public sector using outside management under a stable investment regime.

The report says that under PPP contracts, safety can be traded off against other improvements and warns of recently-leaked health and safety executive fears: "We insist its concerns be addressed in full if PPP is to go ahead".

Calling for the current national audit office investigation into PPP to be broadened to examine the assumptions behind the scheme, Mr Hutton says: "Negotiations are effectively being made over the head of the elected mayor in secrecy, notwithstanding the fact that it will be he and his successors for 30 years who will have to operate the PPP."

"We conclude," the report says, "that PPP should not proceed" unless "it meets much more rigorous safety and value criteria, and if it is substantially amended to protect against the risk that contracts are incomplete and overgenerous." Otherwise, Tube modernisation should be financed within the public sector.

It is based on criteria suggested by Frank Dobson, Labour's London mayoral candidate, and had been welcomed by the party's leadership. But it provides no comfort for the government's scheme, which involves breaking the network into three parts and handing over its infrastructure and maintenance to private firms on 30-year contracts. Mr Prescott's PPP plan, says the report, has been pushed through on the basis of unwarranted assumptions about cost, risk and efficiency advantages; involves potentially serious safety problems; is based on badly-designed contracts and would lead to a loss of democratic accountability. Speaking at a supporters' rally in Brighton yesterday, Mr Livingstone - who will only be given responsibility for the Tube once the private contracts are locked in place - described the Hutton report as "devastating" and said it would now be "almost impossible for the government to go ahead". He later said the report showed that PPP "as presently constituted would be unsafe and poor value for money, giving some of the world's nastiest private sector monopolies intolerable leverage over London's elected government". Although the contracting process is behind schedule, the government currently shows no signs of backing off, despite PPP's unpopularity among core Labour supporters and the hostility of trade unions. The review by Mr Hutton, the former Observer editor, took evidence from all sides, but also commissioned research from a contract theory expert, David Ulph, of University College London, and transport economist Peter White, of Westminster University. Their report is scathing about the state of the Underground and its management, but points out that performance targets for the PPP have been set 5% below even what is being achieved now. It is also sceptical about the extent to which investment risk will really be transferred to the private sector. The design of the PPP has been loaded to favour the private contractors against a notional "public sector comparator", Mr Hutton argues, and the government has unreasonably assumed that a public sector option could only secure 6% efficiency gains, compared with over 20% under PPP. The public sector bond option is cheaper unless the private scheme delivers 21% efficiency gains on investment, the reports says. But much higher efficiencies could be expected in the public sector using outside management under a stable investment regime. The report says that under PPP contracts, safety can be traded off against other improvements and warns of recently-leaked health and safety executive fears: "We insist its concerns be addressed in full if PPP is to go ahead". Calling for the current national audit office investigation into PPP to be broadened to examine the assumptions behind the scheme, Mr Hutton says: "Negotiations are effectively being made over the head of the elected mayor in secrecy, notwithstanding the fact that it will be he and his successors for 30 years who will have to operate the PPP." "We conclude," the report says, "that PPP should not proceed" unless "it meets much more rigorous safety and value criteria, and if it is substantially amended to protect against the risk that contracts are incomplete and overgenerous." Otherwise, Tube modernisation should be financed within the public sector.

webTitle: Dark side of Diana described by ex-aide

fields.headline: Dark side of Diana described by ex-aide
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: A devastating portrait of a wilful and manipulative Princess Diana emerged yesterday from extracts of a book written by her former private secretary, Patrick Jephson, printed in the Sunday Times.
fields.body:
A devastating portrait of a wilful and manipulative Princess Diana emerged yesterday from extracts of a book written by her former private secretary, Patrick Jephson, printed in the Sunday Times.

Publication of Shadows of a Princess, due to come out in Britain and the US next month, has already been condemned as deplorable by the Queen and the Prince of Wales. But from the extract published yesterday the royal family could take comfort from the fact that the outlines and much of the detail are already well known - and much more damaging to the memory of the princess than to themselves.

That may be of small comfort to Mr Jephson, who, although standing to make a great deal of money, knows he will be cast into outer darkness by the Palace and may be stripped of an honour bestowed on him for his service.

Both the palace, which sought for two years to stop the book being published, and the newspaper which purchased the revelations may feel they could have been much worse. Mr Jephson was the princess's equerry and then private secretary for more than seven years until January 1996. He watched the breakdown of her marriage and was instrumental in handling the divorce.

The author claimed that his book would give a more rounded portrait of the princess than previous publications and that it would be "entirely positive" for her sons, Princes William and Harry. "For them there will be nothing new to learn from this that's harmful and a lot of new stuff that's good," the paper quoted him as saying.

The book claims the princess referred to the Duke of Edinburgh as "Stavros", mocking his Greek roots, and said at one point that her royal jewellery was a reward for "years of purgatory with this f***ing family". The book suggests nevertheless that "a small handful of sugar lumps" could have wooed her back to the royal family. She "did not set out to rebel. What in the end was seen as her disaffection was what she did to compensate for a chronic feeling of rejection".

The book claims that Diana found the family emotionally cold and unfriendly and became increasingly reckless in her behaviour, taking a string of lovers - including one smuggled into Kensington Palace in the boot of her car - and becoming paranoid about non-existent plots to bug her conversations or even assassinate her.

The author claims she told him that the letter from the Queen in 1995, telling the couple to get a divorce following Diana's Panorama interview, was the first letter her mother-in-law had ever sent her.

Mr Jephson says the princess told him she had confronted Camilla Parker-Bowles at a party and asked her to leave Charles alone, but had received a stony response which left her in tears.

The princess's 43-year-old former secretary - originally seconded from the Royal Navy, and now running a public relations consultancy and living in Fulham - divulges Diana's ruthless treatment of her staff and her love of dirty jokes.

He claims she once exulted in accusing Tiggy Legge-Bourke, her sons' nanny, at a party of having had an abortion. Mr Jephson claims she sent him and other staff members hurtful messages by pager.

But he says: "For all the squandered chances, the stupidity, the occasional downright wickedness, there was something heroic about her just as there was something essentially brutal about those gathered against her."

Last night a Buckingham Palace spokesman said: "We have said everything we are going to say about this book."
