fields.headline: Milosevic claims poll win
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: President Slobodan Milosevic was fighting for his political life last night with the same audacity that has kept him in power for 13 years.
fields.body:
President Slobodan Milosevic was fighting for his political life last night with the same audacity that has kept him in power for 13 years.

After a turnout in yesterday's elections that may be as high as 60% in Serbia and 75% in the rest of the country, he responded to the threat by staging a victory concert on the main square of the capital.

It began an hour before the polls closed, wrongfooting the plans of his main challenger the Belgrade lawyer Vojislav Kostunica to hold a rally in the same square. The danger of violent clashes grew as both sides in Yugoslavia's hotly contested election accused each other of fraud.

As supporters gathered in Belgrade city centre, state television announced an overwhelming lead for Mr Milosevic in voting in the Serb-populated villages of northern Kosovo. The claim was dismissed by the opposition as "pure manipulation".

Hundreds of thousands voted in Serbia, its sister republic of Montenegro, and UN-administered Kosovo after Mr Milosevic called an early election.

Confident of catching the opposition off-guard, he was surprised by its unity and Mr Kostunica's strength in the latest opinion polls, which suggested that Mr Milosevic's 13 years of power would end if the balloting and count were free and fair.

Mr Milosevic put on a show of looking relaxed and confident as he voted with his wife, Mirjana Markovic, in an exclusive Belgrade suburb, and expressed optimism about the vote in a comment carried by state news agency Tanjug.

"I expect the political scene in Serbia to be clarified, creating the conditions for lasting stability and even faster economic development," he said, referring to efforts to rebuild the country after last year's Nato air strikes.

Mr Kostunica, the candidate of the 18-party alliance known as Democratic Opposition of Serbia, also voted in Belgrade. "It should be shown that the authorities in a democracy are changeable," he said, accusing the government of trying to confuse voters and justify any future moves to preserve power at all cost.

During the afternoon, as the opposition workers were arriving to prepare for their concert, they discovered that President Milosevic's party workers were already building a huge concert stage to the left of the square.

State television, which is controlled by Mr Milosevic had set up in front of the national museum in preparation for a live broadcast when the president's victory would be announced. Serbia was informed of Mr Milosevic's victory before the votes had been counted. "The political landscape has now been cleaned," the president said.

A Serbian traditional band was dressed in blue uniforms and began its concert with second world war songs while confused young people who had come to what they thought was an opposition rally milled around in confusion.

"Staging the concert on Republicca Square is designed to provoke us and give him the chance to crack down. They need a reason to use the police and the army," Steva Markovic, a 41-year-old opposition activist and computer analyst said.

Most of the people who arrived at the floodlit square were young and anti-Milosevic: "He is going to choke us again," a 21-year-old philosophy student said. Others stood in depressed silence. "The queues outside my polling station were the longest I have ever seen in my life," Davor Petrovic said. "I'm sure it will be a big turnout but we hadn't even finished voting when he did this. No one knows what to do."

As the voting got under way the federal prime minister, Momir Bulatovic, who is a regime loyalist said that under the constitution Mr Milosevic was obliged to remain in power until 2001, regardless of the election result - a suggestion aimed at discouraging his opponents from voting.

An uneasy fear has been seeping across the country for days. Even opposition supporters confident of victory at the ballot box are terrified that Mr Milosevic will not step down without bloodshed. Psychologist Zorica Razicsaid: "I think tonight nothing will happen, but on Monday I think people will be killed on the streets of Belgrade," she said.

On the eve of the poll, the election authorities announced a change in voting procedure that many believe breaches the fundamental right of privacy for voters. The Federal Election Commission ruled that every ballot slip would be checked by the local election board ostensibly to ensure that only one slip was put into the ballot box.

In southern Serbia, where voting fraud was most feared, 370 polling stations had no representative of the opposition on the board, an opposition spokesman said.

The Belgrade-based Centre for Free Elections and Democracy listed dozens of irregularities and said the poll was a "complete mess". Marko Blagojevic, its spokesman, said that in Leskovac, the voting lists were not opened up for inspection and voting was taking place without people needing identification.

fields.headline: Pressure builds over pensions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was last night under mounting pressure to force concessions from the chancellor Gordon Brown on petrol and pensions, the two issues that most seriously threaten his government's popularity - and the success of this week's crucial Labour conference.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was last night under mounting pressure to force concessions from the chancellor Gordon Brown on petrol and pensions, the two issues that most seriously threaten his government's popularity - and the success of this week's crucial Labour conference.

As delegates gathered in Brighton after the worst few days of the Blair administration, the prime minister and his allies took to the TV studios in contrite mood, designed to placate angry trade unions and disappointed activists.

Although Mr Blair and Peter Mandelson dismissed renewed talk of cabinet splits as "recycled stuff", they sounded chastened over their "unsympathetic" response to the fuel protest, their mistakes on the Millennium Dome and what John Prescott called the cabinet's failure to sell its complex pensions policy to voters.

But Mr Brown, the man who can head off a conference revolt on pensions on Wednesday, was far from Brighton at the IMF/World Bank conference in Prague - from where he again signalled his determination not to be stampeded into premature action on either big issue ahead of his Budget next March.

The chancellor's absence has hampered negotiations but he will be in Brighton this afternoon to deliver his economic report - stressing that there will be "no return to the old short-term issues, no sudden lurches in tax or spending policy, no irresponsible pre-election sprees or pay demands we cannot afford".

Wrapped up in his familiar message about economic stability as the key to growth, better public services and social justice, that stern message will not be enough - unless the chancellor also manages to signal that his mid-November pre-Budget report will show flexibility in response to grassroots anger.

Instead Mr Brown will parade his radical credentials by revealing that he wants the low pay commission to come forward with proposals for an increase in the minimum wage. In an interview with the Guardian in Prague yesterday, the chancellor said that analysis by the Treasury showed there had been no ill-effects from the minimum wage since it was introduced. "I believe it has been a success, demonstrating that social justice and economic progress can go hand in hand. We always said that it would not destroy jobs and lead to higher inflation, and we were right."

Although Mr Brown refused to speculate on what level the minimum wage would be set at, it is clear that the government would be happy with an above-inflation increase from £3.70 an hour to £4 an hour next year.

Privately, Blairite ministers expect the Treasury to accede to pressure for a generous increase in the basic pension rate - currently £67.50 a week - by election day, probably next May or June. The minimum income guarantee (MIG) will also be raised to £90 a week from next April, it is increasingly likely, as ministers dig their way out of the public relations hole created by the last Budget's 75p basic rise.

"The Treasury wishes it had taken our advice last year and raised the pension by more than the rate of inflation. They know it will cost them more now," said one minister involved.

Some senior ministers are less sympathetic to the fuel protesters and what one called their contradictory demands. On BBC2's Breakfast with Frost Mr Blair said: "We'd all like to do it [make petrol cheaper]. The question is whether you can do it responsibly given your other priorities."

But no less a figure than Mr Mandelson admitted on ITV's Dimbleby that "we were a bit unsympathetic and a little high-handed", that "we got the tone wrong by saying, in a highly bureaucratic way, this all depends on the due process of the budget-making process" - the line adopted by both Downing Street and the Treasury at the time.

It is the mishandling of the fuel issue that has crippled Labour in a succession of polls, including yesterday's NOP survey for Channel 4 which put the Conservatives ahead by 40% to 32% with the Lib Dems on 22%. Another poll, Mori for the Mail on Sunday, put the gap at 39%-35%-21%.

The hotter issue in Brighton is pensions. Leaders of major unions, including the TGWU, the GMB and Unison, are lobbying behind the scenes and in public. They want Mr Brown to sharply increase the basic pension and not to rule out restoring the link with earnings, as Labour's economic commission statement will tomorrow, unless a fudge is engineered.

Mr Blair and Mr Prescott loyally defended Mr Brown's position yesterday, stressing the government's determination to help the poorest pensioners, who will get the lion's share of the extra £6.5bn being spent over five years. But Mr Prescott admitted that older voters' perception was that "they don't think they're being helped".

Some Blair aides believe that conflict will actually help the government, enabling it to bounce back against the Tories more strongly. But ministers do not want a fractious conference and the unions, long neglected by New Labour, sense weakness and are happy to exploit it. One Blair nightmare failed to materialise yesterday: Mo Mowlam's last speech as an MP was loyally on message.

fields.headline: Embryo scandal sparks panic
fields.standfirst: Suspended scientist goes into hiding after inspectors find inconsistencies in clinics' records
fields.trailText: Hundreds of women caught up in a missing frozen embryos scandal have contacted an emergency helpline fearing that their children are not theirs or that their stored embryos have been given to other women, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of women caught up in a missing frozen embryos scandal have contacted an emergency helpline fearing that their children are not theirs or that their stored embryos have been given to other women, it emerged yesterday.

As the embryologist at the centre of the blunder remained in hiding, the two infertility clinics involved confirmed that they had been swamped with calls from distraught women who fear they were either given the wrong embryos or have been told that their hopes of using their stored frozen embryos to conceive a child have been dashed.

Some women have had their fertility treatment suspended because the clinics have discovered errors in their patient records relating to their stored embryos. They have been offered the chance to start treatment afresh using a new embryo cycle.

Tim Hedgley of Issue, the national fertility association brought in to counsel patients, said there was a strong likelihood that women had been implanted with the wrong embryos . He said the legal ramifications of the mix-up were "extremely serious".

Parents might be raising children who were not theirs, he said, while women who had embryos stored before undergoing ovarian cancer treatment could face the prospect that their only hope of conceiving had been dashed.

The scientist, Paul Fielding, well-known in the world of embryology, has not been seen since being suspended from his post at North Hampshire hospital after human fertility and embryology inspectors found "inconsistencies between the recording and storage of frozen embryos" at the hospital's assisted conception unit and at the nearby private Hampshire clinic, where he also worked.

The hospital yesterday refused to discuss his whereabouts as women from both clinics underwent counselling.

The embryologist's home in the Hampshire village of Whitchurch remained deserted. Visible through the windows were floral tributes marking the recent birth of Benjamin, a second child for Mr Fielding and his wife Alison and a brother for three-year-old Jonathan.

The head of the Hampshire clinic, the infertility expert Robert Bates, was said to be devastated by the errors. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has asked the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, to prepare an urgent report on the fiasco.

The NHS trust hospital, where 10 couples are affected, refused to comment on suggestions that women may have been implanted with the embryos from other couples.

The blunder raised the prospect of a potentially massive court case if women gave birth to babies from an embryo which was not theirs.

It also raised serious concerns about auditing and inspections by the HFEA, the organisation which monitors and licenses fertility clinics, Issue added.

"If they have a child from embryo transfer then they are saying can we be sure the child is ours, and if they had embryos stored they are asking are their embryos still there," said Mr Hedgley.

"This situation could get much worse, given that this embryologist held his post for 10 years."

The problem came to light two weeks ago when staff at the Hampshire clinic, which treats 140 patients a year, went to retrieve frozen embryos from a cryovessel ready for implantation.

Carol Friend, spokeswoman for the clinic, confirmed that they had received calls from several hundred patients who were "scared witless" after reading newspaper reports. But she insisted there was "categorically no possibility" that any patient had become pregnant with another couple's embryos, given the stringent checks made at each stage of fertility treatment and the fact that the number of patients opting for frozen embryo treatment was small because of the lower success rate.

The clinic had stopped using Mr Fielding two months ago although it declined to say whether there had been previous concerns about his performance.

Visible through the windows were floral tributes marking the recent birth of Benjamin, a second child for Mr Fielding and his wife Alison and a brother for three-year-old Jonathan. The head of the Hampshire clinic, the infertility expert Robert Bates, was said to be devastated by the errors. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, has asked the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, to prepare an urgent report on the fiasco. The NHS trust hospital, where 10 couples are affected, refused to comment on suggestions that women may have been implanted with the embryos from other couples. The blunder raised the prospect of a potentially massive court case if women gave birth to babies from an embryo which was not theirs. It also raised serious concerns about auditing and inspections by the HFEA, the organisation which monitors and licenses fertility clinics, Issue added. "If they have a child from embryo transfer then they are saying can we be sure the child is ours, and if they had embryos stored they are asking are their embryos still there," said Mr Hedgley. "This situation could get much worse, given that this embryologist held his post for 10 years." The problem came to light two weeks ago when staff at the Hampshire clinic, which treats 140 patients a year, went to retrieve frozen embryos from a cryovessel ready for implantation. Carol Friend, spokeswoman for the clinic, confirmed that they had received calls from several hundred patients who were "scared witless" after reading newspaper reports. But she insisted there was "categorically no possibility" that any patient had become pregnant with another couple's embryos, given the stringent checks made at each stage of fertility treatment and the fact that the number of patients opting for frozen embryo treatment was small because of the lower success rate. The clinic had stopped using Mr Fielding two months ago although it declined to say whether there had been previous concerns about his performance.

webTitle: Swansong Ovation for Mowlam as she rallies the faithful

fields.headline: Swansong Ovation for Mowlam as she rallies the faithful
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Britain's most popular and unpredictable politician, Mo Mowlam, turned her swansong speech at the Labour party conference into a battle cry, urging the party faithful to fight "tooth and nail" against the Tories in a "tough" general election campaign.
fields.body:
Britain's most popular and unpredictable politician, Mo Mowlam, turned her swansong speech at the Labour party conference into a battle cry, urging the party faithful to fight "tooth and nail" against the Tories in a "tough" general election campaign.

Less than three weeks after announcing she would be standing down at the next election, the Cabinet Office minister yesterday warned delegates the opposition would "fight dirty" but that Labour was up to the challenge.

But she said stressing the government's achievements would be a struggle after the problems that have besieged it in the past few weeks, from the fuel crisis to the Ecclestone affair.

The emotion was pitched high as she was welcomed into the hall - to a standing ovation -by one of her junior ministers, Ian McCartney, as someone "affectionate, gutsy, irreverent, disarmingly honest - our Mo". The nod to the prime minister's description of her at the party conference in Blackpool two years ago continued as a video of stills of the Redcar MP kissing children, laughing with Blair, and as a smiling Durham student - was played to Robbie Williams' 1999 hit She's the One.

Her performance will have disappointed many hopeful that she would have used her last conference speech as an MP to pour scorn on those she believes to have been behind an alleged "whispering campaign".

But the former Northern Ireland secretary, replaced by Peter Mandelson last October, and who is recovering from a brain tumour, began by reiterating her departure was her decision. Delegates were told they needed to stress the Tories' plans to "cut billions from health, education and essential services; privatise pensions; ... and play the despicable cards of prejudice and racism".

fields.headline: Labour conference, day one
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday

Good day

Cabinet Office minister Mo Mowlam, who recently announced that she is to stand down at the next election, received a standing ovation at conference as she told delegates of the "pain and pleasure" of her 13 years in politics.

Bad day

New Labour slowly begins to drift into the sidelines as the word "new" loses its emphasis in logos around the conference dropping its capital 'N' and shrinking in size so it pales into insignificance against the "Labour" in bold type. The traditional red colour of old labour also makes a comeback.

Quote of the day

"I think our communications with the public, our relationship with the electorate has just got to be altogether more open, straighter. If we do things wrong we should put up our hands to making mistakes." Peter Mandelson

Delegate of the day

John Doggett, 53, retired BT sales manager from Felixstowe, Suffolk, who works part-time in the Ipswich constituency office: "This is my first conference so I feel very much the new boy. The highlight for me this afternoon was Ian McCartney, who set the conference in the right mood by giving a rousing speech. Mo Mowlam rallied the troops and I didn't find her downbeat. Do I think there should be a debate about fuel? I don't want to be drawn on that."

Decision of the day

Home secretary Jack Straw announced £59m to be provided over three years to boost police scenes-of-crime work in moves to catch more criminals and crackdown on persistent offenders. A new national programme will make sure that 2,500 hardcore young criminals are supervised every day - "24 hours a day if necessary". The government's extra investment, Mr Straw said, would help solve at least 100,000 more crimes a year by 2004.

Today

11.00am : Environment, transport and the regions debate as deputy PM John Prescott spells out how he would get Britain moving

1.00pm: Guardian debate. Has Labour forgotten its roots? Chris Smith and Lord Falconer

2.15pm: Debate on the economy with chancellor Gordon Brown speaking on pensions and petrol.

webTitle: Minister 'may have given misleading reply' on £1m gift

fields.headline: Minister 'may have given misleading reply' on £1m gift
fields.standfirst:
Formula One controversy continues

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson was yesterday drawn into the row over Labour's handling of the £1m gift from Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone when he was forced to concede that he may have misled the public when he said three years ago that the government had already decided to hand back the cash before being contacted by a journalist over the donation.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson was yesterday drawn into the row over Labour's handling of the £1m gift from Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone when he was forced to concede that he may have misled the public when he said three years ago that the government had already decided to hand back the cash before being contacted by a journalist over the donation.

Mr Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, had made the original claim on the Dimbleby programme, and re-interviewed on the same programme yesterday, he denied he had lied. He assured Mr Dimbleby: "Everything I said to you was on the basis of what I thought to be truth."

Mr Mandelson also asserted that he had not been interviewed by Andrew Rawnsley, the Observer journalist whose new book has revived the controversy over the Ecclestone affair. Sources close to the the chancellor claim Downing Street and Mr Mandelson had tried to use the book to damage Gordon Brown.

Tony Blair was also forced to defend himself against accusations that he had misled the public over the funding.

Most of the attention since the Rawnsley publication has centred on whether Mr Brown misled the public, but Mr Mandelson's critics claim he is also in the dock.

On the Dimbleby programme three years ago, he claimed: "We did not get the first journalist's inquiry about the donation originally made by Mr Ecclestone until Thursday afternoon, evening. Already by then, the prime minister had decided that the original donation should be returned and that the further donation should not be accepted."

The party has subsequently admitted that it did not write to Lord Neill's commission on standards in public life about the donation, and the prospect of a further gift from Mr Ecclestone, until Friday - after the first journalistic inquiry showed the media were aware that Ecclestone had given cash. In addition, the letter sent to Lord Neill asks if the original donation should be returned.

Mr Mandelson's remarks received little attention at the time because he was defending the government on the Dimbleby programme at the same time as Blair was interrogated on the BBC On The Record programme.

Mr Mandelson was forced to tell Mr Dimbleby yesterday: "I'm sorry if I was not clearer, but I was not intending to mislead. Why would I? Because on the very same day the prime minister was giving his own views and his account and if there had been a difference between what he said and what I said that would have left us in no good position at all.

"In the case of the original donation, and I am sorry if I did not make this clear, he wanted Lord Neill's view on whether that should be returned and both issues were addressed in the same letter."

Faced by accusations from Mr Dimbleby that he had lied, he said: "You don't have any evidence for that whatsoever. You are entitled to surmise it."

He also said: "I don't lie. The prime minister does not lie. and the chancellor does not lie. You can of course split up words, split hairs and splice up what I said in different sentences."

The degree of the government's culpability turns on interpretation of its letter to Lord Neill. Critics claim the letter only refers to whether it would be wrong to accept a second donation from Mr Eccelstone, but does not address the issue of the original donation.

Pressed on his role in the Rawnsley book, Mr Mandelson was asked: "You didn't talk to him about this book at all, you didn't discuss it with him, you did not give him some steers?"

"Quite right, I didn't," he replied, before adding he had answered one question about the possible resignation of Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England.

webTitle: Prescott scorns links with Lib Dems links

fields.headline: Prescott scorns links with Lib Dems links
fields.standfirst:
Vote reform

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: John Prescott yesterday launched a coded attack on Tony Blair when he declared that supporters of links between Labour and the Liberal Democrats should be "put it in a boat and sent away".
fields.body:
John Prescott yesterday launched a coded attack on Tony Blair when he declared that supporters of links between Labour and the Liberal Democrats should be "put it in a boat and sent away".

In a provocative intervention on the first day of the Labour conference, the deputy prime minister said Labour had never benefited from co-operation with Liberals.

"Just let it slide away," Mr Prescott said about Lib Dem demands for the introduction of proportional representation. I mean what I've seen certainly wasn't to the advantage of the Labour party, was it?

"Put it in a boat and send it away along with the Lib/Labs."

Mr Prescott was careful not to name the prime minister.

But his remarks were aimed directly at Mr Blair whose cherished dream is to realign the centre left by forging closer links between Labour and the Lib Dems.

At his first party conference after the 1997 election, Mr Blair spoke of his hopes that the 21st century would be the "radical" century as the centre left joined forces to keep the Tories out of power.

As a first step, the prime minister appointed a commission under the chairmanship of Lord Jenkins to examine options for reforming Westminster's first past the post electoral system.

Mr Prescott was scathing about proportional representation (PR) yesterday and dismissive of Lord Jenkins. In an interview with BBC1's On the Record, the deputy prime minister said: "I have seen nothing [in the 1970s] or nothing since that convinces me that PR is in the nation's interest of stable government. I've never been a fan of it."

Asked whether the chances of PR being introduced have now waned, Mr Prescott referred his interviewer, John Humphrys, back to the prime minister.

"I don't know, you'd better ask those who make the decision about these matters. Roy Jenkins has written a nice little book about it and you can read it."

Asked whether he had read Lord Jenkins' report, which was published in 1998, Mr Prescott underlined his contempt for the founder of the breakaway SDP when he said: "No, I'm afraid I haven't. But I'll certainly be playing a part if it comes to a decision in the party like everybody else."

Mr Prescott's outburst will be seen as provocative because Labour has agreed to keep alive the prospect of a referendum on electoral reform after the next election.

Defenders of the traditional first past the post system agreed to allow a referendum commitment to be included in Labour's next manifesto on the understanding that Lord Jenkins' preferred system, known as AV Plus, is not introduced. They are hoping that a referendum would be held to introduce a less proportional system, known as AV, which maintains all the existing Westminster constituencies, is introduced.

The deputy prime minister, a known opponent of PR, yesterday effectively included the prime minister among the people who should be placed on his boat and shipped out to sea. Mr Blair set up a joint cabinet committee with the Lib Dems after the election and turns to Lord Jenkins for advice.

webTitle: Diners fork out to meet ministers

fields.headline: Diners fork out to meet ministers
fields.standfirst:
Fundraising

Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: More than 600 lobbyists, PR consultants and captains of industry will pay £350-a-plate to dine with Tony Blair tomorrow night as the business of politics this week earns Labour an estimated £4m.
fields.body:
More than 600 lobbyists, PR consultants and captains of industry will pay £350-a-plate to dine with Tony Blair tomorrow night as the business of politics this week earns Labour an estimated £4m.

The Bernie Ecclestone row appears to have done little to dampen his party's appetite for cash from corporations and wealthy individuals to fund its election campaign.

After rubbing shoulders with the prime minister at a champagne reception, those seeking or selling influence will be called at 8.15pm to enjoy roast rack of lamb or pasta with the Labour leader.

Mr Blair, fresh from making the most important conference speech of his political life, is to say a few more words as Lady Jay, Labour's leader in the Lords, plays the party's host for the evening.

Strategically placed on each table for 10 in the Oxford suite of the Brighton Hilton Metropole hotel will be an "eleventh" guest the diners asked Millbank to deliver. Ministers and MPs ordered to attend will swap gossip with their fellow diners, while defending the government's record and attacking the Tories.

The evening formally ends at 10.30pm and 10 minutes later a fleet of coaches leave for Brighton station and the 11.04pm fast train back to London Victoria.

Sponsored by Manchester airport, the Blair dinner will generate more than £200,000 for a party £2m in the red last year and struggling to raise the £20m needed to fight the next election.

Since the £3,500 cost per table is below the £5,000 threshold for declaring political donations, Labour need never publish a list of who paid and the companies can write it off as entertainment.

Tomorrow night's dinner is the centrepiece of a week-long fundraising drive that will pull in £4m, according to one party official, which even after deducting costs means the Labour conference is likely to turn in a profit.

Millbank is defensive as the Ecclestone row rumbles on, but a spokesman maintained that all parties organised fundraising dinners and attending secured no favours for those paying.

Labour's goal is to raise 10% of its income from commercial activities, 20% from big donors, 30% from unions and 40% from small donors and members.

One corporate executive, dinner invitation in hand, said: "No one asks for anything or tries to influence ministers but never underestimate what the Americans call 'face power', the value of meeting them face to face."

Within an hour of finishing his crucial conference speech tomorrow, Mr Blair is due to rub shoulders with valued donors over Earl Grey and cakes to thank them for their past, and probably future, financial support.

A two-day blue riband corporate programme is expected to raise in excess of £100,000 at a cost of £1,351 per head after attracting 80 or so takers who will be granted briefings by parliamentary aides to Gordon Brown, Helen Liddell, Hilary Armstrong and other ministers.

Anne Cesek, Labour's corporate relations manager, said in a letter to potential visitors that "...the aim of the event is to provide an opportunity for business to engage in, both formal and informal, dialogue and discussion with Labour politicians.

"The event includes briefing sessions, seminars, a reserved seat for the leader's speech and a place at the conference dinner".

But the really big money is to be made from charging corporations up to £25,000 to squat for six days in the sprawling exhibition area with the 189 stands leaving the area outside the main hall resembling a trade fair more than a political gathering.

Camelot, Virgin Atlantic, Connex, Railtrack, Vodafone, Nestle, Pfeizer, National Express, Transco and the other household names on parade will stump up an estimated £3m between them.

Stuart Render, PR manager of the FristGroup bus and train company, said firms attended because it gave them a chance to put their case to opinion formers. "This is an important way, not a cheap one I agree, to put your message to a wide audience."

fields.headline: Quake provokes mild shivers
fields.trailText: An earthquake 13km (eight miles) below the centre of Warwick on Saturday sent shivers as far as Hay on Wye 120km (74.5 miles) away and was a reminder, once again, that Britain is at risk from sudden, violent movements of the Earth.
fields.body:
An earthquake 13km (eight miles) below the centre of Warwick on Saturday sent shivers as far as Hay on Wye 120km (74.5 miles) away and was a reminder, once again, that Britain is at risk from sudden, violent movements of the Earth.

The shock, measuring 4.2 on the Richter scale, came at 5.23am on Saturday, and was felt widely, although there were no reports of damage.

People reported feeling the tremor in Peterborough, 95km to the east, in Gloucester, 65km to the south, and near Cheadle, Staffordshire, 80km to the north.

"Magnitude 4-plus often would be felt further than that," said Chris Browitt, head of the British Geological Survey in Scotland, where seismic research is based.

"The Norwich earthquake in 1994 was felt over 100km and the other mag 4-plus was near Arran on March 4, 1999, and that was felt 150km away."

People reported that houses shook and doors and windows rattled, as if an aircraft or a heavy lorry were passing. "It is a level of shaking just less than that which would damage chimneys and roofs," he said.

"What we can say is that it was about 60,000 times less, in energy, than the Izmit, Turkey, earthquake. That was mag 7.4."

The last big earthquake within 100km of Warwick was at Bishop's Castle in 1990, at mag 5.1, and 30 times more powerful.

That was felt throughout Wales, much of England, and even in Scotland and Ireland. There were no injuries or reports of serious damage. But Britain may have been lucky.

There have been modestly powerful earthquakes in the last two centuries. The most damaging in Britain was relatively small at mag 4.7, in 1884 near Colchester, and damaged a large number of buildings, bringing down roofs, walls and chimneys.

It was relatively shallow. This meant that the energy of the shock was less likely to be absorbed on the way to the surface. The loose, light soils of East Anglia almost certainly shook like jelly, to amplify the seismic waves.

"That's the most damaging we know of, but the biggest we know of, going back through several hundred years of reports, occurred quite recently, in 1931 on the Dogger bank," said Dr Browitt.

"Fortunately that was 100km offshore. It caused damage down the east coast of England, mainly to roofs and chimneys, and was felt over the whole of Britain, over a large part of the west of western Europe, all the way up to the Shetlands - a million square kilometres."
fields.bodyText: An earthquake 13km (eight miles) below the centre of Warwick on Saturday sent shivers as far as Hay on Wye 120km (74.5 miles) away and was a reminder, once again, that Britain is at risk from sudden, violent movements of the Earth. The shock, measuring 4.2 on the Richter scale, came at 5.23am on Saturday, and was felt widely, although there were no reports of damage. People reported feeling the tremor in Peterborough, 95km to the east, in Gloucester, 65km to the south, and near Cheadle, Staffordshire, 80km to the north. "Magnitude 4-plus often would be felt further than that," said Chris Browitt, head of the British Geological Survey in Scotland, where seismic research is based. "The Norwich earthquake in 1994 was felt over 100km and the other mag 4-plus was near Arran on March 4, 1999, and that was felt 150km away." People reported that houses shook and doors and windows rattled, as if an aircraft or a heavy lorry were passing. "It is a level of shaking just less than that which would damage chimneys and roofs," he said. "What we can say is that it was about 60,000 times less, in energy, than the Izmit, Turkey, earthquake. This meant that the energy of the shock was less likely to be absorbed on the way to the surface. fields.headline: Crackdown on young offenders
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The whereabouts of the 2,500 most persistent teenage tearaways in England and Wales are to be checked on at least twice a day as part of a major new anti-crime package unveiled yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
The whereabouts of the 2,500 most persistent teenage tearaways in England and Wales are to be checked on at least twice a day as part of a major new anti-crime package unveiled yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

The 50 most hardcore repeat young offenders in each city are to be kept under surveillance 24 hours a day seven days a week using electronic tags and voice verification call systems. Some will even be issued with pagers to ensure they call in at the right times and others will find themselves accompanied by probation staff at certain times of the day.

The new intensive supervision and surveillance programme was part of a package of measures unveiled by Mr Straw yesterday, designed to blunt the Conservatives' political attack on his record in the run-up to the election, in the face of rising crime figures.

Other measures included cutting the reoffending rates of those coming out of prison, improving police detection rates and updating the victim's charter - first introduced in 1996 - with an ombudsman to deal with cases where victims do not get the service they deserve.

The home secretary praised the remarkable courage of Sarah Payne's parents and confirmed that a new sex offenders order is to be introduced to ensure they cannot go back and live near their child victims.

Mr Straw also defended his record on asylum, insisting that he passionately believed in the rights of those fleeing persecution to seek refuge in Britain. Later this week the home secretary will face a challenge from within his own party to scrap his much criticised "degrading" asylum voucher scheme.

But it was his new programme for dealing with the hard core of persistent juvenile offenders which proved the centrepiece of his speech yesterday. Cracking down on teenage tearaways has always been a popular measure for home secretaries facing a party conference. Mr Straw's announcement differed from those of his predecessors in that he did not say he was going to lock more of them up.

Instead he said better ways of dealing with them outside of prison needed to be found:

"So from next April, a new national programme will make sure that 2,500 hardcore young criminals are supervised in the community not once or twice a fortnight - but every day; seven days a week, 24 hours a day if necessary.

"And we'll make sure they tackle head on their offending behaviour and give them the skills and education they need to turn their backs on crime. That's our approach. Firm supervision, tough standards - yes. But the offer of a helping hand as well."

Home Office researchers claim that 25% of all youth crime is committed by 3% of young offenders - about 3,500 teenagers.

Home Office sources say £45m will be spent over 3 years from next April on this new intensive supervision and surveillance programme.

The money will go to about 50 young offending teams in the biggest cities and towns who will each select 50-60 teenagers who have been charged or warned for a serious offence four or more times in the previous 12 months.

The programme will last at least six months for each teenager who will have to undergo an education and supervision programme lasting five hours a day on weekdays for the first three months.

"The whereabouts of each young offender will be checked at least twice daily with 24 hours a day, seven days a week surveillance where this is necessary.

"Surveillance techniques, including in the late evenings and the weekends, may include electronic tagging, voice verification, tracking by probation and social work staff and policing," said a Home Office source.

The 'voice verification' system involves a young offender ringing in at an appointed time to an automatic call machine which is programmed to recognise his voice. Some offenders will be given pagers to remind them to call in and calls would only be accepted from predetermined numbers - such as their home phones - and not mobile numbers.

Mr Straw said the scheme was part of his package to ensure that overall crime figures will be lower at the end of Labour's first term than when it came to power. The official recorded crime figures are still six points below their level in May 1997 but the trend has turned upwards in recent months.

Last night Harry Fletcher of the National Association of Probation Officers expressed serious doubts about whether keeping a constant eye on the most persistent teenage offenders would do anything to tackle the poverty, social exclusion, and disadvantage that caused their offending.

fields.headline: Charities demand children's minister
fields.trailText: Fifty charities joined together yesterday to back a manifesto to put the interests of children at the heart of the next government's agenda.
fields.body:
Fifty charities joined together yesterday to back a manifesto to put the interests of children at the heart of the next government's agenda.

They demanded a minister of cabinet rank to spearhead a programme including children's commissioners to defend the interests of young people, as recommended by the Waterhouse inquiry into abuse in north Wales.

The manifesto, drawn up by Barnardo's, the Child Poverty Action Group and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, presents evidence of neglect.

"The UK has the worst child poverty rate in Europe, the worst child and infant mortality rates and the highest rate of teenage pregnancy. A quarter of recorded rape victims are children, one child a week dies following abuse or neglect and one in five children suffer a mental health problem," it said.

The initiative follows publication of the government's an nual poverty audit last week, showing the number of children in families below the poverty line continued to grow in the first two years of Tony Blair's administration.

Although the charities paid tribute to a range of child-friendly government policies, including the national minimum wage and working families tax credit, they said: "It is still unclear exactly what impact such innovations will have on children."

The charities are calling on all political parties to incorporate five key proposals in their next election manifestos.

They want England, Scotland and Northern Ireland to follow the lead of the Welsh assembly in establishing children's commissioners as "powerful independent champions" of young people's interests.

A cabinet minister should be appointed to speak for children and raise their political profile. It should be the minister responsible for the Cabinet Office, which should be expanded to include a children's unit planning strategy across Whitehall.

Other proposals included improved access to services for disadvantaged children. "We need increased financial support through child benefit, income support and the new integrated child credit. We need more, well-funded services to support children, particularly the most disadvantaged, to ensure that they have the best possible start and help throughout childhood," the charities said.

They proposed child well-being indicators giving systematic and regular analysis of the state of children in Britain. These would fill a gap in government statistics to show whether children's overall quality of life is improving.

The fifth demand was for children to have a greater say on issues that affect them. Children should no longer be treated as adjuncts of their parents. "It should be recognised that young people, as they mature, have the ability to take important decisions. Governments should seek to engage children in society and to encourage them to become participants in our democracy."

fields.headline: Brighton diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Welcome to Tonytown where everyone always smiles, Labour is still popular and lager costs £2.75 a pint. The huge security cordon thrown round the people's party in Brighton has created a new Labour mini-state headed by Tony Blair
fields.body:
 Welcome to Tonytown where everyone always smiles, Labour is still popular and lager costs £2.75 a pint. The huge security cordon thrown round the people's party in Brighton has created a new Labour mini-state headed by Tony Blair.

Party officials paid £300,000 to build a covered walkway between Blair's HQ, in the Hilton Metropole, and the Grand Hotel and conference centre. The link, already dubbed the "Bridge to Troubled Waters", means the 10,000 politicos, lobbyists, hacks and assorted hangers-on never have to bump into a petrol protester.

 A state, even a mini-state like Tonytown, needs a national anthem and Labour has come up with "Let's Work Together", a No 2 hit 30 years ago for Canned Heat which Bryan Ferry later reworked, twice.

Canned Heat's guitarist Alan "Blind Owl" Wilson died of a drug overdose shortly after recording the song, but lines like "when things go wrong and they sometimes will, the road you travel seems all uphill" have a particular resonance for a party eight points behind in the polls.

 The Richard Branson conference cock-up award is won this year by Railtrack, which picked yesterday to do engineering works on the Brighton line, delaying MPs and ministers for half an hour. Not quite Virgin's two-hour delays to Blackpool of a couple of years ago, but still a worthy extension to what is supposed to be a 60-minute trip.

 Five homeless families have reason not to welcome Labour to Brighton, after they were turfed out of their hotel so the rooms could be rented to the Daily Express at £130 per night. Staff considered a boycott, until it was pointed out that the alternative was a night under the pier.

 Mo Mowlam proved they even swear with charm in Tonytown. Fed up at with a photographer hoping to share her forkfuls of bangers and mash with the outside world, she told him: "Could you please piss off."

 The delights of Tonytown could not compete with the lure of Brighton races for Margaret Beckett and Chris Smith. Lord Falconer, his mind no doubt on the Dome, admitted he did not know the races were on as he asked one gambler, glasses round neck, if he was off to the opera.

webTitle: Brahms and bravos  Italian wins Leeds piano prize

fields.headline: Brahms and bravos  Italian wins Leeds piano prize
fields.trailText: A young Italian pianist carried off the £12,000 top prize when he won the 13th Leeds international piano competition at the weekend with a performance of one of the classical    repertory's great concertos.
fields.body:
A young Italian pianist carried off the £12,000 top prize when he won the 13th Leeds international piano competition at the weekend with a performance of one of the classical repertory's great concertos.

Alessio Bax, 22, was judged the winner by a 14-strong international jury led by Fanny Waterman, who co-founded the competition in 1961. He gave what was a described as a "masterly" account of Brahms's first concerto with the City of Birmingham symphony orchestra, conducted by Sir Simon Rattle. Bax, from Bari, studies in Dallas, Texas, and has already performed in Europe, the US and Japan.

He played in the 1993 competition when he was just 14 and reached the second round.

This time he was a hot favourite and the audience at Leeds town hall seemed to agree with the judges' verdict.

fields.headline: Prozac warning comes under fire
fields.standfirst: Position on suicidal tendencies is 'dangerously misleading'
fields.trailText: A new warning issued by the Medicines Control Agency, stating that people may feel suicidal in the first few weeks of taking Prozac and similar antidepressants, is dangerously misleading and could lead to more deaths, according to a leading authority on the drugs.
fields.body:
A new warning issued by the Medicines Control Agency, stating that people may feel suicidal in the first few weeks of taking Prozac and similar antidepressants, is dangerously misleading and could lead to more deaths, according to a leading authority on the drugs.

David Healy, director of the North Wales Department of Psychological Medicine in Bangor, has told the MCA that among those who are not severely depressed - who are the majority of those now being given antidepressants - it is the drugs, and not the illness, that make people want to kill themselves.

The warning will lead to doctors keeping their patients on the drugs in the assumption that the medication will eventually make them better, when they need to be taken off.

The new warning is the MCA's response to increasing public concern over suicides among people on drugs in the Prozac class. The agency has instructed manufacturers to include it in the drug datasheets for doctors and information leaflets for patients. It states that suicidal thoughts may occur or increase in the early weeks of treatment, and may continue for some time until the drug takes effect.

But Dr Healy, the UK's leading historian of antidepressant medication, believes it is the drugs themselves that are causing some people to feel like killing themselves - not depression. And if, as the patient leaflet warning states, there is an increase in suicidal thoughts, he says, it can only be due to an effect of the drug.

But increasingly the SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors) are being given to adults and children who are not depressed, but merely anxious and who should therefore have no suicidal feelings.

Dr Healy has written to Keith Jones, director of the MCA, pointing to two studies - one of them carried out by his own team - showing that healthy volunteers with no history of depression have become dangerously suicidal after taking one of the SSRI class of drugs for a couple of weeks.

"This will lead to deaths," he told Dr Jones in a letter. "Your advice will lead to a situation where patients who worsen on treatment will be kept on that treatment by their GPs in the belief that it is only in this way that the suicide risk can ultimately be lowered. This is mistaken advice that is going to increase the rate at which patients move from emergent suicidality[beginning to feel suicidal] to suicidal acts."

Earlier this year, Dr Healy published a study of the effects of one of the SSRIs, sertraline, on 20 healthy volunteers. Two of them became suicidal. One told researchers that she had become obsessed with the idea of throwing herself under a car or a train, while the other fantasised about hanging herself from a beam in the bedroom ceiling.

The MCA also has in its possession a much earlier study of the effects of sertraline on healthy volunteers. Dr Jones acknowledged in a letter to Dr Healy that this study similarly shows a "pattern of severe adverse side-effects and drop outs." He goes on to remark that the pattern "seen in this small study was not replicated in any other study involving sertraline".

Yet it has been - in the Healy study published earlier this year in Primary Care Psychiatry and revealed in the Guardian in May. These two studies, says Dr Healy, would be conclusive enough for the manufacturers to get a license from the MCA to market sertraline as a drug to cause agitation - if anybody had a use for such a medicine. Yet the MCA will not accept that this, and other SSRIs, can cause people to feel suicidal as a side-effect.

The MCA's decision to require a new warning with the SSRIs was taken after a review of the data by the Committee on the Safety of Medicines.

The MCA said in a statement that the CSM had considered both the healthy volunteer studies as part of the overall risk assessment.

"The CSM concluded that reports of suicidal thoughts in healthy volunteers were difficult to explain, however, other data were reassuring. For this reason, the issue will be kept under review and further advice will be sought as necessary."

Bill Newton Dunn, MEP for the East Midlands and a strong supporter of the euro, has had the Tory whip withdrawn for voting against the increasingly eurosceptic stance of his party leadership.

Actress Patsy Kensit has ended her three-year marriage to Oasis star Liam Gallagher in an uncontested divorce. A London judge granted a decree nisi on the grounds of the singer's unreasonable behaviour.

Sea search fails to find diver

An air and sea search failed to find a 55-year-old man who disappeared off Dungeness, Kent, yesterday while diving around a shipwreck.

Five ticket holders scooped Saturday's £7.5 million National Lottery jackpot. The winning numbers were 6, 16, 18, 32, 35 and 45 and the bonus ball was 46. One ticket won the £250,000 Thunderball jackpot,with the numbers 11, 25, 28, 29, and 33. The Thunderball number was 1.

webTitle: German invasion alert turned out to be just hot air

fields.headline: German invasion alert turned out to be just hot air
fields.trailText: As regrettable mishaps in balloons go, it was on a scale that would have made even Richard Branson blush.
fields.body:
As regrettable mishaps in balloons go, it was on a scale that would have made even Richard Branson blush.

Only this time it was a pair of unfortunate Germans who were at the centre of a hot air emergency.

It began on Friday as Peter Wittman, 32, and Heinrich Brachtendorf, 67, climbed into their basket in the German town of Marl, north of Essen, and took to the skies alongside fellow ballooning enthusiasts as part of a competition to see who could stay in the air the longest - but at least they won.

The pair, however, probably did not intend to stay up quite as long as they did.

In the early hours of Saturday morning, a radar operator at a military air traffic control centre in London spotted an unexpected blip on his screen. Noting that something was awry, the operator informed the RAF.

Immediately, the air rescue co-ordination centre, at Kin loss, swung into action. A Sea King helicopter was scrambled and at around 9.30pm it was able to define exactly what had caused the blip.

In the stormy skies over the coast of Grimsby, Lincolnshire, the German balloonists, who had by now sent out a distress signal, were more than a few miles off course - and were heading even further afield.

webTitle: Apologetic Mo bows out on downbeat note

fields.headline: Apologetic Mo bows out on downbeat note
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam made what was almost certainly her last speech to a Labour party conference yesterday. It was peculiarly downbeat, understated and disengaged - not so much a last hurrah as a political last gasp. They gave her a standing ovation just for walking into the hall, and 10 minutes later a standing ovation for sitting down.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam made what was almost certainly her last speech to a Labour party conference yesterday. It was peculiarly downbeat, understated and disengaged - not so much a last hurrah as a political last gasp. They gave her a standing ovation just for walking into the hall, and 10 minutes later a standing ovation for sitting down.

Afterwards, she made an inevitably slow progress through the delegates, all of whom seemed to want to touch her or pluck her sleeve, and all of whom possessed that seraphic smile which one imagines a mediaeval peasant would have worn if he had spotted a saint walking past his hovel. But the message she seemed to be sending us was, "thank God it's almost over. I'll soon be out of here."

Her last words were an elegaic apology: "I hope we haven't disappointed you too much. And if we have, I'm sorry."

She had a warm-up man, her deputy Ian McCartney, who, like her, has recently coped with much personal grief. They look remarkably similar, though Mr McCartney is a much smaller, so that they resemble characters from an Austin Powers film - Dr Love perhaps, and her tiny associate Mini-Mo.

Mr McCartney made some good jokes, or so I'm told by Scottish colleagues; being among friends he evidently felt no need to translate from the original dialect. However, I do have restaurant Glaswegian, and most of them seemed to refer to William Hague's drinking exploits, of which we are fated to hear much this week.

Mr McCartney tried to whip up some enthusiasm, but that's going to be more difficult. "Yes or no, are you proud of this government?" "Yurrss" they sort of shouted back. "Are you determined to win?" and the delegates upped the sound level half a decibel or so: "Yi-i-i-s" they remarked.

Then there was an upbeat video showing stills of Mo Mowlam, Mo with the Prince of Wales, Mo as a student, Mo in Northern Ireland, Mo getting married, and a rare shot of Tony Blair and Mo smiling at each other.

The soundtrack was Robbie Williams singing She's The One, and the whole oeuvre was entitled "Our Mo", the phrase the prime minister used at the Labour conference when she got a bigger ovation than him and which is alleged to have marked the beginning of the end of her career.

Luckily I had not had my lunch at that point, otherwise this grisly display of hypocrisy could have spelled disaster for the elaborate hairdo worn by the woman sitting in front of me.

Then, plunging in pink, she fought her way through the cheering throng. "In future, could you use photos which show me from this angle, rather than my protruding features?"

She said that she was leaving because she wanted to go and she wanted to fight for the second term. But she sounded hesitant, unsure.

A successful political speech is not so much spoken as hurled at the listeners. Mo, however, seemed sometimes to wonder why she was there.

Now and again she strayed and lost her thread. "Something I spend a lot of time doing is drugs..." she said, and it took her a few moments to realise why people were laughing. "Takes one to know one," she recovered.

At the end she made her apology; she had heard people talking, she said vaguely. "If we have disappointed you I'm sorry, I hope we haven't disappointed you too much."

She smiled and, very slowly at first, they got to their feet. They love her just as much, but, I felt, they also sense that the time is right for her to leave.

fields.headline: Open House a roaring success
fields.trailText: An invitation to the public to visit the capital's finest and most fascinating buildings at the weekend was taken up with enthusiasm
fields.body:
An invitation to the public to visit the capital's finest and most fascinating buildings at the weekend was taken up with enthusiasm

The annual celebration of architecture featured grand public offices and headquarters, such as the Channel 4 building and the Bank of England, and an extensive collection of private homes.

Many of the 550 buildings that took part in Open House weekend are normally closed to the public, charge a fee, or have restricted access. But for Open House weekend the buildings' owners allow visitors in free.

The Bank of England gave explanatory tours to 2,500 visitors. John Keyworth, curator of its museum, said: "We even had babes in arms. One toddler had a penchant for lions and cooed whenever I mentioned the word, which was often because we've got them everywhere."

Visitors were shown the governor's room and the table used by every governor since 1795.

"One visitor was delighted. She said she'd been to the Foreign Office Open House but didn't get a look at Robin Cook's room," he said.

The headquarters of Imagination, the design and communications company, which is housed in what was once an Edwardian school in Bloomsbury, central London, had more than 400 visitors on Saturday.

"Even though it was a lovely day on Saturday we were completely full. We have had people across the spectrum in here from architects to families," one security guard said.

London's largest and most modern power station, in Barking, east London, was also full. Built in 1945, the station generates about a third of London's electricity.

Peter Bedson, the station's business manager, said: "We had to turn people away. We had families, retired people. We even had power station groupies come all the way from the Midlands to have a look inside."

In west London, Chiswick House - which usually charges visitors to look around the Palladian villa and classical gardens - opened its doors for free yesterday. "We have had a 40% increase in visitors on a normal Sunday," said one of the custodians.

"We have had visitors come from as far as Southend, Surrey and Sussex. We should have more of this. It's a really great idea."

London Open House, which is sponsored by the Guardian, comes a week after the Heritage Open Days, when more than 2,500 sites across the country opened their doors to the public.

fields.headline: Canada calls for moratorium now
fields.standfirst:
Action plan: Ottawa calls for immediate debt write-offs

Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: The Canadian government tried to breathe new life into the west's faltering programme of debt forgiveness yesterday, calling on other creditor countries to support an immediate halt to debt repayments by the world's poorest states.
fields.body:
The Canadian government tried to breathe new life into the west's faltering programme of debt forgiveness yesterday, calling on other creditor countries to support an immediate halt to debt repayments by the world's poorest states.

Leaders from the Group of Seven main industrial countries promised last June that 24 states would be offered help in paying off their debts by the end of 2000. But with less than four months to go, only 10 have begun receiving relief under the heavily indebted poor countries programme (HIPC).

"At a time of unprecedented prosperity in many industrialised economies, it is unacceptable that the promised debt relief has not been delivered," Paul Martin, the Canadian finance minister, said. "The HIPC process has been too slow. We made a commitment last year to faster action and we must make good on this commitment."

The delays are one of the issues drawing protesters to the streets of Prague this week for the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

Mr Martin added that an immediate debt moratorium would free resources for heavily indebted poor countries to spend on health and education programmes.

Britain gave a cautious welcome to the idea, but a treasury source said the Canadian proposal to speed things along would have to be studied in more detail.

Aid agencies suppored a moratorium, saying it would be a chance for a complete overhaul of the HIPC programme. "Canada's call for a moratorium is indicative of the need to take HIPC back to the drawing board," said Karen Joyner, a spokeswoman for Christian Aid.

The programme as it stands, she said, "provides too little debt relief to too few countries too slowly."

The new managing director of the IMF, Horst Köhler, has promised to ease the requirements countries must meet to qualify for the debt programme, one of the main causes of delay.

But aid agencies say the pledge from Mr Kohler has yet to filter through his organisation which they claim is still prescribing detailed reform programmes which countries must achieve before they can receive debt relief.

The Canadian plan would exclude states such as Liberia and Sudan which it says are "not currently committed to the principles of good governance, including protection of human rights".

webTitle: Suddenly everyone wants to go into action

fields.headline: Suddenly everyone wants to go into action
fields.standfirst: Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Life has moved on since the streets of Seattle were awash with riot police last December. Then, it was the protesters who called the shots while trade ministers bickered inside the convention centre. In Prague, the anti-globalisation forces have yet to make their presence felt, allowing ministers from the G7 to seize the initiative.
fields.body:
Life has moved on since the streets of Seattle were awash with riot police last December. Then, it was the protesters who called the shots while trade ministers bickered inside the convention centre. In Prague, the anti-globalisation forces have yet to make their presence felt, allowing ministers from the G7 to seize the initiative.

Suddenly, intervention is no longer a dirty word. Friday's G7 action to prop up the euro and the moves over the weekend to bring down the oil price in part reflected real concerns about the threats posed to global growth by currency imbalances and rising fuel prices. But it also underlined the welcome return to a more activist approach.

A cynical view would be that the west can act when it is in its interests. America's support for intervention to reduce the value of the dollar was prompted by the earbashing the Clinton administration has been getting from multinationals unhappy about the impact of a weak euro on export earnings from Europe. But when Canada's finance minister, Paul Martin, urged creditor countries to support a moratorium on debt repayments from the world's poorest countries there was no obvious selfish motive.

The importance of the actions on Friday and Saturday is that they legitimise intervention in other spheres, from trade to the environment. Once it has been accepted that markets need to be managed by strong and effective institutions, all sorts of possibilities open up. Policymakers have been made painfully aware in the past couple of weeks how easy it is for a combination of fuel shortages and just-in-time production methods to bring a modern economy to a standstill. There is far greater willingness for action - both individually and collectively - to tackle market imperfections and market failures.

The IMF's half-yearly world economic outlook, released last week, provided an excellent overview of the state of play. While the dark clouds that hovered over the global economy two years ago have lifted, the fund warned that there could be more on the horizon. In particular, it expressed concern about the "misalignments among major currencies", the risk of a supply shock caused by higher oil prices and that there could be a sharp correction in US share prices.

To be fair to the fund, it has been highlighting the risks of a hard landing in the US for some time, but until now nobody took its comments seriously. The status of Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan as the man who can master markets has left Americans convinced that a soft landing is inevitable. They have just started to grasp the idea that nobody - not even the redoubtable Mr Greenspan - is perfect and that in recent years soft landings have all too often turned into crash landings.

The strength of the dollar has allowed Americans to believe that the good times can go on for ever. A strong currency has kept inflation low and attracted enough foreign capital to allow the US to continue living beyond its means and to keep the stock market over-valued. When Mr Greenspan cut interest rates two years ago, that helped save the global economy from meltdown, but gave a boost to the US economy at a time when it should have been getting a touch on the brakes.

Monetary policy was subsequently tightened, however, and is now having an effect. Higher interest rates and an over-valued currency mean that the economy is slowing pretty rapidly, something which has been lost on foreign exchange dealers but not on the men and women who run American corporations. As Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary, made clear on Friday, Washington is not abandoning its strong dollar policy, but its support for the intervention to defend the euro suggests that it would like a euro-dollar exchange rate of between 90 and 95 cents.

Shortening the odds

Markets will test the resolve of the G7 this week, and it is crucial that the authorities are not found wanting. Intervention is not like a poker game where you can fold early; having gambled, you have to stick it out. It is true that investment flows reveal great confidence in the US economy, but there is a long history of investors piling into countries just at the moment when the economy is about to take a turn for the worse.

Rising oil prices are an added complication, because they cause a loss of real incomes at a time when the labour market in the US is tight. Inflation will rise if workers try to compensate for the reduction in purchasing power by bargaining for higher pay. In those circumstances, interest rates would go up still further, shortening the odds on a hard landing. The communique issued by the G7 at the end of its meeting on Saturday underlined the concern about escalating energy costs, but that is a less significant problem than misaligned exchange rates. Much of the recent rise has been the result of speculation in the futures markets and will unwind once it becomes apparent that the US and Europe are slowing.

So, if the US can see some merit in co-ordinated action on the world stage, so much the better. Now is the time for those who have campaigned hard for debt relief, for fairer trade rules, for a more democratic system of international governance, and for reform of the bank and the fund to redouble their efforts. Globalisation has spawned its own opposition in the form of non-governmental organisations that have proved effective in exposing the weakness and inadequacies of the current international order. The NGOs are right to say that much still needs to be done to curb the violent excesses of the global financial markets, protect the environment and to tackle poverty in the developing world. The series of catastrophes - financial, political and environmental - that started in Thailand in 1997 and culminated in Seattle only served to underline the point.

Some of these developments appear to have been lost on those who have turned up in Prague with the hope that they can abolish the bank and the fund as the first stage in putting an end to globalisation. Even in its basic conception, this plan makes little sense because the real power in the global economy is vested with the finance ministers and central bank governors of the G7, not the bureaucrats in the Bretton Woods institutions. The bank and the fund act for the G7 in much the same way as Whitehall does for the Cabinet; they translate decisions into actions. Ultimately they take their orders from their big shareholders, the G7. Anybody who tried to argue that Britain would be better off without a civil service would be given short shrift, and rightly so.

However, the real objection to those who propose smashing up the international system is that they do not have any idea what should replace it. The vague hankering for a pre-industrial utopia may appeal to well-heeled eco-toffs, for whom real hardship is when the gardener fails to turn up twice a week, but it is the politics of sixth-form common rooms, not the real world. Progressives have the chance to reshape global institutions; they should not flunk it.

fields.headline: IMF is blind to kleptocapitalism
fields.standfirst: Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: This year, for the first time in nearly 10 years, all bar one of the countries which made up the Soviet bloc should record in an increase in economic output, according to experts at the International Monetary Fund.
fields.body:
This year, for the first time in nearly 10 years, all bar one of the countries which made up the Soviet bloc should record in an increase in economic output, according to experts at the International Monetary Fund.

But the region still bears the scars: the economies of Georgia, Moldova, Tajikistan and Ukraine are around a third of the size they were in 1989, one in five people is living below the poverty line, up from one in 25 ten years ago, and life expectancy, particularly for men, is falling.

The consequences of the second great depression are laid out in two reports released last week by the World Bank and the IMF. The Bank's report paints a grim picture of the social impact on relatively prosperous countries. Most of the new poor are educated people who enjoyed secure jobs before the collapse.

The IMF makes the same point, that the former eastern bloc countries have experienced something which has been largely absent from the west for nearly 70 years, a generation which grew up expecting a decent job with a living wage and security in retirement has been thrown into penury.

The two reports are less forthcoming about the Bank and Fund's own roles as advisers to the new market economies. The IMF's standard macroeconomic prescriptions - privatising inefficient state-owned enterprises, removal of subsidies, creation of a proper market - were expected to quickly result in the creation of functioning capitalist states. Given their highly educated populations, western advisers were bullish about their prospects.

The justification for the privaitsation programmes was that the domination of the state in the communist economy had to be reduced by creating a viable private sector. But the state simply collapsed in most countries, leaving the strong to grab what they could from the privatisation process. Some commentators have described what happened throughout much of the region as kleptocapitalism - the large scale theft by a few powerful people of assets once owned by everybody.

Market liberalism, it seems, is just as much a religion as communism was. The early western advisers who came out with their standard macroeconomic policies genuinely believed they were bringing about an economic revolution. But their ignorance of the region combined with their total belief in the correctness of the economic textbooks blinded them to the political realities of the countries they were advising.

The lesson has been learnt at least by the Bank, which now talks about the importance of strong institutions and good governance. For the IMF, however, the fault lies with the countries themselves for being half-hearted in their reform programmes, allowing "vested interests" the opportunity to plunder the countries' economies.

Shock therapy, it appears, did not go far enough.

webTitle: Canada to deport paroled killer to UK

fields.headline: Canada to deport paroled killer to UK
fields.trailText: One of a group of gangland brothers, dubbed the Canadian Krays, is to be deported to Britain this month after he is released on parole.
fields.body:
One of a group of gangland brothers, dubbed the Canadian Krays, is to be deported to Britain this month after he is released on parole.

Scots-born Philip Wood, 44, has served 14 years of a life sentence for murdering a 21-year-old woman who was due to give evidence against him in a drugs trial.

He emigrated to Canada as a child from Ayrshire in 1965, but he does not have full citizenship and the Canadian authorities insist he must return to Britain.

In 1986, Wood and his brothers, David, 47, and Colin, 42, murdered Karen Thomson by attacking her then throwing her into Lake Ontario to drown. Ms Thomson, Colin's girlfriend, was due to be a key prosecution witness in a drugs case faced by the brothers.

Wood was granted parole last week and a Foreign Office spokeswoman confirmed yesterday that he would be back in Britain by the end of the month.

"Philip Wood is due to be released around the end of September and the instruction from the Canadian authorities is that he will be deported," she said. She could not say when Wood would arrive in Britain or where he would stay. A prisoner release organisation was helping him find accommodation.

David Wood is also eligible for parole but he is reported to have agreed to stay in prison for a further three months to complete psychiatric treatment. It is understood he will also return to Britain when released.

Colin Wood escaped from prison in 1994 and spent three years on the run before he was tracked down in Alabama. He is due to spend three more years in prison before he is deported to Britain.

A row broke out in 1997 when it emerged that the men were likely be deported. Canadian immigration officials said the brothers were not technically Canadian citizens and, under Canadian law, anyone serving more than 10 years in prison can be returned to their country of origin.

As Wood and his brothers have not been convicted of a crime in Britain, they will not be subject to any form of supervision. Three years ago the MP Henry McLeish, then a Scottish Office minister, said he would petition Jack Straw, the home secretary, for changes in the immigration law regarding parole.

Mr McLeish said he wanted to ensure that criminals returning to Britain were subject to the same constraints as those released from British prisons. But the law has not yet been changed.

The Scottish Conservatives' justice spokesman, Phil Gallie, said the deportation of Wood was deeply worrying. "I think Canada is backing out of its moral responsibility by sending him here but we do not have the right to interfere in another country's processes, so we have to cater for the situation we are stuck with."

The Wood brothers became involved with a notorious gang in Toronto in their teenage years. By the time they reached their 20s, they ran a drugs and crime syndicate. Between them they have more than 100 convictions for drugs offences, assaults and theft.
