webTitle: Israel says UN should take over Temple Mount

fields.headline: Israel says UN should take over Temple Mount
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The government of Israel is strenuously promoting an idea once unthinkable: entrusting Judaism's holiest site to United Nations control.
fields.body:
The government of Israel is strenuously promoting an idea once unthinkable: entrusting Judaism's holiest site to United Nations control.

The acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, leaves for Cairo today, where he is to sound out Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, on a proposal to transfer sovereignty of the Temple Mount, or Haram al-Sharif - 86 hectares of hallowed ground on the most fiercely contested hilltop in the Middle East - to the supervision of the five permanent members of the UN security council.

He is also due to talk later in the week with King Abdullah of Jordan, who has played a pivotal role in the tantalisingly slow search for a settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Mr Ben Ami's mission coincides with American efforts to convene a new meeting between the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. Of the 460 hours devoted to peacemaking at the Camp David summit attended by both last July, the two men only spent one hour together.

The very notion that the UN could be part of the solution for the Haram al-Sharif, where history, emotion and religion collide, represents a staggering change in Israeli government policy.

The idea is believed to have resurfaced now as an attempt by Israel to counter a proposal by the Palestinians earlier this month, to lodge sovereignty for the site with the Jerusalem committee of the Organisation of Islamic Countries.

The Haram is sacred to Muslims for the shimmering gold Dome of the Rock that marks the spot where the prophet Mohammed is said to have ascended to heaven; and to Jews, who revere it as the site of their temple, which was destroyed in 70AD, and where God is meant to have called Abraham to sacrifice his son Isaac.

From insisting that Israel would remain sole sovereign of Jerusalem, including all areas of Arab East Jerusalem occupied since 1967, the prime minister, Ehud Barak, has abandoned a whole series of shibboleths in the space of two months.

Since the Camp David meeting ended without agreement in the summer, Israeli officials have floated a bewildering number of proposals for resolving the status of the Haram al-Sharif. The most ingenious include divine sovereignty - handing the whole site over to God's control; and vertical sovereignty - with Palestinians the absolute rulers above ground, and Israelis the master of what lies beneath.

Since 1967, Muslim authorities appointed by Jordan have controlled the mosques. Palestinian police patrol the Haram, and Israeli security forces man the gates and oversee security for the adjacent Western Wall (often known as the Wailing Wall), the holiest shrine of Judaism.

US efforts to steer both sides towards agreement suffered a setback at the weekend with Washington's suspension of its ambassador to Israel, Martin Indyk. State department officials said he was suspected of "sloppy handling of classified information", using an unsecured laptop for sensitive information, and sending emails on an ordinary phone line.

fields.headline: Now Milosevic's people wait
fields.standfirst:
Voters cast ballots and hold their breath: a tense country wonders what the president will do if he loses
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The local elementary school in Pozarevac, the home town of President Slobodan Milosevic in north-eastern Yugoslavia, was spotlessly turned out for its day in the limelight as a polling centre in Yugoslavia's elections.
fields.body:
The local elementary school in Pozarevac, the home town of President Slobodan Milosevic in north-eastern Yugoslavia, was spotlessly turned out for its day in the limelight as a polling centre in Yugoslavia's elections.

From behind two long desks in the freshly painted classroom - hung with the Yugoslav flag, the Serbian coat of arms and children's watercolours - Mr Milosevic's monitors and opposition scrutineers watched.

The president's wayward son, Marko - a racing driver and black marketeer - had closed the bakery, pizza shop and internet cafe he owns but there was no sign of him as the town came out to vote.

The voters made their way laboriously through candidates for both houses of parliament and local councils, but the only vote that mattered to most of them was who would be their new president.

The first to turn up at the polls were mostly Milosevic loyalists. Old women with stiff limbs clambered out of the town's favoured red Yugos.

On a bench in the town square, Milos Obranovic, a retired army captain, sat with his friends. He was slowly draining a cola bottle filled with plum brandy. "I am an orthodox communist, a hard boiled communist, and I will vote for Milosevic," he said.

But as the day wore on the voters got younger. Mira Veljkovic, 30, a beautician, looked surprised when asked about her voting intentions. "I will support [Vojislav] Kostu nica of course," she said, referring to the main opposition candidate.

The elections are, for now, an entirely civilised affair but the enormous importance of this vote can be felt everywhere, despite the calm.

At 7am there were queues outside Belgrade polling stations. This is the heartland of Mr Kostunica, the 56-year-old lawyer who threatens to end the painful 13-year reign of Mr Milosevic.

"I feel like I did before my final exams," said Davor Matic, 41, an engineer. His wife, Mira, said she had bags under her eyes: "I only slept for two hours last night I'm so nervous."

All day, on the government-controlled local news and television stations, the people of Belgrade were warned that the opposition was getting ready to link up with their wayward neighbour, Montenegro, and betray Serbia.

Both the Milosevic and opposition camps plan to proclaim victory. Mr Kostunica is 10 points ahead in public-opinion surveys and says that the only way Mr Milosevic will win is by fraud. Mr Milosevic insists victory will be his.

There is little faith that the election results, due tomorrow, will really reflect the view of ordinary Serbs so, for now, the candidates are fighting a propaganda war.

President Milosevic, the master of propaganda, is being accused by the local Centre for Free Elections and Democracy (Cesid) of rigging the polls but its evidence is thin. The group presents itself as an independent, non-partisan, non-governmental organisation but is staffed by students, trade unionists and academics opposed to Mr Milosevic.

Its claims of corruption were eagerly reported yesterday by the few foreign journalists remaining in the country - 30 were expelled from Yugoslavia on the eve of the vote amid claims that they did not have the correct work permits.

At yesterday's 1pm press conference, Cesid announced that the elections were a "mess" and rife with irregularities. But the most serious development, it said, was that a polling station in the town of Grocka, 30 miles from Belgrade, had been smashed up by radicals.

When I visited Grocka yesterday afternoon it turned out that the "radicals" were drunks who were much more upset over claims that an election monitor had crashed into one of their cars than they were about the fate of either of the two presidential candidates.

These breathless, vague press conferences give some idea of how terrified the opposition is that Mr Milosevic will again steal the votes of his own people to keep himself in power - as he did in the winter of 1996.

The threat to their democratic rights is not from drunken townsfolk on the rampage, it is whatever Mr Milosevic is planning to do with almost 1m votes he controls in Kosovo and Montenegro. It will be another 24 hours before that is clear.

webTitle: Border blocked to stop activists reaching Prague

fields.headline: Border blocked to stop activists reaching Prague
fields.standfirst:
Police braced for tomorrow's opening of IMF meeting

Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: The group of 70 people looked menacing. Dressed mostly in black and carrying almost identical shoulder bags and furled umbrellas, they were being addressed by a woman in Spanish. Then, as one, they surged forward to march through the empty streets and over Cechuv bridge.
fields.byline: John Vidal  and  Kate Connolly  in Prague
fields.body:
The group of 70 people looked menacing. Dressed mostly in black and carrying almost identical shoulder bags and furled umbrellas, they were being addressed by a woman in Spanish. Then, as one, they surged forward to march through the empty streets and over Cechuv bridge.

But the visitors were not neo-Nazis, communists, anarchists, environmentalists or representatives of any of the other non-governmental organisations converging on the Czech capital at the weekend to disrupt the annual meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

These were wealthy Colombian tourists who had each paid more than £2,000 for a 10-day tour. None seemed to know about the meetings or the controversy over whether the lending institutions should write off the debts of the world's poorest states.

"What debt?" asked Ismeraelda Martinez of Bogota. "Prague is so beautiful."

Prague is two cities at the moment, with up to 11,000 police keeping 15,000 financiers and government delegations apart from the growing assembly of international protesters. So far neither side seems interested in confronting the other.

Almost all the rallies and demonstrations have been peaceful, though skinheads and anarchists clashed at the city's main railway station on Saturday afternoon. Earlier in the day the skinheads had requested police protection, fearing they would be outnumbered by the anarchists.

During an anarchists' march through the city yesterday, police formed a dense human wall behind them and followed any who tried to split off.

At least 4,000 mainly young activists from Britain, France, the US, Spain, Italy and Germany are believed to be in Prague, together with several thousand mostly middle-aged members of British and European development and human rights groups.

The consensus is that their demonstrations so far have been dress rehearsals for a major protest when the banking institutions' meetings begin tomorrow.

Some demonstrators - how many is not yet known - are being turned away at Austrian, German and Czech borders, suggesting a European police intelligence operation to weed out people suspected of having violent intent.

About 200 anarchists marched on the Czech interior ministry yesterday chanting "open the border" after a group of 500 protesters, mostly Italians, were held up in a chartered train that was stopped at the Austrian border when officials denied entry to four who refused to get off.

The interior minister, Stanislav Gross, told local television that the four would be kept out of the Czech Republic because they had participated in riots at a World Trade Organisation meeting last year in Seattle.

Inpeg, the Czech organisation coordinating the protests, maintained that " several thousand" people have been turned away at Czech borders.

"For every activist who has arrived, another has been detained at a border," an Inpeg spokesman said. The claim could not be immediately confirmed.

In a symbolic funeral march yesterday, protesters carried white crosses in a demonstration organised by Jubilee 2000 - one of the main groups promoting the idea of debt relief - to draw attention to its assertion that 19,000 children die each day as a result of policies imposed by the IMF and the World Bank.

Organisers had predicted a turnout of 15,000 to 20,000 protesters in Prague, but there was no sign of such a large number yesterday.

Activists have vowed to block the main motorway in Prague. They also hope to trap the delegates to the bank meetings inside a convention centre tomorrow by forming a human chain around it.

A tent city set up in Strahov stadium in the west of the city to house up to 15,000 people had attracted only about 200 campers by yesterday afternoon, causing its manager to cut the entry price. Many said they chose not to stay there out of fear that the police would trap them inside.

The Czech president, Vaclav Havel, held a meeting to bring together elements from both sides. James Wolfensohn and Horst Köhler, heads of the IMF and World Bank, joined Mary Robinson, the former Irish president, and financier George Soros to debate with NGOs. Mr Havel said the dialogue was vital, because "we are all doomed to live on this planet, we cannot emigrate elsewhere".

Later, during a walk in the gardens of Prague castle, Indonesian and African activists had some heated exchanges with Mr Havel and other leaders.

The protesters' strategy for tomorrow was being finalised at a former ship-building yard on Libensky island in the north of Prague where several hundred people gathered. Representatives laid out plans of the city to decide how they would surround the conference centre. There were lessons in using non-violent direct action and on using gas masks. Ex-army shops have reported brisk sales of the masks in recent days.

The protesters' strategy for tomorrow was being finalised at a former ship-building yard on Libensky island in the north of Prague where several hundred people gathered. Representatives laid out plans of the city to decide how they would surround the conference centre. There were lessons in using non-violent direct action and on using gas masks. Ex-army shops have reported brisk sales of the masks in recent days.

webTitle: How paying the minimum raises the stakes

fields.headline: How paying the minimum raises the stakes
fields.trailText: Without a minimum wage, "the good employers are undercut by the bad, and the bad are undercut by the worst". So said Winston Churchill in 1909 when the Liberal government introduced wages councils to represent the 'sweated' trades.
fields.body:
Without a minimum wage, "the good employers are undercut by the bad, and the bad are undercut by the worst". So said Winston Churchill in 1909 when the Liberal government introduced wages councils to represent the 'sweated' trades.

It took another 90 years for Churchill's principle to be extended to all low-paid workers, and for sweat-shop wages to be removed as a form of competition between employers.

But the introduction of a national minimum wage last year did not win universal approval. Many of those who opposed it - and even some who supported it - believed it would be a burden on business, damaging employment, pushing up costs and affecting the ability to compete. Even the low-pay commission, which supports the minimum wage, urged a 'prudent' approach in order to "avoid the adverse effects on business and the economy".

At Cambridge University's centre for business research (CBR), we have been trying to find out whether these pessimistic forecasts have come true. While other research has assessed the impact on employees, we have been focusing on the response of employers, particularly in small and medium-sized businesses. The answers so far are that there are no negative effects on employment and that the minimum wage is beginning to act as a spur to competition and efficiency. Paying the minimum wage has raised employers' costs, but this affects their competitors as well.

We shall be revealing more of our findings at a conference in Cambridge this Friday when the CBR launches 'British Enterprise in Transition'.

This study of more than 1,300 small and medium-sized businesses across the country, funded by the economic and social research council, provides evidence that the impact of the minimum wage on the product market strategies of small businesses is more positive than negative. One third of small firms are responding by adopting new, non-wage forms of competition.

Businesses who employed at least some staff on the minimum wage were asked whether they had increased or decreased their emphasis on a range of competitive strategies. We discovered that 33.6% of businesses had increased their use of certain strategies, especially personal attention to client needs, price, product/service quality, and increased specialisation.

Among these businesses, we saw a difference between the way innovating and non-innovating firms responded. Innovators were more likely to promote flair and creativity; non-innovators to emphasise price and established reputation. These findings echo a study carried out earlier this year for the low-pay commission by Frank Wilkinson and CBR colleagues Anna Bullock and Alan Hughes. This focused on the cleaning and security sectors - hitherto notorious for low pay.

Similarly, it shows that some concerns about the minimum wage have not materialised. There were worries, for example, that companies would resort to younger workers with reduced entitlement to the minimum wage. But so far there is no evidence of this.

Instead, what we see again is that the minimum wage has put pressure on firms to improve their performance. A substantial minority of firms surveyed -particularly in manufacturing, cleaning and security - sought to raise their efficiency by increasing their control of non-labour, as well as labour costs. Our research for the low-pay commission into the effects of the minimum wage continues - as does the debate as to whether it is damaging, or benefiting the economy.

Ninety years ago, Churchill thought that a minimum wage would provide a stimulus to firms to follow a higher-road competitive strategy. It looks as though he was right.

 Mike Kitson and Frank Wilkinson are researchers at the Centre for Business Research at Cambridge University

fields.headline: International roundup
fields.trailText: Police in Indonesia said yesterday that they had 25 people under arrest on suspicion of carrying out bombings in the capital, including the Jakarta stock exchange explosion that killed 15 on September 13.
fields.body:
Jakarta has 25 bomb suspects

Police in Indonesia said yesterday that they had 25 people under arrest on suspicion of carrying out bombings in the capital, including the Jakarta stock exchange explosion that killed 15 on September 13.

One suspect was alleged by the police spokesman to have been armed with a grenade and on his way to attack Jakarta's US embassy. His interrogation led to 24 others being picked up in the capital, the spokesman said.

Four of those detained were believed by the authorities to be the ringleaders of the bombing operation, he added. The hunt was still going on for more suspects.

"The people arrested have no links to military or police," said Senior Superintendent Saleh Saaf, deputy national police spokesman. "We suspect terrorists groups from Aceh are behind the bombings. Most of those caught are Acehnese."

The north-western province of Aceh has long been the scene of conflict between local separatists and Indonesian troops: for both sides, the province's oil is the prize.

At a meeting in Switzerland, meanwhile, the Indonesian government and activists from Aceh agreed yeterday to extend their notional ceasefire until January 15 2001. The truce came into effect on June 2, though since then 135 people have been killed anyway.
AP, Jakarta

Swiss spurn ceiling on immigrants

Swiss voters yesterday rejected a rightwing proposal that would have cut and restricted Switzerland's immigrant population. But the result exposed a sizeable and growing undercurrent of anti-foreigner sentiment.

The referendum proposal would have limited the proportion of foreign residents to 18% of the country's 7.2m people. It was rejected by a 60.3% vote.

At the moment immigrants constitute 19.3% of the population, or about 1.3m people. This is one of the highest proportions in Europe despite a strict system of work permits.

The four-party coalition government, as well as most of the main political parties and the business community, vigorously opposed the anti-immigration motion, because so many key parts of the economy rely on imported labour.
Peter Capella, Geneva

Spy chief flees Peru for Panama

The head of Peru's intelligence service, who provoked a political crisis, turned up in Panama yesterday after fleeing his country in a private jet. The Panamanian government initially refused an request asylum by Vladimiro Montesinos, but was said to be reconsidering.

Peru's leading newspaper, El Comercio, had reported Mr Montesinos's departure for an unknown destination. It said he left about midnight on Saturday.

Mr Montesinos - strongly linked to the military and to President Alberto Fujimori - was accused of trying to bribe an opposition politician.

When the scandal broke in earnest a week ago, President Fujimori surprised the country by announcing that he would be calling new elections in the coming months and then standing down after 10 controversial years in power. Opposition leaders have been calling for the prosecution of Mr Montesinos for alleged corruption.
AP, Lima

French snub vote on big reform

Yesterday's referendum in France on whether to cut the presidential term from seven years to five - the biggest constitutional change for 40 years - failed dismally to fire an electorate more exercised about taxes and the feeling that the fruits of economic growth are not yet reaching their pockets.

With an estimated 73% of those canvassed claiming to be in favour of the reform, a Yes vote appeared almost guaranteed. But not even last-minute appeals to vote by President Jacques Chirac, and the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, looked likely to reduce an abstention rate predicted at 69% last night.

Advocates of the longer term say it contributes to political stability, and claim a shorter mandate would destabilise the system whilst reducing the head of state's role to that of a ceremonial figurehead.

Proponents of the shorter term argue that seven years - and certainly two terms equalling 14, as served by the late François Mitterrand - is too long. They say a five-year term would reduce the risk of paralysing "cohabitations" between presidents and prime ministers from opposing parties, clearing the way for more basic reforms.

Mr Chirac changed his mind quite recently and decided to support the reform, possibly because he felt he would be more likely to be re-elected for a five-year term than a seven-year one. The change is to come into force after the 2002 presidential elections.
Jon Henley, Paris

Iraq's drugs sold off in Beirut

A British drug company has complained to the UN that medicines supplied to Iraq under the oil-for-food programme have been found on sale in Lebanon at bargain prices.

The medicines were part of a consignment of 1.4m Ventolin inhalers - a treatment for asthma and other respiratory conditions - ordered by Iraq from Glaxo-Wellcome.

Iraq said recently that more than 10,000 people had died during July as a result of sanctions, and cited respiratory problems as one of the main causes of death.

There have been many claims that Iraq is re-exporting its humanitarian aid while complaining about the impact of sanctions on its own people, but this is believed to be the first time that a manufacturer has positively identified a batch of re-exported medicines.

Glaxo-Wellcome sent the Ventolin to Beirut where it was handed over to the Iraqi ministry of transport to be taken to Iraq in nine lorries Soon afterwards, aggrieved Lebanese pharmacists reported that cut-price Ventolin was on sale in Beirut.
Brian Whitaker

webTitle: Fraud in republics may be deciding factor

fields.headline: Fraud in republics may be deciding factor
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Several hundred Yugoslav troops and military police guarded polling booths in Montenegro yesterday in a move denounced by Milo Djukanovic, the republic's pro-western president, as blatant intimidation by the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Several hundred Yugoslav troops and military police guarded polling booths in Montenegro yesterday in a move denounced by Milo Djukanovic, the republic's pro-western president, as blatant intimidation by the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

"You can judge for yourself to what extent we can talk of free and fair elections if the army is present at polling stations," he told reporters in Podgorica.

The Montenegrin government was officially boycotting the polls and people ended up voting in premises ranging from homes and butchers' shops to a nuclear shelter in the municipality, which is controlled by the main pro-Belgrade party.

Mr Djukanovic said Mr Milosevic had no chance of winning the elections fairly and that opposition leader, Vojislav Kostunica, a moderate Serb nationalist, had a "huge lead".

"At the same time I've no doubt that Milosevic will not give up power willingly. I've no doubt that, regardless of the actual political defeat, Mr Milosevic will declare victory."

Fraud by Mr Milosevic's officials was expected to be widespread in Montenegro because of the boycott. The republic has an electorate of 440,000 and pro-Belgrade supporters would not normally get more than a third of these, judging by previous elections.

In Kosovo, where fraud could be helped by out-of-date electoral rolls and confusion over the number of Serbs who have fled, the UN organised teams of "witnesses" to count the number of voters. The aim was to prevent inflated turnout claims by the Belgrade authorities.

The chief UN administrator in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, said that by the close they had counted 44,905 people entering polling stations in Kosovo.

In several areas of northern Mitrovice, polling stations never opened. In others, Kosovo Serbs were given no privacy to mark their ballots.

Further north, in the village of Berberishta, poll witnesses said officials of Mr Milosevic's Serbian Socialist party could be seen passing from door to door with a ballot box collecting votes. One opposition politician described them as acting like "postmen".

In Caglavica, another Serb enclave just south of Pristina, one of Kosovo's most prominent Serbs, Momcilo Trajkovic, was refused permission to vote because his name was not on the registration roll. Mr Trajkovic, a lifelong resident of the area, supports Mr Kostunica.

In Gracanica, voting was delayed briefly because of a dispute between the opposition Serbian Radical party and Mr Milosevic's followers over who would be permitted to cast ballots.

Ethnic Albanians, who make up 90% of Kosovo's population, stayed away from the polling and Mr Kouchner said "any claim of massive participation by Kosovo Albanians would be a fiction or manipulation".

Serbs in Pristina, mostly displaced families, voted in an unfinished basement room in a block of flats which has become a virtual prison yard for 150 Serbs, with British commandos providing round-the-clock protection against potential Albanian attacks.

For the rest of the capital, the election was a non-event. "Serbia? We have nothing to do with them. Let them go to hell," said one pensioner. Additional reporting by Nicholas Wood in Pristina

webTitle: G7 piles pressure on Opec with global slump warning

fields.headline: G7 piles pressure on Opec with global slump warning
fields.standfirst: Oil Recession would hit both rich and poor, cartel is told
fields.trailText: The world's leading industrial nations stepped up pressure on oil producers last night to increase supplies of crude oil to the west after expressing serious concern about the impact of higher energy prices on rich and poor countries.
fields.body:
The world's leading industrial nations stepped up pressure on oil producers last night to increase supplies of crude oil to the west after expressing serious concern about the impact of higher energy prices on rich and poor countries.

A strongly worded statement from the International Monetary Fund's key decision-making committee warned of the dangers of higher inflation and slower growth resulting from more expensive oil and put the onus on Opec to announce fresh output increases at its summit in Caracas, Venezuela, this week.

The IMF's move followed tough language on Saturday from the G7 nations which called on the oil cartel to take immediate action to reverse the recent trend in oil prices, which has seen the cost of a barrel of crude triple from around $10 to $32.60 since the start of last year.

Horst Köhler, the managing director of the IMF, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who chairs the fund's international monetary and finance committee, met Hamad Al-Sayari, governor of Saudi Arabia's central bank, yesterday in an attempt to broker a deal with oil producers.

This will be followed up by the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, who will write to all producer countries this week pressing for action to increase production.

Mr Köhler said he was confident that progress would soon be made, adding that both oil producers and oil consumers among the IMF's 182 member governments were worried about recent trends in prices.

A statement issued at the end of yesterday's meeting of the IMF committee - which includes Saudi Arabia, Algeria and the United Arab Emirates among its 24 members - underlined the concerted attempt by the west to bring prices down. It said: "The committee is concerned that current oil prices, if sustained, could hamper global growth, add to inflationary pressures, and adversely affect prospects for many countries."

The communique added that there was joint agreement on the need to stabilise oil markets around reasonable long-term prices. "The committee notes the steps the oil-producing countries have taken this year to increase production and calls on them to take further steps to create conditions in oil markets conducive to healthy global growth."

Mr Brown said he was encouraged by the amount of common ground between oil consuming and producing countries.

Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, said that Britain was better placed than many to absorb the impact of higher oil prices because inflation was below the government's 2.5% target. But he said the Bank's monetary policy committee would be watching closely to make sure that higher oil prices did not feed through into higher prices in the rest of the economy.

In a communique released after its meeting on Saturday, the G7 welcomed the US decision to release oil from its strategic stockpile, adding: "It is important that world oil prices return to a level consistent with lasting global economic prosperity and stability for both oil producing and consuming countries and, in particular, for the poor developing countries.

"In the light of continuing high prices and low level of stocks, it is crucial for the world economy that Opec and other oil producing countries take actions to contribute to a reduction in oil prices and greater stability in oil markets."

Stung by the virulence of fuel protests and fearful that higher oil prices could lead to a recession, the G7 said it had to make more efficient use of energy. But it made it clear that Opec was being held primarily responsible for bringing prices down to a range of between $22 and $28 a barrel.

Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary, said oil prices were "perhaps the largest cloud in a relatively blue sky".

webTitle: Waters engulf vast swath of Vietnam

fields.headline: Waters engulf vast swath of Vietnam
fields.standfirst: Squalid encampments are sprouting in the mud atop the Mekong delta's dykes as people seek high ground to escape record flooding
fields.trailText: The Mekong delta's worst flood for 40 years has cost more than 250 lives and left hundreds of thousands of people homeless. Unusually heavy monsoon rains have inundated vast areas of Laos, Cambodia and southern Vietnam. The relentless rise of the waters - five to 10cm a day for the last two months - has submerged houses and cut roads.
fields.byline: Owen Bennett Jones in Cao Lanh, southern Vietnam
fields.body:
The Mekong delta's worst flood for 40 years has cost more than 250 lives and left hundreds of thousands of people homeless. Unusually heavy monsoon rains have inundated vast areas of Laos, Cambodia and southern Vietnam. The relentless rise of the waters - five to 10cm a day for the last two months - has submerged houses and cut roads.

In the south Vietnamese province of Dong Thap 90% of land is covered by water. One of the last places of refuge, the provincial capital, Cao Lanh, is under a metre of water and levels go on rising. The town's shops try to carry on. But in restaurants, for example, the water is lapping at customers' chairs: takings, needless to say, are down.

For those in remote areas, the flood isn't just bad for business - it is life threatening. "A very large area [is] covered by water and this has a dramatic impact on families because it is difficult for them to earn money and find food for their families," says Peter Michelson, who is running the International Red Cross's relief effort in the Mekong delta.

Most of those forced to leave their homes are squatting on man-made dykes. On one, a few miles from the Cambodian border, 3,000 people are living in squalor on a small patch of muddy raised ground.

One of them, Nguyen Van Thanh, has used a plastic sheet to build a shelter on the dyke. "Life here is very difficult," he says. "It's very hot and I can't earn any money. That means I can't buy any food." The immediate future for him and his family is bleak: the water level will not return to normal until November at the earliest.

Fifteen-year-old Doi is also stuck here. "I have to sleep on our boat," he says. "Often there are storms and heavy rains. It's frightening. I just want to get back to my rice fields."

Most of those who have died in the floods have been children unable to swim. But given the huge scale of the inundation, the death toll has been relatively low because the rise of the water has been gradual, giving people time to escape.

Government policies have also helped. Impressive early warning systems are in place, and in recent years the authorities have encouraged people to build houses on stilts to reduce their vulnerability during the monsoon rains.

Flooding in the Mekong delta is an annual event. But this year, the authorities detected unusually high water levels in Cambodia and Laos. As early as July soldiers started shoring up dykes in the delta. Towns like Hong Ngu have been saved by their efforts. Troops built an 18-mile sandbag wall around Hong Ngu and it remains completely dry.

The Vietnamese authorities are often reluctant to admit that they need outside aid and - according to international aid workers - they initially insisted they could handle the floods alone. As the water level kept rising, the official attitude changed and foreign relief workers are now ranging widely though the delta areas, though their work is tightly controlled. If an aid organisation decides, for example, to provide rice, it must distribute it to beneficiaries selected by the local People's Committee.

For now the challenge for relief workers is mainly to rescue people in remote areas whose homes are becoming submerged. But when the waters start subsiding their task will change.

"We are still in a life-saving phase," says Mr Michelson. "The next stage is to provide food and help people to remain healthy."

Disease will spread quickly in the coming weeks. Evacuees on the dykes have no sanitation facilities and are drinking unboiled water. For now, the strong currents mean water is relatively clean but when the levels subside the water will stagnate.

"Now the water is swelling the quality is OK. I cannot imagine what it will be like when the water recedes" says a local journalist, Nguyen Thi Hong Van.

Water in still pools will become a breeding ground for mosquitoes and aid officials predict an outbreak of malaria.

Unusually heavy monsoon rains have inundated vast areas of Laos, Cambodia and southern Vietnam. The relentless rise of the waters - five to 10cm a day for the last two months - has submerged houses and cut roads. In the south Vietnamese province of Dong Thap 90% of land is covered by water. One of the last places of refuge, the provincial capital, Cao Lanh, is under a metre of water and levels go on rising. The town's shops try to carry on. But in restaurants, for example, the water is lapping at customers' chairs: takings, needless to say, are down. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: A Passage To India | LA Confidential | The Quick And The Dead | Midnight In The Garden Of Good And Evil
fields.body:
A Passage To India

(David Lean, 1984)

1.45pm, Carlton Cinema

Lean came out of semi-retirement to make this, 13 years after the troubles of Ryan's Daughter. But this sub-Merchant/Ivory production of Forster's Raj novel isn't a jewel in his crown, lacking the vibrancy of those early works. Nevertheless, it's well crafted and intelligent, graced by fine performances from Judy Davis as the Englishwoman raped in the Marabar caves, Alec Guinness, and best of all, Peggy Ashcroft.

LA Confidential

(Curtis Hanson, 1997)

10pm, FilmFour

Superb, dense, dark thriller with Russell Crowe as a hardnut cop teaming up with colleagues Guy Pearce and Kevin Spacey to root out crime and corruption. Hanson and Brian Helgeland richly deserved their Oscars for adapting James Ellroy's long, intricate novel, and the murky underworld of 50s LA is brilliantly realised, from shining chrome car bumpers to dead bodies in a diner.

The Quick And The Dead

(Sam Raimi, 1995)

12.20am, FilmFour

Raimi's homage to Sergio Leone is more fun than it sounds. Sharon Stone's woman-with-no-name is about as Eastwood as a woman can be - complete with poncho and cee-gar, she's a lethal contender in a 16-gun prize shoot-out in the two-bit town of Redemption. A quick-draw cast includes Gene Hackman's bad guy, Leonardo DiCaprio as his son, and Russell Crowe, in an early appearance, as Stone's lover. Raimi's Evil Dead pals would be proud of the bloody carnage he wreaks here.

Midnight In The Garden Of Good And Evil

(Clint Eastwood, 1997)

2am, Sky Premier

At a grand Christmas party in Savannah, Georgia, the host (Kevin Spacey) shoots dead his lover (Jude Law). In the ensuing investigation, visiting journalist John Cusack is left gawping at the bizarre reality beneath the town's genteel veneer. Eastwood's version of John Berendt's book about the murder is full of vivid characters, from Irma P Hall's voodoo woman to the vibrant transvestite, Lady Chablis. It's a fascinating portrait of time and place.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The Lake District
fields.trailText: The Lake District
fields.body:
Looking east from Cunswick Scar above Kendal you see the long, graceful line of the Howgill Fells stretched along the horizon, but now, incredibly, in front of them and masking the view, are five massive wind turbines - the largest in England, they say.

Why, for heaven's sake, just here, on a lovely ridge neatly sandwiched between the Lake District and the Yorkshire Dales national parks? Admittedly, not quite in either park but in an area of - until now - unspoiled scenery, and starkly visible from scores of places in both.

I first saw these monstrosities from the Kendal to Sedbergh road, just before they became operational, and could hardly believe what I was seeing. They are straddled on Lambrigg Fell, just to the left of the road, and above the motorway, just ahead, at exactly the point where you first see the Howgill Fells. Indeed, this was always the highlight of the drive from Kendal to Sedbergh - the sudden view of the Howgills in all their glory - but, sadly, now no longer. Instead, we have these monstrous windmills striding the skyline like menacing space-age monsters - surely an offence to all who treasure unspoiled natural scenery.

There may be something to be said for windmills in certain areas, correctly sited - although there seem to be grave doubts about their true cost-saving efficiency - but much more care should have been taken about some recent decisions.

We hear rumours, indeed, that many more are to be scattered along this once secluded ridge just across the river from George Fox's Pulpit on Firbank Fell. Have they got their eyes on this ridge too? And who is it, in some ministry office far from the fells, who, after hearing all the objections, finally decides: "We'll put them here. Nobody'll bother." Perhaps too late to bother now, but what about the next time?

Harry Griffin

fields.headline: Tears at bedtime
fields.standfirst: For most TV directors, the story of the Bristol Royal Infirmary scandal would be a cue for Hollywood tear-jerking. In Peter Kosminsky's Innocents, says  Mark Lawson, the truth is laid heartbreakingly bare
fields.trailText: For most TV directors, the story of the Bristol Royal Infirmary scandal would be a cue for Hollywood tear-jerking. In Peter Kosminsky's Innocents, says Mark Lawson, the truth is laid heartbreakingly bare
fields.body:
That contemptuous expression about politicians on the campaign trail "kissing babies" warns us that children are too easy a way of gaining sympathy. In war-time propaganda, it's standard to insist that the building which the smart missile just hit was a baby-milk factory or an orphanage.

There are baby-kissers and milk-factory propagandists in art as well. One of the problems with entertainment featuring children - the musical Annie, film Home Alone, pop record There's No One Quite Like Grandma - is the sense that they're using a bypass to the heart. The job of fiction is to win smiles, sympathy, tears, anger. But kids at least halve the task.

Producers often complain that reviewers criticise programmes for not being something else. But, in the case of Innocents (Sunday, 9pm, C4), I'm going to praise it - highly and excitedly - for what it astonishingly isn't. This latest docu-drama by Peter Kosminksy - whose previous news-driven dramas include the multi-prize-winning Warriors, about the British army in Bosnia - reconstructs events at the Bristol Royal Infirmary in the 1990s, when the unusually high death-on-the-table rate of two heart surgeons operating on babies was followed by the revelation that the tiny hearts stopped during surgery had been removed from the corpses for research.

Many previous Kosminsky films have dealt with equivocal material. For example, many viewers will have brought to Warriors not only doubts about soldiers as a breed but even greater scepticism towards their presence in Bosnia. His Shoot To Kill - about the Stalker inquiry - asked us to adjudicate between characters from organisations with equally unsavoury reputations at the time: the British police and the Royal Ulster Constabulary. At his best, Kosminsky ping-pongs your sympathy between different characters as fresh facts are presented.

The potential difficulty with the Bristol material - as with Kosminsky's recent drama about school bullying, Walking On The Moon - is that the ushers meet us at the door and tell us where to sit: on one side, parents sitting beside defenceless infants on breathing machines, on the other, arrogant surgeons, Mr James Wisheart (Tim Pigott-Smith) and Mr Janardan Dhasmana (Madhav Sharma), smarmily encouraging the grieving mums and dads to see the cemetery as half empty rather than half full. Unless King Herod happens to be watching British television next Sunday night, there's no dramatic conflict in the piece. A boxing referee would have stopped it the moment the contestants rose from their stools.

This is only a small weakness, though, because this isn't a "what happened?" but a "how did it happen?" piece. While the question in Shoot To Kill was "Who is right?", the central question here is this: how were the qualms of parents and doctor colleagues ignored for so long? And while, the drama is inevitably heart-rending, Kosminsky's direction and Neil McKay's script aren't actively sentimental. They bomb no milk factories.

The Hollywood possibilities - shots of favourite teddies looking sad, speeches about the babies being with the angels now, soprano choirs on the soundtrack - are entirely avoided. The terror of all parents - the death of children - is, for once, presented cold and bleak and clinical without dramatic manipulation or soppy consolation.

This is especially impressive when you remember that Kosminsky is dealing with the heartland material of TV soap opera: the most shameless ratings-chasing storylines in Casualty or Holby City involve the medical peril of young children. In fact, this director's brilliance might be defined as using the worlds of popular drama to tell important stories without the sentimental conventions of those genres.

Drama-documentary has always seemed to me a problematic form. The script can only ever be a compromise between the mouths of the real-life subjects, the ears of the dramatist and the eyes of both sides' lawyers. During any brilliant dramatic scene - the moment here, for instance, when Dhasmana watches a video made by another surgeon in the hope of learning where he's going wrong - you worry about whether the moment was as neat and powerful as this in reality. The viewer must trust the director and writer like a patient trusts the surgeon. But Kosminsky has by now earned our trust. The Bristol doctors were finally found out by their hit rates. Kosminsky's hit rate is his best defence.

There'll be much more to say in future weeks about Simon Schama's epic Millennial series History Of Britain (Beginnings, Sunday, 8.05pm, BBC2) but, by coincidence, it contains an extraordinary moment in which the historian stands before a display case of baubles given by Victorian mothers to the children they were handing over to foundling hospitals. One gift is a walnut with a hole drilled into it, intended to be worn as a pendant. Many viewers will have a rather teary gaze at the screen by the time Schama reveals that the making of these pieces was an emotional placebo: they were never given to the children.

By coincidence, I watched this sequence just before viewing Innocents. And if it seemed as if the Schama scene should carry a warning for those with children, there would be a case for blocking transmission of Innocents to houses in which parents are slumped on sofas listening to the deep-sleep breathing from upstairs. For once it's actually a deep compliment to describe a drama as almost unwatchable.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Devil's Rope | Morning Performance: English Cathedral Music
fields.body:
In 1873 Joseph Glidden visited a county fair in DeKalb, Illinois, where vast cattle herds regularly passed on their way to the Chicago railhead. One exhibit suggested ways of stopping the animals trampling local croplands. It inspired the 60-year-old farmer to convert an old coffee grinder into a machine to manufacture what soon became known as The Devil's Rope (11.0am, Radio 4). Barbed wire brought two classic American responses - 530 legal actions disputing Glidden's patent and a war between cattlemen and farmers.

Every afternoon choristers assemble in cathedrals across Britain to celebrate Evensong. There really is no comparable musical gathering anywhere else in the world. This week the remarkable tradition is honoured in Morning Performance: English Cathedral Music (11.30am, Radio 3). The programmes will feature performances by the choirs at Truro, Lichfield, Wells, Durham and Salisbury.

fields.headline: Broad church
fields.trailText: Sins of the Flesh | Dirty Tricks | Futurama
fields.body:
Some people who remember Emma Freud's stint on Radio 1 - me, for instance - would pay for her to be stuck in a dungeon full of sadomasochists' equipment. You could slip a gimp mask on her, with a zip across the mouth, padlock it shut and never open it again. In Sins of the Flesh (BBC1, Sun), an all too obvious attempt to make religious programming sexy, Emma did indeed find herself surrounded by the accoutrements for all sorts of kinky shenanigans. But, having wandered around San Francisco speaking to gay priests, paused to consider a painting once "restored" for moral reasons, and chatted amiably with Melinda Messenger, she proved herself not half as irritating as I remembered. In fact, she came over as quite lovely and thoughtful. It just shows how wrong you can be about someone.

As Emma stood in front of a crucifix - albeit one with wipe-clean leather pads which looked like a particularly daunting exercise machine - one's thoughts were for her safety and her reputation. Especially as she was hanging about with a dominatrix whose hair looked like it was made from an unravelled Muppet. She survived intact to do some more wandering, pausing and chatting in her discussion of sex and religion and whether religious taboos on sex were a Good Thing or a Bad Thing.

That she never resorted to the foolproof, if cruel, truism that there have been no sexy Christians since John the Baptist was evidence of Emma's contemplative and mature study, which inevitably ended with a statement of the obvious - we do need rules when it comes to sex, but ones we can all agree upon. Well knock me down with a feather (and make me lick your boots, mistress).

Some people are just never going to agree with anything remotely sane - people like Janet Folger, say, whose attitudes would be laughable if they didn't have quite so many adherents. Folger is a creepy American fundamentalist who wasn't content persecuting women who choose choice when it comes to abortion, and so moved on to curing homosexuals. The woman obviously has too much time on her hands. A most informative video, produced by a group called America Anti-Gay Sex, told us that evil homosexuals indulge in such practices as anal sex, fisting and rimming (practices that heterosexuals are apparently incapable of), although they could be "cured" if only they accepted Jesus into their lives.

John and Dena and Tom and Donna had all "struggled" with homosexuality (how difficult can it be?) but had abandoned their lives of sodomy and dressing up as gladiators with not-so-gay abandon. They, along with Folger and a rather grumpy bald talking head who used words like "abomination", were the best advertisement I know for becoming a friend of Dorothy and donning sequinned hotpants . Some people are just no fun at all.

Martin Clunes was great fun in Dirty Tricks (ITV, Sun) although he didn't resort to hotpants. He rarely resorted to pants at all, removing them at every available opportunity to reveal a bottom which would have had any cannibals watching salivating. Meaty doesn't even begin to describe it, although that seems a fair description of the drama's plot, which had adultery, masturbation, musical toilet roll holders and a dead accountant within the first half hour. There aren't nearly enough dead accountants on TV.

Dirty Tricks wasn't challenging, well-written drama but it wasn't pretending to be. It was quite watchable, however, and galloped along merrily, even if most of the characters were so paper thin, they were in danger of blowing away. The dead accountant's wife was dispensed with (she deserved it - she was a gymnastics teacher) and Lindsay Duncan was flown in to up the glacial totty quota. James Bolan's fleeting appearance as a dour policeman also brightened things up. All in all, Our Hero's descent - or ascent? - from language teacher to suspected murderer with £1.2m in the bank was pretty inoffensive stuff, apart from the annoying music, composed by someone who'd had too much tartrazine in their OJ as a child.

Futurama (C4, Sat) will never attain the adoration afforded to The Simpsons but is an exceptionally clever, smartly funny and deliciously dark slice of animation. A future classic, to be sure.

They, along with Folger and a rather grumpy bald talking head who used words like "abomination", were the best advertisement I know for becoming a friend of Dorothy and donning sequinned hotpants . Some people are just no fun at all. Martin Clunes was great fun in Dirty Tricks (ITV, Sun) although he didn't resort to hotpants. He rarely resorted to pants at all, removing them at every available opportunity to reveal a bottom which would have had any cannibals watching salivating. Meaty doesn't even begin to describe it, although that seems a fair description of the drama's plot, which had adultery, masturbation, musical toilet roll holders and a dead accountant within the first half hour. There aren't nearly enough dead accountants on TV. Dirty Tricks wasn't challenging, well-written drama but it wasn't pretending to be. It was quite watchable, however, and galloped along merrily, even if most of the characters were so paper thin, they were in danger of blowing away. The dead accountant's wife was dispensed with (she deserved it - she was a gymnastics teacher) and Lindsay Duncan was flown in to up the glacial totty quota. James Bolan's fleeting appearance as a dour policeman also brightened things up. All in all, Our Hero's descent - or ascent? - from language teacher to suspected murderer with £1.2m in the bank was pretty inoffensive stuff, apart from the annoying music, composed by someone who'd had too much tartrazine in their OJ as a child. Futurama (C4, Sat) will never attain the adoration afforded to The Simpsons but is an exceptionally clever, smartly funny and deliciously dark slice of animation. A future classic, to be sure.

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Stephen Dorff in The Gate (Tibor Takács,1987)

Who?
Diminutive former child star Dorff had pretensions to a serious acting career after starring in boxing drama The Power Of One (1992), in which he perfected his Seth Ifrican accent, before wheeling out an equally peculiar Scouse cadence in the pre-Fab Four Beatles biopic Backbeat (1993). Things went a bit awry with woeful Gen-X comedy SFW, where Dorff played hostage-turned-celebrity Cliff Spab (yes, Spab ). He then turned in a ridiculous performance as drag queen Candy Darling in Mary Harron's I Shot Andy Warhol (1996), followed by the nadir of Space Truckers (1997). His profile finally rose playing bloodsucker Deacon Frost opposite vampire hunter Wesley Snipes in the highly successful - and hugely camp - Blade (1998). Another stab at credibility is looming with John Waters' Cecil B. Demented, where he plays the title character - a maniacal underground film-maker. But starring with Melanie Griffith would make anyone look good.

The role:
Glen, a suburban pre-pubescent who accidentally opens a portal to hell after listening to heavy metal records (as you do).

Best line:
"Suck my nose till my head caves in." Sorry.

Cringe factor:
In the 13 years since The Gate, Dorff's acting skills haven't developed a jot...

Other wannabes:
The subsequent career of Louis Tripp, who plays Glen's friend Terry, extends to playing Terry again in Gate II: The Trespassers (1990).

Critical judgement:
"A worthless first half," opines Leonard Maltin, "is somewhat redeemed by amusing/scary special effects in the second."

Also not starring in:
Dorff had a recurring role in Roseanne, and popped up in the 1989 TV movie Do You Know The Muffin Man?

The Gate, Carlton Cinema, Wednesday 27 Sept, 11pm

webTitle: TV: "Sharp and promising new drama": Attachments

fields.headline: Just the job
fields.trailText: A novelist once claimed that the hardest aspect of fiction was deciding which jobs to give your characters. Few writers have been on proper payrolls, which is why so many central characters tend to be journalists or novelists. In television, except for series where the job is the plot - the cop, doc, vet and teacher shows - people tend to be vaguely "in business" or doing something unspecified in sales or accounts.
fields.body:
A novelist once claimed that the hardest aspect of fiction was deciding which jobs to give your characters. Few writers have been on proper payrolls, which is why so many central characters tend to be journalists or novelists. In television, except for series where the job is the plot - the cop, doc, vet and teacher shows - people tend to be vaguely "in business" or doing something unspecified in sales or accounts.

So long after the Industrial Revolution, writers never expected to be given an entire new profession to deal with - until the internet. The sharp and promising new drama Attachments (Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2) is set among young people setting up a website ). It's no surprise to find this series getting here so quickly, because its creator Tony Garnett made This Life. Many people would have set a yuppie drama among ad executives, but the genius of This Life was to realise the undercurrents of class, sex and deceit to be found in the legal profession.

Attachments, on the evidence of an opening episode from This Life writer Richard Zajdli, is similarly impressive in the way that the professional setting remains relevant to the look and feel of the series. Sex and love may be a major theme - as the email pun in the title gives away (the series was at one point called Click) - but the internet is never simply the background metaphor and CV-dressing that it is, for example, in the new David Hare stage play My Zinc Bed.

In Attachments, important plot twists result from web cameras and email and, as the lawyers in This Life carried their professional lying and power games into their private lives, so the excitability and fickleness of these characters results partly from working in one of the few professions in which days of work can vanish by hitting the wrong switch. Attachments does a good job, in part because of its unusual sensitivity to work.

webTitle: Law: A new ruling could help reverse a huge fall in the number of rape convictions

fields.headline: Found out at last
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Edwards was jailed for life at his eighth rape trial. Yet it might not have taken place without a ruling that could help reverse a huge fall in the number of rape convictions.  Sue Lees  reports
fields.trailText: Nicholas Edwards was jailed for life at his eighth rape trial. Yet it might not have taken place without a ruling that could help reverse a huge fall in the number of rape convictions.  Sue Lees  reports
fields.body:
Nicholas Edwards was finally found guilty of rape at the Old Bailey last week. It was his eighth trial on rape charges, but what was unusual was that this time the jury knew something of his history. In most rape trials the 12 men and women who have to decide the accused's fate are kept in the dark, unaware whether the man before them has a long history - in Edwards' case, 19 years - of forcing women to have sex with him. Edwards had been twice before convicted of rape and acquitted five times.

Each time he admitted that sexual intercourse took place, but claimed that the women consented. As his story shows, by no means all men acquitted of rape are innocent. Some are serial rapists and many, like Edwards, have repeatedly got away with it. But a landmark ruling by the law lords, which saw the 39-year-old welder put away for life last week, could put many more behind bars.

Edwards was one of the serial rapists documented in a 1993 edition of Channel 4's Dispatches programme, Getting Away with Rape, after he was acquitted for the fourth time. In the latest trial he claimed to have had sex with 2,000 women. But how many of his conquests consented? After the trial started, two more women came forward to say Edwards had raped them too. A nurse who accused Edwards of raping her in the early 1990s replied when she was accused of lying in the witness box: "Do you think I'm going to put myself through this ordeal and waste all the time of the police and courts if it didn't happen?"

Yet Edwards was acquitted. He smiled and clapped when the not guilty verdict was announced, and bowed to the jurors, saying: "Thank you very much. Cheers."

Far more men are acquitted of rape than convicted. The conviction rate for reported rapes has dropped from 24% in 1985 to a mere 7% today. This is in spite of advances in DNA analysis which enable separate rapes to be linked. At the same time, the proportion of rapes committed by strangers has dwindled to a mere 12% of reported cases, according to the Home Office's most recent analysis, published in 1999. Stranger rapists use the defence of identification rather than consent and with advances in DNA analysis, identity can now usually be proved.

Serial rapists may well be learning different tactics once they realise that they are much more likely to get off if they chat up their victim beforehand and then argue that the woman consented. This could explain, at least in part, the drop in the proportion of stranger rapes. Edwards was not the mythical unknown rapist who leaps on his victims in the dark. His crimes, like most rapes, could be categorised as "date rape" - a term often used loosely and inappropriately to cover any rape between acquaintances. The term implies that the rape is somehow less serious, that it happened almost accidentally when the man misread the signals given by the woman. But Edwards did not misread signals. He planned his rapes carefully and they fell into a common pattern. His victims were not long-standing girlfriends but women he had met only a short time before and apparently targeted.

In the latest trial, four of the women who had accused him and had their accusations dismissed by previous juries were allowed to testify following a historic ruling of the House of Lords last June. They were joined by another woman whose story had led to one of his two previous convictions. All recounted being raped by him in strikingly similar circumstances.

In each case, he first went up to the woman in a public place. He adopted a low-key approach to gain her confidence, making a date for another meeting. At the second meeting, he continued to chat her up and then isolated her, in most cases by driving her to a secluded spot - in two cases to the same churchyard. Then he changed from Jekyll to Hyde. His mood, previously calm, became angry and he became a domineering, terrifying bully, forcing his victims to give in to his demands. He refused to use a condom and intercourse was accompanied in each case by comments and instructions from him, telling the girl what to do. Afterwards he reverted to friendliness, often denying that anything untoward had occurred.

Like many serial rapists, Edwards has adopted more sophisticated tactics and become more adept at avoiding conviction. In the first case that came to court, in 1983, he held a knife to the victim's throat. The knife was produced in court and this led to his conviction. He never used a weapon again. In the latest case, he managed to persuade the woman to go to his south London flat. As he would know, juries rarely convict where a woman is raped after accepting an invitation to the man's home. This case would probably not even have come to trial if the other women had not been allowed to give evidence.

That breakthrough followed a legal battle by the crown prosecution service to get the evidence in front of the jury. Judges have a discretion to allow juries to hear evidence that the accused has behaved in a similar way in other cases - so called "similar fact" evidence - if the details show a strikingly similar pattern of behaviour. The judge has to decide whether the value of the evidence in proving the charges is so strong that it outweighs the prejudice to the accused. If so, and if admitting the evidence will not make the trial unfair, it can be allowed in.

But there was a stumbling block. In a 1950 case the privy council had ruled that a jury verdict was binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings. For the past 50 years that had been interpreted to mean that once an accused was acquitted, no evidence to show that he had actually committed the offence could be brought forward at a later trial. To do so, it was thought, would breach the "double jeopardy" rule by which no one can be tried twice for the same crime, a cornerstone of the British justice system.

The trial judge disallowed the evidence. The prosecution took the matter to the appeal court, which dismissed it, ruling that a prior acquittal not only precluded a second prosecution for the same offence but also barred the crown from citing evidence in a later prosecution that showed that the defendant was actually guilty of the charge of which he had been acquitted. The court reached this decision "with regret" and gave permission for an appeal to the Lords.

The law lords allowed the prosecution's appeal, overruling the 1950 judgment and setting a new precedent. The five judges said that allowing the women to give their evidence would not breach the double jeopardy rule because Edwards was not now at risk of conviction on the earlier rape charges, but only on the charge for which he was standing trial. The evidence was relevant and came within the ambit of the "similar fact" rule, and was not inadmissible just because it tended to show that the defendant was in fact guilty of offences of which he had earlier been acquitted.

It is a controversial change and not all lawyers agree with it. The law lords' ruling was in line with a recent Law Commission report on double jeopardy, but Andrew Trollope QC, who chaired the Criminal Bar Association group that responded to the Law Commission paper, believes the change breaches the principle that underlies the rule of double jeopardy. "You may easily draw the conclusion that because a man's been accused of rape eight times over, he must be guilty. That's a very dangerous road to go down. You have to remember that in those instances, or a number of those instances, the facts have been closely examined by previous courts and that there has been a doubt in each case." Bruce Houlder QC, vice-chairman of the Criminal Bar Association, argues on the other hand that it "defies common sense" to exclude such evidence.

The change in the law can be seen as an acknowledgment that multiple rapists are going free and that something needs to be done about the high acquittal rate. The acquittal of serial rapists is far more common than often imagined.

Very few men rape only once, and with this change more guilty men will be brought to justice. Perhaps at last the dramatic drop in the conviction rate will be reversed. Women should be encouraged to report rapes and to give evidence in court after this landmark decision.

 Sue Lees is professor of women's studies at the University of North London and author of Carnal Knowledge: Rape on Trial. She has acted as a consultant to two Dispatches programmes: Getting Away with Rape 1993 and Still Getting Away with Rape 2000.

webTitle: Play it cool like Clint, judges told

fields.headline: Play it cool like Clint, judges told
fields.standfirst: Writ large
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.body:
It was a little sneaky of the Lord Chancellor's department to release their most important publication of the year when they knew I was away on a crucial summer research trip in the south of France. I refer, of course, to the long-awaited and much-speculated-on Media Guide for the Judges, which had gone through more revisions than James Joyce's Ulysses. To take a typical issue that had been bothering me for years: what should a judge do on finding a reporter outside his or her house? Should he follow the imaginative example of the now retired Mr Justice Harman, whose solution was to kick the reporter in the goolies, only to be told that the chap was in fact the cabbie driving him to court? Try unsuccessfully to hide his face with a poorly positioned white handkerchief or newspaper (also a Harman ploy)? Swear at the reporter, coupling it with an invitation to settle the matter right there and then, pugilistically? Alas, all the above have found their way to the "don't" section of the advice, although I believe that some of them were controversially transferred from the "do" only at the last minute.

The "do" section urges judges to stay calm and polite, and look friendly. But one piece of advice goes further, urging the judges, virtually in so many words, to behave like a lone Clint Eastwood unexpectedly confronted by a band of outlaws: "If you find yourself at the centre of a media scrum - stop walking momentarily. You will find that the reporters and photographers will naturally back off to give you space. Having established a degree of control, continue on." Wow, that's what I call judicial fightin' talk. But what if we don't back away?

 The law lords sitting on the privy council also managed to slip in a dramatically important judgment in my absence. In an appeal from Jamaica by prisoners on death row, the judges ruled - overturning a long line of previous decisions - that the prisoners should not be executed until their petitions to international bodies such as the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights had been ruled on. The point is that death row prisoners in almost all Caribbean countries make pleas to such bodies; until now the state could disregard them and execute even when the cases were still pending. Potentially, the privy council decision will save many lives and change the face of capital punishment in the Caribbean.

The decision wasn't unanimous. Lord Hoffman dissented. Not for the first time - I choose my words carefully - he has come out in favour of an interpretation of the law that has the effect of allowing the death penalty. In at least one case he was in a 3-2 majority, and prisoners were executed as a result. This time he was alone.

 The National Film Theatre and Geoffrey Robertson QC's Doughty Street Chambers have compiled an interesting selection of courtroom dramas to be shown at the NFT during October, many of them introduced or discussed by John Mortimer and various QCs. The 15 films include some of the classics (Twelve Angry Men, Judgment at Nuremberg, Inherit the Wind, the underrated Anatomy of a Murder) and a televised version of the brilliant play about the Steve Biko inquest, with Albert Finney playing the barrister Sydney Kentridge. It's a pity that the organisers were (presumably) unable to get hold of what, for me, are the two most satisfying courtroom dramas of them all: To Kill a Mockingbird and Witness for the Prosecution. On the other hand, I am much relieved that the programme doesn't include In the Name of the Father, the Hollywoodised story of the Guildford Four, the courtroom scenes of which are the most ludicrous and wildly inaccurate ever seen on a cinema screen. The film versions of Judge Dredd and the Queen of Hearts's sentencing process in Alice in Wonderland are models of careful research in comparison (though admittedly "Off with her head" was not a valid sentence at the time, due to lack of a guillotine).

 I don't do plugs in this column, but I cannot remember the last time I was so impressed with a book about the law. It explains and demystifies the English legal system - how it works , who is in it - simply yet with authority, clearly yet comprehensively. "A kind of upbeat legal mixture of Madame Bovary, As You Like It and La Traviata. I loved every page." (Albert Einstein). The title is The Law Machine (5th edition), published by Penguin, by Marcel Berlins (a columnist) and Clare Dyer, legal correspondent of this parish.

On the other hand, I am much relieved that the programme doesn't include In the Name of the Father, the Hollywoodised story of the Guildford Four, the courtroom scenes of which are the most ludicrous and wildly inaccurate ever seen on a cinema screen. The film versions of Judge Dredd and the Queen of Hearts's sentencing process in Alice in Wonderland are models of careful research in comparison (though admittedly "Off with her head" was not a valid sentence at the time, due to lack of a guillotine).  I don't do plugs in this column, but I cannot remember the last time I was so impressed with a book about the law. It explains and demystifies the English legal system - how it works , who is in it - simply yet with authority, clearly yet comprehensively. "A kind of upbeat legal mixture of Madame Bovary, As You Like It and La Traviata. I loved every page." (Albert Einstein). The title is The Law Machine (5th edition), published by Penguin, by Marcel Berlins (a columnist) and Clare Dyer, legal correspondent of this parish.

webTitle: Women: Mel B's got hers in a twist over a little bit of airbrushing.

fields.headline: Anyone seen my knickers?
fields.standfirst: Mel B's got hers in a twist over a little bit of airbrushing.  Stephanie Theobald goes on the trail of the missing underwear
fields.trailText: Mel B's got hers in a twist over a little bit of airbrushing.  Stephanie Theobald goes on the trail of the missing underwear
fields.body:
Karl Lagerfeld predicted that plastic surgery would be the haute couture of the 21st century, but maybe we should make that airbrushing. Mel B knows all about airbrushing - or digital removal in Photo Shop as it's known in the trade. She recently did a shoot for Loaded wearing a bikini, but when the magazine came out this month, there she was on the cover, wearing just a light swarm of bees around her more sensitive parts.

She says she's going to sue, but frankly - apart from the obvious point of what did she expect, doing a photo shoot with Loaded - she surely can't deny that the airbrush has done her a few favours? What, not even a single line on your face, Mel? Not a single stretchmark after the birth of your baby daughter? Amazing, such naturally perky breasts? The airbrush is every celebrity's best friend these days.

Take nude Robbie Williams on the cover of this month's Vogue, photographed with model Gisele by Mario Testino. Airbrush, honey-coloured lighting, almond oil (used by the pros for that genuine sexually abandoned glow), it's all the same, it's all a game.

There are other ways of reading these pictures, of course. The Loaded image is not a pleasant one. Mel's body is being molested by bees. True, Robbie's behind is exposed, but he gets away with his nakedness. He has a vaguely "phwoar" look on his face and is even making a thumbs-up-for-the lads sign (while Gisele is wearing clothes like a "nice girl", a mystery - until, it is implied, Robbie has the pleasure of discovering her).

The problem is that there is no female equivalent of the naked Robbie Williams, of the Bruce Webber hunk who's spent all day working on an oil rig. There is no mainstream female aesthetic that allows a woman to look au naturel without immediately becoming sexualised. You could also say that Mel B is just helping to prop up a system whereby famous women can get on only by looking passive or "bad" - it's all the same thing in the soft porn context - and taking their clothes off. Whether you are covered in bees or a skimpy bikini, it's all much of a muchness.

Mel B is obviously upset because she feels she has lost control of her image. Nor is she the first to make a fuss about photographic liberties being taken with their smalls. Melanie Sykes was less than amused earlier this year when her bikini bottom vanished after a cover shoot for Maxim magazine, while Kylie Minogue insisted that her thong disappeared between posing and publication in GQ. But it is hard to stand up for Mel B, like it used to be hard to stand up for Naomi Campbell - though I used to try because it is harder to be a black woman than a white one. Both Naomi and Mel are perceived as stroppy and this is not unconnected to the fact of their colour. Like being a lesbian, nobody really cares until you get successful and then they care. Then they hate you.

So why fret about the absence of something that was barely there in the first place? Does the bees thing make it a porn image whereas a Gucci bikini would have made it classy? On paper, yes, there's a difference, although my view is that theyshould all wake up and smell the coffee if they choose to be in that mainstream arena. The Greenham Common women were much more interesting and worthwhile.

Perhaps the real question is: what's with all this no-clothes "fashion"? We seem to be in a real post-clothes moment and, according to last week's New York fashion shows, we're all going to be wearing 24-hour bikinis next summer. But before everyone starts stripping off, a word of advice: a good body is the best fashion accessory of all but clothes are important, too. It is often only the thought of what the person was wearing before they took their clothes off that gets you through the night.

webTitle: Letters: A jab for the government

fields.headline: A jab for the government
fields.trailText: I am 71, with arterial and serious heart problems, including two heart attacks. Being classified as high risk, I visited my local surgery last week to arrange for my annual flu jab and was refused on the grounds that the "lists were full" and the government was the cause.
fields.body:
I am 71, with arterial and serious heart problems, including two heart attacks. Being classified as high risk, I visited my local surgery last week to arrange for my annual flu jab and was refused on the grounds that the "lists were full" and the government was the cause.

Try to imagine my feelings when I read your news item published the following day (Over 65s resist flu jabs, September 22) in which the government blames the patients and not the system.

I may be excessively cynical but I feel that governments wish that people died when reaching 65, so as to remove a social irritant.
E McHale
