fields.headline: Down with sport!
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: The age of dissent
fields.body:
What a fabulous opening to the Olympics: the little girl in pink flying about, the fishes, the flame. My mother was enraptured. Briefly. Soon it was just cyclists' bottoms and swimming pools. More wall-to-wall sport. There are certain things in life that one likes to avoid: rabies, loud noise, Bruce Forsyth, food poisoning. With a bit of luck and effort, you can manage it. But not if it's sport. Once upon a time you could jump up minutes from the end of the news, snap the telly off quickly and miss the sport, but not any more. The news IS sport: this manager is leaving, that sports person had his hair cut, cried, took drugs/bribes, thumped his wife/ another player/the referee, earns millions, was transferred, failed a urine test, wore a new swimsuit.

Last week we had several chaps to dinner. Imagine the conversation. Football "is a soap opera, spectacle, live drama, ballet, competition, only the middle class can afford it/no they can't/yes they can and isn't Beckham handsome".

What a dull meal. I blame Gardener's friend. He came visiting specifically to learn about football. Then he can earn huge amounts of money making websites. He felt this was justification enough to set Gardener and Fielding blathering and bore his hostess rigid.

These fellows had forgotten that in our house the majority feel bitter about sport. My mother had a particularly rough time of it recently, bedridden and in need of distraction. All she could do was read or watch telly, which meant the European Cup or Wimbledon. Or racing, golf, cricket, eventing or snooker, hour after hour for weeks and months. As usual, Coronation Street was all over the place and my mother's routine shot to hell.

And for what? Sport is hardly pleasant, even to the enthusiast. "Look at the blood on that white horse," said Gardener, flobbed on the sofa. There were worrying red spatterings where the jockey had gouged away with his spurs. And little footballing boys of nine are now eyeballing referees, pulling their shirts over their heads, cheating and swearing, just like their grown-up heroes. But perhaps the worst sporting event ever has just arrived - an Andrew Lloyd Webber musical about football: The Beautiful Game. What an odd title.

fields.headline: Poverty and chastity
fields.standfirst: Not all great buildings are made from elaborate, costly materials. Le Corbusier's monastery of Sainte-Marie de la Tourette, near Lyon, was built with humble, pure concrete. And, says  Jonathan Glancey, it's all the better for that
fields.trailText: Not all great buildings are made from elaborate, costly materials. Le Corbusier's monastery of Sainte-Marie de la Tourette, near Lyon, was built with humble, pure concrete. And, says Jonathan Glancey, it's all the better for that
fields.body:
Great architecture has never been dependent on the expenditure of vast sums of money. It can be, yet there is no law that says it must be. I reminded myself of this by making a pilgrimage to what for me is one of the very greatest buildings of all time. This is the monastery of Sainte-Marie de la Tourette near Eveux-sur-l'Arbresle, Lyon, consecrated in 1960 and built cheaply from humble concrete.

To make such an extravagant claim for the building is bold, given that this Dominican monastery, although designed in the spirit of the chaste Carthusian foundations of medieval Italy, may look to some like a brutalist refugee from London's South Bank.

Yet here is a building that is at once as poor and as rich as the mendicant monks for whom it was designed and built. Poor in terms of cost and the stark poverty of the materials used to build it, rich in ideas and spirituality. Today, much new architecture is slick and polished, erected by teams of highly competent contractors and engineers working to designs fed through fairly reliable computer programs. The buildings, whether office blocks, shopping malls or distribution depots (or public libraries, hospitals or schools) are expensive in absolute terms, yet generally good value for money given what they are required to do. Most, however, are soulless or even cynical.

La Tourette, by contrast, is a tour de force. Set high on a ridge overlooking the vineyards of Beaujolais country, this college and monastery, now essentially a lay study centre, was commissioned from the great architect Le Corbusier by the formidable priest Père Couturier. This was in 1953. Le Corbusier had already, encouraged by Couturier, been working on the superb pilgrimage chapel of Notre-Dame du Haut at Ronchamp (1950-54). Buildings such as this and La Tourette marked a profound change in Le Corbusier's approach to architecture; a move away from the severe, white geometry of his pre-war years. They also represented a new architecture for a church trying to come to terms with a world of modernism and progress.

An artist who was to live a monk-like existence in his later years, Le Corbusier had always been drawn to the powerful yet simple architecture of the most severe medieval monasteries. While learning to be an architect, back in 1907-11, he had travelled throughout the Mediterranean and central Europe, and had been particularly inspired by the Charterhouse of Ema at Galluzzo, Tuscany. That building, with its interplay of collective spaces and "living cells", influenced his later work, so that many of his famous buildings - long before he designed La Tourette - seem like monasteries in one form or other. The Pavillon Suisse (1930) and the Unité d'Habitation housing block in Marseilles (1946-52) certainly have that look and feel.

Le Corbusier had always been fascinated by religion and the religious experience. Swiss by birth, he was a descendant of the Cathars - the 13th-century Albigensian heretics - all but exterminated by St Dominic and his Inquisition shock-troops appointed to their gruesome task in the Languedoc by the Vatican. I felt, as I sat in the church at La Tourette, as if the architect must have been reconciled to that distant historical memory by the act of building so intelligently for those who would have burned him at the stake had he been alive seven centuries earlier.

Le Corbusier pondered the design of La Tourette for three whole years before the concrete mixers turned. The result was a design of immense subtlety and grace. Planned around a central glazed cloister, three sides of the building comprise lecture rooms, refectory, chapter room, library and two storeys of cells, each with its own loggia. The fourth is dominated by the church. The complex yet contained geometry of the building is broken by two dramatic elements - the oratory with its pyramid roof that juts into the cloister, and the undulating wall of the lower church, its roof capped with sloping rooflights.

The monastery is bathed in a wash of ever-changing daylight, except for the deliberate darkness of the oratory. After the dank rigours of 19th-century Gothic revival colleges, it must have been a relief to the Dominican novices who came here to be bathed in sun, light and air; to experience an architecture that was at once ancient and modern. Though La Tourette has unfinished ceilings and exposed pipework, though it is a little crumbly 40 years on, it still lifts the soul.

Le Corbusier had come to believe that the beautiful, taut, white villas he had built in his 40s were for the eye only; now, in his 60s and into his 70s, he wanted to engage all the senses and the spirit, too. To do so, he made his architecture increasingly less pure, less slick. And into the design of La Tourette he poured a lifetime's learning - not just of architecture, but of the Bible, of Greek myths, of the scholastic philosophy propounded by the Dominicans (from St Thomas Aquinas).

La Tourette is not just another bru talist concrete building. There is immense subtlety in its proportions, and in the way that light plays through its cells, lecture rooms and corridors. There is, too, a quiet virtuosity in the way that the monastery's spaces have been gently squeezed into what proves to be a much smaller building than its dominant position in its wine-growing landscape suggests.

Here is an architecture of real maturity, but also of grace and, above all, of poverty. A freely chosen poverty very much at odds with our shiny new world, 40 money-grabbing and money-blowing years down the line.

 Sainte-Marie de la Tourette, Eveux-sur- l'Arbresle, near Lyon, France, can be visited. Details: 00 33 4 74 26 79 70.

fields.headline: The new divorce
fields.standfirst: The Yorks look like the archetypal old-fashioned happy family. Except, of course, we know they're divorced.  Yvonne Roberts looks at splitting up, 21st-century style
fields.trailText: The Yorks look like the archetypal old-fashioned happy family. Except, of course, we know they're divorced.  Yvonne Roberts looks at splitting up, 21st-century style
fields.body:
Suddenly it's as if saying goodbye to a spouse is no longer the dismal climax to protracted misery that it once was. Instead, divorce in the 21st century appears almost a positive (and permanent) lifestyle choice: a brand new glossy beginning. And who in their right minds would wish to resist that?

Now the ex-wife can buy a magazine designed especially for her (Divorce and New Era are shortly to appear), or watch the TV programme (Channel 4's Break Up) to see how others have done it before her, or sign up for the game show (promised by Channel 5), or open celebrity bulletin Hello! in the certainty that there is bound to be a dazzling divorcee draped over her Terminal 4-sized stainless steel kitchen, parroting Jerry Hall and saying that, alone, she's never been happier, more fulfilled, more, well, complete.

So how different is divorce in the new millennium? Once, it meant a sharp drop in the standard of living, especially for the wife at home - but has the female influx into permanent employment meant the family coffers are no longer so sharply affected? If glitz and gloss have replaced stigma and loss of status, what impact does that have, if any, on the steep learning curve we are now embarked upon to establish what makes a marriage work? And are we better equipped to limit the damage of divorce - not least for the sake of the children?

In 1998, there were 145,000 divorces. "Divorce rate falls to a 10-year low" read a Daily Mail headline last week. On the issue of matrimony and its consequences, however, broad generalisations are often contradicted by myriad complex undertows. Divorce is partly down because marriages have slumped. At 267,000 per year, matrimony is reduced to post-first world war rates when bachelors were scarce. Today, those people who once entered marriage because living together was frowned upon are now cohabiting instead.

Their departure still leaves a phenomenally high rate of marital breakdown - four out of 10. So who divorces and why? And what might that tell us about marriages that last? Academics Kathleen Kiernan and Ganka Mueller have analysed three major surveys of adult lives. They discovered that the deprived are more divorce-prone, as are those who have cohabited more than once before marriage, those who have embarked on relationships at a young age, those who have experienced parental divorce and those who have "low emotional wellbeing". In short, an awful lot of us are vulnerable.

The crude take on divorce used to be that the rich didn't because they had too much invested, while the poor did because they had nothing to lose. The analysis is now becoming more subtle. For instance, Ceridwen Roberts of the Family Policy Studies Centre suggests another group vulnerable to divorce might be individuals reared in "relationship-poor" families - an emotional deprivation that can strike at even the wealthiest. At the London School of Economics, meanwhile, academics are examining how married couples living in the least advantaged areas make their relationship flourish, against the odds. Part of the answer appears to lie in strong networks of family and friends, and a willingness to ask for support.

Two other influences may also play a part in 21st-century divorce. One is time, or rather the lack of it. Increasingly, both partners are stretched by their jobs; they may commute, they may have to travel. Absence makes the heart grow fonder, but not if the reunions are fraught and fleeting. A second factor is the inflated value of perfection: perfect wedding, perfect baby, why not order up the perfect marriage, too?

"The enemy of the long-term relationship," says Penny Mansfield of marriage and partnership research charity One Plus One, "is this desire for perfection. The idea that as soon as the partnership doesn't feel right, it must be intrinsically wrong."

One Plus One has conducted research for an information pack which, from next year, will be available to all those intending to marry. This is part of the government's bid to encourage us to do more homework on our relationship before we commit. (A lot cheaper than mopping up the aftermath of divorce, now costing over £4b per year.) Asked what had made a long relationship rewarding, individuals talked about companionship, shared hopes and ideals, mutual respect, but also, crucially, the capacity to weather the bad times. "If the basic ingredients are right," Mansfield says, "the more couples struggle through, the more reasons they have to stay."

Popular consumer culture, of course, goes against the grain of long-term marriage. The message that we are all entitled to something newer, shinier, better, can eat away at even the veterans of matrimony. Half of all divorces come in the first 10 years of marriage but now one in five is granted to couples who have been married for 20 years or more. It may be triggered by the death of a parent or illness or retirement; events that remind us we are mortal beings. "Is this as good as it gets?" can prove a far more destructive question in a marriage than: "Are you having an affair?"

If divorce is inevitable, how do we unravel what's best for the children? A review of 200 British studies, spanning 30 years, reveals that long- term difficulties (poor qualifications, unemployment, relationship or health problems) are twice as common among the children of separated couples, although - and this is vital - they still affect only a minority. A "good" divorce requires sufficient money so that children's lives don't change drastically; it requires parents to resolve conflict; it is one in which multiple changes (new house, school, "dad") are avoided and in which parents resist using their offspring as ammunition. The fact that Fergie and Prince Andrew have managed it says something about the scale of resources (and, perhaps, the air of unreality) required to make it happen.

Are divorcees a flush new consumer market just waiting to be tapped? A recent report on how parents cope on marriage breakdown revealed that three out of four experienced a sharp decline in living standards, with ex-wives - some in full-time jobs - hit hardest of all. "Women relying on their earnings for their main source of income increased fourfold," the report says, "while the proportion relying on benefits doubled."

Still, we do have a small but growing group of divorcees who can afford the cost of double holidays, two houses, resurrected social lives, personal therapy and "guilt" presents for children shuttling between homes. But no matter how hard the entrepreneurs who smell profits in marital discord try to persuade us that this is a lifestyle to aspire to, old-fashioned apsirations prevail. Paul Davies of future trend forecasters the Henley Centre says: "In survey after survey, when people are asked what matters to them, the majority say, again and again, the family and being a parent."

It's just the happy ever after that we can't quite seem to get right.
fields.bodyText: Suddenly it's as if saying goodbye to a spouse is no longer the dismal climax to protracted misery that it once was. Instead, divorce in the 21st century appears almost a positive (and permanent) lifestyle choice: a brand new glossy beginning. And who in their right minds would wish to resist that? Now the ex-wife can buy a magazine designed especially for her (Divorce and New Era are shortly to appear), or watch the TV programme (Channel 4's Break Up) to see how others have done it before her, or sign up for the game show (promised by Channel 5), or open celebrity bulletin Hello! in the certainty that there is bound to be a dazzling divorcee draped over her Terminal 4-sized stainless steel kitchen, parroting Jerry Hall and saying that, alone, she's never been happier, more fulfilled, more, well, complete. So how different is divorce in the new millennium? Once, it meant a sharp drop in the standard of living, especially for the wife at home - but has the female influx into permanent employment meant the family coffers are no longer so sharply affected? If glitz and gloss have replaced stigma and loss of status, what impact does that have, if any, on the steep learning curve we are now embarked upon to establish what makes a marriage work? And are we better equipped to limit the damage of divorce - not least for the sake of the children? In 1998, there were 145,000 divorces. "Divorce rate falls to a 10-year low" read a Daily Mail headline last week. On the issue of matrimony and its consequences, however, broad generalisations are often contradicted by myriad complex undertows. Divorce is partly down because marriages have slumped. At 267,000 per year, matrimony is reduced to post-first world war rates when bachelors were scarce. Today, those people who once entered marriage because living together was frowned upon are now cohabiting instead. Their departure still leaves a phenomenally high rate of marital breakdown - four out of 10. So who divorces and why? And what might that tell us about marriages that last? Academics Kathleen Kiernan and Ganka Mueller have analysed three major surveys of adult lives. They discovered that the deprived are more divorce-prone, as are those who have cohabited more than once before marriage, those who have embarked on relationships at a young age, those who have experienced parental divorce and those who have "low emotional wellbeing". In short, an awful lot of us are vulnerable. The crude take on divorce used to be that the rich didn't because they had too much invested, while the poor did because they had nothing to lose. The analysis is now becoming more subtle. For instance, Ceridwen Roberts of the Family Policy Studies Centre suggests another group vulnerable to divorce might be individuals reared in "relationship-poor" families - an emotional deprivation that can strike at even the wealthiest. At the London School of Economics, meanwhile, academics are examining how married couples living in the least advantaged areas make their relationship flourish, against the odds. Part of the answer appears to lie in strong networks of family and friends, and a willingness to ask for support. Two other influences may also play a part in 21st-century divorce. One is time, or rather the lack of it. Increasingly, both partners are stretched by their jobs; they may commute, they may have to travel. Absence makes the heart grow fonder, but not if the reunions are fraught and fleeting. A second factor is the inflated value of perfection: perfect wedding, perfect baby, why not order up the perfect marriage, too? "The enemy of the long-term relationship," says Penny Mansfield of marriage and partnership research charity One Plus One, "is this desire for perfection. The idea that as soon as the partnership doesn't feel right, it must be intrinsically wrong." One Plus One has conducted research for an information pack which, from next year, will be available to all those intending to marry. This is part of the government's bid to encourage us to do more homework on our relationship before we commit. (A lot cheaper than mopping up the aftermath of divorce, now costing over £4b per year.) Asked what had made a long relationship rewarding, individuals talked about companionship, shared hopes and ideals, mutual respect, but also, crucially, the capacity to weather the bad times. "If the basic ingredients are right," Mansfield says, "the more couples struggle through, the more reasons they have to stay." Popular consumer culture, of course, goes against the grain of long-term marriage. The message that we are all entitled to something newer, shinier, better, can eat away at even the veterans of matrimony. Half of all divorces come in the first 10 years of marriage but now one in five is granted to couples who have been married for 20 years or more. It may be triggered by the death of a parent or illness or retirement; events that remind us we are mortal beings. "Is this as good as it gets?" can prove a far more destructive question in a marriage than: "Are you having an affair?" If divorce is inevitable, how do we unravel what's best for the children? A review of 200 British studies, spanning 30 years, reveals that long- term difficulties (poor qualifications, unemployment, relationship or health problems) are twice as common among the children of separated couples, although - and this is vital - they still affect only a minority. A "good" divorce requires sufficient money so that children's lives don't change drastically; it requires parents to resolve conflict; it is one in which multiple changes (new house, school, "dad") are avoided and in which parents resist using their offspring as ammunition. The fact that Fergie and Prince Andrew have managed it says something about the scale of resources (and, perhaps, the air of unreality) required to make it happen. Are divorcees a flush new consumer market just waiting to be tapped? A recent report on how parents cope on marriage breakdown revealed that three out of four experienced a sharp decline in living standards, with ex-wives - some in full-time jobs - hit hardest of all. "Women relying on their earnings for their main source of income increased fourfold," the report says, "while the proportion relying on benefits doubled." Still, we do have a small but growing group of divorcees who can afford the cost of double holidays, two houses, resurrected social lives, personal therapy and "guilt" presents for children shuttling between homes. But no matter how hard the entrepreneurs who smell profits in marital discord try to persuade us that this is a lifestyle to aspire to, old-fashioned apsirations prevail. Paul Davies of future trend forecasters the Henley Centre says: "In survey after survey, when people are asked what matters to them, the majority say, again and again, the family and being a parent." It's just the happy ever after that we can't quite seem to get right.

fields.headline: Remainders of the day
fields.trailText: As if things weren't bad enough for Gordon Brown (Brown's worst week, September 23), Paul Routledge's biography of the chancellor (published price £17.99) is now on sale near Birmingham New Street station for £2.
fields.body:
As if things weren't bad enough for Gordon Brown (Brown's worst week, September 23), Paul Routledge's biography of the chancellor (published price £17.99) is now on sale near Birmingham New Street station for £2.
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes, Bucks

 Have any political parties considered an Olympics team event? The Conservatives could try pursuit cycling, New Labour a triathalon involving spin, duck and waver and the Liberal Democrats the armchair events.
Adam Potterton
Oxford

 It is incorrect to say you couldn't get a bowl of spaghetti in the 50s (No spuds please, September 22). Even during the wartime shortages, Olivellis restaurant in Soho served large helpings of spaghetti. I lived in Glasgow throughout the 1950s and we often ate pasta.
Marion Woolfson
Edinburgh
MarionWoolfson@ compuserve.com

 The Lady's Slipper orchid (Passnotes, September 19) might have been in the guardianship of English Nature since its discovery by my mother's father in 1937, but my mother remembers the precautions taken to ensure its continued existence. Its flower was cut to aid concealment, though it was thought lost when trampling cows contributed to its disguise.
Erica Halvorsen
Southsea, Hants
ecs@cix.compulink.co.uk

 The figurative use of "literally" (A bit of lit crit, September 23) was disposed of in Punch well over a century ago. Quoting a report that Gladstone "sat literally glued to the bench," during a debate, the magazine commented: "That's torn it!' said the Grand Old Man as he literally wrenched himself away for supper."
John Whiting
London

webTitle: Letters: Surtitles added to English opera

fields.headline: Harsh words over critic's anguished aria on surtitles
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements is foaming at the mouth because surtitles are to be provided for an opera sung in English (Incomprehensible, September 23).
fields.body:
Andrew Clements is foaming at the mouth because surtitles are to be provided for an opera sung in English (Incomprehensible, September 23).

Yet a visit to the cinema these days presents quite an aural challenge - and opera sung in our native tongue is more difficult. Surtitles have increased my enjoyment of opera and for Mr Clements to suggest it will become "museum art of a vacuous kind" as a result of their use is ludicrous.

Why should he mind? Many musical people follow instrumental works with a score on their knee. Does this transform the performances to mere "engaging background music"?
Gavin Bullock
Winchester
gavin.bullock@dial.pipex.com

 So Andrew Clements is outraged at the use of surtitles for an opera sung in English. This "bizarre decision" helps the one in seven of us who have a hearing loss and who are unable to make out lyrics in whatever language they are sung. Does he really find surtitles so intrusive that he would deny someone with a hearing disability the opportunity to enjoy opera?
Leigh Donnison
Leighton Buzzard, Beds

 The last time I saw Billy Budd, a few years ago in Newcastle, again with the charismatic Simon Keenlyside as Billy, I was bowled over by the music but couldn't follow the words in the choruses and ensembles.

This time I was able to refer when necessary to the non- intrusive screen which those in the side of the stalls circle were given to view the surtitles, and this enhanced my enjoyment of the whole opera. During the monologues and other solos I had no need of the surtitles and was able to ignore them.
Drusilla Calvert
London
d.calvert@macrex.com

 Andrew Clements's outrage is misplaced. Like him, I attended Billy Budd. Unlike him, I was glad of the surtitles when I was unable to understand the English that was being sung.

My ire is reserved for the people who chose surtitling over the system available at the Metropolitan in New York. There, both Mr Clements and I would be satisfied - our differing needs served by an individual monitor mounted in the seatback in front of us. Mine would be on, his off.
Hywel Sims
London
HandR@limehouse62. freeserve.co.uk

 Andrew Clements's note of despair over the use of surtitles is well taken and yet another sign of a dumbing down in the arts in the UK. I believe it was the Italians who started this practice at La Scala. We watch opera from Italy on satellite TV now and again. Even in this medium, where the words are perfectly clear, we get subtitles on the screen despite the libretto being in the vernacular.
Reg Williamson
Kidsgrove, Staffs
regwilliamson@beeb.net

fields.headline: Hezza is to blame
fields.trailText: Harry Beresford (Letters, September 23) calls on Clare Short to call on Peter Mandelson to apologise for the Millenium Dome. Surely a case of mistaken identity?
fields.body:
Harry Beresford (Letters, September 23) calls on Clare Short to call on Peter Mandelson to apologise for the Millenium Dome. Surely a case of mistaken identity?

The dome is Michael Heseltine's brainchild. He decided to build at Greenwich rather than Birmingham. In January 1997, as deputy prime minister, he pleaded with Tony Blair to get the Labour party behind the project.

When the newly elected Labour government discussed whether to cancel, it found that the project was so advanced that uncancellable construction contracts had been entered into.
NT Shepherd
Bristol

 In all the flurry of letters and editorials about the dome, I think I haven't seen one morsel of print that mentions that it is, in its way, extraordinarily beautiful.

If you don't believe me, just go and stand by the Thames with your back to Canary Wharf in the evening and take a look. If Monet was alive today he'd be there painting it in all weathers.
Kevin McGrath
Harlow, Essex
kevin.mcgrath@bigfoot.com

 Now Tony Blair has the opportunity to solve two problems in one go and recoup a bit of lost popularity at the same time - close down the dome and sell or lease it to the biotech industry as the sole, safe, non-contaminating environment for trials of GM crops.
Jeremy Hilton
Tackley, Oxon
firejhilton@talk21.com

fields.headline: Russell's arid legacy
fields.trailText: One could do little better to mislead (and mire) the public's image of philosophy further than your restatement of the myth that "Bertrand Russell was one of the greatest philosophers of the 20th century" (The ghost of madness, September 23).
fields.body:
One could do little better to mislead (and mire) the public's image of philosophy further than your restatement of the myth that "Bertrand Russell was one of the greatest philosophers of the 20th century" (The ghost of madness, September 23). This view of him isn't shared outside the narrow, Cartesian and positivist mindset of the analytic school, whose maths fixation and envy have reduced philosophy to an arid, remote and blinkered field.

Your extract from Ray Monk's book portrays Russell's family life as a war between reason and the senses, cold, procrustean logic and the emotions, a behaviourist "science of child psychology" and psychoanalysis, leading to the anguish and mental derangement of several of his family. It mirrors the Cartesianism in which Russell's own philosophising was immured.

Though Russell was a gifted writer, and a brave campaigner against the bomb and for socialism and justice, there's another story to be told. His philosophical legacy is a disaster.
David Rodway
Kensington and Chelsea College, London

fields.headline: Failing the pensions test
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee's partial reading of the research on take-up of means-tested benefits by pensioners does her little credit (Targets for pensions, September 22).
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee's partial reading of the research on take-up of means-tested benefits by pensioners does her little credit (Targets for pensions, September 22).

The government's pilot exercises to increase the take-up of income support among pensioners induced only one in seven of those contacted to make a claim (one in three of which were successful): 86% did not claim even when they knew about it. Only two-fifths of claims were from entitled non-recipients and three-fifths from people who were ineligible or not entitled. Pensioners told the pilot's evaluators that a more adequate retirement pension would remove the need for income support.

Means tests are deeply unpopular and not an effective solution to pensioner poverty.
Alan Walker
Professor of social policy, University of Sheffield

 Social insurance and means testing are both ways of redistributing resources, but in different ways. Social insurance mainly redistributes across life cycles, while means testing more directly targets resources to low-income groups. They are not "left" or "right", "good" or "bad", "new" or "old". Both are better at some things than others. The issue is what the balance should be in pension provision over the next couple of decades.

Thanks to the government's excellent management of the economy the prospects for public finances are better than for generations. As a result, re-indexing pensions to earnings is affordable. The government actuary's evidence to the social security select committee's report on pensioner poverty, published in August, was that this would require a 0.23% per annum increase in contributions over 60 years.

In my experience as a local councillor, the minimum income guarantee is not reaching enough of those who need it. Pensioners do not support means-tested benefits and do want re-indexation. It is wholly consistent with the principles on which New Labour has tried to govern to learn from experience, respond to their views and change policy to take account of them.
Steve Munby
Liverpool

 Payment of national insurance contributions entitles us to (among other things) the state pension. There has never, however, been any direct financial link between the amounts, and the government of the day has always determined its level. Pensions have in practice been paid out of current taxation.

Fifty years ago few pensioners had any other income, and the same state benefit for all was appropriate. Today there are huge variations in pensioner income, strongly correlated with age. Published figures show that 41% of pensioner couples are actually in the top half of the population income distribution. William Beveridge would never have suggested the same pension for all in today's situation.

Short of introducing age-related benefits, I believe that the government's broad strategy is correct. If more is to be spent, it would be ludicrous to pay it out equally to all, when so many over-80s still live in poverty. Far better to target those in real need, whatever Lady Castle may think.
Alan Pavelin
Chislehurst, Kent
alan@pavelin.fsnet.co.uk

 Polly Toynbee is absolutely right. Residual memories of the horrors of the means test in the 1920s have an enduring place in the collective consciousness of the Labour party but it is misleading to allow the whole principle of means testing to be tarred with the same brush.

I could hardly live on my state pension without housing and council tax benefit, but I regard these, like the pension itself, as a right, earned in my working years and see no reason to be deterred by any sense of hurt pride from letting the council know I am entitled to them.
Derek Fane
Bognor Regis, Sussex

webTitle: Letters: The case of the cojoined twins

fields.headline: Life or death dilemmas
fields.trailText: In his piece on the case of the conjoined twins, Alexander McCall Smith (Tough justice, September 23) rightly asks Archbishop Murphy O'Connor what he would do if he could save only one of two people dangling from a rope below his balloon.
fields.body:
In his piece on the case of the conjoined twins, Alexander McCall Smith (Tough justice, September 23) rightly asks Archbishop Murphy O'Connor what he would do if he could save only one of two people dangling from a rope below his balloon.

This made me think of a case we were given in law school, concerning two shipwrecked people. One was holding on to a plank and the other swimming towards it. The plank would not keep two people afloat, so the one who had reached the plank first pushed back the other, who subsequently drowned. The survivor was acquitted.

The law recognises that a person who is in the position of having a reasonable chance to survive cannot be expected to give up his life to save another or to share the fate of death.

I think this would convince most people if they try to put themselves into the position of Jodie. As for the church leaders who are prepared to accept that two die where one could be saved, their moral credibility has once more been diminished.
Christian Wisskirchen
London

 Lord Justice Ward appears to state that one of the factors that entered into his decision in the case of the conjoined twins was an assessment that, without Mary, Jodie would be able to live a "fairly normal" life. If she was not a "bright, alert baby" would the decision have been a different one?

On the other hand, he describes Mary "parasitic" and "sucking the life-blood" of her sister. I feel sure that language like this would not have been used if Mary did not have severe brain damage.
Jennifer Hoskins
Reading, Berks

fields.headline: Yes or no...
fields.standfirst: ...the Danes have done Europe a favour
fields.trailText: Denmark's decision on joining the euro is both less important than British sceptics have been trying to make it and a great deal more significant than Labour and most other European Union governments would like.
fields.body:
Denmark's decision on joining the euro is both less important than British sceptics have been trying to make it and a great deal more significant than Labour and most other European Union governments would like. Polls show the Nos well ahead, providing sceptics here with Danish delight. But Denmark is a small country with a penchant for hard-fought referenda (Thursday's will be the sixth on Europe since Danish accession).

A Danish No will make very little difference either to the fate of the euro on the exchanges or, since the krone is pegged to it, to the long-run value of the national currency. The campaign has highlighted a reactionary and racist element among a people the left here used to hold up as a kind of welfarist superego. Some Noes are fighting for "national socialism". The campaign shows opposition to the single currency sliding into rejection of the European Union, hostility to immigration and rejection of ethnic diversity within a single country. Danish nationalism is no oxymoron. Like all its kin, however meek and mild their spokespeople (see below for Scotland) part of its appeal lies in exclusion, aggression and hate.

The Blair cabinet's silence over the Danes' decision might be diplomatic reticence or a sign of recent distraction. But let us hope their scouts have been out on the Skaggerat. It is not just the intensity of the campaign - "normal" politics has gone by the board for six weeks. Nor is it the way former alignments have come unstuck: the bulk of the No votes are likely to come from left-of-centre voters, as in 1992 when the Danes rejected the Maastricht treaty. A principal lesson, all the more worrying after the petrol protests, is the rejection by people "out there" of the line adopted by the elites, stretching that term to include not just the ruling party but the rest of the political class, corporate business interests and trade unions.

Regardless of the result, the Danish experience demonstrates that the euro is not and can never be an "economic" issue. Forget Gordon Brown's mantra about five tests. The Danes say it is a matter of national destiny and so it is here. The Danish economy is booming. Unemployment is 5%, half the EU average. Joining the single currency would merely legitimise a de facto union. Danes do not believe it is just about krone in their purses. The currency may be a symbol - but changing it still says something fundamental about who they are. A weakness of the pro campaign led by the prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, has been its reluctance to grasp that this is a key instance in the politics of identity that speaks about the shape of Denmark for decades to come, perhaps even its existence as an "imagined community".

The foundations of the European house were neglected by the architects. It has to have people's adherence, heart and mind. And people live still inside nation states with all their dense (and sometimes oppressive) allegiances, histories and predilections.

For some, for example Italians and Germans, Europe has been a kind of better self; national leaders have advanced the European cause with, often, popular acclaim. But in what member state are people not now confused, if not downright hostile? To enlargement (witness German polls), to "integration" (sentiments in the UK are shared in Scandinavia), to altered financial circumstances in which recipient countries become donors (look at recent changes of tune in Spain and the Irish Republic). However they decide this week, Danes have done the rest of us the great favour of bringing popular sentiment to bear on the EU. At last.

fields.headline: No: 1726
fields.standfirst: Napoleon
fields.trailText: Napoleon
fields.body:
Age:
Will be born next month.

Appearance:
Old hat.

Tricorn:
Let's not prejudge it.

But I thought Napoleon was long dead?
You are confusing the man and the musical.

The musical!?
'Fraid so. Les Misérables has a lot to answer for.

I thought it was rather good.
Indeed, but it has given West End producers the idea that we are aching to see an endless succession of gallic blockbusters - Martin Guerre, Lautrec, Notre-Dame de Paris, and now Napoleon.

And are we?
Non: so far we have voted with our pieds. Martin Guerre and Lautrec quickly met their Waterloo, and the critical bells failed to chime for Notre-Dame.

Dare one ask how Napoleon's epic life is being treated?
As a love story, of course - yes tonight Joséphine, and twice on Saturdays. The show plots "an improbable romance that is to bloom into one of the world's most passionate, tempestuous and heart-breaking love stories".

How does that fit historically?
It's a bit like making a musical about Hitler and concentrating on his relationship with Eva Braun.

All About Eva. I see it now - the burgeoning love affair in the 30s, the embattled chancellor, marriage in the bunker as Berlin burns, the final kiss before...
No doubt the German blockbuster's day will come.

Was Napoleon a great lover?
Unlikely. He spent most of the time marching across Europe subjugating other countries. In any case, he eventually dumped Joséphine, who had failed to produce an heir, so he could marry an Austrian princess.

At least he was a great revolutionary.
Non-sens! He was a counter-revolutionary, destroyer of the republic, founder of an empire and, worst of all, had the most ridiculous haircut.

Not to be confused with:
Boney M.

Do say:
"C'est la guerre, mais ce n'est pas magnifique."

Don't say:
"I really think the Dreyfus case has musical potential."

fields.headline: Policy made manifest
fields.standfirst: Here is the Guardian's version
fields.trailText: Today the Guardian makes a move that we believe is unprecedented in United Kingdom journalism. Instead of merely reporting the ideas of politicians, or criticising them one by one, we have sought to do what they do - publishing a detailed, coherent manifesto of our own, available with copies of the paper.
fields.body:
Today the Guardian makes a move that we believe is unprecedented in United Kingdom journalism. Instead of merely reporting the ideas of politicians, or criticising them one by one, we have sought to do what they do - publishing a detailed, coherent manifesto of our own, available with copies of the paper.

This was an endeavour that went beyond merely asking Guardian staff to sit down and produce an extra supplement. Our aim was to put ourselves in the shoes of those we usually watch and analyse, to simulate as closely as we could the experience of drawing up what we hope is a radical and realistic programme for the next government. That meant more than just writing our own wish lists for the UK - though we did that in the pages of the paper from May until August. It also meant submitting to the rigour of an external scrutineer, in the form of the former civil servant and custodian of the public purse, Sir Peter Kemp. He writes of his experience as a Guardian watch dog on the opposite page. We had to listen, too, to the views and opinions of readers, put, often forcefully, through letters, emails and discussion on a dedicated part of our website. The forum - at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/manifesto - is still there and we hope it enjoys a fresh surge of attention now that people can see the finished product.

For debate was the goal of this entire exercise. Timed to coincide with the Labour party conference, it would, we hoped, provide some talk of substance amid all the frenzy of opinion polls, memoirs and personalities at war: after all, offering a vision for the country is what politics should ultimately be all about. The Guardian specialists who wrote the manifesto have occasionally strayed from the existing editorial "line" of the newspaper, raising some bold, new ideas. We hope they stimulate a vigorous, enjoined discussion about not only the future of the government - but the future of the country.

fields.headline: Microsoft backs NHS online project
fields.standfirst: Patients' files to be instantly accessible
fields.trailText: Microsoft is backing a project from Isoft, a small British technology company, to put the country's medical records online, allowing controlled access by doctors and healthcare workers throughout the NHS.
fields.body:
Microsoft is backing a project from Isoft, a small British technology company, to put the country's medical records online, allowing controlled access by doctors and healthcare workers throughout the NHS.

Patrick Cryne, chief executive of Isoft, which supplies computer systems to hospitals and health organisations, said: "We want to make sure that modern technology available to other sectors is also available to the health sector because there is nothing more important than delivering high quality, efficient healthcare quickly."

The government's 1998 information for health strategy and this years NHS plan say computers are crucial to the aim of putting the patient first in the health process. The government plans to invest £1bn in new IT systems by 2005 to make it easy to transfer healthcare information between GPs, hospitals, community care and social services.

Anne Irving, head of marketing at Isoft, said that the partnership with Microsoft would create a system making available anywhere at any time a complete picture of a patient's medical history.

The initial agreement between the two companies will last 18 months, the time thought necessary to develop the technology. The systems are being developed with City Hospital, Birmingham, for market testing in March 2001.

Microsoft and Isoft will both put money into the project, but the exact financial arrangements have not been disclosed.

Under the agreement, Isoft will develop prototype systems that will show how healthcare information can be shared between professionals in different organisations. The company will also look at how this information can be used to provide treatment that is co-ordinated and based on knowledge of a patient's medical history.

Microsoft will supply technical skills and advice on technology advances.

The technology resulting from the project will be made available on emerging devices such as smart phones, digital interactive TV and tablet PCs, as well as traditional computer workstations.

webTitle: After four months MBO floats at £250m

fields.headline: Early riser
fields.standfirst: After four months MBO floats at £250m
fields.trailText: Just four months after completing a £122m management buyout from the investment group Singer & Friedlander, stockbroker Collins Stewart is being floated with a value of £250m.
fields.body:
Just four months after completing a £122m management buyout from the investment group Singer & Friedlander, stockbroker Collins Stewart is being floated with a value of £250m.

Deputy chairman Andrew Stewart and chief executive Terry Smith will see the value of their stakes in the business, which has almost £700m under management as well as acting as a traditional broker, crystallised at £21m and £10m respectively.

Some £70m of new money is being raised in the flotation to pay off debt and help fund the firm's Quest online database and share analysis system. But none of the existing shareholders, which include Citicorp Financial Ventures and Bank of Scotland as well as the management team, is selling any stock.

Unusually, the manage ment team has agreed not to cash in any of its shares for at least two and a half years.

Mr Smith, who sprang to prominence in the City 10 years ago with a critical book on corporate accounting techniques, Accounting for Growth, said the early decision to float simply reflected the strength of trading at Collins Stewart, which boasts an unbroken nine-year record of profit growth.

"At the time of the MBO we said we would review the situation after three months and we were ready to remain private for a number of years. But the opportunity to pay back the MBO debt arose and we decided to go for it."

The move would make it easier to offer staff share options andother incentives.

HSBC Investment Bank is advising on the float, with trading expected to get under way early next month.

webTitle: GUS will help make net more rewarding

fields.headline: GUS will help make net more rewarding
fields.trailText: Great Universal Stores, the retailing and credit reference group, will launch the electronic equivalent of the Green Shield stamps reward programme today.
fields.body:
Great Universal Stores, the retailing and credit reference group, will launch the electronic equivalent of the Green Shield stamps reward programme today.

GUS is allying with American group MyPoints, which will bring its internet-based loyalty points schemes to Europe.

Internet users will be rewarded for a wide range of online activities, from reading and responding to email offers to completing surveys or making purchases.

Steve Markowitz, chairman and chief executive of MyPoints.com, said: "It's a great deal for consumers because they are rewarded for what they do every day."

The aim of MyPoints is to enable companies to reach more people and attract them to their sites in an increasingly competitive e-commerce world.

GUS has a 10% stake in MyPoints.com and will be investing £8m as the majority shareholder in MyPoints Europe. GUS's information services division, Experian, will develop, implement and operate the loyalty infrastructure services, such as net databases and direct marketing services.

MyPoints began in the US in 1996 and has attracted more than 15m members. It claims to reach more than 12% of internet users and expects to attract more than 5% of Britain's online population within 12 months. It also has plans for France and Germany.

Points can be redeemed for products and services such as theatre tokens and travel and gift vouchers.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: An investigation into possible insider dealing in Thames Water shares has been begun by the stock exchange. It follows as suspicious price moves before last week's announcement that the company was in advanced takeover talks.
fields.body:
Sunday Express

An investigation into possible insider dealing in Thames Water shares has been begun by the stock exchange. It follows as suspicious price moves before last week's announcement that the company was in advanced takeover talks.

The oil group BP, which is worth just under £140bn, is close to overtaking Vodafone at Britain's biggest company by market capitalisation.

Mail on Sunday

Sturmey-Archer, one of the oldest names in the British cycle industry, is threatened with liquidation, putting 300 jobs at risk.

Two more Rover employees have been dismissed following an investigation into financial irregularities at the car company. They were alleged have have been claiming night shift payments while working days.

Sunday Times

Coutts, the Queen's bank, will be at the centre of a Manhattan criminal court case on Wednesday when two Canadian businessmen are accused of defrauding it of £22m.

British Airways is poised to sell or float Go, its low-cost subsidiary, because it is not compatible with its overall strategy. Chief executive Rod Eddington is also expected to announce another round of job cuts, targeting middle management this time round rather than cabin crew and ground staff.

Observer

Deputy prime minister John Prescott will use his speech to the Labour Party conference today to start a crackdown on company directors who neglect health and safety regulations.

Abbey National is coming under pressure from City institutions to sell out or merge with a banking rival.

Oftel, the telecoms watchdog, is setting up an inquiry into BT's treatment of rivals which are seeking access to its local exchanges, in an effort to deflect criticism that it is too soft on the former monopoly.

Sunday Business

Ford motor company is seeking up to 1,600 redundancies from its Land Rover factory in Solihull by the end of next year in a drive to return the company to profitability.

Tyco International, the US conglomerate, is considering a £6bn bid for Invensys, the British automation and controls group.

Sir Richard Branson has withdrawn his personal guarantee for the extra £50m the national lottery commission has demanded to satisfy its concerns over his bid for the licence.

Sunday Telegraph

A management team at Seagram's wine and spirits division has abandoned plans to undertake a buyout of the liquor business.

Land Securities, Britain's largest property group, has made a £175m bid for a Bank of England building in the heart of the City.

IoS

British Airways is to attempt a merger with Swissair , Switzerland's largest airline, after the failure of its £3.1bn deal with KLM.

webTitle: The store that is no longer undersold

fields.headline: The store that is no longer undersold
fields.standfirst: Southampton's Tyrrell & Green is a 1950s period piece - oppressive shades of brown lining dingy stairwells with ceramic steps and black plastic handrails
fields.trailText: Built in 1956, two years after Tyrrell & Green joined the John Lewis Partnership, the shop was a south coast shopping institution until it closed its doors for the last time on Saturday.
fields.body:
Built in 1956, two years after Tyrrell & Green joined the John Lewis Partnership, the shop was a south coast shopping institution until it closed its doors for the last time on Saturday.

Such is local feeling that store manager Peter Turner was carrying around a poem penned by a regular customer this weekend as he prepared for Thursday's opening of the replacement - a £40m John Lewis located down the road.

But Mr Turner, who has run Tyrrell & Green for the past five years, fully understands why the image needs to be changed.

"We can't grow our business on our present customer base," he says.

For all its appeal to the faithful, the Tyrrell & Green name meant that 20 minutes up the road in Winchester, more than 35% of the population did not realise the store was part of the John Lewis chain.

At the new shop in the nautically-themed £400m West Quay shopping centre, the aim is to harness the greater pull of the partnership's name.

Bright and modern, the aesthetic contrast between John Lewis Southampton and Tyrrell & Green is inescapable. The brownish colours remain, but high ceilings and open-plan design create an impression of space. Fixtures are in fashionable wood and brand names are given greater prominence. There is an enticing "place to eat" and there are new services, such as advice for parents on creating a nursery.

Mr Turner is anxious that the only changes should be cosmetic. "The older customers, they do feel an affection for Tyrrell & Green, but that comes from the people, the partners."

His local partners - the workers - also feel strongly about the old store.

But if the views of Diane Warren, manager of perfumes and a partner for 27 years, are any guide, they too know that it is time for a change.

"When I ring the suppliers and say 'Tyrrell & Green', they seem uncertain. Once I say 'John Lewis Partnership', things are done.

"I'm delighted (with the name change) because we should have a corporate image," she says.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Five charged in Egg case
fields.body:
Five charged in Egg case

Five people have been charged with conspiracy to defraud Egg, the online and telephone bank in which Prudential has a majority stake. Four men and a woman will appear before Milton Keynes magistrates next month. Detectives say they are still seeking a 24-year-old man.

Britain heads for 'slugflation'

The British economy is heading for two years of "slugflation", a combination of sluggish growth and rising inflation, according to the Centre for Economics and Business Research. The London-based consultancy said higher fuel prices and the pound's weakness against the dollar were chiefly to blame.

fields.headline: Makeover for John Lewis
fields.standfirst: Partnership spends £300m to make the brand a national name
fields.trailText: A radical shake-up of the John Lewis Partnership's department stores now under way will see the John Lewis brand extended across the country in the first stage of a £300m makeover of the 25-strong chain.
fields.body:
A radical shake-up of the John Lewis Partnership's department stores now under way will see the John Lewis brand extended across the country in the first stage of a £300m makeover of the 25-strong chain.

The first sign that some of the oldest names on Britain's provincial high streets will disappear came this weekend as Tyrrell & Green, the 103-year-old department store in Southampton, closed its doors for the last time. It will reopen on Thursday in a new location as John Lewis Southampton, the first store to change its name in the history of the partnership.

The John Lewis name is now expected to be given a national focus as the uniquely structured partnership works frantically to tackle a sharp fall in profits despite rising sales.

Intense competition from high street rivals and uncertainties surrounding the effect of the internet on shopping habits are heaping pressure on the group to update not only its outward appearance, but also internal procedures.

Two years ago it was forced to fend off a move by rebels to break-up the partnership, so-called because the 40,000 employees share in its profits, and list on the stock market.

Now, in the most visible sign of the group's desire to modernise itself, £300m will be spent over the next three years on the department stores, 11 of which are still known by the names of their individual founders. But the associated costs, coming in the wake of a 43% fall in first half pre-tax profits to £38.5m, have put a halt to the long-awaited refurbishment of its London head office. Partners were informed of the abandoned facelift to the Victoria office last week.

The name changes to remaining stores are expected to take place with the approval of partners locally after the completion of the makeover of the stores. New stores opening in out-of-town sites will be called John Lewis. The rebranding in Southampton is part of the partnership's plan to focus on an "authoritative, distinctive and profitable" network of shops, according to Luke Mayhew, director of trading.

At a meeting last week Mr Mayhew told partners of plans to advertise nationally across Scotland for the first time, where three stores have opened recently. The partnership is also trying to tackle the way the internet could affect sales while also working on plans to use the web to improve logistics.

Jessop & Son, the Nottingham department store, is expected to be next in line to shed its founder's name, adopting John Lewis Nottingham instead, as part of a £20m redesign.

Only Peter Jones, the flagship store on Sloane Square in Chelsea, currently undergoing a £80m refit over three years, is expected to buck the trend towards a single brand.

Aside from Peter Jones in London, the former Tyrell & Green in Southampton, and Jessop & Son in Notting- ham, the John Lewis Partnership also owns stores which do not bear its name in Windsor, where it known as Caleys, Reading (Heelas), Southsea (Knight & Lee), Watford (Trewin Brothers), Cambridge (Robert Sayle), Norwich (Bonds), Liverpool (George Henry Lee) and Newcastle upon Tyne (Bainbridge).

fields.headline: Jack Weir
fields.standfirst: Presbyterian churchman and patient servant of the peace process in Northern Ireland for over 20 years
fields.trailText: Dr Jack Weir, who has died aged 81, was a Presbyterian churchman who helped ignite the first glimmering sparks of the Irish peace process and, over 20 years, fanned them into life.
fields.body:
Dr Jack Weir, who has died aged 81, was a Presbyterian churchman who helped ignite the first glimmering sparks of the Irish peace process and, over 20 years, fanned them into life.

Soon after the Birmingham pub bombings in November 1974, which killed 19 people and injured 182, Weir, who was then clerk to the general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Ireland, defied widespread criticism and hostility from the Unionist community and joined the leaders of other principal Protestant denominations in a bold pilgrimage to a small hotel in the backwater village of Feakle, County Clare.

There they were joined by the elusive leadership of the Provisional IRA, whom they confronted with a condemnation of violence, a dissertation on its futility and a plea for peace, so that the future of Northern Ireland and the differences between its communities could be resolved democratically by negotiation.

The encounter swiftly proved fruitful and by Christmas that year, the churchmen, now designated the postmen of peace, were at the heart of negotiations between the terrorists and the British government. These resulted in a fragile, but short-lived, ceasefire. Weir was not surprised that it crumbled within months. He had privately been horrified by the 1920s-based unreality of IRA political thinking and the closed minds that perpetuated it, but he recognised that a vital breakthrough had been made and that it must be enlarged.

He dedicated his work and life to sundering communal divisions, promoting ecumenism and cooperation between the churches and, above all, opening minds and hearts to a much broader perspective than the narrow confines of Northern Ireland's highly dysfunctional and sectarian society. It required courage, vision, leadership, dedication and faith, qualities Weir possessed.

His considerable influence and vision was engaged in pioneering encounters in the 1970s between the leaders of the Catholic church, Methodists, Presbyterians and Church of Ireland. This ecumenical initiative is now so strongly rooted that continuing meetings at head of church level pass without comment.

Weir again defied convention and bigotry by leading a Presbyterian delegation to meet the Pope, during his visit to Ireland in 1979. Two years later he led a tour of US cities to counter the one-sided view of events being given by Republicans and their sympathisers.

By the 1990s, Weir, whose information and judgment about undercurrents of life in Northern Ireland was consistently unrivalled, learned about secret contacts between the British and the IRA. With sectarian violence at a high level, he again defied public hostility, and engaged in further talks and contacts in a bid to bolster the fledgling peace process.

When both the Republican and Loyalist terrorist groups finally declared open-ended ceasefires in 1994 and the Belfast Agreement was concluded on Good Friday, 1998, Weir was entitled to some credit, for without his intervention the flames of peace would have been even more difficult to kindle. Among the fulsome tributes paid on his death came one from the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams, who described Weir with obvious respect as "an old dissenter".

Weir had been born in China, the son of missionaries. After primary education in mission schools, he returned to Belfast to continue his studies at Campbell College and Queen's university, where he graduated in experimental physics before training for ordination in 1944.

After mission service in China, until expulsion by the Communists in 1950, he returned to Ireland as parish minister in Letterkenny, before becoming deputy and then clerk to the general assembly, where he served until retirement in 1985. He served a term as moderator in 1976.

In later years he courageously endured Parkinson's disease without ever compromising his interest in church and political affairs, or his love for China, the land of his birth, which he visited again in 1996.

He was unmarried.

webTitle: BP on route to acquiring a big autobahn presence

fields.headline: BP on route to acquiring a big autobahn presence
fields.trailText: BP's new logo will appear on petrol station forecourts lining autobahns as part of a deal under discussion between the British oil company and German utility RWE to merge their continental fuel retailing businesses.
fields.body:
BP's new logo will appear on petrol station forecourts lining autobahns as part of a deal under discussion between the British oil company and German utility RWE to merge their continental fuel retailing businesses.

The new operation, taking in RWE's 2,600 service stations, would be the second largest petrol group in Germany, behind Aral.

A source close to the talks yesterday said discussions on a joint venture have been under way for some time, but he stressed that agreement had yet to be reached.

Details of the talks, which involve RWE injecting its oil refining assets as well as the petrol stations into a joint venture run by BP, emerged on the eve of today's expected confirmation of RWE's £4.3bn takeover of Thames Water.

The German utility has made no secret of its desire to dispose of its oil-related assets, grouped under the DEA banner and thought to be worth around £1.2bn, to become a global player in the water industry. The DEA division employs more than 10,000 people and last year generated sales of £5.6bn

Neither BP nor RWE would comment, although a statement clarifying the matter is expected today.

The supervisory board of the German utility is understood to have met last Friday to discuss the sale of DEA.

The German group also declined to discuss its bid for Thames Water, although it has been widely cited as likely to take over since last week when the British utility said talks with an unnamed predator were at an advanced stage.

RWE already has a presence in the sector in Germany through its 22.5% stake in Berlin Water Works, the city's municipal utility. Thames' long experience in deregulated and privatised water supply would give it the necessary management skills to exploit new opportunities in Germany.

Globally, water remains a fragmented industry, but French companies Vivendi Environment and Suez Lyonnaise are already exploiting consolidation opportunities in the United States and elsewhere.

Thames does not have the clout to take on the French companies on its own, but RWE is one of Europe's "big six" utilities, with a market capitalisation of about €21bn (£12.7bn). A planned merger with fellow German utility VEW will add a further €2.7bn and make it Germany's largest electricity producer.

Following the acquisitions of Amoco, Atlantic Richfield and Burmah Castrol, the DEA merger would be the fourth large deal for BP in the past two years.

Shell is also thought to have held discussions about buying DEA but is no longer interested.

fields.headline: Jeanloup Sieff
fields.standfirst: A Left Bank lensman of the age of existentialism
fields.trailText: The work of photographer Jeanloup Sieff, who has died aged 66, connected him constantly to youth and beauty. His interests were nudes, the erotic, and an extended study of the body in dance. He was best-known for his fashion magazine photography, but he also enjoyed experimenting, technically and thematically, especially in the 1960s, when he lived in the US and went on the road, documenting southern landscapes.
fields.body:
The work of photographer Jeanloup Sieff, who has died aged 66, connected him constantly to youth and beauty. His interests were nudes, the erotic, and an extended study of the body in dance. He was best-known for his fashion magazine photography, but he also enjoyed experimenting, technically and thematically, especially in the 1960s, when he lived in the US and went on the road, documenting southern landscapes.

Sieff (born in Paris, the son of a Polish engineer) was given a camera for his 14th birthday. He took photographs from then on, sleeping with his precious camera by his pillow. He dropped out of courses in literature, in journalism, and at the Vaugirard photography school in Paris, before completing seven months at the Vevey photography school in Switzerland.

Returning home in 1954, he attempted to get work in the cinema industry. He ditched the attempt, but remained fascinated with stars and directors; 20 years later, his portraits of Hitchcock, Catherine Deneuve and other movie people were, and have remained, famous.

Sieff began his career proper at French Elle magazine in 1956, where he began to introduce an element of the erotic into what had been before a mostly highly respectable art. Naughtiness replaced haughtiness in his shots, with partly-dressed models seductively extending a bare arm and shoulder, or bending a naked back to the camera.

For a while Sieff also took up street photography, and with considerable prescience, shot the the Left Bank in the last age of existentialism; the Deux Magots cafe, the bookshops and the jazz clubs of the grands boulevards - his black-and-white images caught the period, and were later recycled in advertising.

Sieff was the antithesis of the Robert Cartier-Bresson school of life photography, but Cartier-Bresson himself assessed Sieff's admission to the Magnum Photo Agency. To Sieff's rage, the master inscrutably tipped the aspirant's photos this way and that, holding them upside down to assess form over content.

Sieff stayed with Magnum for only a couple of years, leaving France for New York in 1960. There, he became caught up in fashion magazines, working for Harper's, Vogue and Esquire. Later came books of photography , including Sad Landscapes and Lazy Nudes (1972) and Twenty Years, Oh Nicephore! (1975). At one point, he contemplated a mock retrospective entitled "Portraits of Seated Ladies and Indolently Weary Nudes, with Certain Selected Moments and Accompanied by Texts having no Connection with the Images".

Sieff was extremely articulate about his own work. When the great photographer of the Parisian moment, Robert Doisneau, visited him, and left Sieff a copy of his latest book, Trois Secondes d'Eternité, Sieff wrote: "All photography is a moment, of oneself and others, of things and of the world; it is, at one and the same time, the eternalising of an emotion and its erosion. Taking photographs is a strange occupation, daring to want to stop time."

Sieff called this the freezing of the instant into the permanence of effigy, the creation of "so many small whitestones helping us, according to our mood, rediscover feelings and forgotten faces".

Yet many of his own images are taken with a short-focus lens, their foregrounds filled by reminders of boring or brutal reality; a table jutting into the backview of a sinuous nude; a car dashboard obtruding on a desert landscape. He was always subverting the perfection of his own technique.

His work is owned by major museums in France, Germany, Switzerland and the US, and he exhibited in all those places as well as in London (where he held his first show in 1967) and Tokyo (where the erotic aspect of his work was well regarded). Other books, which eschewed silly titles, were called The Ballet (1962) or Best Nudes (1980) - although he couldn't resist calling one volume Bottoms (1994).

He was married to Barbara Williams, and had two children Sonia and Sasha.

He was married to Barbara Williams, and had two children Sonia and Sasha. Jeanloup Sieff, photographer, born November 30 1933; died September 20 2000

fields.headline: Returning to the fray
fields.standfirst: Going back to work after several years bringing up children can be daunting. But temping could be the ideal way to start. Hilary Whitney reports
fields.trailText: Going back to work after several years bringing up children can be daunting. But temping could be the ideal way to start. Hilary Whitney reports
fields.body:
Although some people's hearts sink as the temperature drops and dusk arrives earlier each day, to others that autumnal nip in the air represents new challenges. For many women who have taken a career break, this is the time to start thinking about returning to work. An increasing number of them are finding temping the ideal way to reacquaint themselves with office work, and often to find permanent employment.

"Not surprisingly, many women are very nervous about returning to work after a gap, says Julia Killingbeck, a senior consultant at Tate Appointments. "Even if they are obviously capable and previously held down a demanding job, they often lack confidence. This is mainly because they think that office technology has progressed to such an extent theyêll never be able to catch up. The reality is that advances in technology have made everything much easier and people are usually surprised how quickly they pick up new packages.

Rachel Greenwood, who has not worked outside the home for eight years and has just started temping, says this was her experience: "When I started to think about going back to work, it used to terrify me to look at job adverts. I didn't understand half of them; things seemed to have changed so much from when I worked in an office. Then I did a refresher course at a local college and I couldn't believe how much easier everything is now.

Killingbeck points out that, although it might sound like a cliche, women who have been at home bringing up their children have developed useful, highly transferable skills. "Women who have children are often terribly organised because they are so used to having to think about 16 things at once, she says.

It is helpful to sign up with an agency that is aware of your agenda and sympathetic to your needs. Killingbeck, who herself temped when she decided to return to work after having children, is aware that one of the main problems that women in this situation face is worrying about their children. "This might be the first time they've been separated from their children for any length of time and, understandably, this can make them anxious. Temping is a way of gently testing the water. You haven't made a commitment to an employer so if things aren't working out as you planned you can extricate yourself.

Pauline Ford-Smith approached recruitment consultancy Prime Time 11 years ago, when she registered as a temp after having a baby. She wanted to have time with her son but not neglect her career.

"I'd spent five years at home and lost a lot of confidence, she says. "Prime Time gave me some training and made sure that at first I was given only straightforward assignments. It was useful to work in a variety of places because I learnt a lot more that way.

"However, the chief reason for wanting to temp was that it would fit in with my son. I knew that if he was ill, or there was a problem with my childcare arrangements, it would be easier to deal with. I found that as long as people were happy with my work, they were often willing to compromise. For example, I worked through my lunch hour so I could get away early to pick up my son.

As her son demanded less of her time, Ford-Smith began to concentrate on her career. After years of relying on her as a temp, Prime Time spotted her potential and now, 13 years on, she is the branch manager of the temporary recruitment section at its Harrogate office.

"Most people find the transition far less traumatic than they initially thought it would be, Killingbeck says. "After all, looking after children all day is incredibly hard work. If you can do that, I think you can rise to pretty much anything.

fields.headline: The IT revolution
fields.trailText: Information technology was meant to lead to the "death of the secretary"; indeed, a few doom-mongers still believe it will. If the prediction is sometimes pronounced with glee, the feeling is reciprocated, with many secretaries giving their ambition as "not to be a secretary anymore".
fields.body:
Information technology was meant to lead to the "death of the secretary"; indeed, a few doom-mongers still believe it will. If the prediction is sometimes pronounced with glee, the feeling is reciprocated, with many secretaries giving their ambition as "not to be a secretary anymore".

Nevertheless, 2000 has been a dismal year for futurologists. Not only has the world not come to an end, but secretarial skills remain in demand. Not just hi-tech skills either. Shorthand is a skill in short supply, says the Recruitment and Employment Confederation.

How has this come about? It can be partly explained by the misconception that machines save work. In fact, they create it, because they boost productivity and make tasks that would have been prohibitively expensive much cheaper. In the days of carbon paper, sending memos was labour intensive. Now 100 copies of a document are a mouse click away - hence there's more work rather than less.

It is also the case that secretaries have maintained the head start they had when the IT revolution arrived, because they were the only ones with keyboard skills. As PCs appeared on managers' desks, the structure of organisations also changed. Business became less hierarchical, and work was organised into projects. Each project team needed a co-ordinator. A new job for the department secretary.

Similarly the internet has enhanced the secretary's position. For business, the net's practical applications are booking flights and hotel rooms - whose responsibility has that always been?

Then there is the rise in internal communications. Every day, emails tell us more and more things we didn't want to know. How is the important stuff to be communicated? Management of the intranet has devolved to the secretary. As the PA to a chairman of an international PR company once told me: "I was tired of answering the same questions over and over again, so I put the information on-line."
